verses.translation: There is no fear for the one who is wide awake, whose mind is not soaked by lust, whose heart is not smitten by ill-will, and who has gone beyond both merit and demerit.
verses.commentary: 'Anavassuta' (not soaked) means the 'rain' of lust cannot leak into the mind. 'Ananvāhata' (not struck/smitten) means the mind is not wounded by anger. 'Puññapāpapahīnassa' refers to an Arhat who has transcended the dualities of 'merit' and 'demerit.' Such a person is 'jāgarato' (fully awake) and thus 'natthi bhayaṃ' (has no fear).

story.title: The Fearless Arhat
story.content: A certain Arhat was living in a forest when a group of bandits surrounded him, intending to kill him. While a normal person would have been paralyzed by 'bhaya' (fear), the monk remained perfectly calm. His mind was 'anavassuta' (not soaked by lust for life) and 'ananvāhata' (not smitten by ill-will toward his attackers). He had reached a state where he had 'gone beyond both merit and demerit' (puññapāpapahīnassa); he was no longer acting for future rewards or avoiding future punishments, but was simply 'jāgarato'—wide awake in the present moment. The bandits were confused by his lack of fear. He explained to them that fear only arises when there is a 'self' to be protected or a 'desire' to be fulfilled. Since he had no attachment to his body and no hatred toward them, there was nothing for fear to latch onto. The Buddha later used this monk as an example of the ultimate mental security. He explained that most people are 'soaked' with the liquid of craving, which makes them heavy and prone to fear. But a mind that is 'dry' of lust and 'unwounded' by anger is like a solid diamond that cannot be scratched. The 'fearlessness' of the Arhat is not a display of bravery, but a natural result of having 'nothing to lose.' This story teaches that the end of fear is found through the total purification of the mind. When we stop 'soaking' our hearts in the poisons of lust and hate, we become 'wide awake' to a reality where death is no longer an enemy, but merely a change of state.

verses.pali:
Kumbhūpamaṃ kāyamimaṃ viditvā, nagarūpamaṃ cittatidaṃ thapetvā;
Yodhetha māraṃ paññāyudhena, jitañca rakkhe anivesano siyā.
verses.translation: Realizing that this body is as fragile as a clay pot, and fortifying this mind like a well-guarded city, let one fight Mara with the weapon of wisdom. Guarding one's conquest, let one be unattached.
verses.commentary: The body is 'kumbhūpamaṃ' (like a pot)—it breaks easily. The mind should be 'nagarūpamaṃ' (like a fortress)—strong and defended. 'Paññāyudhena' (the weapon of wisdom) is the only tool that can defeat 'Mara.' After 'jitaṃ' (victory), one must 'rakkhe' (guard it) without 'anivesano' (clinging/attachment).

story.title: The Fortress of the Mind
story.content: A group of monks were meditating in a forest when they began to feel overwhelmed by the hardships of the environment—the heat, the insects, and the lack of comfort. They began to obsess over their physical discomfort, forgetting their practice. The Buddha appeared to them and gave them this meditation. He told them to look at their bodies and see them as 'clay pots' (kumbhūpamaṃ)—fragile, temporary, and destined to break. If you spend all your time trying to protect a clay pot, you will never have peace. Instead, he told them to 'fortify the mind like a city' (nagarūpamaṃ). A well-guarded city has high walls (virtue), a deep moat (shame and fear of wrongdoing), and a skilled gatekeeper (mindfulness). He urged them to 'fight Mara'—not an external demon, but their own internal weaknesses—using 'the weapon of wisdom' (paññāyudhena). This weapon is the sharp realization of impermanence. The monks took this teaching to heart. They stopped trying to make their 'clay pot' bodies comfortable and started building their 'fortress' minds. Whenever a thought of laziness or desire arose, they struck it down with the 'weapon of wisdom.' Eventually, they 'conquered' their defilements. The Buddha warned them to 'guard the conquest' (jitañca rakkhe) by staying 'unattached' (anivesano), meaning they shouldn't even cling to their spiritual success. This story illustrates that spiritual warfare is an internal defense project. By recognizing the fragility of the physical and the potential strength of the mental, we can stop being victims of our environment and start being masters of our own inner 'city.' The 'clay pot' will eventually break, but the 'fortress' built of wisdom remains unshakeable.

verses.pali:
Aciraṃ vatayaṃ kāyo, paṭhaviṃ adhisessati;
Chuddho apetaviññāṇo, niratthaṃva kaliṅgaraṃ.
verses.translation: Before long, this body will lie upon the earth, cast aside, devoid of consciousness, like a useless log.
verses.commentary: This verse is a powerful contemplation on death. 'Aciraṃ' (before long) emphasizes urgency. 'Kaliṅgaraṃ' refers to a rotten log that is of no use even for firewood. The 'body' (kāyo) is only valuable as long as 'viññāṇo' (consciousness) inhabits it; once that leaves, it is mere 'paṭhaviṃ' (earth).

story.title: The Story of Thera Pūtigatta Tissa
story.content: Thera Tissa was a monk who developed a terrible skin disease. His body became covered in sores that broke open, and his robes became soaked in pus and blood. Because of the foul smell, his fellow monks abandoned him, leaving him to lie in his own filth. His body was literally 'pūti' (rotten). The Buddha, through his divine eye, saw Tissa's suffering and went to his cell. Instead of turning away in disgust, the Buddha personally washed Tissa's sores and boiled water to clean his robes. While Tissa was feeling slightly relieved by the Buddha's care, the Buddha spoke this verse to him. He pointed out that this body, which Tissa was so identified with, was 'aciraṃ' (short-lived) and would soon 'lie upon the earth' like a 'useless log' (niratthaṃva kaliṅgaraṃ). He taught Tissa to look past the 'rotten' body and focus on the 'viññāṇo' (consciousness) that could still be purified. Tissa, contemplating the absolute impermanence of his physical form, let go of his attachment to the body. Even as he was dying from the disease, his mind became clear and liberated; he attained Arahatship and passed away into Parinibbana. This story is one of the most touching in the Pali tradition, showing the Buddha's immense compassion. It teaches that the body's decay is not a spiritual failure, but a natural law. By accepting that the body will inevitably become 'niratthaṃ' (useless), we can prioritize the development of the mind, which is the only thing that can transcend the 'earth' to which the body must return. Tissa's 'rotten' body became the very vehicle for his enlightenment, proving that wisdom can flourish even in the most broken of vessels.

verses.pali:
Diso disaṃ yaṃ taṃ kayirā, verī vā pana verinaṃ;
Micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ, pāpiyo naṃ tato kare.
verses.translation: Whatever harm an enemy may do to an enemy, or a hater to a hater, an ill-directed mind can do one even greater harm.
verses.commentary: 'Micchāpaṇihita' means ill-directed or wrongly set. An 'enemy' (diso/verī) can only hurt the body or the reputation, but a mind set on the path of greed, hatred, and delusion (pāpiyo) can lead one to eons of suffering in the lower realms. The internal enemy is 'worse' (pāpiyo) than any external foe.

story.title: The Story of the Herdsman Nanda
story.content: Nanda was a wealthy herdsman who was a devoted supporter of the Buddha. However, Nanda was tragically killed by a stray arrow just after seeing the Buddha off after a meal. The monks were saddened and wondered how such a good man could have such a violent end. The Buddha explained that while the arrow was the external 'enemy' (diso), the real danger to Nanda would have been an 'ill-directed mind' (micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ). If Nanda had been filled with anger or greed at the moment of death, that 'ill-directed mind' would have done him 'greater harm' (pāpiyo) than any arrow—it would have dragged him to a woeful rebirth. But because Nanda had 'directed' his mind toward the Dhamma, the physical harm of the arrow was limited to his body. The Buddha taught that we often spend all our energy defending ourselves against 'enemies' and 'haters' (verī), yet we leave our own minds 'ill-directed' and unprotected. A mind that is 'wrongly set' on vengeance or craving is a 'traitor' within our own gates; it can destroy us far more effectively than any external army. The story teaches us to prioritize the 'direction' of our thoughts. If we keep the mind 'well-directed' toward kindness and wisdom, no external 'hater' can truly harm us in the long run. The most dangerous 'enemy' we will ever face is the one that looks back at us from the mirror if it is not trained in the Dhamma.

verses.pali:
Na taṃ mātā pitā kayirā, aññe vā pi ca ñātakā;
Sammāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ, seyyaso naṃ tato kare.
verses.translation: What neither mother, nor father, nor any other relative can do, a well-directed mind does for one, even better.
verses.commentary: The 'sammāpaṇihita' (well-directed) mind is one set on the Ten Wholesome Actions. While 'mother and father' (mātā pitā) provide the best worldly support and care, they cannot 'direct' one toward Nibbana. Only one's own 'well-directed' mind can achieve the 'seyyaso' (greater/superior) result of liberation.

story.title: The Story of Soreyya
story.content: Soreyya was a young man who, due to a disrespectful thought toward the Elder Mahākaccāna, suddenly turned into a woman. Ashamed, he fled to another city, married, and even had children. Years later, he met the Elder again and asked for forgiveness. Immediately, he turned back into a man. Soreyya was overwhelmed by the complexity of his life—having been both a father and a mother. He decided to ordain as a monk to find peace. When people asked him which children he loved more, those from when he was a man or those from when he was a woman, he eventually replied that since he had 'well-directed' his mind through meditation, he no longer had any 'clinging' to either. The Buddha praised him, stating that his 'well-directed mind' (sammāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ) had done something for him that 'neither mother nor father' could do. They could give him life and love, but only his own mind could give him the 'seyyaso' (superior) gift of total detachment and peace. The story illustrates that our families, despite their best intentions, are limited in the help they can provide. They can support our bodies, but they cannot purify our hearts. Soreyya’s 'well-directed' mind took his bizarre and traumatic life experiences and used them as fuel for enlightenment. This verse teaches us that we are our own ultimate benefactors. By 'directing' our mind toward the truth, we achieve a level of welfare and security that exceeds even the most perfect parental love.

chapters.summary: This chapter uses flowers as metaphors to illustrate the Dhamma, teaching about the nature of existence, the importance of virtue over empty words, and the cultivation of good deeds.

verses.pali:
Ko imaṃ paṭhaviṃ vicessati, yamalokañca imaṃ sadevakaṃ;
Ko dhammapadaṃ sudesitaṃ, kusalo pupphamiva pacessati.
verses.translation: Who shall conquer this earth and the realm of Yama and this world with its gods? Who shall find the well-taught path of virtue even as a skilled person finds the right flower?
verses.commentary: 'Paṭhaviṃ' (earth) refers to the self or the body. 'Yamaloka' is the realm of death. The 'skilled person' (kusalo) is a seeker who can distinguish between the 'flower' of true Dhamma and the 'weeds' of worldly distraction.

story.title: The Story of Five Hundred Monks and the Mirage
story.content: A group of five hundred monks were traveling to the Buddha after spending the rains retreat in the forest. Along the way, they saw a mirage shimmering over the hot sand. Initially, they were fascinated by the beauty of the shifting light, but soon realized it was an illusion with no substance. The Buddha, perceiving their thoughts from afar, appeared to them in a vision. He asked them who would truly 'conquer this earth' (vicessati) and understand the realm of death. He explained that just as a skilled garland-maker (kusalo) walks through a garden to pick only the finest, most fragrant flowers while ignoring the common weeds, a monk must walk through life picking the 'Dhammapada'—the path of virtue. He told them that the body and the world are as substanceless as the mirage they were looking at. The monks realized that the search for external 'flowers' or pleasures was a waste of time. They redirected their focus inward to find the 'well-taught path' within their own minds. This story illustrates that the world is a vast garden, but most people are 'unskilled' and pick poisonous or fading blossoms. To 'conquer the earth' is not to own it, but to understand its nature so thoroughly that it no longer has power over you. The monks, inspired by the Buddha's flower-garland simile, attained Arahatship by the time they reached the monastery, having successfully 'picked' the flower of liberation from the midst of the world's illusions.

verses.pali:
Sekho paṭhaviṃ vicessati, yamalokañca imaṃ sadevakaṃ;
Sekho dhammapadaṃ sudesitaṃ, kusalo pupphamiva pacessati.
verses.translation: The seeker (Sekha) shall conquer this earth and the realm of Yama and this world with its gods. The seeker shall find the well-taught path of virtue, even as a skilled person finds the right flower.
verses.commentary: A 'Sekha' is a 'learner' or 'one in training' who has reached at least the first stage of enlightenment (Sotapanna) but is not yet an Arhat. This verse confirms that even those still in training can achieve the same mastery over the 'earth' (self) as the Buddha, provided they remain skilled in their choice of 'flowers' (virtuous actions).

story.title: The Training of the Five Hundred Monks
story.content: Following the previous discourse regarding the mirage, the five hundred monks realized that they were 'Sekhas'—seekers who were on the right path but still had work to do. They asked the Buddha how they could ensure they would not 'fall away' before reaching the end. The Buddha explained that a 'Sekha' is like a gardener who has learned to distinguish between a real flower and a weed but must still put in the labor to harvest the garden. He told them that as 'Sekhas,' they had already begun to 'conquer this earth' because they no longer believed in the permanent reality of the body. He encouraged them to continue 'picking the flowers' of mindfulness. Just as a 'kusalo' (skilled garland-maker) does not just pick any flower but selects only those that are fresh and capable of being woven into a beautiful crown, the monks were told to select only those mental states that lead to liberation. The monks practiced with this renewed understanding, seeing every thought as a choice between a fading blossom and an eternal one. By the end of the day, through their 'skilled' selection of mental objects, all five hundred monks moved from being 'Sekhas' (learners) to being 'Asekhas' (those who have finished the training), attaining full Arahatship. This story emphasizes that enlightenment is a progressive mastery of selection—learning to choose the 'essential' over the 'unessential' until the mind is naturally aligned with the truth.

verses.pali:
Pheṇūpamaṃ kāyamimaṃ viditvā, marīcidhammaṃ abhisambudhāno;
Chetvāna mārassa papupphakāni, adassanaṃ maccurājassa gacche.
verses.translation: Realizing that this body is as fragile as foam, and understanding its nature to be as unsubstantial as a mirage, let one snap the flowery arrows of Mara and pass beyond the sight of the King of Death.
verses.commentary: 'Pheṇūpamaṃ' (like foam) describes the fragility of the body. 'Marīcidhammaṃ' (nature of a mirage) describes its deceptive appearance. Mara's 'flowery arrows' (papupphakāni) are the sensual pleasures that look beautiful but lead to death. To be 'beyond the sight of Death' is to reach Nibbana.

story.title: The Monk Who Contemplated the Foam
story.content: A certain monk was meditating by the side of a river. As he watched the water, he saw large clumps of 'pheṇa' (foam) forming and then suddenly bursting into nothingness. He realized that his own body was exactly 'pheṇūpamaṃ'—it was just a collection of bubbles that seemed solid from a distance but had no core. At that same moment, he saw a 'marīci' (mirage) shimmering on the riverbank, and he understood that the beauty of the world was equally 'unsubstantial.' The Buddha, appearing to him in a ray of light, encouraged this insight. He told the monk that most people are struck by 'Mara's flowery arrows'—the desires that make the 'foam' of the body seem desirable. The Buddha urged him to 'snap' these arrows by seeing through the illusion. He explained that once a person truly understands the 'foam-like' and 'mirage-like' nature of existence, they become invisible to the 'Maccurāja' (King of Death), because death can only find those who claim ownership over a body. The monk, focusing intensely on the bursting bubbles of the foam, saw the bursting of his own ego-clinging. He attained Arahatship right there on the riverbank. This story teaches that we don't need to fear death if we stop identifying with the thing that dies. By seeing the body as 'foam,' we realize there is nothing for the 'King of Death' to take. The monk's liberation was not an escape from life, but an escape from the 'mirage' of self, leading to the 'unsightable' peace of Nibbana.

verses.pali:
Pupphāni heva pacinantaṃ, byāsattamanasaṃ naraṃ;
Suttaṃ gāmaṃ mahogho va, maccu ādāya gacchati.
verses.translation: Death carries off the man who is gathering only the flowers of sensual pleasure, whose mind is distracted, even as a great flood carries off a sleeping village.
verses.commentary: Sensual pleasures are 'pupphāni'—beautiful but fading. 'Byāsattamanasaṃ' refers to a mind that is 'clinging' or 'entangled.' The 'flood' (mahogho) of death is sudden and absolute, giving no warning to those who are 'asleep' in their desires.

story.title: The Story of Viḍūḍabha's Revenge
story.content: Viḍūḍabha, the King of Kosala, was driven by a deep-seated rage against the Sakyan clan because of a past insult regarding his birth. He marched his army to massacre them. After the slaughter, on his return journey, his army camped on the dry bed of the Aciravatī River. Some of the soldiers, who were 'gathering the flowers' of their victory, slept on the high bank, but Viḍūḍabha and the rest of the army slept on the riverbed itself, distracted by their triumph and planning their future celebrations. They were 'byāsattamanasaṃ'—their minds were entangled in the satisfaction of their revenge. Suddenly, a massive cloudburst in the mountains sent a 'great flood' (mahogho) down the river. The water swept away the sleeping army, including the King, just as a flood 'carries off a sleeping village.' The Buddha used this tragedy to teach that death does not wait for us to finish 'gathering our flowers.' Viḍūḍabha thought he had many years of kingship ahead of him, but his life was cut short in an instant because he was heedless. This story serves as a terrifying reminder of the unpredictability of 'maccu' (death). We are often so busy arranging our lives—picking our 'flowers'—that we fail to notice the rising water. The only safety is not in the 'flowers' of revenge or power, but in being 'awake' and established on the high bank of mindfulness before the flood arrives.

verses.pali:
Pupphāni heva pacinantaṃ, byāsattamanasaṃ naraṃ;
Atittaññeva kāmesu, antako kurute vasaṃ.
verses.translation: The Destroyer (Death) brings under his sway the man who is gathering only the flowers of sensual pleasure, whose mind is distracted, and who is insatiable in his desires.
verses.commentary: This verse reinforces the tragedy of Verse 47. 'Atittaṃ' (insatiable) means that no amount of 'flowers' can ever satisfy the mind. 'Antako' (the Ender/Death) takes control (vasaṃ) while the person is still 'wanting more,' making their death one of profound regret.

story.title: The Story of Patipūjikā Kumāri
story.content: Patipūjikā was a woman who had a unique past-life memory; she remembered being a celestial nymph in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven. She spent her human life performing great acts of merit, always wishing to be reborn back with her celestial husband. She was constantly 'gathering flowers'—both literally as offerings and figuratively as wholesome deeds—but her mind was 'distracted' by her longing for her former heavenly home. One day, while she was in the middle of a meal and serving others, she suddenly died. She was 'insatiable in her desires' (atittaññeva) to return to heaven, and 'Death' (Antako) took her exactly while she was planning her future. Even though she was reborn in heaven as she wished, her human life ended abruptly, leaving her family in shock. The Buddha used her story to show that whether we are seeking earthly or heavenly 'flowers,' death does not wait for us to feel 'satisfied.' We are all 'under the sway' of the Ender. Patipūjikā’s death was a reminder that even 'good' desires can be a form of distraction if they keep us from realizing the ultimate end of all conditioned things. This story highlights the 'insatiable' nature of craving (tanha)—even when we get the 'flower' we want, we immediately want another one, or we want the one we have to never fade. Death’s power comes from our 'unfinished business.' By letting go of the need for 'one more flower,' we weaken the grip that the 'Destroyer' has over our hearts.

verses.pali:
Yathāpi bhamaro pupphaṃ, vaṇṇagandhaṃ aheṭhayaṃ;
Pāleti rasaṃādāya, evaṃ gāme munī care.
verses.translation: Just as a bee drinks the nectar of a flower and flies away without harming its color or fragrance, so should a sage move through a village.
verses.commentary: This is a classic simile for the ideal relationship between the Sangha and the laity. The 'sage' (munī) takes only what is necessary (rasaṃ) for survival but leaves the 'color and fragrance' (the faith and wealth of the people) intact and even 'protected' (pāleti) by their presence.

story.title: The Story of Kosiya the Miserly Rich Man
story.content: In a village, there lived a very wealthy man named Kosiya who was so miserly that he would not even share a pancake with his own wife. He feared that if he gave anything away, his wealth would disappear like a flower's scent. One day, the Buddha sent Moggallāna, his chief disciple with psychic powers, to teach him. Moggallāna appeared at Kosiya's window and simply stood there, like a 'bee' (bhamaro) waiting for 'nectar' (rasaṃ). Kosiya tried to ignore him, then tried to give him the smallest, burnt pancake possible, but every time his wife tried to take a small piece of dough, it grew until it filled the whole pan. Eventually, Kosiya was so impressed by Moggallāna’s 'non-harming' (aheṭhayaṃ) presence that he invited him in and gave all the pancakes away. Moggallāna took the food and flew back to the Buddha, having left Kosiya’s house not only with the 'nectar' of the meal but having left the 'fragrance' of Kosiya's faith much stronger than before. The Buddha taught that a true 'munī' (sage) does not 'crush' the flower of the laity’s generosity. They take alms in a way that the donors feel enriched rather than depleted. Just as the bee helps the flower to pollinate and grow even while taking its nectar, the sage helps the laity to grow in merit while taking only what is needed for the day. This story serves as a model for ethical consumption and social responsibility, showing that spiritual practitioners should be a 'value-add' to the communities they inhabit, never a burden.

verses.pali:
Na paresaṃ vilomāni, na paresaṃ katākataṃ;
Attanova avekkheyya, katāni akatāni ca.
verses.translation: Let none find fault with others; let none see the omissions and commissions of others. But let one see one’s own acts, done and undone.
verses.commentary: The verse warns against 'vilomāni' (finding fault/hostility). It suggests that 'watching others' is a distraction from the only work that matters: 'avekkheyya' (investigating) one's own 'katāni akatāni' (what has been done and what is left to do).

story.title: The Story of the Ascetic Pāveyya
story.content: An ascetic named Pāveyya lived in a forest and was highly respected by a local woman. When the woman’s son became a monk under the Buddha, Pāveyya became jealous and began to 'find fault' (vilomāni) with the Buddha's teachings and the young monk's behavior. He spent all his time watching the 'omissions and commissions' (katākataṃ) of the Buddha's disciples, looking for any small mistake to criticize. The Buddha, knowing this, taught that Pāveyya was like a man trying to clean someone else’s house while his own was burning down. He told the woman to tell Pāveyya that his spiritual progress was stalled because he was 'investigating others' instead of 'investigating himself' (attanova avekkheyya). The Buddha explained that we only have a limited amount of time and mental energy; if we spend it on the 'done and undone' acts of others, we have none left for our own purification. Pāveyya eventually realized that his jealousy had made him a 'spiritual spy' rather than a 'spiritual seeker.' He stopped looking at the monks and started looking at his own 'undone' work of overcoming anger. This story is a fundamental teaching on mindfulness: the 'field of investigation' is always the internal world. By shifting the focus from 'paresaṃ' (others) to 'attano' (self), the practitioner stops being a judge and starts being a student, which is the only way to reach the end of suffering.

verses.pali:
Yathāpi ruciraṃ pupphaṃ, vaṇṇavantaṃ agandhakaṃ;
Evaṃ subhāsitā vācā, aphalā hoti akubbato.
verses.translation: Just as a beautiful flower, colorful but scentless, so is the well-spoken word of one who does not practice it; it is fruitless.
verses.commentary: The Buddha compares a 'subhāsitā vācā' (well-spoken word or scripture) to a flower that has 'vaṇṇavantaṃ' (color) but is 'agandhakaṃ' (scentless). Without 'akubbato' (practice/action), the most beautiful philosophy is 'aphalā' (fruitless).

story.title: The Story of the Two Friends (Revisited)
story.content: There were two friends who ordained as monks. One was a master of the Tipitaka, capable of reciting thousands of verses with perfect elocution. He was like a 'beautiful flower' that everyone admired for its 'color'—his brilliant intellect and vast knowledge. However, he was 'agandhakaṃ' (scentless) because he did not apply the teachings to his own heart. He was arrogant and quick to judge others, proving that his 'well-spoken words' were 'fruitless' (aphalā). The Buddha explained that knowledge without practice is a hollow beauty. Just as a flower without a scent cannot attract a bee or leave a lingering fragrance in a room, a scholar without virtue cannot inspire others to reach the end of suffering. The Buddha used this simile to remind the monks that the Dhamma is meant to be 'worn' as a scent, not just 'displayed' as a color. The scholarly monk eventually realized that his vanity was a sign that he was 'not practicing' (akubbato). He had mistaken the map for the journey. This story teaches that the true 'fruit' of the Dhamma is the transformation of character, and that eloquence without ethics is like a plastic flower—striking to look at from a distance, but ultimately disappointing and devoid of life's true essence.

verses.pali:
Yathāpi ruciraṃ pupphaṃ, vaṇṇavantaṃ sagandhakaṃ;
Evaṃ subhāsitā vācā, saphalā hoti kubbato.
verses.translation: Just as a beautiful flower, colorful and fragrant, so is the well-spoken word of one who practices it; it is fruitful.
verses.commentary: The positive counterpart to Verse 51. When a 'learner' (kubbato) matches their speech with their deeds, the Dhamma becomes 'saphalā' (fruitful), spreading its 'fragrance' (virtue) far and wide.

story.title: The Fruitful Practice of the Forest Monk
story.content: In contrast to the scholarly monk, his friend lived a simple life in the forest. He could only recite a few verses of the Dhamma, but he was 'kubbato'—one who practiced diligently. He was like a flower that was not only 'colorful' in its limited knowledge but also 'sagandhakaṃ' (fragrant) in its profound peace and kindness. People who met him felt the 'scent' of his holiness immediately. The Buddha praised him, saying that his 'well-spoken words' were 'fruitful' (saphalā) because they were rooted in experience. Even if he only said 'Mindfulness is the way,' the power of his practice made that one sentence more effective than a thousand lectures. The Buddha explained that when wisdom and conduct are joined, they create a 'fragrance' that never fades. The forest monk eventually attained Arahatship, proving that the 'fruit' of the path is accessible to anyone who 'does' the work. This story illustrates that the weight of one's words comes from the depth of one's silence and practice. A single 'fragrant' act of compassion or self-restraint is worth more than a library of 'scentless' books. It encourages seekers to focus on making their life a 'sagandhaka' flower—one that benefits the world not just by its appearance, but by the invisible, pervasive influence of its internal purity.

verses.pali:
Yathāpi puppharāsimhā, kayirā mālāguṇe bahū;
Evaṃ jātena maccena, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ bahuṃ.
verses.translation: As many a garland can be made from a heap of flowers, so many good deeds should be done by one born a mortal.
verses.commentary: Life is compared to a 'puppharāsimhā' (heap of flowers). Since we are 'maccena' (mortals) and our time is limited, we should use the 'flowers' of our opportunities to weave a 'mālāguṇe' (garland of virtues).

story.title: The Story of Visākhā’s Garlands of Merit
story.content: Visākhā was the Buddha's most prominent female lay disciple, known for her immense generosity. She spent her life building monasteries, providing robes, and feeding thousands of monks. When people asked why she did so much, she explained that she saw her life and wealth as a 'heap of flowers' (puppharāsimhā) given to her by her past kamma. She realized that if she just let the flowers sit there, they would wilt and rot. Instead, she decided to weave them into 'many garlands' (mālāguṇe bahū) of 'good deeds' (kusalaṃ bahuṃ). She understood that being 'born a mortal' (jātena maccena) meant her time was short, so she was never idle in her merit-making. The Buddha praised her, saying that just as a skilled garland-maker uses every single blossom in a heap to create something beautiful, a wise person uses every moment of their human life to perform acts of kindness, honesty, and wisdom. Visākhā’s life was not just a collection of random acts; it was a carefully woven 'garland' of virtue that lasted long after her death. This story teaches that we should not be overwhelmed by the 'heap' of life's choices, but should focus on 'weaving' them into a coherent path of merit. Each 'flower'—each day, each dollar, each conversation—is an opportunity to add to the 'garland' that is the only thing we truly take with us when we leave this mortal world.

verses.pali:
Na pupphagandho paṭivātameti, na candanaṃ tagaramallikā vā;
Satañca gandho paṭivātameti, sabbā disā sappuriso pavāti.
verses.translation: The fragrance of flowers does not travel against the wind, nor does that of sandalwood, jasmine, or tagara. But the fragrance of the virtuous travels even against the wind; a good man pervades every quarter.
verses.commentary: Physical 'fragrance' (gandho) is limited by the direction of the 'wind' (vāta). Even the finest 'sandalwood' (candanaṃ) has physical boundaries. However, the 'scent' of a 'sappuriso' (good/virtuous person) is 'spiritual' and thus 'paṭivātameti'—it can travel against any opposition or distance.

story.title: The Fragrance of the Elder Ānanda’s Question
story.content: One evening, the Venerable Ānanda was sitting in reflection and wondered if there was any fragrance in the world that could travel against the wind. He knew that the scent of 'sandalwood' (candanaṃ) and 'jasmine' (mallikā) was wonderful, but it always followed the breeze. He asked the Buddha if there was a scent that could 'pervade every quarter' (sabbā disā) regardless of the wind. The Buddha replied that the 'fragrance of the virtuous' (satañca gandho) is the only such scent. He explained that when a person is truly 'good' (sappuriso)—living with integrity, compassion, and wisdom—their reputation and influence spread in all directions. It 'travels against the wind' of slander, time, and distance. People who have never met a virtuous person can still be inspired by the 'scent' of their deeds. The Buddha noted that while a flower's scent is a physical emission, a person's virtue is a 'spiritual emission' that transcends the physical laws of nature. This story highlights the pervasive power of character. It teaches that we shouldn't worry about 'advertising' our goodness; if we truly cultivate virtue, the 'fragrance' of our life will naturally 'pervade every quarter.' Like a master-perfumer, the practitioner 'blends' the ingredients of the Five Precepts to create a scent that can sweeten the air of the entire world, reaching even those who are 'upwind' of their physical presence.

verses.pali:
Candanaṃ tagaraṃ vāpi, uppalaṃ atha mallikā;
Etesaṃ gandhajātānaṃ, sīlagandho anuttaro.
verses.translation: Sandalwood, tagara, lotus, and jasmine—of all these fragrances, the perfume of virtue is the best.
verses.commentary: The Buddha lists the most prized ancient perfumes (sandalwood, tagara, lotus). He declares 'sīlagandho' (the perfume of virtue) as 'anuttaro' (incomparable/unsurpassed) because physical scents only mask the body, whereas virtue purifies the mind.

story.title: The Perfume of the Poor Man’s Virtue
story.content: In a city, there was a poor man who lived in the slums, yet he was known for his incredible 'sīla' (virtue). He would share his meager food with those hungrier than him and never spoke a harsh word. A wealthy merchant, curious about the man's reputation, visited him and noticed that even in the midst of the dirty slums, there was a sense of 'sweetness' around the man. The merchant, who wore the finest 'sandalwood' (candanaṃ) and 'jasmine' (mallikā) oils, realized that his expensive perfumes were 'unessential' compared to the man's 'sīlagandho' (perfume of virtue). The Buddha explained that physical scents are 'temporary' and 'superficial'; they eventually fade or turn sour. But 'sīla' is a fragrance that comes from the 'inside' out. It is 'anuttaro' (the best) because it doesn't just please the nose; it cals the heart and inspires the spirit. The Buddha taught that a person established in virtue is the most 'beautiful' being in the world, regardless of their clothes or social status. This story encourages us to invest in our 'internal perfume.' While the world spends billions on 'tagara' and 'lotus' scents to make themselves attractive to others, the practitioner focuses on 'sīla' to make themselves 'attractive' to the truth. The 'perfume of virtue' is the only one that stays with us through life and death, making it the most valuable 'cosmetic' a human can ever acquire.

verses.pali:
Appamatto ayaṃ gandho, yvāyaṃ tagaracandanaṃ;
Yo ca sīlavataṃ gandho, vāti devesu uttamo.
verses.translation: Faint is the fragrance of tagara and sandalwood, but the fragrance of the virtuous is excellent, wafting even amongst the gods.
verses.commentary: Physical scents are 'appamatto' (faint/slight) because they are limited to the human realm. The 'scent' of the virtuous is 'uttamo' (excellent/highest) because it is noticed and praised by the 'devas' (gods) in higher dimensions.

story.title: The Fragrance that Reached the Heavens
story.content: A monk named Mahākassapa was meditating in a cave after a long illness. He was so weak that he couldn't go to the city for alms. Sakka, the King of the Devas, smelled the 'fragrance' of Mahākassapa's 'sīla' all the way in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven. Sakka realized that this 'spiritual scent' was far 'excellent' (uttamo) than any celestial perfume. Disguising himself as a poor weaver, Sakka came to earth just to offer alms to the monk, wanting to 'breathe in' the scent of such high virtue. The Buddha later explained to the other monks that when a person lives with high integrity and deep meditation, they become a 'light' and a 'scent' that the gods cannot ignore. The 'fragrance of the virtuous' (sīlavataṃ gandho) 'wafts even amongst the gods' (vāti devesu) because it is the rarest and most precious thing in the universe. This story emphasizes that our actions have 'cosmic' consequences. We are never truly 'alone' in our practice; the 'scent' of our patience, our honesty, and our kindness reaches far beyond our immediate surroundings. It teaches that the 'best' audience for our virtue is not the crowd of humans, but the 'devas' of our own higher consciousness and the universal laws of Dhamma. By living an 'excellent' life, we align ourselves with the highest forces of the universe, proving that the 'faint' scents of the world are nothing compared to the 'wafting' power of a pure heart.

verses.pali:
Tesaṃ sampannasīlānaṃ, appamādavihārinaṃ;
Sammadaññāvimuttānaṃ, māro maggaṃ na vindati.
verses.translation: Mara cannot find the path of those who are perfect in virtue, who live heedfully, and who are emancipated through right knowledge.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the 'invisibility' of the enlightened. 'Sampannasīlānaṃ' (perfect in virtue) and 'appamādavihārinaṃ' (living heedfully) are the prerequisites. One who is 'sammadaññāvimuttānaṃ' (freed by right knowledge) has left no 'footprints' for 'Mara' (death/desire) to follow.

story.title: The Story of the Monk Godhika's Liberation
story.content: Thera Godhika was a monk who struggled with a recurring illness that interrupted his meditation. Six times he reached a high level of concentration, only to fall back because of his physical pain. The seventh time, he decided to 'live heedfully' (appamādavihārinaṃ) and attain liberation before the pain could return. He practiced with such 'perfection in virtue' (sampannasīlānaṃ) that he finally broke through and became 'emancipated through right knowledge' (sammadaññāvimuttānaṃ) at the very moment of his death. Mara, the King of Death, was furious because he couldn't find where Godhika had been reborn. Mara searched everywhere, looking for a 'path' or a 'footprint' in the mental realms, but he could 'not find the path' (maggaṃ na vindati). The Buddha explained that Godhika had become 'invisible' to Mara because he had no more 'fuel' (craving) for Mara to track. He had entered Parinibbana. This story is a profound teaching on the nature of Nibbana. It is the 'untraceable' state. Mara's power is limited to the 'tracks' of desire; where there is no desire, there is no Mara. By living 'perfectly in virtue' and 'heedfully,' Godhika had 'erased' his own tracks in the cycle of birth and death. The verse encourages us that the ultimate security is not in 'hiding,' but in 'emptying.' When we are 'emancipated through right knowledge,' we transcend the very realm where Mara and Death operate, becoming as untraceable as a bird in the sky.

verses.pali:
Yathā saṅkāradhānasmiṃ, ujjhitasmiṃ mahāpathe;
Pappumaṃ tattha jāyetha, sucigandhaṃ manoramaṃ.
verses.translation: Just as a lotus, fragrant and lovely, may grow upon a heap of rubbish discarded on the highway...
verses.commentary: This verse uses the 'saṅkāradhānasmiṃ' (rubbish heap) as a metaphor for the 'world' or the 'uninstructed crowd.' Even in the most 'discarded' or 'ugly' environments, the 'lotus' (the practitioner) can 'grow' (jāyetha) with 'sucigandhaṃ' (pure fragrance).

story.title: The Story of the Two Friends Garahadinna and Sirigutta
story.content: Garahadinna was a follower of a non-Buddhist sect, while his friend Sirigutta was a devout Buddhist. Garahadinna, full of prejudice, tried to 'rubbish' the Buddha's name by digging a deep pit filled with glowing coals and covering it with a rug, inviting the Buddha for a meal in hopes he would fall in. The Buddha, knowing the 'heap of rubbish' (saṅkāradhānasmiṃ) that was Garahadinna's mind, walked onto the rug anyway. As his foot touched the rug, a giant 'lotus' (pappumaṃ) bloomed from the coals to support him. The Buddha sat on the lotus, 'fragrant and lovely' (sucigandhaṃ manoramaṃ), in the middle of the 'discarded' trap. Garahadinna was so ashamed and amazed that he immediately sought forgiveness. The Buddha used this event to show that a true practitioner is like that lotus. No matter how much 'rubbish' (slander, traps, or worldly corruption) is thrown on them, they use that very 'rubbish' as fertilizer to grow even more 'lovely.' The 'heap of rubbish on the highway' is the chaotic world we all live in. The Buddha taught that we don't need to find a 'clean' place to practice; the 'lotus' of our enlightenment grows exactly in the 'mud' of our daily struggles. This story encourages the seeker that their environment—no matter how 'trashy' or difficult—is the perfect place for the Dhamma to bloom. By maintaining 'pure fragrance' in the middle of the highway of life, the practitioner becomes a 'manoramaṃ' (delightful) sign of hope for all who pass by.

verses.pali:
Evaṃ saṅkārabhūtesu, andhabhūte puthujjane;
Atirocati paññāya, sammāsambuddhasāvako.
verses.translation: ...so does the disciple of the Fully Enlightened One shine by his wisdom among those who are like rubbish—the blind worldlings.
verses.commentary: This concludes the lotus simile from Verse 58. The 'puthujjane' (worldlings) are 'andhabhūte' (blind) because they don't see the truth. The 'sāvako' (disciple) 'shines' (atirocati) with 'paññāya' (wisdom), standing out from the 'rubbish' of the ignorant world.

story.title: The Shining Disciple in the Blind World
story.content: Following the miracle of the lotus pit, Garahadinna and his family became 'disciples of the Fully Enlightened One' (sammāsambuddhasāvako). In their village, they were surrounded by 'andhabhūte puthujjane'—blind worldlings who were still lost in superstition and greed. However, Garahadinna and Sirigutta 'shone by their wisdom' (atirocati paññāya). They no longer participated in the 'rubbish' of the village quarrels or the 'blind' rituals of their former sect. Their lives were so transformed that they became like 'lights' in a dark room. The Buddha explained that a true 'sāvako' is not just someone who wears a robe, but someone whose 'paññā' (wisdom) is visible in their actions. Just as the lotus in Verse 58 stood out from the rubbish heap, the 'wise disciple' stands out from the 'blind crowd' by their lack of anger, their honesty, and their peace. This story teaches that spiritual 'shining' is not an act of pride, but an act of 'presence.' By simply being different—by being 'awake' among the 'blind'—the disciple provides a 'map' for others to follow. The Buddha encouraged them to stay in the 'heap of rubbish' (the world) because that is where the 'shining' is most needed. The transformation of a 'trap-maker' like Garahadinna into a 'shining disciple' is the ultimate proof of the Dhamma's power to turn 'rubbish' into 'lotuses.' It teaches that our 'wisdom' is our only true 'light,' and that by cultivating it, we can illuminate the path for ourselves and the 'blind' world around us.

chapters.summary: This chapter explores the characteristics and consequences of foolishness, warning against ignorance, heedlessness, and association with the unwise.

verses.pali:
Dīghā jāgarato ratti, dīghaṃ santassa yojanaṃ;
Dīgho bālānaṃ saṃsāro, saddhammaṃ avijānataṃ.
verses.translation: Long is the night to the wakeful; long is the league to the weary; long is the cycle of birth and death to the foolish who do not know the True Dhamma.
verses.commentary: This verse uses physical weariness and insomnia as metaphors for spiritual ignorance. Just as a night seems endless to one who cannot sleep, and a mile (yojana) seems like ten to a tired traveler, the 'long night' of Samsara (rebirth) feels interminable to the 'bālo' (fool). This is because the fool lacks the 'Saddhamma' (True Teaching), which is the only map that shows the way out of the cycle of suffering.

story.title: The King and the Poor Man’s Wife
story.content: King Pasenadi of Kosala once became infatuated with a beautiful woman he saw from his palace window. Discovering she was married, he plotted to have her husband executed by sending him on an impossible mission. He ordered the man to travel to a distant river to fetch a rare 'Kumuda' flower and 'Aruna' earth, demanding he return before the city gates closed for the evening or face death. The poor man traveled with desperate speed, realizing how 'long the league' (dīghaṃ yojanaṃ) is to one who is 'weary' (santo) and fearful for his life. Meanwhile, the King, plagued by his murderous intentions and the fear of discovery, could not sleep. To him, the 'night was long' (dīghā jāgarato ratti) as he tossed and turned. During that long night, he heard four terrifying sounds—'Sa, Na, Du, Vi'—screamed by beings in the depths of Lohakumbhi Hell who were suffering for past acts of adultery. Terrified, the King sought the Buddha's counsel the next morning. The Buddha explained that the husband’s journey and the King’s insomnia were both symptoms of the 'long' nature of suffering caused by desire. He warned that for 'fools' (bālānaṃ) who do not know the 'True Dhamma,' the cycle of birth and death (Samsara) is immeasurably longer and more painful than a single sleepless night. Shaken by the karmic vision, the King abandoned his plan and the husband returned safely. This story illustrates that our internal state dictates our perception of time and distance; only by following the Dhamma can one 'shorten' the road and eventually reach the end of the long night of Samsara.

verses.pali:
Carañce nādhigaccheyya, seyyaṃ sadisattano;
Ekacariyaṃ daḷhaṃ kayirā, natthi bāle sahāyatā.
verses.translation: If a seeker finds no companion who is better or equal, let him resolutely pursue a solitary course; there is no fellowship with the fool.
verses.commentary: Spiritual progress is influenced by association. 'Seyyaṃ' means better in virtue/wisdom; 'sadisattano' means equal. If such a friend is unavailable, 'ekacariyaṃ' (solitary wandering) is superior because a 'bāle' (fool) will only pull the seeker down into heedlessness.

story.title: The Story of the Monk who was a Former King
story.content: A certain monk, who had been a king in his previous life, found himself surrounded by younger monks who were lazy and interested only in gossip and worldly talk. He tried to guide them, but they mocked his seriousness. He realized that these 'bālā' (fools) were like weights tied to his ankles as he tried to swim across the ocean of Samsara. He remembered the Buddha's teaching that 'there is no fellowship with the fool' (natthi bāle sahāyatā). He decided to move to a distant forest to practice 'ekacariyaṃ' (solitary life) with 'daḷhaṃ' (firmness). The Buddha encouraged him, explaining that while human beings are social creatures, the spiritual path requires the right environment. If you are in a boat with people who are drilling holes in the hull, it is better to jump out and swim alone. The Buddha taught that a fool's 'friendship' is actually a form of hostility because it prevents one from seeing the truth. By choosing solitude over bad company, the monk was able to focus his mind without distraction. He realized that the 'loneliness' of the forest was actually a profound 'fellowship' with the Dhamma. He eventually attained Arahatship. This story teaches that we should be highly selective with our inner circle. Solitude is not a lack of friends; it is a presence of self-clarity. If we cannot find a 'seyyaṃ' (better) or 'sadisa' (equal) companion who inspires us toward virtue, walking alone is the most 'resolute' and wise choice a seeker can make.

verses.pali:
Puttā matthi dhanaṃ matthi, iti bālo vihaññati;
Attā hi attano natthi, kuto puttā kuto dhanaṃ.
verses.translation: ‘Sons have I, wealth have I’—thus the fool worries himself. Verily, he himself does not belong to himself; how then can sons be his? How can wealth?
verses.commentary: This verse attacks the root of ego-clinging. The fool ('bālo') suffers ('vihaññati') because of 'mamatā' (the sense of 'mine'). If the 'self' (attā) is an illusion and does not even 'own' itself, then external 'possessions' like children and gold are even more distant from true ownership.

story.title: The Story of Ānanda the Miserly Banker
story.content: There was a very wealthy banker named Ānanda in Sāvatthi who was extremely miserly. He was obsessed with the idea of 'mine,' constantly saying, 'Sons have I, wealth have I' (puttā matthi dhanaṃ matthi). He buried five pots of gold in his house and told his son, Mūlasiri, never to give anything to anyone. After his death, due to his intense craving and attachment, he was reborn as a deformed, blind beggar child in the same city. Driven by an instinctive memory, the child wandered to his old home. His former son, Mūlasiri, not recognizing him, had him beaten and thrown out. The Buddha arrived and, through his psychic powers, revealed to Mūlasiri that this beggar child was actually his own father. The Buddha explained that Ānanda had 'worried himself' (vihaññati) for years over 'his' wealth and 'his' son, but now he had neither. Even his own 'self' (attā) was now a different, suffering body. The Buddha taught that if we do not even 'own' our own physical form—which ages and dies against our will—how can we claim ownership of others? Ānanda’s tragedy was his 'foolish' belief in permanent possession. This story illustrates that 'ownership' is a mental fiction that leads to rebirth and pain. True peace comes only when we realize that everything, including our identity, is 'anattā' (not-self). By letting go of the 'my,' we find a freedom that no 'wealth' or 'sons' can ever provide.

verses.pali:
Yo bālo maññati bālyaṃ, paṇḍitovāpi tena so;
Bālo ca paṇḍitamānī, sa ve ‘bālo’ti vuccati.
verses.translation: The fool who knows his foolishness is wise at least to that extent; but the fool who thinks himself wise is called a fool indeed.
verses.commentary: Self-awareness is the first step toward wisdom. A 'bālo' (fool) who 'maññati bālyaṃ' (recognizes his foolishness) has opened the door to learning. However, the 'paṇḍitamānī' (the one who conceits himself to be wise) is the true 'fool' because his pride makes him unteachable.

story.title: The Story of the Two Pickpockets
story.content: Two thieves once went to the Jetavana monastery to rob the lay devotees while they were listening to the Buddha. One thief, as he listened to a few words of the Dhamma, realized the 'foolishness' of his ways. He felt a sense of 'bālyaṃ' (folly) and decided to stop stealing. He sat quietly and reflected on the Buddha's words. The other thief, however, successfully stole a purse and thought he was 'wise' (paṇḍita) for being so clever while everyone else was distracted. Later, the clever thief mocked his friend, calling him a fool for coming all the way to the monastery and leaving empty-handed. When they met the Buddha, he uttered this verse. He explained that the thief who 'recognized his foolishness' was the 'wise' one because he was now capable of change. But the thief who 'thought himself wise' while committing crimes was 'the fool indeed' (sa ve bāloti vuccati). His pride in his 'cleverness' was a wall that prevented him from ever escaping the path to suffering. This story teaches that the most dangerous form of ignorance is the belief that one is already enlightened or superior. The beginning of wisdom is the humble admission of one's own errors. By recognizing the 'fool' within, the first thief began his journey toward being a 'Paṇḍita' (wise man), while the second thief remained trapped in a self-congratulatory darkness that would eventually lead to his downfall.

verses.pali:
Yāvajīvampi ce bālo, paṇḍitaṃ payirupāsati;
Na so dhammaṃ vijānāti, dabbī sūparasaṃ yathā.
verses.translation: Even if for his whole life a fool associates with a wise man, he will not understand the Dhamma, even as a spoon does not know the taste of the soup.
verses.commentary: This verse critiques passive association. 'Payirupāsati' means to attend upon or sit near. A fool (bāla) may be physically close to a Buddha or a great teacher for a 'whole life' (yāvajīvam), but if the mind is closed by pride or lack of interest, he remains 'hard' like a wooden spoon. Just as a spoon (dabbī) enters the soup (sūpa) but cannot absorb its essence, the fool remains unchanged by the wisdom surrounding him.

story.title: The Story of the Monk Udāyī
story.content: Thera Udāyī was a monk who lived in the same monastery as the Buddha and the great elders like Sāriputta and Moggallāna for many years. He was often seen sitting in the front rows during discourses and was a constant shadow to the most enlightened beings of that era. However, Udāyī was a 'bālo' (fool) in spirit; he was more concerned with his robes, his seat, and his perceived status than with the actual practice of the Dhamma. One day, a group of visiting monks, seeing him so close to the Buddha, assumed he was a master of the teachings and asked him a simple question regarding the 'Aggregates' and the 'Sense Bases.' Udāyī stammered and could not answer even the most basic tenets of the path. When the Buddha heard of this, he uttered this verse. He explained that Udāyī was like a 'dabbī' (spoon) in a pot of 'sūpa' (soup). A spoon is immersed in the flavor day and night, but because it is made of wood or metal, it has no capacity to taste. Udāyī lacked the 'tongue' of mindfulness. Despite his proximity to the fountain of wisdom, he remained spiritually dry. His story serves as a warning that physical proximity to greatness is not a substitute for personal effort. Without internal receptivity, a person can spend an entire lifetime in the company of a Buddha and still leave empty-handed, proving that the 'taste' of the Dhamma is only for those who open their hearts to absorb it.

verses.pali:
Muhuttamapi ce viññū, paṇḍitaṃ payirupāsati;
Khippaṃ dhammaṃ vijānāti, jivhā sūparasaṃ yathā.
verses.translation: If a person of quick intuition associates with a wise man even for a moment, he will quickly understand the Dhamma, even as the tongue knows the taste of the soup.
verses.commentary: The 'viññū' is an intelligent person with 'ready' intuition. In contrast to the spoon, the 'jivhā' (tongue) has the organic capacity for 'rasa' (taste). For such a person, even a 'muhutta' (moment) of association with the truth is enough for a profound realization. It emphasizes quality of attention over quantity of time.

story.title: The Story of the Thirty Monks from Pāṭheyya
story.content: A group of thirty monks known as the 'Pāṭheyya' monks were traveling to see the Buddha. They were 'viññū'—men who had already been practicing diligently and had clarified their minds through forest meditation. When they arrived at the Jetavana monastery, they were tired and dusty from their journey. The Buddha, knowing their state of readiness, gave a very brief but deep discourse on the 'beginningless nature of the cycle of birth and death' (Samsara). Although they associated with the 'paṇḍita' (the Buddha) for only a 'muhutta' (a brief moment), they 'quickly understood the Dhamma' (khippaṃ dhammaṃ vijānāti). Their minds were like a sensitive 'jivhā' (tongue) touching a flavorful 'sūpa' (soup); the recognition of truth was instantaneous. While the Buddha was still finishing his short speech, all thirty monks were liberated from all defilements and attained Arahatship. The Buddha used this event to illustrate that for a prepared mind, a single drop of Dhamma is more effective than an ocean of study for an unprepared one. The Pāṭheyya monks demonstrated that spiritual breakthrough is not a matter of 'time served' but of 'readiness attained.' Their story encourages practitioners to 'sensitize' their own minds through daily discipline, so that when they finally encounter a moment of deep truth, they can 'taste' it immediately and achieve the ultimate freedom.

verses.pali:
Caranti bālā dummedhā, amitteneva attanā;
Karontā pāpakaṃ kammaṃ, yaṃ hoti kaṭukapphalaṃ.
verses.translation: Fools of little wit move about as if they are their own enemies, committing evil deeds which bear bitter fruits.
verses.commentary: 'Dummedhā' (little wit) refers to the lack of wisdom to see cause and effect. The fool acts as an 'amittena' (enemy) to 'attanā' (himself) because he is the one who will have to eat the 'kaṭukapphalaṃ' (bitter fruit) of the 'pāpakaṃ kammaṃ' (evil deeds) he is currently sowing.

story.title: The Story of the Hunter Koka
story.content: Koka was a hunter who lived with a heart full of anger. One day, while going to the forest with his dogs, he met a monk. He considered it a bad omen and, after failing to catch any game, blamed the monk. On his way back, he saw the monk again and, in a rage, set his dogs upon him. The monk climbed a tree, but Koka began to prick the monk’s feet with his arrows. In the struggle, the monk’s robe fell and covered Koka. The dogs, thinking the monk had fallen, attacked the figure in the robe and killed their own master. The Buddha explained that Koka was 'his own enemy' (amitteneva attanā). By committing 'pāpakaṃ kammaṃ' (evil deeds) out of spite, he created the very conditions for his own agonizing death. The 'bitter fruit' (kaṭukapphalaṃ) was not a punishment from a god, but a natural result of his own 'little wit.' He thought he was hurting the monk, but he was actually 'hunting' himself. This story is a vivid illustration of the self-destructive nature of malice. When we act with hatred, we are like a person throwing dust into the wind; it only blows back into our own eyes. Koka moved about the world thinking he was a predator, but because he lacked wisdom, he was actually the prey of his own bad kamma. The verse warns us that the 'enemy' we should fear most is not someone outside, but our own 'foolish' intentions that plant the seeds of our future misery.

verses.pali:
Na taṃ kammaṃ kataṃ sādhu, yaṃ katvā anutappati;
Yassa assumukho rodaṃ, vipākaṃ paṭisevati.
verses.translation: That deed is not well done which, being done, one afterwards repents, and the fruit of which one reaps with a tearful face and lamentation.
verses.commentary: 'Anutappati' (repents/remorse) is the first 'bitter fruit.' A 'well done' (sādhu) deed should leave the mind cool. If a person must 'reap the fruit' with 'assumukho' (a tearful face), it is proof that the original 'kamma' (action) was unwholesome.

story.title: The Story of the Farmer and the Thief
story.content: A thief stole a purse of gold and, while running through a field, accidentally dropped it near a hardworking farmer. When the King's guards arrived, they found the gold and, assuming the farmer was the thief, arrested and tortured him. The farmer cried out in 'lamentation' (rodaṃ), realizing that his 'tearful face' (assumukho) was the result of a situation he didn't even understand. However, the real 'deed not well done' (na taṃ kammaṃ kataṃ sādhu) was that of the thief. Even though he escaped the guards, he lived in constant fear and 'remorse' (anutappati), knowing that his 'pāpakaṃ kammaṃ' had caused an innocent man to suffer. The Buddha explained that any action that leads to 'tears'—whether for the doer or the victim—is a 'bad' action. The thief eventually 'reaped the fruit' when his own guilt drove him to a state of mental breakdown. The Buddha taught that we should judge the quality of our actions by their 'aftertaste.' If the aftertaste is bitter and leads to 'crying' (rodaṃ), the deed was a mistake. This story encourages us to practice 'yoniso manasikāra' (wise reflection) before we act. A truly 'good' deed is one that we can look back on with a smile of 'pasāda' (clarity) rather than a face wet with the 'tears' of regret. By avoiding actions that lead to 'anutappati,' we ensure that our future 'vipāka' (result) is one of peace rather than pain.

verses.pali:
Tañca kammaṃ kataṃ sādhu, yaṃ katvā nānutappati;
Yassa patīto sumano, vipākaṃ paṭisevati.
verses.translation: But well done is that deed which, being done, one does not afterwards repent, and the fruit of which one reaps with a joyful and contented mind.
verses.commentary: The positive twin of Verse 67. A 'sādhu' (well done) deed is followed by 'nānutappati' (no remorse). The 'vipāka' (result) is experienced with a 'sumano' (happy/contented) mind. This is the bliss of blamelessness.

story.title: The Story of Sumana the Flower-Girl
story.content: Sumana was a young girl whose job was to provide flowers to the King. One day, she saw the Buddha and, filled with 'pasāda' (faith), she decided to offer the King's flowers to him instead, even though she knew she might be punished or even executed for it. After the offering, she felt no 'remorse' (nānutappati); instead, her mind was 'patīto' (joyful). She felt that even if she died, her life was 'well done' (kataṃ sādhu). When the King heard of this, instead of being angry, he was moved by her devotion and rewarded her with great wealth. Sumana 'reaped the fruit' of her merit with a 'sumano' (contented mind) in this very life. The Buddha used her as an example, explaining that a 'well done' deed is like a refreshing drink—it leaves the heart 'contented' from the first moment of intention to the final moment of result. Unlike the fool who cries when they see their kamma, the wise person 'reaps' with a 'joyful mind.' This story teaches that 'goodness' is its own reward because it brings an immediate end to the 'burning' of anxiety. By choosing the 'wholesome' over the 'safe,' Sumana ensured that her 'vipāka' would be as beautiful as the flowers she offered. It encourages us to perform acts of generosity and courage that leave us with a 'clear conscience,' which the Buddha declares as the highest form of 'wealth' a human can possess.

verses.pali:
Madhuṃvā maññati bālo, yāva pāpaṃ na paccati;
Yadā ca paccatī pāpaṃ, atha bālo dukkhaṃ nigacchati.
verses.translation: As sweet as honey thinks the fool an evil deed as long as it ripens not; but when it ripens, then the fool comes to grief.
verses.commentary: The fool ('bālo') is deceived by the 'madhu' (honey)—the temporary pleasure or gain from an evil act. Because 'pāpaṃ' (evil) takes time to 'paccati' (ripen), he thinks he has 'gotten away with it.' However, the 'dukkhaṃ' (grief) is inevitable once the conditions are met.

story.title: The Story of the Greedy Treasurer
story.content: A royal treasurer once cheated a poor widow out of her only piece of land. For several months, he enjoyed the 'honey' (madhuṃvā) of his ill-gotten gain; he felt 'wise' and 'clever' because he had increased his wealth without any immediate consequence. He 'thought it was sweet' as long as the 'evil had not ripened' (yāva pāpaṃ na paccati). However, the widow's 'tears' eventually reached the King's ears. An investigation was launched, and the treasurer was stripped of his rank and his wealth, and thrown into prison. It was only 'then' (atha) that the 'fool came to grief' (dukkhaṃ nigacchati). The Buddha explained that evil is like a slow-acting poison; it may taste 'sweet' on the tongue, but it burns in the stomach. The 'fool' is like someone who eats a delicious meal unaware that it contains a toxin. His 'joy' is based on ignorance. The Buddha taught that we should never be 'envious' of the success of the wicked, because their 'honey' is just a mask for future 'grief.' The story serves as a warning against short-term thinking. Just as a fruit takes time to grow from a seed, kamma takes time to 'ripen' (paccati). The 'sweetness' of an evil deed is a dangerous illusion that leads the 'fool' deeper into the trap until the 'grief' becomes overwhelming and inescapable.

verses.pali:
Māse māse kusaggena, bālo bhuñjetha bhojanaṃ;
Na so saṅkhātadhammānaṃ, kalaṃ agghati soḷasiṃ.
verses.translation: Month after month a fool may eat only as much food as can be picked up on the tip of a blade of kusa grass, but he is not worth even a sixteenth part of those who have understood the Dhamma.
verses.commentary: Extreme asceticism (eating with 'kusaggena'—the tip of grass) is useless without 'saṅkhātadhammānaṃ' (understanding the Dhamma). External rituals and self-mortification are the works of a 'bālo' (fool) if the mind remains filled with 'self' and 'pride.'

story.title: The Story of the Ascetic Jambuka
story.content: Jambuka was an ascetic who practiced extreme austerities for fifty-five years. He lived naked, slept on the ground, and pretended to eat nothing but air, though he secretly ate filth at night. To the public, he seemed like a great saint who 'ate only a blade-tip of food' (kusaggena bhuñjetha). However, his mind was 'foolish' because it was filled with 'deceit' and 'pride.' When he finally met the Buddha, he realized that all his years of suffering were 'not worth a sixteenth part' (kalaṃ agghati soḷasiṃ) of the merit gained by even a 'moment' of true 'understanding of the Dhamma.' The Buddha taught that 'sīla' (virtue) and 'paññā' (wisdom) are the only true 'food' for the spirit. Jambuka’s extreme 'rituals' were just another form of 'ego-clinging.' Once he 'understood the Dhamma'—the Four Noble Truths—he attained Arahatship instantly. This story is a critique of 'spiritual performance.' We may 'look' like saints through our 'fasting' and 'rituals,' but if our 'self' remains untamed, we are still 'fools.' The Buddha emphasized that a 'single word' of truth is more 'precious' than fifty years of 'starvation' without wisdom. It encourages us to focus on the 'internal' quality of our practice rather than 'external' displays of holiness, which the Buddha declares as 'worthless' in the pursuit of true liberation.

verses.pali:
Na hi pāpaṃ kataṃ kammaṃ, sajju khīraṃva muccati;
Dahantaṃ bālaṃ anveti, bhaymamivacchanno pāvako.
verses.translation: An evil deed, like newly-drawn milk, does not turn sour at once; smoldering like fire covered by ashes, it follows the fool.
verses.commentary: This verse uses two vivid similes. 'Khīraṃ' (milk) takes time to 'muccati' (turn/curdle); similarly, 'pāpaṃ' (evil) doesn't produce 'bad' results instantly. It is like 'pāvako' (fire) 'acchanno' (covered) by 'bhasma' (ashes)—it is invisible but 'dahantaṃ' (burning) and 'anveti' (following) the 'bālo' (fool).

story.title: The Story of the Snake-Ghost
story.content: A monk with psychic powers saw a 'peta' (hungry ghost) in the form of a giant snake that was constantly 'burning' with fire. The Buddha explained that in a past life, this being had burned down the leaf-hut of a Silent Buddha out of spite. At the time of the 'evil deed' (pāpaṃ kataṃ kammaṃ), nothing happened; it was 'like newly-drawn milk' (sajju khīraṃva) that remained 'sweet' and 'fresh.' The man even thought he had 'gotten away with it.' However, the kamma was 'smoldering like fire covered by ashes' (bhymamivacchanno pāvako) beneath the surface of his life. After death, the 'ashes' were blown away, and the 'fire' of his deed began to 'burn the fool' (dahantaṃ bālaṃ). He was 'followed' (anveti) by his own action into the ghost realm. This story teaches that 'time' is the fool's greatest deceiver. Because the 'milk' hasn't turned 'sour' yet, he continues to act recklessly. The Buddha warns us that every unwholesome act is a 'live coal' buried in the 'ashes' of our memory. We may 'forget' the deed, but the 'heat' remains. It encourages us to 'cool' the fire of our kamma 'now' through 'repentance' and 'merit' before the 'ashes' are removed by death and the 'burning' becomes our entire reality.

verses.pali:
Yāvadeva anatthāya, ñattaṃ bālassa jāyati;
Hanti bālassa sukkaṃsaṃ, muddhaṃ assa vipātayaṃ.
verses.translation: To his own ruin the fool acquires knowledge, for it destroys his good fortune and cleaves his head.
verses.commentary: 'Ñattaṃ' (knowledge/fame) is 'anatthāya' (for ruin) for a 'bālo' (fool) because he uses it to feed his 'ego' rather than to purify his mind. It 'destroys his good fortune' (sukkaṃsaṃ) because his 'pride' leads to the 'cleaving of his head' (muddhaṃ vipātayaṃ)—the destruction of his potential for wisdom.

story.title: The Story of the Intelligent Elephant-Trainer
story.content: A young man learned the art of 'elephant-training' so well that he became 'famous' (ñattaṃ). However, he was a 'bālo' (fool) because he used his 'knowledge' to bully others and show off his 'power.' He became so 'proud' that he even challenged his own teacher. His 'good fortune' (sukkaṃsaṃ) was 'destroyed' because he lost the respect of the community and the King. Eventually, in a display of 'arrogance,' he tried to tame a wild elephant without 'mindfulness,' and the elephant 'cleaved his head' (muddhaṃ vipātayaṃ). The Buddha explained that 'knowledge' in the hands of a 'fool' is like a sword in the hands of a child—it is 'to his own ruin' (anatthāya). He taught that 'secular knowledge' without 'spiritual wisdom' (paññā) only increases 'conceit' (māna). The young man's 'head'—representing his 'ego' and his 'intellect'—was 'split' because he had no 'foundation' of 'virtue.' This story is a warning against 'intellectual pride.' We may be 'brilliant' in our fields, but if we are 'fools' in our hearts, our 'brilliance' will only 'burn' us. It encourages us to use our 'knowledge' as a 'tool' for 'service' rather than a 'pedestal' for 'pride,' ensuring that our 'fortune' leads to 'liberation' rather than 'ruin.'

verses.pali:
Asataṃ bhāvanamiccheyya, purekkharatañca bhikkhusu;
Āvāsesu ca issariyaṃ, pūjā parakulesu ca.
verses.translation: The fool desires undue reputation, precedence among monks, authority in monasteries, and honor among families.
verses.commentary: The 'bālo' (fool) is driven by 'asataṃ' (unreal/undue) desires. He seeks 'purekkharataṃ' (precedence) and 'issariyaṃ' (authority). He views the 'holy life' as a 'career' for 'pūjā' (honor) rather than a 'path' to 'purity.'

story.title: The Story of the Ambitious Monk Sudhamma
story.content: Sudhamma was a monk who took 'authority' (issariyaṃ) over a local monastery and expected 'honor' (pūjā) from the local families. When the great disciple Citta the Householder invited the Chief Disciples Sāriputta and Moggallāna for a meal, Sudhamma felt 'slighted' because he wasn't given 'precedence' (purekkharataṃ). He was a 'bālo' (fool) because his 'desire' for 'undue reputation' (asataṃ bhāvanam) made him 'rude' to the great elders. He 'insulted' Citta and 'left' the monastery in a 'huff.' The Buddha explained that Sudhamma had 'forgotten' the 'essence' of the 'holy life.' He was 'monk-like' on the outside but 'world-like' on the inside. His 'desire' for 'authority' was just 'attachment' in a 'yellow robe.' The story teaches that 'spiritual status' is the 'ultimate trap' for the 'ego.' If we seek 'honor' in our 'practice,' we are no different from 'politicians' seeking 'votes.' The Buddha taught that a 'true' monk is one who is 'content' to be 'invisible.' By seeking 'pūjā' (honor) in 'other families' (parakulesu), Sudhamma 'poisoned' his own 'peace.' It encourages us to 'root out' the 'desire' for 'recognition,' realizing that the only 'reputation' that matters is our 'standing' with the 'Truth.'

verses.translation: ‘Let both laymen and monks think that this was done by me; let them be subject to me in every work, great or small’—thus is the thought of the fool; his desire and pride increase.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the 'narcissism' of the 'fool' ('bālassa saṅkappo'). He wants 'credit' ('mameva kataṃ'—'by me alone was it done') for everything. This 'thought' leads to a 'vaḍḍhati' (increase) of 'icchā' (desire) and 'māno' (pride), making him a 'slave' to his own 'ego.'

story.title: The Story of the Architect of the Monastery
story.content: A layman built a beautiful monastery and 'wanted' everyone to 'know' that 'it was done by me' (mameva kataṃ). He spent all his time 'ordering' the monks 'in every work' (kiccākiccesu) and 'wanted' them to be 'subject to him' (mamevātivasā). He was a 'bālo' (fool) because his 'generosity' was 'tainted' by 'pride' (māno). Instead of 'joy,' he felt 'anger' whenever he wasn't 'recognized.' The Buddha explained that 'true' merit is 'selfless.' If we 'attach' our 'name' to our 'deeds,' we 'lose' the 'blessing.' The 'increase' of 'desire' (icchā) for 'recognition' is a 'disease' that 'kills' the 'spirit.' The story teaches that 'giving' is a 'release' of 'self,' not an 'expansion' of it. The layman's 'thought' was 'foolish' because he was 'building' a 'monument' to his 'ego' rather than a 'shelter' for the 'Sangha.' The Buddha encourages us to 'do' the 'work' and then 'disappear.' By 'releasing' the 'thought' of 'me' and 'mine,' we 'increase' our 'peace' rather than our 'pride,' proving that the 'best' deed is the one that has 'no name' attached to it except the 'name' of 'Compassion.'

verses.translation: One path leads to worldly gain, another to Nibbana. Clearly realizing this, let the monk, the disciple of the Buddha, not delight in worldly honor, but devote himself to solitude.
verses.commentary: This concludes the chapter with a 'choice.' 'Lābhūpanisā' (path to gain) and 'nibbānagāminī' (path to Nibbana) are 'aññā' (different/distinct). The 'sāvako' (disciple) must 'not delight' (nābhinandeyya) in 'sakkāraṃ' (honor) but 'devote himself' (anubrūhaye) to 'viveka' (solitude/detachment).

story.title: The Story of the Monk Tissa of the Forest
story.content: Tissa was a monk who lived in a small forest cave. Because of his 'purity,' many wealthy families wanted to 'honor' him (sakkāraṃ) with 'lavish offerings.' Tissa realized that 'this path leads to worldly gain' (lābhūpanisā) and would 'distract' him from the 'path to Nibbana' (nibbānagāminī). He 'clearly realized' (abhiññāya) that 'honor' is a 'golden chain' that binds as tightly as an iron one. He 'did not delight' in the 'praise' but instead 'devoted himself to solitude' (vivekamanubrūhaye) by moving to an even more 'remote' forest. The Buddha praised Tissa, stating that he was a 'true' 'disciple' (sāvako). He taught that we 'cannot' walk 'both' paths at once; we must 'choose' between 'looking good' to the 'world' and 'being good' to the 'Truth.' Tissa’s 'solitude' was his 'protection.' This story is the 'final lesson' of the 'Fools' chapter: the 'fool' seeks the 'world,' but the 'wise' seeks 'liberation.' By 'devoting' himself to 'viveka,' Tissa 'transcended' the 'foolishness' of the 'ego' and 'attained' the 'quiet' 'bliss' of Nibbana. It encourages us to 'choose' the 'quiet path' of 'detachment,' realizing that the 'honor' of the 'world' is 'fading,' but the 'peace' of the 'spirit' is 'eternal.'

chapters.summary: This chapter describes the qualities of wise persons and emphasizes the importance of associating with noble companions who guide one toward enlightenment.

verses.translation: One should follow a wise man who, as if revealing a hidden treasure, points out your faults and rebukes you. Following such a wise man leads to good, not to evil.
verses.commentary: A true friend is 'vajjadassinaṃ' (one who sees faults) and 'niggayhavādiṃ' (one who speaks to rebuke). This is compared to someone pointing out a 'nidhīnaṃ' (hidden treasure), because correcting a fault is a spiritual gain. Associating with such a 'paṇḍita' ensures one becomes 'seyyo' (better).

story.title: The Story of Thera Rādha
story.content: Rādha was a poor old man who lived in the monastery performing menial tasks, but no monk wanted to ordain him because of his advanced age. The Buddha, seeing his potential, asked the monks if anyone remembered a kindness from Rādha. Sāriputta remembered that Rādha had once given him a ladleful of rice. The Buddha then allowed Sāriputta to ordain him. As a teacher, Sāriputta was very strict; he was a 'vajjadassinaṃ' who constantly pointed out Rādha's mistakes and 'niggayhavādiṃ' who rebuked him to ensure he practiced correctly. Rādha, instead of being offended, treated every criticism as if Sāriputta were 'revealing a hidden treasure' (nidhīnaṃva pavattāraṃ). He followed every instruction with deep gratitude and humility. Because he associated with such a 'paṇḍita' (wise man) as Sāriputta, Rādha attained Arahatship in a very short time. The Buddha praised Rādha's attitude, explaining that a fool hates being corrected, but a wise man seeks out a teacher who will tell him the truth about his failings. This story illustrates that spiritual growth is accelerated when we view discipline not as an insult, but as a gift. Rādha’s success was not just his own; it was the result of a 'wise association' where the student had the humility to recognize that the one who rebukes is his greatest benefactor. It teaches that to find a 'hidden treasure' of wisdom, we must be willing to let someone point out the 'dirt' covering it.

verses.pali:
Ovadeyya nusāseyya, asabbhā ca nivāraye;
Sataṃ hi so piyo hoti, asataṃ hoti appiyo.
verses.translation: Let him advise, let him instruct, and let him restrain one from evil. Such a person is pleasing to the good, but displeasing to the evil.
verses.commentary: The wise man 'ovadeyya' (advises) and 'anusāseyya' (instructs repeatedly). He acts as a shield to 'nivāraye' (restrain) others from 'asabbhā' (unworthy/evil conduct). While 'sataṃ' (the good) love him for this, the 'asataṃ' (the wicked) find him 'appiyo' (unpleasant) because they don't want to change.

story.title: The Story of the Monks Assaji and Punabbasu
story.content: Assaji and Punabbasu were two monks who led a group that ignored the monastic rules. They planted trees, gave flowers to laypeople for favors, and engaged in worldly entertainment. When the Buddha sent his chief disciples to 'advise' (ovadeyya) and 'instruct' (anusāseyya) them to stop their 'unworthy' (asabbhā) behavior, the two monks became extremely angry. They found the elders 'appiyo' (unpleasant) and refused to listen, eventually leaving the Sangha in a huff. The Buddha explained that this reaction is the mark of an 'unwise' person. A person who loves their defilements will naturally hate the person who tries to 'restrain' them. In contrast, the 'good' (sataṃ) monks in the monastery were 'pleased' (piyo) because they valued the integrity of the Sangha. This story highlights the social friction that truth-telling creates. The wise man does not speak to be popular; he speaks to be helpful. He understands that while the 'evil' will reject him, his duty is to protect the 'Saddhamma' (True Teaching). It teaches us to examine our own reactions to criticism: if we feel 'appiyo' (annoyed) when corrected, we are aligning ourselves with the 'asataṃ.' But if we feel 'piyo' (grateful), we are moving toward the path of the wise. The wise man's instruction is like medicine—it might taste bitter to the sick, but the healthy recognize its life-saving value.

verses.pali:
Na bhaje pāpake mitte, na bhaje purisādhame;
Bhajetha mitte kalyāṇe, bhajetha purisuttame.
verses.translation: Associate not with evil friends, associate not with mean men; associate with good friends, associate with noble men.
verses.commentary: Association is the primary architect of character. 'Pāpake mitte' (evil friends) and 'purisādhame' (low/mean men) lead one to ruin. One should actively seek 'kalyāṇe mitte' (noble/virtuous friends) and 'purisuttame' (the best of men).

story.title: The Story of Thera Channa
