story.content: Channa was the charioteer who accompanied Prince Siddhartha on the night he renounced the world. Because of this historical connection, Channa was extremely proud and refused to listen to any monk, often insulting the chief disciples Sāriputta and Moggallāna. He was associating with his own pride and 'mean' (adhame) thoughts, refusing to find 'good friends' (mitte kalyāṇe) among the Sangha. He considered himself 'superior' because of his past, but the Buddha saw that he was becoming 'inferior' because of his associations. On his deathbed, the Buddha instructed the monks to impose the 'Brahmadanda' (the highest penalty) on Channa—complete social silence. No monk was to speak to him or advise him. This total lack of 'association' finally broke Channa's pride. He realized that without the 'fellowship of the noble' (purisuttame), he was lost. He became deeply humble, sought out the elders he had insulted, and through their 'kalyāṇa' (noble) influence, he practiced diligently and attained Arahatship. The Buddha used Channa’s journey to show that even a person with a great past can be ruined by 'pāpake mitte' (evil companions, including one's own ego). Only when he 'associated' with the 'best of men' by following their guidance did he find his way. The story teaches that we are the average of the people we spend time with. If we surround ourselves with those who justify our faults, we stay stuck; if we surround ourselves with the noble, we are naturally pulled upward toward liberation.

verses.pali:
Dhammapīti sukhaṃ seti, vippasannena cetasā;
Ariyappavedite dhamme, sadā ramati paṇḍito.
verses.translation: He who drinks in the Dhamma lives happily with a serene mind. The wise man ever rejoices in the Dhamma made known by the Noble Ones.
verses.commentary: 'Dhammapīti' refers to one who 'drinks' the nectar of the Dhamma, finding deep satisfaction in it. 'Vippasannena cetasā' describes a mind that is clear and transparent, free from the silt of defilements. The 'Noble Ones' (Ariyas) are the Buddhas and their enlightened disciples, whose teachings provide the 'range' where the wise person (paṇḍito) takes delight.

story.title: The Story of Thera Mahākappina
story.content: Mahākappina was once a king who renounced his throne along with his queen and ministers to find the Buddha. After ordaining as a monk, he attained Arahatship. However, he had a habit of exclaiming 'Aho Sukhaṃ! Aho Sukhaṃ!' (Oh, what happiness! Oh, what happiness!) while sitting in meditation or walking in the monastery. The other monks, thinking he was reminiscing about his former royal luxuries and the 'happiness' of his palace life, reported this to the Buddha. The Buddha called Mahākappina and asked him about his exclamation. The Thera explained that his joy was not for the worldly kingdom he left behind, but for the 'kingdom of Dhamma' he had found. The Buddha then explained to the monks that Mahākappina was a 'Dhammapīti'—one who drinks the essence of the Dhamma. He lived 'happily' (sukhaṃ seti) because his mind was 'serene' (vippasannena cetasā) and no longer burdened by the worries of a ruler or the attachments of a worldling. The Buddha taught that the happiness of the Dhamma is superior to any royal bliss because it is unconditioned and stable. Mahākappina’s joy was the 'joy of the Noble Ones' (Ariyappavedite), which arises when the heart is completely liberated from the 'thirst' of craving. This story illustrates that the true 'Paṇḍita' (wise man) does not look back at what he has lost, but rejoices in the boundless internal peace he has gained, proving that the Dhamma is a wellspring that never runs dry for those who have the wisdom to drink from it.

verses.pali:
Udakañhi nayanti nettikā, usukārā namayanti tejanaṃ;
Dāruṃ namayanti tacchakā, attānaṃ damayanti paṇḍitā.
verses.translation: Irrigators regulate the waters; fletchers straighten the arrow shaft; carpenters shape the wood; the wise control themselves.
verses.commentary: This verse uses three similes of external mastery to illustrate internal mastery. An 'irrigator' (nettikā) directs water where it doesn't naturally go; a 'fletcher' (usukārā) straightens crooked wood; a 'carpenter' (tacchakā) shapes raw timber. Similarly, the 'paṇḍitā' (wise) perform 'damayanti' (taming/control) on the raw, crooked, and wandering nature of 'attānaṃ' (the self/mind).

story.title: The Story of the Novice Paṇḍita
story.content: A seven-year-old novice named Paṇḍita was walking with his teacher, Thera Sāriputta. Along the way, he saw 'irrigators' (nettikā) directing water into their fields, 'fletchers' (usukārā) heating and straightening arrows, and 'carpenters' (tacchakā) carving wood into useful wheels. The young novice asked: 'If people can tame lifeless things like water, wood, and metal, why can't we tame our own minds?' This question triggered a deep 'Appamāda' (heedfulness) in him. He asked his teacher's permission to return to his cell to meditate. While Sāriputta went for alms, the young novice sat down with the firm resolve to 'tame himself' (attānaṃ damayanti). He used the images he had seen as his meditation subjects: if water can be led, he would lead his thoughts; if an arrow can be straightened, he would straighten his intentions. His effort was so intense that Sakka, King of the Devas, ensured the monastery was quiet so he wouldn't be disturbed. By the time Sāriputta returned with food, the seven-year-old had attained Arahatship. The Buddha explained that just as craftsmen 'shape' their materials into valuable tools, the wise 'shape' their own character through meditation. This story teaches that the most important 'technology' in the world is not the control of the environment, but the 'damayana' (taming) of the heart. The raw 'self' is like the raw timber—it has no value until it is shaped by the wise into the 'vessel' of enlightenment.

verses.pali:
Selo yathā ekaghano, vātena na samīrati;
Evaṃ nindāpasaṃsāsu, na samiñjanti paṇḍitā.
verses.translation: As a solid rock is not shaken by the wind, even so the wise are not moved by praise or blame.
verses.commentary: The 'paṇḍitā' (wise) are compared to a 'selo ekaghano' (solid, single-block rock). 'Nindā' (blame) and 'pasaṃsā' (praise) are like the 'vāta' (wind)—temporary and external. Because the wise man's happiness is internal, external opinions cannot 'samiñjanti' (disturb/move) his equanimity.

story.title: The Story of Thera Lakuṇṭaka Bhaddiya
story.content: Thera Bhaddiya was an Arhat who was extremely short in stature, almost like a child. Because of his appearance, young monks and novices would often tease him, pulling his ears or patting his head, saying, 'How are you today, little monk?' They were giving him 'nindā' (blame/ridicule). On the other hand, the Buddha and the senior elders frequently 'pasaṃsā' (praised) his great wisdom and psychic powers. Whether he was being ridiculed by the novices or honored by the Buddha, Bhaddiya’s expression and mind remained unchanged. He was like a 'solid rock' (selo ekaghano). He didn't feel hurt by the ears-pulling, nor did he feel pride at the Buddha's praise. The Buddha pointed him out to the other monks as an example of a 'Paṇḍita.' He explained that a person who is 'shaken' by a compliment is just as vulnerable as a person who is 'shaken' by an insult. Both reactions show that the mind is leaning on external validation. Bhaddiya, however, stood on the 'rock' of his own realization. The 'wind' (vāta) of worldly opinion could blow as hard as it wanted, but it couldn't move him even an inch. This story illustrates that true wisdom is synonymous with 'upekkhā' (equanimity). It teaches us that our peace should not be 'up for vote' by the people around us. Like the 'selo,' we should be so substantially established in our own virtue that the 'words' of the world simply breeze past us without leaving a scratch.

verses.pali:
Yathāpi rahado gambhīro, vippasanno anāvilo;
Evaṃ dhammāni sutvāna, vippasīdanti paṇḍitā.
verses.translation: Just as a deep lake is clear and still, even so, on hearing the teachings, the wise become exceedingly peaceful.
verses.commentary: The mind of a worldling is like a shallow pond, easily muddied by the winds of emotion. The 'Paṇḍita' (wise person) is compared to a 'rahado gambhīro' (deep lake). 'Vippasanno' (clear) and 'anāvilo' (un-agitated) signify that the wisdom gained from 'hearing the teachings' (dhammāni sutvāna) allows the mind to settle into a profound state of 'vippasīdanti' (clarity/peace).

story.title: The Story of the Five Hundred Lay Disciples
story.content: A group of five hundred lay disciples went to the Jetavana monastery to listen to the Buddha. However, as the Buddha spoke, many of them were distracted: some were sleeping, some were drawing in the sand with their fingers, and some were looking up at the trees. Only one disciple sat perfectly still, listening with total absorption. Ānanda asked the Buddha why there was such a difference in their behavior. The Buddha explained that the minds of most people are like shallow puddles; they are easily disturbed by the smallest 'pebble' of a sensory distraction. But the one disciple who was truly 'wise' (paṇḍita) had a mind like a 'deep lake' (rahado gambhīro). He had practiced mindfulness in many past lives, allowing his mind to become 'vippasanno' (transparent) and 'anāvilo' (undisturbed). When such a person 'hears the teachings,' the words do not just skim the surface; they sink into the depths, causing the mind to become 'exceedingly peaceful' (vippasīdanti). The Buddha taught that wisdom is the ability to maintain depth in the face of the world's noise. The deep lake is not affected by the wind that creates ripples on the surface; similarly, the wise man’s internal peace is not shattered by external events because it is rooted in the deep understanding of the Dhamma. This story emphasizes that the quality of our 'hearing' depends on the 'depth' of our mental preparation, encouraging us to cultivate a mind that can hold the truth without being muddied by restlessness.

verses.pali:
Sabbattha ve sappurisā cajanti, na kāmakāmā lapayanti santo;
Sukhena phuṭṭhā atha vā dukhena, na uccāvacaṃ paṇḍitā dassayanti.
verses.translation: The good renounce (attachment to) everything; the saintly do not prattle with a yearning for pleasures. Whether affected by happiness or by sorrow, the wise show neither elation nor depression.
verses.commentary: 'Sappurisā' (good/virtuous men) 'cajanti' (give up/renounce) attachment to all worldly things. They are 'santo' (tranquil ones) who do not 'lapayanti' (talk/chatter) with 'kāmakāmā' (desire for pleasure). Their most prominent feature is 'upekkhā' (equanimity)—they show no 'uccāvacaṃ' (fluctuation/highs and lows) when touched by the 'Eight Worldly Winds' of joy and pain.

story.title: The Story of the Monk who was a Former Weaver
story.content: A weaver became a monk and, through his diligent practice, attained Arahatship. One day, a group of his former colleagues visited him and tried to tempt him by talking about the 'pleasures' (kāma) of his old life and the fine clothes he used to make. They expected him to either be nostalgic and 'prattle' with yearning, or to be annoyed and defensive. However, the monk remained perfectly 'santo' (tranquil). He showed neither 'elation' at their memories nor 'depression' at his current simple life. He had 'renounced everything' (sabbattha cajanti), including the ego that would react to such talk. The Buddha pointed him out as a true 'Paṇḍita.' He explained that the wise are like a level balance; they do not tilt toward 'happiness' (sukha) or 'sorrow' (dukkha). Most people are 'uccāvacaṃ'—they are high when they get what they want and low when they lose it. But the wise have 'renounced' the very mechanism of craving that creates these fluctuations. The weaver-monk's silence was his most powerful 'speech,' demonstrating that he was no longer a victim of circumstances. This story teaches that the hallmark of spiritual maturity is the 'unmoving' mind. By letting go of the 'yearning' for the pleasant and the 'aversion' to the unpleasant, we achieve a state of 'dassayanti' (visible stability) that serves as a beacon of peace for everyone around us, proving that true freedom is found in the middle of the storm, not just in the absence of it.

verses.pali:
Na attahetu na parassa hetu, na puttamicche na dhanaṃ na raṭṭhaṃ;
Na iccheyya adhammena samiddhi mattano, sa sīlavā paññavā dhammiko siyā.
verses.translation: Neither for one's own sake nor for the sake of another, should one desire a son, wealth, or a kingdom. Nor should one desire success by unjust means. Such a man is indeed virtuous, wise, and righteous.
verses.commentary: This verse defines the 'Dhammiko' (righteous person) as someone whose ethics are absolute and not transactional. They do not 'desire success' (samiddhi) through 'adhammena' (unrighteous/unjust means). Their virtue ('sīlavā') and wisdom ('paññā') are based on the realization that gains achieved through harm are actually losses in the long run.

story.title: The Story of the Honest Merchant
story.content: A merchant who was a follower of the Buddha was once offered a chance to make a massive profit by cheating his business partners. He knew that this 'wealth' (dhanaṃ) would allow him to provide better for his 'sons' (puttā) and even gain influence in the 'kingdom' (raṭṭhaṃ). However, he remembered that the Buddha taught that one should not seek 'success by unjust means' (adhammena samiddhi). He realized that performing an evil act for 'one's own sake' (attahetu) or even for the 'sake of another' (parassa hetu) like his family was still a violation of the Dhamma. He refused the deal, choosing to remain 'righteous' (dhammiko) even at the cost of poverty. His partners mocked him, but the merchant felt a deep internal peace that no money could buy. The Buddha praised him, stating that he was 'sīlavā' (virtuous) and 'paññavā' (wise) because he understood that the 'karmic debt' of an unjust act far outweighs any material gain. The story teaches that true 'success' is the ability to sleep with a clear conscience. Most 'fools' believe that they can 'buy' happiness with ill-gotten gains, but the wise man knows that 'righteousness' is the only 'wealth' that is truly ours. By putting 'Dhamma' above 'desire,' the merchant proved that he had 'conquered' the most difficult kingdom of all—his own greed—earning him a reputation for integrity that lasted long after his physical wealth had faded.

verses.pali:
Appakā te manussesu, ye janā pāragāmino;
Athāyaṃ itarā pajā, tīramevānudhāvati.
verses.translation: Few among men are those who cross to the further shore. The rest of mankind only runs up and down the hither bank.
verses.commentary: The 'hither bank' (tīraṃ) represents the realm of 'Samsara' (suffering and rebirth). The 'further shore' (pāraṃ) represents Nibbana. 'Appakā' (few) indicates the rarity of those who actually take the 'step' to 'cross' (gāmino), while 'itarā pajā' (the rest of the people) are caught in the 'Anudhāvati'—the perpetual, restless running back and forth within their own desires.

story.title: The Story of the Ferryman and the Travelers
story.content: A group of travelers stood by a wide, turbulent river, wanting to get to the beautiful land on the other side. Most of them spent their time 'running up and down the hither bank' (tīramevānudhāvati), arguing about the best place to cross, looking for easier paths, or getting distracted by the stalls and entertainment on their side. Only a 'few' (appakā) actually built a raft and began the difficult journey of 'crossing to the further shore' (pāragāmino). The Buddha used this analogy to describe humanity's spiritual condition. The 'hither bank' is the world of sensory pleasures, work, and family, which seems safe but is actually prone to the 'flood' of death. Most people are so busy with the 'running'—the endless pursuit of the next meal, the next thrill, or the next status—that they never even attempt to 'cross' the river of suffering. The Buddha taught that the 'further shore' (Nibbana) requires leaving behind the 'safety' of the bank. It takes immense 'Appamāda' (heedfulness) to realize that the 'hither bank' is actually on fire. Those few who 'cross' are the 'Paṇḍitas' (wise ones) who have understood that the 'running' never ends unless you change the direction of your life. This story is a sobering reminder that spiritual life is not about 'waiting' on the bank, but about 'effort' (viriya) in crossing. It encourages us to be among the 'few' who build the raft of the Eightfold Path, rather than the 'many' who are still 'running' in circles when the flood finally arrives.

verses.pali:
Ye ca kho sammadakkhāte, dhamme dhammānuvattino;
Te janā pāramessanti, maccudheyyaṃ suduttaraṃ.
verses.translation: But those who act according to the well-taught Dhamma will cross the realm of Death, so difficult to cross.
verses.commentary: This verse provides the 'how' for Verse 85. The 'well-taught Dhamma' (sammadakkhāte dhamme) is the raft. Those who are 'dhammānuvattino' (practitioners who live according to the Dhamma) are the ones who 'pāramessanti' (will go to the further shore). The 'maccudheyyaṃ' (realm of Death/Mara) is described as 'suduttaraṃ'—exceedingly difficult to transcend without the Buddha's guidance.

story.title: The Story of the Shipwrecked Merchants
story.content: Five hundred merchants were once shipwrecked in the middle of a vast, shark-infested ocean. While most of them panicked or tried to swim back to the shore they could no longer see, a few of them remembered the 'well-taught Dhamma' (sammadakkhāte dhamme) they had heard from a wandering monk. They remained 'dhammānuvattino' (practitioners) by maintaining their mindfulness and chanting the virtues of the Buddha. Through their calm and collective effort, they were able to find a floating piece of wood and, guided by their 'right knowledge,' they eventually reached the 'further shore.' The Buddha explained that the ocean is like the 'realm of Death' (maccudheyyaṃ), which is 'suduttaraṃ' (extremely difficult to cross) because of the 'sharks' of lust and the 'storms' of anger. Only those who 'act according to the Teaching' have the 'buoyancy' needed to stay afloat. The Dhamma acts as the 'compass' and the 'raft.' Most people sink because they are weighed down by the 'iron' of their attachments. But those who follow the 'well-taught' path find that the 'impossible' crossing becomes possible. The story teaches that 'Death' is not just the end of life, but the state of being 'lost' in the ocean of Samsara. By 'acting according to the Dhamma,' we ensure that we are always moving toward the shore of safety, proving that the 'difficult' path is the only one that actually leads to an 'end' to the journey.

verses.pali:
Kaṇhaṃ dhammaṃ vippahāya, sukkaṃ bhāvetha paṇḍito;
Okā anokamāgamma, viveke yattha dūramaṃ.
verses.translation: Let the wise man leave the way of darkness and follow the way of light. Leaving his home for the homeless state, let him seek delight in solitude, which is so difficult to enjoy.
verses.commentary: 'Kaṇhaṃ' (dark/black) refers to unwholesome states; 'sukkaṃ' (bright/white) refers to wholesome states. The 'Paṇḍito' (wise man) moves from 'okā' (home/attachment) to 'anoka' (homelessness/detachment). He learns to find 'viveke' (solitude) to be a 'delight' (dūramaṃ), even though the worldly mind finds it 'difficult' and lonely.

story.title: The Story of Thera Mahā Kassapa’s Choice
story.content: Mahā Kassapa was born into a very wealthy family, but from a young age, he felt that his home was a 'way of darkness' (kaṇhaṃ dhammaṃ) because it was filled with the 'shadows' of greed and maintenance. He longed for the 'way of light' (sukkaṃ bhāvetha). Even after being forced into marriage, he and his wife agreed to live as celibates, and eventually, he 'left his home for the homeless state' (okā anokamāgamma). He went into the forest to 'seek delight in solitude' (viveke). Other people thought he was 'miserable' because he was 'lonely,' but Kassapa found that 'solitude' was 'difficult to enjoy' (dūramaṃ) only for those who still had 'internal noise.' Once his mind was quiet, the forest became a palace of 'light.' The Buddha praised him as the foremost in 'austere practices.' He explained that the 'wise man' understands that 'home' is not just a building, but the 'clinging' to one's identity and possessions. By moving into the 'anoka' (homeless) state, Kassapa had cleared away the 'darkness' of 'me and mine.' This story illustrates that the 'way of light' is the path of 'subtraction'—the less you have to 'protect,' the 'brighter' your mind becomes. Kassapa’s 'delight' in the solitude of the caves was a sign that he had found the 'internal sun' of wisdom, proving that the 'lonely' path is actually the most 'crowded' with peace and clarity.

verses.pali:
Tatrābhiratimiccheyya, hitvā kāme akiñcano;
Pariyodapeyya attānaṃ, cittaklesehi paṇḍito.
verses.translation: There let him seek delight, giving up all sensual pleasures, with no attachments. Let the wise man cleanse himself from the defilements of the mind.
verses.commentary: This continues the theme of Verse 87. The goal is to become 'akiñcano' (having nothing/no attachments). By 'hitvā kāme' (giving up sensual pleasures), the 'Paṇḍito' can 'pariyodapeyya' (thoroughly cleanse) the 'cittaklesehi' (defilements of the mind) such as lust, ill-will, and sloth. This 'cleansing' is the true purpose of 'solitude.'

story.title: The Story of the Five Hundred Monks and the Mirror
story.content: A group of five hundred monks were meditating in the forest but found their minds constantly drifting to 'sensual pleasures' (kāme) and their past 'attachments.' They were physically in 'solitude,' but their minds were 'dirty' with 'cittaklesehi' (defilements). The Buddha appeared to them and asked them to look at a 'mirror.' He explained that if a mirror is covered in dust, it cannot reflect anything. Similarly, a mind covered in 'klesas' cannot see the Dhamma. He urged them to 'seek delight' (abhiratimiccheyya) in the 'cleansing' (pariyodapeyya) process itself. He told them to become 'akiñcano'—to act as if they owned 'nothing,' not even their own thoughts. The monks realized that they had been 'holding on' to their memories while trying to 'let go' of the world. They began to 'thoroughly cleanse' their hearts by treating every thought of 'pleasure' as 'dust' on the mirror. As they became 'attachment-free,' they finally felt the 'delight' of a truly 'clean' mind. By the end of the discourse, all five hundred monks attained Arahatship. This story teaches that 'giving up pleasures' is not a 'sacrifice' but a 'purification.' When the 'dust' of desire is removed, the 'mirror' of the mind naturally reflects the light of Nibbana. The 'wise man' is simply one who understands that 'cleanliness' of the spirit is the only 'beauty' that matters, leading to a state where the mind is as 'transparent' and 'spotless' as a diamond.

verses.translation: Those whose minds are well-developed in the factors of enlightenment, who, without clinging, delight in the giving up of attachment, they, the shining ones, whose appetites are stilled, attain Nibbana even in this world.
verses.commentary: This is the 'Grand Finale' of Chapter 6. The 'shining ones' (jutimanto) are those who have developed the 'Seven Factors of Enlightenment' (sambodhiyaṅgesu). They have achieved 'ādānapaṭinissagge' (the giving up of the four types of clinging). Being 'khīṇāsavā' (those whose taints are exhausted), they are 'parinibbutā' (fully liberated) even while still living 'in this world' (loke).

story.title: The Story of the Final Liberation of the Elders
story.content: A group of elder monks, who had spent their entire lives practicing the 'Seven Factors of Enlightenment' (sambodhiyaṅgesu), reached their final days. They were 'jutimanto' (shining ones) because their 'sīla' and 'paññā' were so bright that they seemed to glow with an internal light. They 'delighted in the giving up of attachment' (anupādāya ye ratā), treating their very lives as something they were ready to 'give back' to nature. They had no 'clinging' (ādāna) to their bodies or their reputations. The Buddha praised them as 'Khīṇāsavā'—those whose 'appetites' for existence were 'stilled' and 'exhausted.' He explained that they had 'attained Nibbana even in this world' (te loke parinibbutā) because they were already living in a state of 'emptiness' and 'peace.' When they finally passed away, it was like a 'shining' light merging into the sun. This story represents the 'summit' of the 'Wise' chapter. The 'Wise Man' (Paṇḍita) starts by 'following a teacher who points out faults' (Verse 76) and ends by 'becoming a shining one' who is 'fully liberated' (Verse 89). It teaches that the path of wisdom is a complete 'un-folding' of the human potential. By 'well-developing' the mind in the enlightenment factors—mindfulness, investigation, energy, joy, tranquility, concentration, and equanimity—we move from being a 'disturbed worldling' to being a 'shining saint' who is 'cool' and 'extinguished' (parinibbutā) in the midst of a 'burning' world.

chapters.summary: This chapter details the qualities of Arahants—those who have achieved complete enlightenment and liberation from all suffering and attachments.

verses.pali:
Gataddhino visokassa, vippamuttassa sabbadhi;
Sabbaganthappahīnassa, pariḷāho na vijjati.
verses.translation: For him who has completed the journey, who is sorrowless, who is wholly free, and who has discarded all ties, there is no burning (of grief).
verses.commentary: 'Gataddhino' (one who has finished the journey) refers to the Arhat who has traveled the entire path of Samsara to its end. 'Sabbadhi' (in every way) indicates total freedom. 'Sabbaganthappahīnassa' means one who has untied the four knots of greed, ill-will, attachment to rituals, and dogmatism. For such a person, the 'pariḷāho' (burning/fever) of passion and suffering no longer exists.

story.title: The Story of Jīvaka Komārabhacca
story.content: Jīvaka was the most renowned physician of the Buddha's time. On one occasion, the Buddha was suffering from a stomach ailment caused by an imbalance of the humors. Jīvaka prepared a special medicinal oil and applied it skillfully, predicting that the Buddha would be fully recovered by the time the oil was absorbed. However, as the Buddha's health improved, Jīvaka began to worry that he might have over-medicated the Blessed One. Sensing Jīvaka's concern, the Buddha explained that for one who has 'completed the journey' (gataddhino), there is no longer any internal 'burning' or 'fever' caused by mental anxiety or physical grasping. The Buddha stated that an Arhat is 'wholly free' (vippamuttassa) from the emotional distress that usually accompanies illness or the fear of making a mistake. While the physician might worry about the outcome of a treatment, the Arhat remains 'sorrowless' (visokassa) because he has discarded all 'ties' (gantha) to the body and its conditions. The Buddha used Jīvaka's professional concern as a teaching moment to show that the ultimate health is the cessation of the 'fever' of craving. By attaining Nibbana, one becomes immune to the 'burning' of the world. Jīvaka, hearing this, understood that while he could heal the physical body, the Buddha had provided the cure for the soul. This story illustrates that the Arhat's peace is unshakeable, even in the face of physical ailment, because the 'fire' of the defilements has been permanently extinguished.

verses.pali:
Uyyuñjanti satimanto, na nikete ramanti te;
Hansāva pallalaṃ hitvā, okamokaṃ jahanti te.
verses.translation: The mindful exert themselves; they do not delight in an abode. Like swans that leave their lake, they abandon one home after another.
verses.commentary: 'Satimanto' (the mindful) are always 'uyyuñjanti' (exerting/striving) in their practice. They do not 'ramanti' (take delight) in 'nikete' (fixed abodes or attachments). The simile of the 'hansa' (swan) leaving a 'pallalaṃ' (small pond) highlights the Arhat's total lack of clinging to any place or state of being.

story.title: The Story of Mahā Kassapa Thera
story.content: Venerable Mahā Kassapa was famous for his austere lifestyle, living only in the forest, wearing robes made of rags, and accepting alms from anyone regardless of their status. Once, when the Buddha and his disciples were staying in a well-appointed monastery offered by a wealthy donor, Mahā Kassapa chose to stay in a distant, simple cave. Some younger monks wondered why such a senior elder would avoid the comfort and companionship of the main monastery. The Buddha explained that Mahā Kassapa was among the 'mindful' (satimanto) who 'do not delight in an abode' (na nikete ramanti). For an Arhat, a palace and a cave are of equal value because their 'home' is the Dhamma, not a physical building. The Buddha compared Mahā Kassapa to a 'swan' (hansa) that visits a pond to feed but never stays there permanently; as soon as the need is met, the swan flies away without looking back. Similarly, the Arhats 'abandon one home after another' (okamokaṃ jahanti), meaning they have no psychological 'nest' in the world of appearances. They are travelers of the spirit who recognize that any 'abode' in Samsara is merely a temporary stopping point. This story emphasizes that the Arhat's freedom is found in his mobility of mind. By refusing to 'settle down' in comfort or reputation, he remains 'wide awake' and ready to move wherever the Dhamma requires. Mahā Kassapa’s life was a living example of 'exertion'—not the exertion of a worker, but the effortless exertion of a being who is always mindful and never tethered.

verses.translation: Those who have no accumulation, who have understood the nature of food, and whose range is the empty and the signless liberation—their path is difficult to track, like that of birds in the sky.
verses.commentary: 'Sannicayo' (accumulation) refers to both material possessions and karmic deposits. 'Pariññātabhojanā' means they understand food as mere support for the body, not a source of pleasure. Their mental 'range' (gocaro) is 'Suññato' (Emptiness) and 'Animitto' (Signlessness). Like birds leaving no footprints in the 'ākāse' (sky), the Arhat leaves no 'gati' (trace/path) for rebirth.

story.title: The Story of Belaṭṭhasīsa Thera
story.content: Thera Belaṭṭhasīsa had a habit of drying his leftover alms-food so that he wouldn't have to go on alms-round every day, allowing him more time for meditation. When other monks saw this, they accused him of 'accumulation' (sannicayo), which was against the monastic rules. The Buddha, however, defended him, explaining that Belaṭṭhasīsa had 'no accumulation' in his heart. While he kept physical food for convenience, his mind was 'wholly free' from craving it. He was 'pariññātabhojanā'—he understood food as medicine for the body and nothing more. The Buddha explained that the Arhat's mind dwells in 'Emptiness' (Suññato) and 'Signlessness' (Animitto), meaning they do not identify with the 'signs' of the world. Because they have no 'clinging,' their 'path' is 'difficult to track' (durannayā). Just as a bird flies through the air leaving no footprints, an Arhat performs actions without creating the 'tracks' of kamma that lead to rebirth. The 'signless liberation' means they are no longer fooled by the outward appearances of things. Belaṭṭhasīsa’s simple act of drying food was an external behavior that had no internal 'stain' of greed. This story teaches that the true 'poverty' of the Arhat is not the absence of objects, but the absence of the 'owner' within. By dwelling in the 'sky' of liberation, the Arhat becomes untraceable by the forces of death and desire, proving that the ultimate freedom is to be 'no one' going 'nowhere' in particular.

verses.translation: He whose taints are exhausted, who is not attached to food, and whose range is the empty and the signless liberation—his path is difficult to track, like that of birds in the sky.
verses.commentary: A twin to Verse 92. 'Asavā parikkhīṇā' (taints exhausted) specifically refers to the four cankers: sensuality, existence, views, and ignorance. 'Anissito' means being independent or not leaning on food or any worldly support. The 'padaṃ' (footprint/track) is 'durannayaṃ' (hard to follow) because there is no 'I' remaining to leave a mark.

story.title: The Story of Thera Anuruddha
story.content: Anuruddha was a cousin of the Buddha and a master of the 'divine eye.' Even after becoming an Arhat, he lived with extreme simplicity. Once, while seeking cloth for a new robe, he found some discarded rags in a rubbish heap. A goddess who had been his relative in a past life tried to 'help' him by hiding fine celestial cloth among the rags. Anuruddha found the cloth and used it, but his mind remained 'independent' (anissito) and 'not attached' to the quality of the material. When the other monks saw the beautiful cloth, they wondered how a forest monk could acquire such fine things. The Buddha explained that Anuruddha’s 'taints were exhausted' (āsavā parikkhīṇā). Whether he wore rags or celestial silk, his mind was fixed on the 'signless liberation' (animitto vimokkho). He was like a bird in the sky (ākāse va sakuṇtānaṃ), moving through the world without leaving the 'footprint' (padaṃ) of greed. The Buddha taught that the Arhat's 'range' (gocaro) is Emptiness, meaning they see the void nature of all possessions. Anuruddha’s 'path' was 'difficult to track' because he had no personal agenda; he was simply responding to the needs of the moment without any 'canker' of self-interest. This story highlights that the Arhat is the only truly 'independent' being in the universe. While others are 'attached' to their status and possessions, the Arhat 'leans on nothing' (anissito), making him invincible to the changes of fortune and invisible to the 'tracking' of Mara.

verses.pali:
Indriyāni samathaṃ gatāni, assā yathā sārathinā sudantā;
Pahīnamānassa anāsavassa, devāpi tassa piha-yanti tādiso.
verses.translation: He whose senses are calmed, like horses well-tamed by a charioteer, who is free from pride and taints—even the gods hold such a person dear.
verses.commentary: The 'indriyāni' (senses) of an Arhat are 'samathaṃ gatāni' (perfectly calmed). The simile of the 'sārathinā' (charioteer) and 'sudantā' (well-tamed horses) illustrates the mastery over internal impulses. 'Pahīnamānassa' (pride abandoned) and 'anāsavassa' (taintless) make the Arhat so pure that even 'devāpi' (the gods) envy or admire (pihayanti) them.

story.title: The Story of Mahā Kaccāyana Thera
story.content: Venerable Mahā Kaccāyana was renowned for his ability to explain the Buddha's brief teachings in great detail. He was also a man of great physical beauty and serene presence. Once, while the monks were gathered for the rainy season, a god named Sakka, the King of the Devas, descended to earth specifically to pay homage to Kaccāyana. Sakka was impressed by how Kaccāyana’s 'senses were calmed' (indriyāni samathaṃ gatāni). Even in a crowded monastery, Kaccāyana remained as still and focused as 'horses well-tamed by a charioteer' (assā yathā sārathinā sudantā). He had 'abandoned all pride' (pahīnamānassa) and was 'free from taints' (anāsavassa). The other monks were surprised to see the King of the Devas kneeling before a human monk. The Buddha explained that there is no one more 'dear' (pihayanti) to the gods than a human who has conquered their own nature. A person who can control their senses is rarer and more powerful than any celestial being. The Buddha taught that the Arhat's 'taming' is a spiritual achievement that transcends the heavens. While gods still have traces of pride and desire, the Arhat is completely 'stainless.' Therefore, the gods look to the Arhat as a teacher and a refuge. This story illustrates that true 'glory' is not found in celestial status, but in the 'calming' of the internal fires. By becoming a master of his own 'chariot' (the mind and senses), Kaccāyana became a being so sublime that the very rulers of the heavens felt honored to be in his presence.

verses.pali:
Paṭhavisamo no virujjhati, indakhīlūpamo tādi subbato;
Rahadova apetakaddamo, saṃsārā na bhavanti tādiso.
verses.translation: Like the earth, he is not provoked; like a pillar of Indra, he is firm; like a lake free from mud, he is pure. For such a person, there is no more wandering in Samsara.
verses.commentary: Three similes describe the Arhat's stability: 'Paṭhavisamo' (like the earth) which accepts both filth and perfume without reacting; 'indakhīlūpamo' (like an Indra-pillar) which is deeply embedded and immovable; and 'rahadova apetakaddamo' (like a mud-free lake) which is perfectly clear. 'Samsara' (wandering) ceases because there is no 'reaction' left to fuel the cycle.

story.title: The Story of Thera Sāriputta’s Patience
story.content: A certain Brahmin, hearing of Sāriputta’s legendary patience, decided to test him. He walked up to Sāriputta and struck him hard from behind. Sāriputta did not even turn around with anger; he simply continued walking, checking to see if he had dropped anything. He was 'like the earth' (paṭhavisamo)—he accepted the blow without 'provocation' (no virujjhati), just as the earth accepts both rain and refuse. The Brahmin was so overwhelmed by Sāriputta’s 'firmness' (indakhīlūpamo) that he fell at his feet and asked for forgiveness. Sāriputta invited the Brahmin to his meal, showing that his mind was as 'pure as a lake free from mud' (rahadova apetakaddamo). The Buddha, hearing of this, explained that an Arhat is 'tādi'—one who remains 'such' or 'the same' regardless of treatment. Because Sāriputta had no 'I' to be offended, there was no 'karmic friction' created by the incident. For such a 'steady' person, the 'wandering in Samsara' (saṃsārā na bhavanti) has come to an end. The cycle of birth and death is fueled by the 'reactions' of greed and hatred; since Sāriputta was incapable of reacting with hate, he had no more 'fuel' for future existence. This story illustrates that the Arhat's 'purity' is not a fragile thing that must be protected, but a 'mountain-like' stability that cannot be disturbed by the petty actions of the world. By being like the earth, the Arhat becomes the ultimate foundation of peace.

verses.pali:
Santaṃ tassa manaṃ hoti, santā vācā ca kamma ca;
Sammadaññā vimuttassa, upasantassa tādiso.
verses.translation: His mind is calm, his speech is calm, and his deed is calm; thus, the one who is liberated by right knowledge is perfectly at peace.
verses.commentary: The Arhat's 'manaṃ' (mind), 'vācā' (speech), and 'kamma' (deeds) are all 'santaṃ' (calm/peaceful). This is not a forced calmness but a natural state of 'upasantassa' (perfect peace) that comes from being 'sammadaññā vimuttassa'—liberated through the direct, correct knowledge of reality.

story.title: The Story of the Novice Tissa of Kosambi
story.content: A young novice named Tissa was staying in a monastery where a senior monk was extremely irritable. One night, while Tissa was fanning the senior monk, the monk accidentally struck Tissa with the fan. Tissa did not get angry; instead, he apologized for being in the way. Throughout the interaction, Tissa’s 'speech' and 'deeds' remained 'calm' (santā vācā ca kamma ca). The senior monk, realizing his own lack of control, became even more agitated, but Tissa’s 'mind' remained 'calm' (santaṃ tassa manaṃ). The Buddha explained that Tissa was 'liberated by right knowledge' (sammadaññā vimuttassa). Even though he was just a young novice, his internal 'peace' was 'perfect' (upasantassa) because he understood the nature of suffering and the non-self. He didn't have to 'try' to be calm; his calmness was the outward expression of his internal liberation. The Buddha taught that a 'perfectly at peace' person is the same 'inwardly and outwardly.' While most people 'perform' calmness while their minds are boiling with resentment, the Arhat is 'cool' through and through. Tissa’s behavior was a 'sign' of his Arhatship. This story illustrates that true 'Right Knowledge' manifests as a profound, effortless 'tranquility' in the face of provocation. The 'calmness' of the Arhat is his most powerful teaching, showing the world that it is possible to be 'unshakable' even in a world of constant friction and misunderstanding.

verses.pali:
Assaddho akataññū ca, sandhicchedo ca yo naro;
Hatāvakāso vantāso, sa ve uttamaporiso.
verses.translation: The man who is not credulous, who knows the Unconditioned, who has severed all ties, who has destroyed all opportunities (for rebirth), and who has given up all desires—he, indeed, is the supreme man.
verses.commentary: This verse uses 'puns' on words usually considered negative. 'Assaddho' (not credulous/faithless) here means one who knows by direct experience, not by 'faith' in others. 'Akataññū' (ungrateful/knower of the unmade) means one who knows the 'Unconditioned' (Nibbana). 'Sandhicchedo' (house-breaker) means one who has 'severed' the links of rebirth. Such a 'vantāso' (desire-vomiter) is the 'uttamaporiso' (supreme man).

story.title: The Story of Thera Sāriputta’s Realization
story.content: A group of monks once overheard Sāriputta saying that he no longer had 'faith' in the Buddha’s teachings. Shocked, they reported him to the Buddha for being 'faithless' (assaddho). The Buddha called Sāriputta and asked him to explain. Sāriputta clarified that he was 'assaddho' because he no longer needed 'faith'—he had 'direct knowledge' of the truth. He was 'akataññū' because he had realized the 'Unmade' (the Unconditioned Nibbana). He was a 'house-breaker' (sandhicchedo) because he had broken the 'house' of the five aggregates that led to rebirth. He had 'destroyed all opportunities' (hatāvakāso) for the defilements to take root and had 'vomited all desires' (vantāso). The Buddha praised this explanation, telling the other monks that Sāriputta was the 'supreme man' (uttamaporiso). He used these provocative terms to show that the Arhat has transcended even the 'virtues' of the beginner. While the beginner needs 'faith' to start, the Arhat has 'realization.' While the beginner seeks 'merit' (the conditioned), the Arhat seeks the 'Unconditioned.' This story is a masterclass in the 'language of liberation.' It teaches that the Arhat is 'supreme' because he has 'nothing left to do' and 'nowhere left to go.' He is a 'traitor' to the world of Samsara because he has 'broken the links' of the chain. By redefining these words, the Buddha showed that the Arhat's state is beyond conventional morality and conventional categories, standing as the ultimate 'individual' who has found the ultimate 'freedom.'

verses.pali:
Gāme vā yadi vāraññe, ninne vā yadi vā thale;
Yattha arahanto viharanti, taṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṃ.
verses.translation: Whether in the village or in the forest, in the valley or on the hill, wherever the Arhats dwell—delightful, indeed, is that place.
verses.commentary: 'Gāme' (village), 'araññe' (forest), 'ninne' (lowland/valley), or 'thale' (highland/hill)—these are merely physical locations. The 'delightfulness' (rāmaṇeyyakaṃ) of a 'bhūmi' (place) is not in its scenery, but in the 'presence' of those who are 'Arahanto.' The purity of the inhabitant transforms the environment.

story.title: The Story of Khadiravaniya Revata Thera
story.content: Revata, the younger brother of Sāriputta, chose to live in an extremely remote forest of 'Khadira' (acacia) trees, which was considered a harsh and 'unpleasant' place. When Sāriputta and other monks went to visit him, they found that the 'unpleasant' forest felt like a 'delightful' paradise. Some monks wondered if the 'scenery' had changed. The Buddha explained that the beauty of the place did not come from the trees or the valley, but from the 'Arahant' (Revata) who dwelt there. He taught that 'wherever the Arhats dwell' (yattha arahanto viharanti), that 'ground is delightful' (taṃ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṃ). Whether it is a 'village' (gāme) or a 'forest' (araññe), the Arhat's mind is a 'garden of peace' that radiates outward. The Arhat doesn't need 'beautiful' places to be happy; rather, his presence makes any place 'beautiful.' The 'delight' mentioned is not a sensory delight but a spiritual atmosphere of 'calm' and 'purity.' Revata's harsh acacia forest became 'rāmaṇeyyakaṃ' because his heart was free from the 'thorns' of greed and hate. This story teaches that we should focus on 'purifying' ourselves rather than 'improving' our surroundings. A beautiful house filled with angry people is a 'hell,' while a simple cave inhabited by an Arhat is a 'heaven.' The Arhat is the ultimate 'interior designer'—by transforming his inner world, he makes the outer world a 'place of delight' for everyone who visits him.

verses.pali:
Ramaṇīyāni araññāni, yattha na rammati jano;
Vītarāgā ramessanti, na te kāmagavesino.
verses.translation: Delightful are the forests where worldlings find no pleasure. There the passionless will find delight, for they seek no sensual pleasures.
verses.commentary: The 'forest' (araññāni) is 'ramaṇīyāni' (delightful) only to the 'vītarāgā' (passionless ones). The 'jano' (worldlings/ordinary people) find 'no pleasure' (na rammati) there because there are no 'sensual pleasures' (kāma) to be 'found' (gavesino). The Arhat's delight is in 'detachment,' whereas the worldling's delight is in 'attachment.'

story.title: The Story of the Monk in the Lonely Forest
story.content: A certain monk was living deep in the forest and was being mocked by some worldly people who thought he was 'miserable' because he had no entertainment, no company, and no comforts. They said, 'How can anyone find pleasure in such a lonely place?' The monk remained silent and peaceful. The Buddha, knowing the situation, explained that 'delightful are the forests' (ramaṇīyāni araññāni) to those who have 'stilled' their desires. For a 'worldling' (jano), a forest is a 'boring' place because there is nothing to 'gavesino' (seek/chase)—no shows, no fine food, no praise. But the 'passionless' (vītarāgā) find 'delight' (ramessanti) in that very 'emptiness.' Their 'pleasure' is the absence of 'pressure.' The Buddha taught that true 'delight' is not found in 'getting' what you want, but in 'not wanting' anything at all. The forest provides the perfect 'mirror' for a mind that is 'free from passion.' While the worldling feels 'lonely' in the forest, the Arhat feels 'free.' This story illustrates the radical 'reversal' of values in the spiritual path. What the world calls 'pleasure' (sensual chase), the Arhat calls 'pain.' What the world calls 'pain' (solitude/quiet), the Arhat calls 'supreme delight.' By seeking nothing, the Arhat finds everything in the 'delightful forests' of his own quietude, proving that the 'highest happiness' is not a 'thing' you find, but a 'state' of being 'without search.'

chapters.summary: This chapter emphasizes quality over quantity in spiritual practice, showing that one meaningful word, verse, or moment of understanding is worth more than thousands of meaningless ones. It also teaches that self-conquest is the greatest victory and that honoring the virtuous brings great blessings.

verses.pali:
Sahassampi ce vācā, anatthapadasaṃhitā;
Ekaṃ atthapadaṃ seyyo, yaṃ sutvā upasammati.
verses.translation: Better than a thousand words that are senseless and unconnected is one sensible word, hearing which one becomes peaceful.
verses.commentary: 'Sahassampi' (even a thousand) 'vācā' (words) are useless if they are 'anatthapada' (meaningless/unbeneficial). The Buddha defines 'seyyo' (better) as a single 'atthapada' (meaningful word) because its result is 'upasammati'—the stilling of the mind and the calming of defilements.

story.title: The Story of Tambadāṭhika the Executioner
story.content: Tambadāṭhika served as the public executioner for fifty-five years. Upon his retirement, he met the Venerable Sāriputta and offered him alms. However, Tambadāṭhika’s mind was heavily burdened with 'anatthapada'—the senseless, noisy memories of the thousands of criminals he had executed. He was so distracted by guilt that he could not focus on the Dhamma. Sāriputta, seeing his distress, used a skillful means by asking him, 'Did you kill those people out of your own malice, or because the King ordered you?' Tambadāṭhika realized he was just an instrument of the law, and his mind suddenly became calm. Sāriputta then taught him the Dhamma using simple, 'sensible words' (atthapada). While a thousand epic poems might have provided entertainment, it was that one meaningful discourse that allowed Tambadāṭhika to attain a high degree of spiritual calm (upasammati). He died shortly after and was reborn in the Tusita heaven. The Buddha explained to the monks that the length of a speech does not determine its power. For someone like Tambadāṭhika, who had lived a life of violence, a thousand lectures on worldly history would have been useless. It was the 'one word' that pointed toward peace that saved him. This story illustrates that the Dhamma is a targeted medicine; its goal is not to fill the head with 'thousands of words,' but to reach the heart and extinguish the fire of remorse. One sentence of truth is more 'fruitful' than a library of trivialities because it has the power to transform a destiny.

verses.pali:
Sahassampi ce gāthā, anatthapadasaṃhitā;
Ekaṃ gāthāpadaṃ seyyo, yaṃ sutvā upasammati.
verses.translation: Better than a thousand verses that are senseless and unconnected is one verse, hearing which one becomes peaceful.
verses.commentary: Similar to the previous verse, but specifically addressing 'gāthā' (verses or poems). In the Buddha's time, many sought fame through complex poetry. The Buddha taught that a single line of poetry that inspires 'upasammati' (tranquility) is superior to a thousand 'empty' verses.

story.title: The Story of Bāhiya Dārucīriya
story.content: Bāhiya was a man who lived as a false ascetic, wearing bark clothing (dāru-cīra) and believing he was an Arhat because of his physical austerities. A former relative who had become a Deva corrected him and told him to seek out the Buddha. Bāhiya traveled a vast distance in a single night to find the Buddha in Sāvatthi. He was so urgent that he approached the Buddha while he was on his alms-round. He begged for a teaching, but the Buddha twice refused, saying it was an inappropriate time. When Bāhiya pleaded for the third time, stating that life is uncertain, the Buddha gave him an incredibly brief 'verse-like' teaching: 'In the seen, let there be only the seen; in the heard, only the heard...' Upon hearing this 'one verse' (ekaṃ gāthāpadaṃ), Bāhiya’s mind, which was already highly refined by years of asceticism, completely let go of all clinging and he attained Arahatship instantly. He was killed by a stray cow shortly after. The Buddha explained that Bāhiya didn't need a thousand 'unconnected' verses or long hours of study. His years of false asceticism were like 'thousands of senseless words,' but the Buddha's brief instruction was the 'one verse' that led to total peace (upasammati). This story teaches that when the mind is ready, a single 'seed' of truth can bloom into full enlightenment. The 'thousand verses' of others are merely distractions compared to the 'one verse' that addresses the core of human perception and suffering.

verses.pali:
Yo ca gāthāsataṃ bhāse, anatthapadasaṃhitā;
Ekaṃ dhammapadaṃ seyyo, yaṃ sutvā upasammati.
verses.translation: Better than reciting a hundred verses of senseless words is one line of the Dhamma, hearing which one becomes peaceful.
verses.commentary: The Buddha contrasts 'gāthāsataṃ' (a hundred verses) with 'ekaṃ dhammapadaṃ' (one word/line of the Teaching). While a hundred verses might offer intellectual stimulation or entertainment, they are 'anatthapada' (senseless/unprofitable) if they do not lead to 'upasammati'—the stilling of the mind.

story.title: The Story of the Nun Kuṇḍalakesī
story.content: Kuṇḍalakesī was once a beautiful girl who fell in love with a thief and saved him from execution. However, the thief later tried to kill her for her jewelry. Using her presence of mind, she pushed him off a cliff first. Distraught by her life, she became a wandering ascetic, traveling across India and challenging anyone to a debate. She could recite 'a hundred verses' (gāthāsataṃ) of complex philosophy and was proud of her intellectual prowess. One day, she encountered Venerable Sāriputta. She asked him a hundred questions, all of which he answered easily. When he asked her a single question about the nature of 'The One,' she was silenced. Sāriputta then taught her 'one line of the Dhamma' (ekaṃ dhammapadaṃ) regarding the Four Noble Truths. While her 'hundred verses' had only led to pride and restlessness, this one meaningful teaching led to her total 'peace' (upasammati). She became a nun and attained Arahatship. The Buddha praised her, saying that her long years of reciting senseless philosophy were worthless compared to the one moment she heard the truth. This story teaches that the value of spiritual study is not in the volume of texts memorized, but in the power of the words to bring the heart to silence. One true word, correctly understood, is the only bridge to the further shore.

verses.pali:
Yo sahas saṃ sahas sena, saṅgāme mānuse jine;
Ekañca jeyyamattānaṃ, sa ve saṅgāmajuttamo.
verses.translation: Though one may conquer a thousand times a thousand men in battle, yet he indeed is the noblest victor who conquers himself.
verses.commentary: 'Saṅgāme' (in battle) refers to external warfare. 'Sahas saṃ sahas sena' (a million) signifies the greatest possible worldly victory. Yet, the Buddha declares that 'jeyyamattānaṃ' (conquering oneself) is 'saṅgāmajuttamo'—the ultimate victory—because an external enemy can return, but a conquered 'self' (internal defilements) never rises again.

story.title: The Story of the Girl and the Performance
story.content: A certain young girl, the daughter of a famous dancer, was performing at a festival where the King was present. Many people were 'conquered' by her beauty and skill. However, a young man who was a follower of the Buddha watched the performance and felt no lust. He had 'conquered himself' (jeyyamattānaṃ) through the practice of mindfulness of the body. While the King and his soldiers could 'conquer a thousand men in battle,' they were still slaves to their own sensory desires. The Buddha used this occasion to teach that the true 'noblest victor' (saṅgāmajuttamo) is not the one who stands on a pile of corpses, but the one who stands over his own defeated ego. He explained that external conquest only creates more 'enemies' and 'hatred,' leading to further 'battles' in the future. But the conquest of one's own greed, hatred, and delusion is a final victory. It does not require weapons, but it requires a 'strength' far greater than that of a million soldiers. The young man's ability to remain unmoved by the 'arrows' of desire was a sign of his 'superior victory.' This story emphasizes that we are our own greatest opponents. The 'thousand times a thousand men' are mere reflections of our own externalized conflicts; only by ending the war within can we achieve a peace that is truly 'ultimate.' The 'noblest victor' is the one who has turned his 'sword' of wisdom inward to cut the bonds of attachment, finding a kingdom of peace that no external army can ever invade.

verses.pali:
Attā have jitaṃ seyyo, yā cāyaṃ itarā pajā;
Datassa yatassa jantuno, niccaṃ saṃyatacārino.
verses.translation: Self-conquest is indeed far better than the conquest of all other people; it is the victory of a man who is self-controlled and ever-restrained.
verses.commentary: This verse reinforces Verse 103. 'Attā have jitaṃ' (self-conquest) is 'seyyo' (better) because the 'itarā pajā' (other people) are external and temporary. The victory belongs to the 'saṃyatacārino'—one who walks in constant restraint of the senses and thoughts.

story.title: The Story of the Brahmin Anatthapucchaka
story.content: A Brahmin named Anatthapucchaka asked the Buddha if there was any loss greater than the loss of wealth or the death of a relative. The Buddha replied that the greatest loss is the loss of 'self-control' (saṃyama). He explained that even if a man 'conquers all other people' (yā cāyaṃ itarā pajā), he is still a 'loser' if he cannot conquer his own anger or greed. The Buddha described the 'self-conquered' man as one who is 'ever-restrained' (niccaṃ saṃyatacārino). Such a man does not react to insults or praise; he is the master of his own internal environment. While 'other people' can be unpredictable and difficult to 'conquer,' the 'self' is the one territory we have direct access to. The Brahmin realized that he had spent his life worrying about external 'losses' while ignoring the 'decay' of his own character. The Buddha taught that 'self-conquest' is better because it is the only victory that cannot be taken away by time or death. The 'controlled man' is like a king who rules his own impulses, making him richer than any monarch who 'conquers' others but is a slave to his own temper. This story encourages the seeker to shift their competitive energy inward. Instead of trying to be 'better' than others, the goal is to be 'better' than one's own past defilements. The 'supreme victory' is not won on the stage of the world, but in the silence of one's own 'self-restraint,' where every 'subjugated' desire is a step toward true sovereignty.

verses.pali:
Na ve jitaṃ apajitaṃ, taṃ kayirā maghavā sahampati;
Neva gandhabbo na māro, brahunā saddhiṃ pajāpatinā.
verses.translation: Neither a god, nor a Gandhabba, nor Mara with Brahma, can turn into defeat the victory of such a person (who has conquered himself).
verses.commentary: Worldly victories can be reversed by a stronger army or the passage of time. However, the victory of 'self-conquest' is absolute. Not even the highest beings in the universe—Maghavā (Sakka), the 'Gandhabbas' (celestial musicians), 'Māra' (the Tempter), or 'Brahma'—have the power to 'turn into defeat' (apajitaṃ) the liberation of an Arhat.

story.title: The Story of the Brahmin Anatthapucchaka (Conclusion)
story.content: Continuing from the discussion on self-conquest, the Brahmin asked the Buddha if a person who tames his mind is still vulnerable to the gods or the forces of nature. The Buddha explained that once a person has 'conquered himself,' his victory is safe from any external interference. He used the most powerful beings as examples: Sakka (Maghava), the king of gods; the Gandhabbas, who control the realms of beauty; Mara, who controls the realm of death; and even Brahma, the creator. None of these beings can 'undo' the enlightenment of an Arhat. This is because these gods are still within the 'conditioned' realm, while the Arhat has reached the 'Unconditioned' (Nibbana). You cannot 'defeat' someone who no longer identifies with anything that can be lost. The Arhat's victory is an 'internal' state of being that exists outside the reach of the 'Eight Worldly Winds' (praise, blame, gain, loss, etc.). This story emphasizes that the highest security in the universe is the mastery of one's own impulses. While worldlings live in constant fear that their 'victories' will be taken away by others or by fate, the practitioner who has tamed his mind holds a 'conquest' that is literally out of this world. It encourages us to strive for the only form of success that is permanent and invulnerable to even the highest celestial powers.

verses.translation: Though for a hundred years one should offer sacrifices by the thousands month after month, yet if for even a moment one should worship a self-developed person, that worship is better than a hundred years of sacrifice.
verses.commentary: Ritual sacrifice ('hutaṃ'/'yajetha') was the standard of merit in ancient India. The Buddha declares that 'muhuttamapi' (even for a moment) spent honoring a 'bhāvitattānaṃ' (a self-developed/enlightened person) is 'seyyo' (better). It highlights that the merit from honoring 'wisdom' exceeds the merit from 'rituals' (hundreds of thousands of sacrifices).

story.title: The Story of Thera Sāriputta's Uncle
story.content: The uncle of Venerable Sāriputta was a Brahmin who spent an enormous amount of money every month 'offering sacrifices by the thousands' (māse māse sahas sena) in the hope of being reborn in the Brahma world. He had done this for 'a hundred years' (sataṃ samaṃ), believing that the volume of his offerings would guarantee his success. Sāriputta, realizing his uncle was wasting his effort on 'rituals' without 'understanding,' took him to see the Buddha. The Buddha explained that all those 'sacrifices' were like trying to fill a bucket with a hole in it. He taught that 'worshipping a self-developed person' (ekañca bhāvitattānaṃ pūjaye)—someone who has actually purified their mind—is far superior. He explained that 'even for a moment' (muhuttamapi) of such 'pūjā' generates more wholesome kamma than 'a hundred years of fire-offerings' (vassasataṃ hutaṃ). This is because the 'self-developed' person is a 'field of merit' (puññakkhetta) that multiplies the intention of the giver. The uncle, realizing that he had been focusing on the 'quantity' of wood and butter rather than the 'quality' of his heart, began to honor the Buddha and the Sangha. This story teaches that 'blind ritual' is 'asāra' (unessential). The true 'altar' is the mind, and the true 'sacrifice' is the honoring of wisdom. By shifting his focus from 'external fires' to the 'internal light' of an enlightened person, the old Brahmin found a shortcut to the peace he had been seeking for a century.

verses.translation: Though for a hundred years one should tend the sacrificial fire in the forest, yet if for even a moment one should worship a self-developed person, that worship is better than a hundred years of sacrifice.
verses.commentary: This verse critiques the Vedic tradition of 'aggiṃ paricare' (tending the fire). For the Buddha, the 'internal fire' of a 'bhāvitattānaṃ' (self-developed/Arhat) is the only fire worthy of honor. The merit of 'muhuttamapi' (one moment) of such worship exceeds 'vassasataṃ' (a century) of literal fire-worship.

story.title: The Story of Sāriputta's Nephew
story.content: Sāriputta's nephew followed the footsteps of his elders by becoming a forest ascetic. He spent his life 'tending the sacrificial fire in the forest' (aggiṃ paricare vane), believing that this ritual would lead him to the Brahma world. He did this for 'a hundred years' (vassasataṃ), living a life of extreme hardship and discipline. Sāriputta visited him and realized that his nephew was stuck in a ritualistic 'husk.' He took him to the Buddha. The Buddha explained that 'rituals' are based on the 'belief' in a permanent self that needs to be rewarded. In contrast, 'worshipping a self-developed person' (ekañca bhāvitattānaṃ pūjaye) is an act of honoring the 'absence' of self—the very state that leads to liberation. He taught that one moment of truly seeing an Arhat's virtue is 'better' (seyyo) than a century of 'hutaṃ' (sacrifice) because it points the mind toward the truth of Nibbana. The nephew realized that he had been trying to 'buy' his way into heaven through fire, while the 'light' was actually within a purified mind. He stopped his fire-rituals and became a disciple of the Buddha, eventually attaining Arahatship himself. This story teaches that we should not mistake 'hardship' for 'holiness.' Ten thousand hours of 'doing' a ritual is nothing compared to one second of 'seeing' the truth in a living example of wisdom.

verses.pali:
Yaṃ kiñci yiṭṭhaṃ va hutaṃ va loke, saṃvaccharaṃ yajetha puññapekkho;
Sabbampi taṃ na catubhāgameti, abhivādanā ujjugatesu seyyo.
verses.translation: Whatever offering or sacrifice a person may make in the world for a whole year to gain merit, all that is not worth a fourth part of the honor paid to the upright.
verses.commentary: 'Yiṭṭhaṃ' (offering) and 'hutaṃ' (sacrifice) done for 'puññapekkho' (desire for merit) are seen as inferior. The Buddha asserts that they do not reach 'catubhāga' (a fourth part) of the value of 'abhivādanā' (paying homage) to the 'ujjugatesu' (the upright/straight-minded).

story.title: The Story of Sāriputta's Friend
story.content: Sāriputta had a Brahmin friend who was incredibly generous; he spent an entire 'year' (saṃvaccharaṃ) giving away vast amounts of wealth in elaborate 'sacrifices' (yajetha), hoping to accumulate 'merit' (puñña). He believed that the more he gave, the 'higher' his spiritual status would be. The Buddha taught that while generosity is good, 'merit-seeking' is still a form of greed for the future. He explained that a person who 'pays homage' (abhivādanā) to an 'upright person' (ujjugatesu)—someone whose mind is 'straight' and free from defilements—is doing something far more 'fruitful.' This is because paying honor to the 'upright' is a way of 'straightening' one's own mind. The Brahmin's year of giving was 'not worth a fourth part' (na catubhāgameti) because his heart was still 'crooked' with the hope of a reward. But in the presence of an Arhat, one's ego is naturally humbled. The Buddha taught that the best 'offering' is the surrender of pride. The merchant friend changed his approach, focusing on honoring the 'upright' and practicing the Dhamma himself. He realized that 'buying merit' is like painting a rotten house; it looks good for a year, but it doesn't stop the rot. But 'honoring the wise' is like fixing the foundation. This story reminds us that the value of an action is in the 'direction' of the mind, not the 'amount' of the gift.

verses.pali:
Abhivādanasīlissa, niccaṃ vuḍḍhāpacāyino;
Cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti, āyu vaṇṇo sukhaṃ balaṃ.
verses.translation: For one who is respectful and ever honors the elders, four things increase: life, beauty, happiness, and strength.
verses.commentary: This verse explains the 'natural laws' of merit. 'Abhivādanasīlissa' (one of respectful habit) and 'vuḍḍhāpacāyino' (honoring the elders) creates a wholesome 'Vipaka' (result). The 'cattāro dhammā' (four things)—'āyu' (longevity), 'vaṇṇo' (beauty/complexion), 'sukhaṃ' (happiness), and 'balaṃ' (health/strength)—are the automatic byproducts of a humble heart.

story.title: The Story of Āyuvaḍḍhanakumāra
story.content: A Brahmin couple had a son whose horoscope predicted he would die at the age of seven. Desperate, they sought the Buddha’s help. The Buddha instructed the parents and their son to remain 'respectful' (abhivādanasīlissa) and to 'honor the elders'—specifically the monks—with sincerity. He had the monks chant the Paritta (protection) verses for seven days. When the 'End-of-Life' demon (the Yakkha) came to take the child, he could not approach because of the 'aura' of merit and respect surrounding the boy. The child lived to be 120 years old and was named Āyuvaḍḍhanakumāra (The Boy Whose Life-Span Increased). The Buddha explained that 'respect' is a powerful protective force. It 'softens' the heart and attracts 'wholesome energies' from the environment. For the one who 'honors the elders' (vuḍḍhāpacāyino), the 'four things' (āyu, vaṇṇo, sukhaṃ, balaṃ) 'increase' (vaḍḍhanti) because humility removes the 'stress' of the ego, allowing the life-force to flourish. This story is often cited in Buddhist cultures to emphasize the importance of filial piety and respect for wisdom. It teaches that our 'luck' or 'lifespan' is not entirely fixed; it is a dynamic field that can be 'expanded' through the simple, daily practice of being 'humble' and 'respectful' to those who have traveled the path before us.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve, dussīlo asamāhito;
Ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo, sīlavantassa jhāyino.
verses.translation: Better than a hundred years lived immorally and with an uncontrolled mind is a single day lived by one who is virtuous and meditative.
verses.commentary: 'Dussīlo' (immoral) and 'asamāhito' (un-concentrated) life is a life of 'scattered' energy. Even 'vassasataṃ' (a hundred years) of such life is a waste. But 'ekāhaṃ' (one day) of being 'sīlavantassa' (virtuous) and 'jhāyino' (meditative) is 'seyyo' (better) because it is a day of true 'presence' and 'purity.'

story.title: The Story of the Novice Saṃkicca
story.content: Saṃkicca was a seven-year-old novice who had already attained Arahatship. A group of thirty monks went into the forest to meditate, but they were captured by a gang of five hundred bandits who demanded one monk for a human sacrifice. Saṃkicca volunteered to go. The bandit leader prepared to kill the boy, but as he swung his sword, it bent like a palm leaf and did not even scratch Saṃkicca's skin. The boy remained perfectly 'virtuous and meditative' (sīlavantassa jhāyino), showing no fear or anger. The bandits were terrified and asked for his forgiveness. Saṃkicca taught them the Dhamma, and all five hundred bandits became monks. The Buddha later explained that Saṃkicca's 'single day' of 'meditative virtue' was worth more than 'a hundred years' of 'immoral living' (vassasataṃ dussīlo). He showed that a mind established in 'Jhāna' (meditation) has a 'shield' that is stronger than steel. The bandits had lived 'hundreds of years' collectively in 'uncontrolled' violence, but it brought them only fear. Saṃkicca's 'one day' brought five hundred people to the path of peace. This story teaches that the 'length' of our life is irrelevant compared to the 'depth' of our ethics. One day of living with a 'clear conscience' and a 'stilled mind' is a 'complete' life, whereas a century of 'headless' living is just a long sleep.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve, duppañño asamāhito;
Ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo, paññavantassa jhāyino.
verses.translation: Better than a hundred years lived ignorantly and with an uncontrolled mind is a single day lived by one who is wise and meditative.
verses.commentary: This verse parallels Verse 110, but replaces 'sīla' (virtue) with 'paññā' (wisdom). 'Duppañño' (ignorant/foolish) living is compared to 'paññavantassa' (wise) living. Wisdom is the ability to see things as they are, which 'jhāyino' (meditation) makes possible.

story.title: The Story of Khānu-Koṇḍañña Thera
story.content: Thera Koṇḍañña was meditating deep in the forest and was so still that he looked like a tree stump (khānu). A group of thieves, returning from a raid with heavy bags of loot, mistook him for a real stump and began to pile their stolen goods on top of him. When they finished, Koṇḍañña stood up to resume his walking meditation. The thieves were terrified, thinking the 'stump' had come to life. Koṇḍañña, who was 'wise and meditative' (paññavantassa jhāyino), did not panic or shout; he simply sat back down and taught them the Dhamma. The Buddha praised him, saying that his 'single day' of 'wise meditation' was superior to 'a hundred years' of 'ignorant' living (vassasataṃ duppañño). The thieves realized that while they had 'thousands of gold coins,' Koṇḍañña had a 'wisdom' that made him richer than any king. His 'uncontrolled' mind had become 'controlled' through the power of 'Jhāna.' The story teaches that a 'wise day' is one where you are the master of your own mind, while an 'ignorant century' is one where you are a slave to every passing thought. Koṇḍañña's 'stillness' was not the stillness of wood, but the stillness of 'profound clarity.' By being 'wide awake' for just one day, he achieved a level of reality that the 'ignorant crowd' never reaches in a hundred years of 'busy' dreaming.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve, kusīto hīnavīriyo;
Ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo, vīriyamārabhato daḷhaṃ.
verses.translation: Better than a hundred years lived lazily and without energy is a single day lived by one who is energetic and resolute.
verses.commentary: 'Kusīto' (lazy) and 'hīnavīriyo' (lacking energy) describe a stagnant life. The Buddha praises 'vīriyamārabhato daḷhaṃ'—one who has 'aroused' (ārabhato) 'firm' (daḷhaṃ) 'energy' (vīriya). One day of 'striving' is 'better' (seyyo) than a hundred years of 'idleness.'

story.title: The Story of Thera Sappadāsa
story.content: Sappadāsa was a monk who struggled with his practice for twenty-five years. He felt 'lazy' (kusīto) and 'lacking in energy' (hīnavīriyo), unable to attain even a moment of peace. Desperate and feeling like his life was a 'hundred-year waste,' he decided to commit suicide by hanging himself. However, as he was tying the noose, he had a sudden surge of 'firm energy' (daḷhaṃ vīriya). He realized that he was about to die without 'seeing the truth.' He directed all his 'aroused energy' into his meditation right then and there. Within that single moment of 'resolute striving,' he broke through his defilements and attained Arahatship. The Buddha praised him, noting that his 'single day'—even his single 'hour'—of 'firm energy' was 'better' than the 'twenty-five years' he had lived in 'sloth.' The story teaches that it is never too late to 'arouse energy.' The 'laziness' of a century can be wiped out by the 'effort' of a single resolute day. Sappadāsa’s 'noose' became his 'bridge' to liberation because he chose to 'strive' rather than 'give up.' It encourages the practitioner to realize that the 'quantity' of time spent practicing is less important than the 'intensity' of the 'vīriya' (energy) applied in the present moment.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve, apassaṃ udayabbayaṃ;
Ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo, passato udayabbayaṃ.
verses.translation: Better than a hundred years lived without seeing the rise and fall of things is a single day lived by one who sees the rise and fall of things.
verses.commentary: 'Udayabbayaṃ' refers to the arising and passing away of all conditioned phenomena (Anicca). To live a 'vassasataṃ' (hundred years) 'apassaṃ' (without seeing) this truth is to live in a dream. A 'single day' (ekāhaṃ) of 'seeing' (passato) reality is 'seyyo' (better) because it triggers the process of detachment and liberation.

story.title: The Story of the Nun Paṭācārā
story.content: Paṭācārā was a woman whose entire world collapsed in a single day: she lost her husband, her two children, her parents, and her brother in various tragic accidents. She lost her mind and wandered the streets in grief until she met the Buddha. The Buddha helped her recover her senses by asking her to reflect on the 'rise and fall' (udayabbayaṃ) of life. He showed her that the 'tears' she had shed in her countless past lives were more than the water in the four oceans. He taught her that living a 'hundred years' in the 'sleep' of attachment is meaningless. He uttered this verse, explaining that 'a single day lived by one who sees the rise and fall' (ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ passato udayabbayaṃ) is more valuable than a century of 'blind' living. Paṭācārā realized that her family members were not 'hers' to keep; they were merely 'conditioned things' that arose and passed away according to kamma. With this profound 'vision' (passato), she attained the first stage of enlightenment (Sotapanna) and eventually became one of the foremost nuns and an Arhat. Her story is the ultimate proof of the verse: her 'long years' of family life were lived 'without seeing,' and they led to madness. But 'one day' of 'seeing' the truth of impermanence led her to a peace that no tragedy could ever touch. It encourages the practitioner not to count their years, but to count their 'moments of insight,' for it is the quality of our 'seeing' that defines the value of our 'living.'

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve, apassaṃ amataṃ padaṃ;
Ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo, passato amataṃ padaṃ.
verses.translation: Better than a hundred years lived without seeing the Deathless State is a single day lived by one who sees the Deathless State.
verses.commentary: 'Amataṃ padaṃ' (The Deathless State) refers to Nibbana. To live 'vassasataṃ' (a hundred years) 'apassaṃ' (without seeing/realizing) Nibbana is to stay within the 'realm of death' (Samsara). One day of 'seeing' (passato) Nibbana is 'seyyo' (better) because it is a day spent outside of time and suffering.

story.title: The Story of the Nun Kisāgotami
story.content: Kisāgotami was a young mother who lost her only child. Crazed with grief, she carried the dead child from house to house asking for 'medicine.' The Buddha asked her to find a mustard seed from a house where no one had ever died. Through this search, she realized that 'Death' is universal. She returned to the Buddha, and he taught her that 'Life' is a 'burning' and 'fading' process. He uttered this verse, explaining that 'one day lived by one who sees the Deathless' (ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ passato amataṃ padaṃ) is better than a century of 'ignorant' attachment. Kisāgotami realized that while her child had 'died,' the 'Deathless' state was accessible through the end of 'attachment.' She 'saw' the 'Deathless' (Nibbana) and became an Arhat. Her story shows that 'tragedy' is often the 'door' to 'truth.' The 'hundred years' of her family happiness were lived 'without seeing' the 'Amata' (Deathless), but the 'one day' of her profound grief led her to 'see' the only thing that never dies. This story teaches us to look for the 'unconditioned' in the middle of the 'conditioned.' By 'seeing' the Deathless, we are no longer victims of 'Death,' making our 'single day' of wisdom a victory over a hundred years of 'mortality.'

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve, apassaṃ dhammamuttamaṃ;
Ekāhaṃ jීvitaṃ seyyo, passato dhammamuttamaṃ.
verses.translation: Better than a hundred years lived without seeing the Supreme Truth is a single day lived by one who sees the Supreme Truth.
verses.commentary: 'Dhammamuttamaṃ' (The Supreme Truth) is the ultimate reality of the Dhamma. This verse concludes the 'Sahassa Vagga' by reinforcing that 'quantity' of life is meaningless without 'quality' of 'vision.' One day of 'seeing' (passato) the 'Supreme' is the only life worth living.

story.title: The Story of the Nun Bahūputtikā
story.content: Bahūputtikā was a woman who had ten children and spent her entire life serving them. However, in her old age, her children and their families neglected her. Feeling bitter, she joined the Order of Nuns. She realized that she had lived 'a hundred years' (vassasataṃ) focused on the 'unessential' (the family) while 'never seeing' the 'Supreme Truth' (apassaṃ dhammamuttamaṃ). She began to practice meditation with extreme 'energy,' even in her old age. One night, while focusing on a lamp flame, she realized the 'Supreme Truth' of impermanence and liberation. The Buddha, seeing her progress, praised her 'single day' of 'vision.' He taught that the 'Supreme Truth' (dhammamuttamaṃ) is the only thing that doesn't 'neglect' us in old age. Bahūputtikā’s 'hundred years' of 'family service' were lived in 'spiritual blindness,' but her 'one day' of 'Dhamma service' made her an Arhat. This story is the final 'Twin' in the chapter's similes. It teaches that 'truth' is the only 'investment' that never fails. Whether we are seven (like Saṃkicca) or eighty (like Bahūputtikā), the 'single day' we 'see' the 'Supreme' is the day our 'real' life begins. It concludes the 'Thousands' chapter by reminding us that the 'One' truth is more valuable than 'Thousands' of distractions, and 'One' day of wakefulness is better than a 'Century' of sleep.

chapters.summary: This chapter discusses the consequences of unwholesome actions and urges practitioners to hasten toward good while restraining the mind from evil.

verses.pali:
Abhittharetha kalyāṇe, pāpā cittaṁ nivāraye;
Dandhaṁ hi karoto puññaṁ, pāpasmiṁ ramatī mano.
