story.content: Returning to the story of Koka the Hunter, after he was killed by his own dogs, a lightning strike hit his home, and a 'consuming fire' (aggi pāvako) burned down his entire house and all his worldly possessions. His family was left with nothing. The Buddha noted that this was the tenth misfortune in the series. But the physical fire was only the beginning. 'Upon the dissolution of the body' (kāyassa bhedā), because Koka had lived a life of 'unwise' (duppañño) violence, he was immediately 'reborn in hell' (nirayaṃ). The Buddha explained that the external fire that burned his house was a reflection of the internal fire of hatred that had burned in Koka's heart for years. Hell is not a place where one is sent as a punishment by a judge; it is a state of existence that the mind 'falls into' when it is heavy with the 'kamma' of violence. Koka’s story concludes with the total erasure of his presence from the world—his body crushed, his home burned, and his consciousness descending into torment. This sequence from Verse 137 to 140 provides a complete portrait of the 'Law of Recoil.' It teaches that violence is a failed strategy for happiness. It may seem to work in the short term, but the 'ten states' are always waiting, proving that the only way to avoid 'burning' is to extinguish the 'fire' of malice before it consumes everything we hold dear.

verses.pali:
Na naggacariyā na jaṭā na paṅkā, nānāsakā thaṇḍilasāyikā vā;
Rajo ca jallaṃ ukkuṭikappadhānaṃ, sodhenti maccaṃ avitiṇṇakaṅkhaṃ.
verses.translation: Neither going naked, nor matted hair, nor filth, nor fasting, nor sleeping on the bare ground, nor smearing the body with dust, nor sitting on one’s heels can purify a mortal who has not overcome doubt.
verses.commentary: The Buddha critiques extreme ascetic practices. External rituals like 'naggacariyā' (nakedness) or 'jaṭā' (matted hair) are 'asāra' (unessential). A person remains unpurified if they have not 'avitiṇṇakaṅkhaṃ' (overcome doubt) regarding the nature of the self and the path to liberation.

story.title: The Story of the Ascetic Jambuka
story.content: Jambuka was an ascetic who practiced extreme austerities for fifty-five years. He went 'naked' (naggacariyā), let his hair become 'matted' (jaṭā), and 'smeared his body with dust' (rajo ca jallaṃ). He even 'sat on his heels' (ukkuṭikappadhānaṃ) and 'fasted' (anāsakā) to prove his holiness to the public. However, inside, he was filled with pride and deceit, secretly eating the leftovers of others. He had not 'overcome doubt' (avitiṇṇakaṅkhaṃ) because his mind was still clouded by the illusion of a 'self' that needed to be honored through these displays. When he met the Buddha, he realized that all his 'filth' and 'bare-ground sleeping' (thaṇḍilasāyikā) had not moved him even an inch closer to peace. The Buddha taught him that 'purification' (sodhenti) is a mental process. You can wash the body, but if the mind is 'dirty' with doubt and ego, you are still a 'mortal' (maccaṃ) bound to suffering. Jambuka abandoned his 'nakedness' and extreme rituals, focusing instead on 'overcoming doubt' through the Dhamma. He realized the Four Noble Truths and attained Arahatship instantly. This story is a powerful reminder that spiritual growth is not a 'performance.' We often mistake 'suffering' for 'holiness,' but the Buddha makes it clear that self-mortification is just another form of attachment. True purity is the clarity that comes when the 'mud' of doubt is cleared from the heart, leaving a mind that is 'naked' in its honesty rather than just a body 'naked' in its clothes.

verses.pali:
Alaṅkato ce pi samaṃ careyya, santo danto niyato brahmacārī;
Sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṃ, so brāhmaṇo so samaṇo sa bhikkhu.
verses.translation: Even if he is richly adorned, if he walks in peace, is tranquil, controlled, and certain, living a holy life and refraining from violence toward all beings—he is a Brahmin, he is an ascetic, he is a monk.
verses.commentary: This verse presents the opposite of Verse 141. It doesn't matter if a person is 'alaṅkato' (adorned/wealthy). If he is 'santo' (peaceful), 'danto' (controlled), and 'niyato' (certain of the goal), he is a true 'samaṇo' (monk). The key is the 'nidhāya daṇḍaṃ'—the total laying down of the 'stick' (violence) toward all living things.

story.title: The Story of Santati the Minister
story.content: Santati was a high-ranking minister who returned from a successful military campaign. To reward him, the King gave him seven days of royal power, during which Santati lived 'richly adorned' (alaṅkato), enjoying every luxury. However, on the seventh day, the sudden death of a favorite dancer threw him into deep grief. He realized the 'impermanence' of all things and sought the Buddha. While still dressed in his 'royal ornaments' and standing on his chariot, he listened to the Buddha's teaching and attained Arahatship in that very moment. The monks were surprised: how could a man in 'royal clothes' be a true monk? The Buddha explained that 'monkhood' is a state of the 'heart' (citta), not a type of 'clothing.' Because Santati had 'laid down the stick' (nidhāya daṇḍaṃ) toward all beings and was 'perfectly tranquil' (santo), he was a 'Brahmin' in the highest sense. He had reached 'niyato'—the certainty of liberation. The Buddha taught that the 'Brahmin,' 'samaṇo,' and 'bhikkhu' are not social labels but descriptions of a mind that has transcended violence and desire. Santati rose into the air and passed into Parinibbana, demonstrating that the 'holy life' (brahmacārī) can be lived anywhere, even in a palace, if the mind is 'controlled' (danto). This story shatters the idea that spiritual achievement is limited to those who look the part. It teaches that the 'jewelry' of the spirit—peace and non-violence—is the only adornment that truly defines a holy person.

verses.pali:
Hirīnisedho puriso, koci lokasmi vijjati;
Yo niddaṃ apabodheti, asso bhadro kasāmiva.
verses.translation: Rare is the man in this world who is restrained by a sense of shame, and who keeps himself awake like a thoroughbred horse avoids the whip.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the 'humility' of a 'bhadro asso' (thoroughbred horse) to describe the 'rare' (koci) person who is 'hirīnisedho' (restrained by shame). 'Hiri' is the internal 'conscience' that makes one 'wake up' (apabodheti) from the 'sleep' (niddaṃ) of heedlessness before the 'whip' (kasā) of suffering strikes.

story.title: The Story of Pilotikatissa Thera
story.content: Pilotikatissa was a man who used to be a poor beggar, wearing only 'pilotika' (rags). After becoming a monk, he kept his old rags and his begging bowl in a corner of his cell. Whenever he felt lazy or was tempted by the comforts of the monastery, he would go to his rags and scold himself: 'Hey, you poor wretch! Do you want to go back to wearing these and begging for crumbs?' This 'sense of shame' (hiri) would immediately 'wake him up' (apabodheti) from his 'sleep' of desire. He was like a 'thoroughbred horse' (bhadro asso) that only needs to see the 'shadow of the whip' (kasāmiva) to move faster. He didn't need a great tragedy to motivate him; his own 'conscience' was enough. The Buddha praised him, noting that 'rare' (koci) is the man who can use 'shame' as a spiritual fuel. Most people only change when they are 'beaten' by disaster, but the 'thoroughbred' monk changes simply because he 'sees' the potential for error. Pilotikatissa eventually attained Arahatship using his 'rags' as his primary meditation subject. This story teaches that 'Hiri' (shame) is not a negative emotion of guilt, but a positive force of 'integrity.' It is the 'alarm clock' of the spirit. By staying 'awake' to our own dignity as human beings, we avoid the 'whip' of bad kamma and move swiftly toward the further shore, just as a noble horse moves with grace and speed at the slightest hint of the trainer's will.

verses.translation: Like a thoroughbred horse touched by the whip, be energetic and filled with a sense of urgency. By faith, virtue, energy, concentration, and discernment of the Dhamma—being perfect in knowledge and conduct, and being mindful—you will leave behind this great suffering.
verses.commentary: The Buddha lists the tools for liberation: 'Saddhāya' (faith), 'sīlena' (virtue), 'vīriyena' (energy), 'samādhinā' (concentration), and 'dhammavinicchayena' (discernment). These, combined with 'satimanto' (mindfulness), allow one to 'pahassatha' (abandon/leave behind) 'dukkhamidaṃ' (this great suffering).

story.title: The Training of the Monks
story.content: A group of monks were practicing meditation in the forest but were becoming 'lazy' and 'comfortable.' The Buddha visited them and gave them this instruction, telling them to be like 'thoroughbred horses' (asso bhadro) that have been 'touched by the whip' (kasāniviṭṭho). He urged them to develop 'saṃvega'—a sense of 'spiritual urgency'—by reflecting on the certainty of death and the uncertainty of life. He told them that 'faith' (saddhā) is the seed, 'virtue' (sīla) is the ground, and 'energy' (vīriya) is the effort required to make the garden grow. They needed 'concentration' (samādhi) to keep the mind steady and 'discernment' (dhammavinicchayena) to pull out the 'weeds' of defilement. The monks, feeling the 'whip' of the Buddha's words, became 'ātāpino' (ardent/energetic). They realized that they had been 'perfect in conduct' (caraṇā) but lacked the 'perfect knowledge' (vijjā). They practiced with a renewed 'mindfulness' (satimanto) and, within that rainy season, all of them 'left behind this great suffering' (pahassatha dukkhamidaṃ anappakaṃ) by attaining Arahatship. This story illustrates that the spiritual path requires a 'high-performance' mindset. We cannot drift into Nibbana; we must 'ride' there with the 'speed' and 'focus' of a thoroughbred. The 'great suffering' of Samsara is like a 'heavy load' that only the 'strongest horses' can leave behind. By combining these six spiritual powers, the practitioner transforms from a 'slow jade' into a 'noble steed' of the spirit, capable of reaching the ultimate destination of peace.

verses.pali:
Udakañhi nayanti nettikā, usukārā namayanti tejanaṃ;
Dāruṃ namayanti tacchakā, attānaṃ damayanti subbatā.
verses.translation: Irrigators regulate the waters; fletchers straighten the arrow shaft; carpenters shape the wood; the virtuous control themselves.
verses.commentary: This verse concludes the chapter by repeating the 'mastery' similes first seen in Verse 80. The focus here is on 'subbatā' (the virtuous/those of good vows). The repetition emphasizes that the 'shaping' of the 'self' (attānaṃ damayanti) is the only work that truly matters, transcending all external 'violence' and 'suffering.'

story.title: The Final Taming of the Novice Sukha
story.content: A novice named Sukha was walking with his teacher when he saw 'irrigators' (nettikā), 'fletchers' (usukārā), and 'carpenters' (tacchakā) at work. He asked the same question that the novice Paṇḍita had once asked: 'If these people can tame lifeless things, why can't we tame ourselves?' His teacher encouraged him to practice 'attānaṃ damayanti' (taming the self). Sukha sat in his cell and realized that his 'mind' was like the 'water'—it needed to be led into the channel of concentration. His 'intentions' were like the 'arrows'—they needed to be straightened over the 'fire' of wisdom. His 'character' was like the 'wood'—it needed to be 'carved' into the form of an Arhat. He became a 'subbatā'—one who is 'virtuous' and dedicated to his 'vows.' Within a single day, he mastered his own internal environment so thoroughly that he attained Arahatship. The Buddha praised him, noting that 'self-taming' is the greatest of all crafts. While the irrigator, fletcher, and carpenter change the 'world,' the 'subbatā' changes 'himself.' This story, and the conclusion of the chapter, teaches that the 'violence' we experience from the outside is secondary to the 'violence' we do to ourselves through an 'untamed' mind. By becoming the 'architect' and 'craftsman' of our own consciousness, we create a 'self' that is immune to 'force' and 'fear,' proving that 'Self-Mastery' is the ultimate 'Non-Violence' (Ahimsa).

chapters.summary: This chapter reflects on the impermanence of life, the inevitability of aging and death, and the urgency of spiritual practice while one still has the opportunity.

verses.pali:
Ko nu hāso kimānando, niccaṃ pajjalite sati;
Andhakārena onaddhā, padīpaṃ na gavesatha.
verses.translation: How is there laughter, how is there joy, when the world is ever burning? Shrouded by darkness, why do you not seek a light?
verses.commentary: The world is 'ever burning' with the eleven fires: greed, hate, delusion, birth, aging, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair. Ignorance is the 'darkness' that prevents beings from seeing this reality. The 'light' is the wisdom that reveals the Four Noble Truths.

story.title: The Story of Visākhā's Companions
story.content: Five hundred female friends of Visākhā, the great lay benefactress, accompanied her to the Jetavana monastery. While Visākhā sat respectfully to listen to the Buddha, her companions—who had secretly consumed alcohol—began to behave in a most unseemly manner. In the very presence of the Teacher, they started singing, dancing, and laughing uncontrollably, their minds clouded by intoxication and the illusion of permanent joy. Seeing their state, the Buddha used his psychic powers to emanate darkness, followed by a brilliant, piercing light that shocked them into sobriety. He spoke this verse to address their heedlessness. He explained that 'laughter' and 'joy' based on intoxication or worldly pleasures are misplaced in a world where the 'fire' of old age and death never ceases to burn. The women, who were 'shrouded by the darkness' of their own delusion and the physical darkness the Buddha manifested, were urged to seek the 'light' of the Dhamma. He reminded them that the body is a fragile vessel constantly undergoing decay, and that true happiness cannot be found in the fleeting thrill of wine or music. Struck by the gravity of his words and the miraculous display, most of the women reached a state of deep realization, letting go of their attachment to trivialities and attaining the first stage of enlightenment, the path of the Stream-winner.

verses.pali:
Passa cittakataṃ pappaṃ, arukayāṃ samussitaṃ;
Āturaṃ bahusaṅkappaṃ, yassa natthi dhuvaṃ ṭhiti.
verses.translation: Look at this beautified image, a mass of sores, a diseased body, full of many thoughts, which has no permanence or stability.
verses.commentary: The body is described as 'beautified' because people use cosmetics, jewelry, and clothing to hide its true nature. In reality, it is a 'mass of sores' and a vessel for countless diseases. The 'many thoughts' are the ego's projections of beauty onto a form that is inherently unstable.

story.title: The Story of Sīrimā the Courtesan
story.content: Sīrimā was the most beautiful courtesan in Rājagaha, famous for her grace and stunning appearance. For a single night with her, men would pay a thousand pieces of gold. However, she fell ill and died suddenly at a young age. At the Buddha's request, King Bimbisāra did not bury or cremate her body immediately; instead, he left it in the charnel ground for three days. The Buddha then invited the townspeople, including a young monk who had been obsessed with her beauty, to view the corpse. By this time, the once-radiant Sīrimā had become a 'mass of sores,' bloated, discolored, and infested with maggots. The Buddha had the town crier announce that anyone could now have Sīrimā for a thousand gold coins. No one spoke. The price was lowered to five hundred, then one hundred, and finally offered for free. Still, no one wanted the body. The Buddha then uttered this verse, explaining that the 'beautified image' which had driven men to madness was always a 'diseased body' and a temporary construction of kamma. He showed them that while the mind projects 'many thoughts' of desire onto the flesh, the body itself has 'no permanence' (natthi dhuvaṃ). The young monk, seeing the literal decay of his object of lust, realized the futility of his attachment. He understood that the beauty was a mirage and that the truth was found in the impermanent nature of all form, leading him to achieve deep insight and eventually liberation from the cycle of craving.

verses.pali:
Parijiṇṇam idaṃ rūpaṃ, roganīḷaṃ pabhaṅguraṃ;
Bhijjati pūtisandeho, maraṇantaṃ hi jīvitaṃ.
verses.translation: This body is worn out, a nest of diseases and fragile. This heap of corruption breaks into pieces, for life ends in death.
verses.commentary: The Buddha defines the body as 'parijiṇṇam' (decrepit) and 'roganīḷaṃ' (a nest of sicknesses). It is 'pabhaṅguraṃ' (fragile) because it requires constant maintenance just to survive. The inevitable end for every living being is 'maraṇantaṃ'—the cessation of the life-force.

story.title: Continuation of Sīrimā's Story
story.content: As the crowd stood around the decaying corpse of Sīrimā, the stench became overwhelming. The Buddha used this vivid and visceral scene to drive home the lesson of mortality. He addressed the monks and the laypeople, pointing out that what they were witnessing was the 'pūtisandeho'—a heap of corruption that was once the pride of the city. He explained that every human body, regardless of how much it is pampered or adorned, is effectively a 'nest of diseases' waiting for the right conditions to manifest. The beauty they once admired was merely a temporary arrangement of the four elements, now breaking into pieces before their very eyes. He emphasized that 'life ends in death' (maraṇantaṃ hi jīvitaṃ) as a fundamental law of nature that applies to kings and beggars alike. The crowd was silent as they contemplated the 'fragile' (pabhaṅguraṃ) nature of their own existence. The Buddha taught that instead of being terrified of this decay, one should use the realization of it as a catalyst for spiritual practice. By understanding that the body is 'worn out' from the moment of birth, one stops building a future based on physical vanity. Many in the audience, including those who had been most intoxicated by Sīrimā's living beauty, were moved to tears and deep reflection. They recognized that the only thing that does not rot is the merit of a virtuous life and the wisdom of the Dhamma, which provides a refuge beyond the 'heap of corruption' that is the physical form.

verses.pali:
Yānimāni apatthāni, alāpūneva sārade;
Kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni, tāni disvā kā rati.
verses.translation: These dove-colored bones are like gourds cast away in autumn. Seeing them, what joy is there?
verses.commentary: Bleached by the sun and rain, old bones take on a greyish, 'dove-colored' (kāpotakāni) appearance. They are compared to 'alāpūneva sārade'—bitter gourds that have been discarded in the fields. The verse asks the critical question: how can anyone find sensual pleasure ('rati') in a body that eventually turns into such a sight?

story.title: The Charnel Ground Meditation
story.content: In ancient India, it was common for bodies to be left in open spaces known as charnel grounds. A group of monks visited such a place to practice 'Asubha Bhāvanā' (meditation on the unattractive nature of the body). They saw skeletons that had been scattered by wild animals, the 'bones' bleached by the elements until they were the color of pigeons or 'doves' (kāpotakāni). These remains were 'cast away' and ignored by everyone, much like 'bitter gourds' left in a field after the autumn harvest. The Buddha appeared to the monks and spoke this verse to help them bridge the gap between their abstract meditation and their internal experience. He asked them, 'Seeing these, what joy is there?' He pointed out that every bone they saw was once part of a person who laughed, loved, and felt as if they would live forever. By identifying these 'apatthāni' (scattered things) as the ultimate destination of the physical self, the monks were able to sever the roots of lust and vanity. The Buddha explained that 'rati' (sensual delight) is only possible when one ignores the final outcome of the body. Once the truth of the skeleton is seen, the 'decorated' exterior loses its power to enchant. The monks reflected on the fact that their own bodies currently contained identical structures that would one day be cast away in exactly the same manner. This profound realization of shared mortality allowed them to turn their minds away from the 'husk' of the body and toward the 'kernel' of spiritual liberation, ultimately leading many of them to attain the high fruits of the path.

verses.pali:
Aṭṭhīnaṃ nagaraṃ kataṃ, maṃsalohitalepanaṃ;
Yattha jarā ca maccu ca, māno makkho ca ohito.
verses.translation: This city (the body) is built of bones, plastered with flesh and blood; within it dwell old age and death, pride and deceit.
verses.commentary: The body is described as a 'nagaraṃ' (city) or fortress. Its structural beams are the 'aṭṭhīnaṃ' (bones), and its plaster is the 'maṃsalohita' (flesh and blood). Inside this 'city,' the inhabitants are not peace and joy, but the inevitable processes of aging ('jarā'), death ('maccu'), and the defilements of pride and hypocrisy.

story.title: The Story of Rūpanandā (Janapadakalyāṇī)
story.content: Princess Rūpanandā was the Buddha's half-sister and was known as 'Janapadakalyāṇī' because of her supreme beauty. She was extremely proud of her looks and avoided the Buddha for a long time, fearing he would criticize her appearance. Eventually, she went to hear him out of curiosity. The Buddha, knowing her character, used his psychic powers to manifest a vision of an even more beautiful woman sitting near him. Rūpanandā was mesmerized, but as she watched, the woman in the vision rapidly aged, withered, and died, turning into a heap of bones before her eyes. The Buddha then spoke this verse, comparing the body to a 'city built of bones' (aṭṭhīnaṃ nagaraṃ). He explained that even the most beautiful form is just a structure 'plastered with flesh and blood' (maṃsalohitalepanaṃ) that serves as a dwelling place for 'old age and death.' He directly addressed her 'pride' (māno) and her 'deceit' (makkho), showing her that she was protecting a fortress that was already under siege by time. Rūpanandā realized that her beauty was a temporary decoration on a biological structure destined for decay. She understood that she had spent her life maintaining the 'walls' of a city that was inhabited by her greatest enemies—aging and death. This realization shattered her vanity, and she turned her mind to the practice of the Dhamma, eventually becoming an Arhat and a leader among the nuns, having found a peace that did not depend on the fragile 'plaster' of her physical form.

verses.pali:
Jīranti ve rājarathā sucittā, atho sarīrampi jaraṃ upeti;
Satañca dhammo na jaraṃ upeti, santo have sabbhi pavedayanti.
verses.translation: Even the decorated royal chariots wear out, and so does the body reach old age. But the Dhamma of the Good never decays; thus do the good reveal it to the good.
verses.commentary: 'Rājarathā sucittā' (well-painted royal chariots) represent the height of worldly technology and luxury, yet even they 'jīranti' (decay/crumble). The 'sarīram' (body) follows the same law. Only the 'Dhammo' (the truth/path) remains 'na jaraṃ upeti' (untouched by old age).

story.title: The Story of Queen Mallikā
story.content: Queen Mallikā was the wise and virtuous chief consort of King Pasenadi of Kosala. When she passed away, the King was overwhelmed with grief and could not be consoled. He went to the Buddha, lamenting the loss of such a beautiful and noble woman. The Buddha pointed to the 'decorated royal chariots' (rājarathā sucittā) that belonged to the King, noting that even they, despite being made of the finest wood and gold, eventually became 'worn out' and broken. He explained that the 'body' (sarīram) is no different; it is a physical construction subject to the same laws of physics and time. However, he offered the King a profound comfort: while the 'form' decays, the 'Dhamma of the Good' (satañca dhammo) never decays. The virtues that Mallikā had cultivated—her generosity, her kindness, and her wisdom—were not subject to 'old age.' He explained that the 'Good' (the enlightened) share this truth with 'the good' (the seekers) to show that the real essence of a person is their character and their realization of the truth, which transcends the physical body. Mallikā had lived a life of merit, and that merit remained as a legacy that 'na jaraṃ upeti' (does not grow old). The King, hearing this, found the strength to let go of his attachment to her physical form and instead focus on the virtuous path she had exemplified. This story teaches that while we cannot stop the 'chariot' of the body from crumbling, we can invest in the 'eternal' Dhamma which provides a refuge that time cannot touch.

verses.pali:
Appassutāyaṃ puriso, balivaddo va jīrati;
Maṃsāni tassa vaḍḍhanti, paññā tassa na vaḍḍhati.
verses.translation: The man of little learning grows old like an ox. His flesh increases, but his wisdom does not.
verses.commentary: 'Appassuta' (one who has heard little/little learning) refers to a lack of spiritual knowledge. Such a person 'grows old like an ox' (balivaddo va jīrati)—a purely biological process of aging. While their 'flesh' (maṃsāni) or worldly status might 'increase' (vaḍḍhanti), their 'paññā' (wisdom) remains stagnant and immature.

story.title: The Story of Lāludāyī Thera
story.content: Lāludāyī was a monk who, despite spending many years in the presence of the Buddha and the great elders, remained remarkably ignorant. He was unable to deliver even a simple discourse correctly, often mixing up funeral verses with wedding blessings. He was a 'man of little learning' (appassutāyaṃ puriso) because he did not apply himself to the study or practice of the Dhamma, preferring to spend his time on his physical comforts. The Buddha compared him to an 'ox' (balivaddo). An ox may grow large, strong, and fleshy as it ages, but it gains no deeper understanding of life; it only knows eating and sleeping. Similarly, Lāludāyī’s 'flesh'—his physical size and his years as a monk—had increased, but his 'wisdom' (paññā) had 'not increased' (na vaḍḍhati). He was spiritually 'un-grown.' The Buddha explained that just as an old ox is eventually sent to the slaughter without having achieved anything, a person who ages without wisdom has wasted their human opportunity. The story serves as a sharp warning against 'passive aging.' Merely surviving for many years does not make one an elder (Thera); only the growth of wisdom and character confers true seniority. Lāludāyī’s failure was a lack of 'hearing' (suta)—not just with the ears, but with the heart. He is a cautionary example for anyone who mistakes physical maturity or social status for spiritual progress, reminding us that we must 'feed' our wisdom as diligently as we feed our bodies.

verses.pali:
Anekajātisaṃsāraṃ, sandhāvissaṃ anibbisaṃ;
Gahakārakaṃ gavesanto, dukkhā jāti punappunaṃ.
verses.translation: Through many a birth in Samsara have I wandered, seeking but not finding the builder of this house. Sorrowful is it to be born again and again.
verses.commentary: This and the following verse are the Buddha's 'Paean of Joy' uttered at the moment of his enlightenment. 'Anekajātisaṃsāraṃ' refers to the countless past lives. The 'gahakārakaṃ' (house-builder) is craving (tanha), which 'builds' the physical 'house' of the body. 'Dukkhā jāti' (sorrowful is birth) is the core realization of the First Noble Truth.

story.title: The Buddha's Enlightenment
story.content: As Prince Siddhartha sat under the Bodhi tree on the night of the full moon in May, his mind entered the deepest states of concentration. He looked back through his 'many births' (anekajātisaṃsāraṃ) and saw himself 'wandering' (sandhāvissaṃ) through every realm of existence—as an animal, a human, and a god. He realized that in every life, he had been a victim of 'sorrowful birth' (dukkhā jāti) because he was subject to aging, sickness, and death over and over again. He had been 'seeking but not finding' the 'builder of this house'—the hidden cause that keeps constructing new bodies for consciousness to inhabit. This 'house-builder' was the invisible architect of his suffering. At the break of dawn, as the morning star rose, he finally 'found' the builder. He realized that 'Craving' (Tanha), fueled by ignorance, was the force that binds the mind to the cycle of rebirth. This verse captures the immense weariness of the 'wandering' and the profound 'sorrow' of the 'again and again' (punappunaṃ). It is the first half of the Buddha's triumphant declaration of victory. He acknowledged the long journey he had taken—spanning eons—just to reach this single moment of clarity. The 'house' of the body was seen not as a refuge, but as a prison, and for the first time in countless ages, the prisoner had identified the jailer. This story represents the turning point in the history of the world, where the cycle of 'sorrowful birth' was finally understood and the path to the 'Unborn' was opened.

verses.translation: O house-builder, you are seen! You shall build no house again. All your rafters are broken, your ridgepole is shattered. To the Unconditioned the mind has gone; the end of craving has been reached.
verses.commentary: This is the second half of the Paean. The 'phāsukā' (rafters) are the defilements, and the 'gahakūṭaṃ' (ridgepole) is ignorance. To 'visaṅkhataṃ' (shatter) these is to reach the 'Visaṅkhāragataṃ' (the Unconditioned/Nibbana). The 'end of craving' (taṇhānaṃ khayam) is the final goal of the holy life.

story.title: The Moment of Full Enlightenment
story.content: Immediately following the realization in Verse 153, the Buddha addressed the 'house-builder' (Craving) directly. He declared, 'You are seen!' (diṭṭhosi). By bringing the subconscious process of craving into the light of full awareness, its power was destroyed. He saw that the 'rafters'—the various mental defilements like anger, greed, and pride—were 'broken' (bhaggā). The 'ridgepole'—the foundational 'ignorance' that supports the whole structure of the 'self'—was 'shattered' (visaṅkhataṃ). Without these supports, the 'house' of future rebirth could 'no longer be built' (puna gehaṃ na kāhasi). His 'mind had gone to the Unconditioned' (visaṅkhāragataṃ cittaṃ), meaning it was no longer subject to the laws of cause and effect that produce suffering. He had reached the 'end of craving' (taṇhānaṃ khayam), the state of Nibbana. The 'Paean of Joy' is an expression of absolute spiritual triumph. The 'house-builder' had been evicted forever. This moment marked the end of Siddhartha's quest and the beginning of his life as the Buddha. The story teaches that enlightenment is an 'undoing' of the structures of the mind. It is not about building something new, but about 'shattering' the 'ridgepole' of ignorance so that the 'house' of suffering collapses. For the Buddha, the 'Unconditioned' was the only true 'home,' a state of unshakeable peace that is no longer 'built' by the hands of desire, but discovered through the power of perfect wisdom.

verses.pali:
Acaritvā brahmacariyaṃ, aladdhā yobbane dhanaṃ;
Jiṇṇakoñcā va jhāyanti, khīṇamacche va pallale.
verses.translation: They who have not led the holy life, who have not acquired wealth in their youth, pine away like old herons at a pond without fish.
verses.commentary: This verse warns against wasted opportunities. If one fails to practice the 'holy life' (brahmacariyaṃ) and also fails to acquire worldly 'wealth' (dhanaṃ) in 'youth' (yobbane), they end up like 'jiṇṇakoñcā' (old herons) standing by a 'pallale' (pond) that has 'no fish' (khīṇamacche). They have neither spiritual peace nor material security.

story.title: The Story of the Millionaire's Son (Mahādhana)
story.content: Mahādhana was the son of a multi-millionaire in Benares. Both he and his wife inherited vast fortunes but spent their youth in 'heedlessness,' indulging in every possible luxury and entertainment. They 'did not lead the holy life' (acaritvā brahmacariyaṃ) because they were too busy with their pleasures, and they 'did not acquire wealth' (aladdhā dhanaṃ) because they only knew how to spend it. By the time they were old, they had lost everything and were forced to beg for food at the monastery gates. The Buddha, seeing them, spoke this verse. He compared them to 'old herons' (jiṇṇakoñcā) standing at a dried-up 'pond without fish' (khīṇamacche va pallale). A heron without fish has no strength and no food; similarly, Mahādhana had no 'spiritual strength' from practice and no 'material food' from his wealth. They 'pined away' (jhāyanti) with regret, looking back at a youth that was wasted on the 'unessential.' The Buddha explained that if Mahādhana had practiced in his youth, he would have been an Arhat; if in middle age, a Non-returner. But because he waited until he was 'worn out' by life, he had neither the energy to practice nor the means to live. This story is a stark reminder that 'time is the fire in which we burn.' Youth is the most precious 'capital' we have, and to waste it without securing either the worldly or the transcendental is the greatest of all human tragedies.

verses.pali:
Acaritvā brahmacariyaṃ, aladdhā yobbane dhanaṃ;
Senti cāpātikhīṇāva, purāṇāni anutthunaṃ.
verses.translation: They who have not led the holy life, who have not acquired wealth in their youth, lie like worn-out bows, sighing after the past.
verses.commentary: The second half of Mahādhana's tragedy. Those who waste their youth 'lie like worn-out bows' (senti cāpātikhīṇāva)—bows that have lost their tension and can no longer shoot arrows. They spend their old age 'sighing after the past' (purāṇāni anutthunaṃ), dwelling on 'what might have been' because they have no 'present' peace.

story.title: The Old Men Full of Regret
story.content: Continuing the story of Mahādhana, the Buddha described the mental state of the old couple as they sat in the dust. He noted that they were 'sighing after the past' (purāṇāni anutthunaṃ), constantly talking about the 'good old days' when they had servants and gold. But these memories provided no comfort; they only made their current poverty and sickness feel more acute. They were like 'worn-out bows' (cāpātikhīṇāva)—useless and discarded. Just as a bow without tension is no longer a weapon, a human being without the 'tension' of purpose or the 'flexibility' of wisdom is no longer able to face the challenges of aging. The Buddha taught that 'regret' is the heaviest burden of old age. While the 'wise' look back at their lives and see a 'garland' of good deeds, the 'foolish' look back and see only a 'void' of wasted time. Mahādhana and his wife were living proof that 'heedlessness' in youth leads to a 'sighing' old age. The story emphasizes that the 'holy life' (brahmacariyaṃ) is a 'pension' for the spirit; it is the only thing that provides 'joy' when the body can no longer enjoy the world. By the time Mahādhana realized his error, he was too 'worn out' to change his destiny. The Buddha used their example to urge the younger monks to 'arouse energy' while they still had the 'strength' of a new bow, ensuring that their later years would be filled with the 'delight' of realization rather than the 'sighs' of a lost past.

chapters.summary: This chapter deals with self-control, self-respect, and the importance of being one's own refuge through diligent practice and ethical conduct.

verses.pali:
Attānañce piyaṃ jaññā, rakkheyya naṃ surakkhitaṃ;
Tiṇṇamaññataraṃ yāmaṃ, paṭijaggeyya paṇḍito.
verses.translation: If one holds oneself dear, one should watch oneself carefully. During one of the three watches of life, the wise man should keep vigil.
verses.commentary: True self-love is shown through spiritual vigilance. The 'three watches' (yāma) refer to youth, middle age, and old age. A wise man ('paṇḍito') ensures he dedicates at least one of these periods to intense spiritual practice ('paṭijaggeyya').

story.title: The Story of Bodhirājakumāra
story.content: Prince Bodhi was a man of great wealth and power who built a magnificent palace called Kokanada. To ensure his palace remained unique, he planned to kill or blind the architect. However, the architect escaped. Later, the Prince invited the Buddha for a meal. Being childless, the Prince spread white cloths on the floor, vowing that if he was to have a son, the Buddha would step on them. The Buddha, however, stood at the entrance and refused to step on the cloths. Ananda, sensing the Buddha's intent, asked the Prince to remove them. After the meal, the Buddha explained that the Prince and his wife had committed a grave sin in a past life; while shipwrecked on an island, they had survived by eating the eggs and fledglings of birds, showing no compassion for the living beings. Because of this lack of 'self-protection' through virtue, they were destined to be childless. The Buddha spoke this verse, explaining that if one truly 'holds oneself dear' (attānaṃ piyaṃ jaññā), one must 'watch oneself' (rakkheyya) by avoiding evil deeds. He pointed out that the Prince had already wasted his youth and middle age without 'keeping vigil' over his character. He urged the Prince to use his remaining years to cultivate merit. The Prince realized that by harming others, he had actually been his own greatest enemy. This story teaches that the highest form of self-preservation is the maintenance of one's ethical integrity, as our actions are the only things that truly belong to us.

verses.pali:
Attānam eva paṭhamaṃ, patirūpe nivesaye;
Athaññam anusāseyya, na kilisseyya paṇḍito.
verses.translation: One should first establish oneself in what is proper; then only should one instruct others. Thus the wise man will not be reproached.
verses.commentary: Self-mastery must precede the guidance of others. 'Patirūpe' means a fitting or proper state of virtue. If a teacher is 'kilisseyya' (soiled/reproached) by their own faults, their instructions lack power and bring them only stress.

story.title: The Story of Upananda Thera
story.content: Upananda was a monk who was very eloquent and loved to preach the Dhamma to others. He would often speak about the virtues of simplicity, contentment, and having few possessions. However, he did not practice what he preached. He was greedy and would go from monastery to monastery, collecting high-quality robes and luxury items given by devotees. Once, during the rains retreat, two young monks were disputing over the division of two expensive robes and a velvet blanket. They asked Upananda to arbitrate. He took the two robes for the monks but kept the expensive velvet blanket for himself as his 'fee.' When the Buddha heard of this, he rebuked Upananda. He explained that a person who 'instructs others' (aññam anusāseyya) without 'establishing oneself' (attānam eva paṭhamaṃ) in virtue is like a person who tries to wash others while being covered in mud. The Buddha taught that a 'wise man' (paṇḍito) leads by example. If your own conduct is 'proper' (patirūpe), your words will have the weight of truth and you will not be 'reproached' (kilisseyya) by the wise. This story serves as a warning to teachers and leaders that spiritual authority is earned through personal discipline, not just intellectual knowledge. Upananda’s hypocrisy made him a figure of ridicule, proving that the most important sermon is the one preached by one's own life.

verses.pali:
Attānaṃ ce tathā kayirā, yathāññam anusāsati;
Suntanto vata dammetha, attā hi kira duddamo.
verses.translation: If one would only practice what one preaches to others, then being well-tamed, one could tame others. Truly, the self is difficult to tame.
verses.commentary: 'Duddamo' (difficult to tame) highlights the inherent stubbornness of the human ego. Only a person who is 'sudantena' (well-tamed) has the moral authority and the practical experience to 'dammetha' (tame) or guide others effectively.

story.title: The Story of Thera Padhānikatissa
story.content: Thera Padhānikatissa was a teacher of many monks. He was very strict with his students, urging them to stay awake all night to meditate and scolding them if he found them resting. However, while his students were struggling to stay awake, the teacher himself would go to his cell and sleep soundly. The students, realizing their teacher's laziness, became discouraged and lost faith in his instructions. When the Buddha became aware of this, he used it as a teaching moment for the Sangha. He explained that 'the self is difficult to tame' (attā hi kira duddamo), and it is much easier to give orders than to follow them. He said that if Padhānikatissa would 'only practice what he preaches' (yathāññam anusāsati), his students would follow him naturally. He taught that a true leader is 'well-tamed' (sudanto) first. Just as a wild horse must be broken by a trainer who is himself disciplined, a mind can only be guided by one who has already conquered their own laziness and desire. The monks learned that the highest form of 'taming' is self-taming. This story illustrates that hypocrisy is the greatest barrier to helping others. When we align our actions with our words, our influence becomes a natural force for good, but when we remain 'untamed' ourselves, our instructions are merely hollow sounds.

verses.pali:
Attā hi attano nātho, ko hi nātho paro siyā;
Attanā hi sudantena, nāthaṃ labhati durlabhaṃ.
verses.translation: Self is the master of self; for who else could be the master? With a well-tamed self, one finds a master that is difficult to find.
verses.commentary: This is a core tenet of Buddhist self-reliance. 'Nātho' (master/refuge/protector) cannot be found in a god or another person. Only through a 'sudantena' (well-tamed) mind does one attain the 'durlabhaṃ' (rare/difficult) refuge of Nibbana.

story.title: The Mother of Kumāra Kassapa
story.content: A young woman became a nun not knowing she was pregnant. When her pregnancy became visible, the monks accused her of misconduct. She insisted on her innocence and sought the Buddha's help. The Buddha assigned Visākhā and the King to investigate. They proved she had conceived before ordaining. When her son, Kumāra Kassapa, grew up, he also became a monk. Despite being an Arhat, the young monk's mother was so attached to him that she would cry whenever she saw him, hindering her own progress. One day, Kassapa spoke harshly to her to break her attachment, saying, 'Can't you even give up this small affection after all these years?' Shaken and realizing that her son could not save her, she understood that 'Self is the master of self' (attā hi attano nātho). She realized that the Buddha and her son could show the way, but they could not 'tame' her mind for her. She turned her focus inward, 'taming' her own grief and desire. By becoming 'sudantena' (well-tamed), she attained Arahatship that very day. She found the 'master difficult to find'—the unshakeable refuge of her own enlightened nature. This story highlights the limits of external help. Even with a Buddha as a teacher and an Arhat as a son, the mother remained bound until she took responsibility for her own liberation. It teaches that the ultimate 'Protector' is not an external being, but our own disciplined and purified consciousness.

verses.pali:
Attanā va kataṃ pāpaṃ, attajaṃ attasambhavaṃ;
Mathati dummedhaṃ, vajiraṃ vasmāmayaṃ maṇiṃ.
verses.translation: The evil done by oneself, born of oneself, and produced by oneself, crushes the fool as a diamond grinds a hard gem.
verses.commentary: 'Attajaṃ' (born of self) and 'attasambhavaṃ' (produced by self) emphasize that evil is not an external force. Like a 'vajiraṃ' (diamond) that is used to cut or 'mathati' (crush/grind) other 'maṇiṃ' (gems), one's own 'pāpaṃ' (evil) becomes the instrument of one's own destruction.

story.title: The Story of Mahādhana the Merchant's Son
story.content: Mahādhana was the son of a very wealthy merchant who inherited a vast fortune. However, he was 'dummedhaṃ' (a fool) who spent his youth in heedlessness, indulging in alcohol, gambling, and expensive entertainment. He never learned a trade or practiced the Dhamma. Eventually, he lost all his wealth and was reduced to begging for food in the streets. The Buddha, seeing him, noted that Mahādhana's current misery was 'born of himself' (attajaṃ). No enemy had robbed him, and no god had cursed him; it was his own 'evil deeds' (pāpaṃ)—his laziness and lack of self-control—that were now 'crushing' him. The Buddha compared his bad kamma to a 'diamond' (vajiraṃ) that grinds down a hard stone. Just as the diamond is the only thing hard enough to destroy a gem, our own negative intentions are the only things powerful enough to destroy our happiness. Mahādhana had 'produced' his own downfall through years of 'attasambhavaṃ' (self-originated) neglect. This story teaches that we are the authors of our own suffering. We often blame 'fate' or 'others' for our problems, but the Buddha reminds us that the seeds of our ruin are planted by our own hands. By the time Mahādhana realized his error, he was too broken to change his life, serving as a cautionary tale that the 'evil done by oneself' is a weight that eventually becomes too heavy to carry.

verses.pali:
Yassa accanta-dussīlyaṃ, māluvā sālam iv' otataṃ;
Karoti so tath' attānaṃ, yathā naṃ icchatī diso.
verses.translation: As a creeper (māluvā) overpowers a sal tree, so the man of exceeding vice does to himself what an enemy would wish for him.
verses.contentary: 'Accanta-dussīlyaṃ' refers to habitual, chronic immorality. The 'māluvā' is a parasitic creeper that eventually strangles the 'sāla' tree it climbs. A person without virtue ('tath' attānaṃ') effectively does the work of a 'diso' (enemy) by ensuring their own destruction.

story.title: The Story of the Monk who was a Former King
story.content: A certain monk had been a king in his previous life, but due to his 'exceeding vice' (accanta-dussīlyaṃ) and cruelty, he was reborn in a state of suffering for a long time. In his final life, even after joining the Sangha, he struggled with his old habits of arrogance and ill-will. The Buddha used the simile of the 'māluvā' creeper to describe his condition. He explained that just as a creeper slowly wraps around a majestic 'sal tree,' eventually choking the life out of it, habitual 'vice' wraps around a person's potential for goodness. By refusing to follow the precepts, the monk was 'doing to himself' exactly what his 'enemies' (diso) would want. An enemy wishes for your ruin, your loss of reputation, and your eventual misery; by being immoral, you grant all those wishes to your enemies for free. The monk realized that his worst enemy was not someone outside, but the 'creeper' of his own bad habits. He began to 'cut' the vines of his desire and anger through intense meditation. This story illustrates that immorality is a form of 'spiritual suicide.' We think we are 'getting away' with something when we act unethically, but we are actually just tightening the vine around our own necks. True 'self-love' involves keeping the 'tree' of our life free from the parasitic creepers of vice.

verses.pali:
Sukarāni asādhūni, attano ahitāni ca;
Yaṃ ve hitañca sādhuñca, taṃ ve paramadukkaraṃ.
verses.translation: Easy to do are things that are bad and harmful to oneself; but what is beneficial and good is exceedingly difficult to do.
verses.commentary: 'Sukarāni' (easy to do) refers to 'asādhūni' (bad deeds) because they follow the path of least resistance—craving and anger. In contrast, 'sādhu' (the good) is 'paramadukkaraṃ' (extremely difficult) because it requires 'going against the stream' of one's own habits.

story.title: The Conflict between Devadatta and the Buddha
story.content: Devadatta, the Buddha's cousin, was a monk who allowed his ambition to lead him astray. He found it 'easy to do' (sukarāni) bad things—he plotted to kill the Buddha, caused a schism in the Sangha, and allied himself with the murderous King Ajātasattu. These 'harmful' (ahitāni) acts were easy for him because they were fueled by his own greed for power. However, he found it 'exceedingly difficult' (paramadukkaraṃ) to perform 'beneficial and good' (hitañca sādhu) acts like practicing humility or showing genuine compassion. The Buddha explained that the mind is like a slope; it is easy for a stone to roll down into the 'bad,' but it takes great effort to push it up into the 'good.' Devadatta’s life ended in tragedy as he was swallowed by the earth due to his heavy kamma. The Buddha used Devadatta's example to teach that we should not be surprised that 'evil' is common, as it is the 'easy' path. The 'difficult' path of virtue is the only one that leads to the summit of peace. This story teaches us to be wary of the 'easy' choice. If a path requires no discipline and feeds our ego, it is likely 'ahitāni' (harmful). We must be willing to engage in the 'difficult' labor of the 'sādhu' if we want to reach the goal of liberation.

verses.translation: The fool who, on account of his evil views, scorns the teaching of the Arahants and the Noble Ones who live according to the Dhamma, bears fruit only for his own destruction, like the bamboo that dies after bearing fruit.
verses.commentary: 'Dummedho' (the fool) is one who 'paccosati' (scorns/rejects) the 'sāsanaṃ' (teaching) due to 'pāpikaṃ diṭṭhiṃ' (evil/wrong views). Like the 'kaṭṭhakassa' (bamboo) that 'phullati' (flowers/bears fruit) and then immediately withers and dies, the fool's 'success' in argument or worldly power leads only to his 'attaghāñāya' (self-destruction).

story.title: The Story of the Monk Sunakkhatta
story.content: Sunakkhatta was a Licchavi prince who became a monk and served as the Buddha's personal attendant for some time. However, he was a 'fool' (dummedho) who was obsessed with 'wrong views' (pāpikaṃ diṭṭhiṃ). He wanted to see miracles and was disappointed when the Buddha focused on the 'teaching of the Arahants' (sāsanaṃ ara hataṃ)—the internal purification of the mind. He eventually 'scorned' the Buddha, disrobed, and began spreading false rumors that the Buddha's teaching was merely a product of reasoning and not of divine realization. The Buddha compared Sunakkhatta to a 'bamboo' tree (kaṭṭhakassa). A bamboo tree produces many seeds (fruit) all at once, and immediately after this 'flowering,' the entire plant dies. Sunakkhatta's 'flowering'—his vocal rejection and his brief fame as a critic—was actually the sign of his spiritual death. His 'fruit' was 'for his own destruction' (attaghāñāya). The Buddha explained that those who live 'according to the Dhamma' (dhammajīvinaṃ) grow slowly and steadily, like a great banyan tree, while the fool who rejects the truth for the sake of his ego burns out quickly. This story teaches that intellectual arrogance and 'wrong views' are the most dangerous forms of ignorance. By mocking the Noble Ones, Sunakkhatta ensured his own spiritual ruin, proving that the 'fruit' of a sharp tongue is often the 'death' of the heart.

verses.translation: By oneself is evil done; by oneself is one defiled. By oneself is evil left undone; by oneself is one purified. Purity and impurity depend on oneself; no one can purify another.
verses.commentary: This is the ultimate statement of 'Kammic Accountability.' 'Suddhi' (purity) and 'asuddhi' (impurity) are 'paccattaṃ' (individual/personal). The Buddha explicitly states 'nāñño aññaṃ visodhaye'—one cannot 'wash away' another's sins or grant them enlightenment.

story.title: The Story of the Brahmin who wanted to be Purified
story.content: A Brahmin once came to the Buddha and asked him to 'purify' him of his sins. He believed that by the Buddha's grace or through a special ritual performed by the Teacher, he could be made 'clean' (visujjhati). The Buddha spoke this verse to clear the Brahmin's confusion. He explained that 'evil is done by oneself' (attanā va kataṃ pāpaṃ) and therefore the 'defilement' (saṅkilissati) is internal. If you eat poison, no one else can feel the pain for you; similarly, if you act with hatred, your own mind is the one that becomes 'soiled.' Conversely, 'purity' (suddhi) comes from the 'evil left undone' (akataṃ pāpaṃ) by one's own choice. The Buddha emphasized that he was a 'Teacher' (Sātthā), not a 'Savior.' He can provide the map, but the walking must be done by the individual. 'No one can purify another' (nāñño aññaṃ visodhaye) because the 'stain' of the mind is not like dirt on the skin that can be washed off by water; it is a quality of intention. The Brahmin realized that he had been trying to 'outsource' his morality. He understood that his 'purity' was 'paccattaṃ' (dependent on himself). He began to take responsibility for his thoughts and actions, realizing that the Buddha's role was to inspire, but his own role was to transform. This story is the 'Declaration of Independence' for the Buddhist practitioner, placing the power of change firmly in the hands of the individual.

verses.pali:
Attadattham paratthena, bahunā pi na hāpaye;
Attadattham abhiññāya, sadatthapasuto siyā.
verses.translation: Let no one neglect one's own welfare for the sake of another, however great. Clearly understanding one's own welfare, let one be intent upon the true goal.
verses.commentary: 'Attadattham' (one's own welfare/goal) refers specifically to spiritual progress toward Nibbana. The verse warns not to 'hāpaye' (neglect) this even for 'paratthena' (another's welfare). This is not selfishness but the realization that one must 'have' peace before one can 'give' peace. One must be 'sadatthapasuto' (intent on the true goal).

story.title: The Story of Thera Attadattha
story.content: When the Buddha announced that he would pass away into Parinibbana in four months, thousands of monks flocked to him to pay their respects and spend time in his presence. However, one monk named Attadattha did not go. He thought, 'The Teacher is leaving us soon. I am not yet an Arhat. Instead of spending time in ceremonies and farewells, I should use every moment to reach the goal.' He went into a remote part of the forest and practiced meditation day and night. The other monks criticized him, calling him 'selfish' and 'uncaring' for 'neglecting' the communal farewell for the 'sake of his own goal.' When the Buddha heard of this, he called Attadattha and praised him in front of everyone. He explained that Attadattha had 'clearly understood his own welfare' (attadattham abhiññāya). The Buddha told the monks that the best way to honor a teacher is not through 'ceremonies' (paratthena), but by 'becoming' what the teacher taught. He said that a person who is 'intent upon the true goal' (sadatthapasuto) is the one who truly respects the Dhamma. He taught that you cannot save a drowning person if you are drowning yourself; therefore, securing your own 'welfare' (liberation) is the most compassionate thing you can do for the world. This story teaches that spiritual priority is essential. By 'not neglecting' his own practice, Attadattha became an Arhat before the Buddha passed away, proving that 'self-interest' in the Dhamma is the ultimate form of 'service.'

chapters.summary: This chapter explores the nature of the world as filled with attachment and illusion, teaching that through mindfulness and right view, one can transcend worldly suffering.

verses.pali:
Hīnaṁ dhammaṁ na seveyya, pamādena na saṁvase;
Micchādiṭṭhiṁ na seveyya, na siyā lokavaḍḍhano.
verses.translation: Do not follow inferior teachings; do not dwell in heedlessness. Do not embrace wrong views; do not be one who prolongs worldly existence.
verses.commentary: This verse warns against four dangers that perpetuate suffering: following ignoble ways (sensual indulgence), living heedlessly (without mindfulness), holding wrong views (denying karma and rebirth), and being attached to worldly existence (clinging to saṁsāra). 'Lokavaḍḍhana' literally means 'world-increaser' - one who, through attachment and wrong action, prolongs the cycle of rebirth for themselves and influences others negatively.

story.title: The Story of a Young Monk
story.content: A young monk was left at Visākhā's house while his teacher went elsewhere. Visākhā's granddaughter was filtering water, and when she saw her reflection in the pot, she smiled. The young monk, seeing her smile, also smiled at her. The girl became angry and shouted, 'You shaven-head! Why are you looking at me?' The monk felt humiliated and wanted to disrobe. When the Buddha heard this, he spoke this verse, advising the monk not to follow inferior ways (sensual attraction), not to be heedless, not to embrace wrong views, and not to increase worldly bondage.

verses.pali:
Uttiṭṭhe nappamajjeyya, dhammaṁ sucaritaṁ care;
Dhammacārī sukhaṁ seti, asmiṁ loke paramhi ca.
verses.translation: Arise! Do not be heedless! Follow the Dhamma and practice good conduct. One who lives by the Dhamma dwells happily in this world and the next.
verses.commentary: This verse provides the positive counterpart to the previous warning. 'Arise' (uttiṭṭhe) means to rouse oneself from spiritual lethargy. Living according to Dhamma and practicing good conduct brings happiness both now and in future lives. The happiness mentioned is not fleeting pleasure but the deep contentment that comes from ethical living and mental clarity.

story.title: Continuation of the Young Monk's Story
story.content: After speaking the previous verse, the Buddha encouraged the young monk with these words. He advised him to arise from his dejection, not to be heedless, and to practice the Dhamma with good conduct. The Buddha explained that those who live virtuously experience happiness in this very life through a clear conscience and peace of mind, and in future lives through favorable rebirths. The monk took this teaching to heart, renewed his commitment to practice, and eventually attained Arahantship.

verses.pali:
Dhammaṁ care sucaritaṁ, na naṁ duccaritaṁ care;
Dhammacārī sukhaṁ seti, asmiṁ loke paramhi ca.
verses.translation: Practice the Dhamma with good conduct; do not practice it with bad conduct. One who lives by the Dhamma dwells happily in this world and the next.
verses.commentary: This verse reinforces the previous one, emphasizing the difference between proper and improper practice. It's not enough merely to claim to follow the Dhamma - one must embody it through ethical conduct. 'Sucarita' (good conduct) means practicing in accordance with virtue, while 'duccarita' (bad conduct) means hypocritical or half-hearted practice. Authentic practice brings lasting happiness.

story.title: The Proper Way to Practice
story.content: Some monks claimed to practice Dhamma but their conduct was questionable - they were careless with precepts, spoke harshly, and showed little compassion. Other monks practiced diligently, maintaining strict ethical standards while cultivating wisdom and compassion. The Buddha observed both groups and spoke this verse to clarify that merely identifying as a practitioner is insufficient. Only those who practice the Dhamma with good conduct experience true happiness in this life and the next.

verses.pali:
Yathā pubbuḷakaṁ passe, yathā passe marīcikaṁ;
Evaṁ lokaṁ avekkhantaṁ, maccurājā na passati.
verses.translation: One who looks upon the world as a bubble and as a mirage - the King of Death does not see such a person.
verses.commentary: This verse teaches contemplation of impermanence and insubstantiality. A bubble appears solid but bursts at the slightest touch; a mirage appears real but vanishes on approach. Similarly, the world (meaning the five aggregates) appears substantial but is actually empty of inherent existence. One who truly perceives this is invisible to Māra, the King of Death, because such insight leads to liberation from the cycle of birth and death.

story.title: The Story of Five Hundred Monks
story.content: Five hundred monks took a meditation subject from the Buddha and went to the forest. Making little progress, they returned for a more suitable subject. On their way back, they saw a mirage and contemplated it. Upon entering the monastery, a storm broke out, forming bubbles from raindrops that quickly disappeared. The Buddha, knowing their thoughts, spoke this verse. Contemplating the world as bubble-like and mirage-like, all five hundred monks attained Arahantship, becoming invisible to the King of Death.

verses.pali:
Etha passathimaṁ lokaṁ, cittaṁ rājarathūpamaṁ;
Yattha bālā visīdanti, natthi saṅgo vijānataṁ.
verses.translation: Come and look at this world, which is like a decorated royal chariot. Here fools flounder, but the wise have no attachment to it.
verses.commentary: The world is compared to an ornate royal chariot - attractive on the surface but ultimately just a vehicle for suffering. Fools are dazzled by worldly attractions and become trapped in them ('visīdanti' - they flounder, sink, get stuck). The wise, seeing through the decoration to the true nature of things, remain unattached. They use the world without being enslaved by it.

story.title: The Story of Prince Abhaya
story.content: Prince Abhaya successfully suppressed a rebellion and was honored by King Bimbisāra for seven days with royal privileges and a dancer to entertain him. On the last day, while performing, the dancer suddenly had a stroke and died. The prince was shocked and distressed. He went to the Buddha, who explained that the world is like a decorated chariot - attractive but impermanent. Fools become attached and suffer when things change, but the wise remain free. Understanding this, Prince Abhaya attained stream-entry.

verses.pali:
Yo ca pubbe pamajjitvā, pacchā so nappamajjati;
Somaṁ lokaṁ pabhāseti, abbhā mutto va candimā.
verses.translation: One who was formerly heedless but later becomes heedful illuminates this world like the moon freed from clouds.
verses.commentary: This verse offers hope for reformation. No matter how heedlessly one has lived before, if they reform and practice diligently, they can shine brightly with wisdom and virtue. The simile of the moon emerging from clouds captures the dramatic transformation possible through dedicated practice. Past mistakes need not define one's future if genuine change occurs.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Aṅgulimāla
story.content: Aṅgulimāla was a notorious bandit who killed 999 people, collecting their fingers. After his encounter with the Buddha, he transformed completely, ordaining as a monk. Though people initially feared and hated him, his sincere practice and conduct eventually won respect. He attained Arahantship and became a shining example of transformation. The Buddha spoke this verse in reference to him and others who reformed their lives, showing that past heedlessness can be overcome by present diligence.

verses.pali:
Yassa pāpaṁ kataṁ kammaṁ, kusalena pithīyati;
Somaṁ lokaṁ pabhāseti, abbhā mutto va candimā.
verses.translation: One whose evil deed is obscured by wholesome action illuminates this world like the moon freed from clouds.
verses.commentary: This verse teaches that wholesome actions can counterbalance past unwholesome ones. While karma cannot be erased, performing abundant good deeds creates positive results that 'cover over' or outweigh negative karma. The transformation is so dramatic that the reformed person shines with virtue, like the moon's brightness overwhelms the memory of its eclipse. This encourages those burdened by past mistakes to actively cultivate goodness.

story.title: The Transformation Through Good Deeds
story.content: Many people who had committed various misdeeds in the past came to the Buddha seeking guidance. He taught them that while past actions have consequences, present wholesome actions are powerful. He encouraged them to practice generosity, maintain ethical conduct, and cultivate loving-kindness abundantly. Those who followed this advice found that their wholesome actions began to 'cover' their past evil, like the moon emerging from clouds. Their lives transformed, and they became respected members of the community, their past increasingly overshadowed by their present goodness.

verses.pali:
Andhabhūto ayaṁ loko, tanukettha vipassati;
Sakuṇo jālamutto va, appo saggāya gacchati.
verses.translation: Blind is this world; few here see clearly. Like birds escaping from a net, few go to the heavenly realm.
verses.commentary: Most people are 'blind' - they lack insight into the true nature of existence, living in ignorance of impermanence, suffering, and not-self. Very few develop the vision (vipassanā) to see things as they really are. The simile of birds and a net illustrates how rare escape from saṁsāra is - most remain trapped. Even rebirth in heaven is achieved by few, and liberation (which transcends even heaven) is rarer still.

story.title: The Rare Vision of Truth
story.content: The Buddha surveyed the world with his divine eye and saw countless beings wandering in darkness, blind to truth. Among millions, only a handful developed insight and escaped the net of saṁsāra. He compared humanity to birds caught in a vast net - most flutter helplessly within it, while very few find the openings and fly free. This observation inspired him to teach tirelessly, knowing that even if only a few understand, their liberation justifies the effort.

verses.pali:
Haṁsādiccapathe yanti, ākāse yanti iddhiyā;
Nīyanti dhīrā lokamhā, jetvā māraṁ savāhiniṁ.
verses.translation: Swans fly on the path of the sun; those with psychic powers travel through space. The wise are led away from the world, having conquered Māra and his army.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the image of swans flying toward the sun to symbolize spiritual ascent. While ordinary practitioners might develop psychic powers (iddhi), the truly wise transcend the world entirely by conquering Māra - representing all defilements and obstacles. 'Led away from the world' (nīyanti lokamhā) refers to liberation from saṁsāra. Having defeated Māra and his forces (the defilements), they are no longer bound to worldly existence.

story.title: The Story of Thirty Monks
story.content: Thirty monks came to pay homage to the Buddha. Venerable Ānanda, who was attending the Buddha, stepped out to give them privacy. After some time, he returned but found no one there. Puzzled, he asked the Buddha where the monks had gone. The Buddha replied that after hearing his discourse, all thirty had attained Arahantship. Using their psychic powers, they had departed through the air. The Buddha spoke this verse to explain that the wise, having conquered Māra, are led away from the world.

verses.pali:
Ekaṁ dhammaṁ atītassa, musāvādissa jantuno;
Vitiṇṇaparalokassa, natthi pāpaṁ akāriyaṁ.
verses.translation: For one who has violated the one principle of truthfulness, who speaks falsely and rejects the next world - there is no evil they would not do.
verses.commentary: This verse identifies lying as the gateway to all evil. One who lies has violated the fundamental principle of truthfulness, which underlies all ethics. Furthermore, if they deny rebirth and karma ('vitiṇṇaparaloka' - crossing beyond belief in the next world), they remove the final restraint on their behavior. Without regard for truth or consequences, such a person is capable of any wickedness. Truthfulness is thus presented as foundational to all moral conduct.

story.title: The Unrestrained Liar
story.content: A man developed the habit of lying for personal gain. At first, his lies were small, but as lying became easier, the lies grew larger. Eventually, he began denying the law of karma and the existence of future lives, thinking this freed him from moral constraints. With no regard for truth and no belief in consequences, he committed increasingly terrible acts without remorse. The Buddha used his example to teach this verse, showing that lying is the root that enables all other evils to flourish.

verses.translation: Truly, the miserly do not go to the heavenly realm. Fools indeed do not praise giving. But the wise person, rejoicing in giving, thereby becomes happy in the next world.
verses.commentary: Stinginess prevents rebirth in heaven because it stems from greed and creates no positive karma. Fools fail to appreciate the value of generosity, seeing it only as loss. The wise, however, understand that giving brings both immediate joy (the happiness of generosity) and future benefit (good rebirth). By delighting in giving rather than resenting it, they create the causes for future happiness. The verse encourages generosity as both immediately rewarding and karmically beneficial.

story.title: The Miser and the Generous Person
story.content: Two wealthy men lived in the same town. One was miserly, hoarding his wealth and giving nothing to anyone. The other was generous, regularly offering alms and helping those in need. When both died, the miser was reborn in a realm of suffering, while the generous man was reborn among the devas. The Buddha explained that the miser's attachment and lack of generosity prevented a fortunate rebirth, while the generous person's joy in giving created positive karma leading to happiness. This verse was spoken to encourage generosity.

verses.pali:
Pathavyā ekarajjena, saggassa gamanena vā;
Sabbalokādhipaccena, sotāpattiphalaṁ varaṁ.
verses.translation: Better than sole sovereignty over the earth, better than going to heaven, better than lordship over all worlds - is the fruit of stream-entry.
verses.commentary: This concluding verse of the chapter establishes the supreme value of spiritual attainment over worldly or even heavenly achievement. Stream-entry (sotāpatti) is the first stage of enlightenment, guaranteeing liberation within seven lives at most. This is declared superior to ruling the entire earth, being reborn in heaven, or having power over all realms. Why? Because worldly power is temporary and still within saṁsāra, while stream-entry marks irreversible progress toward complete liberation.

story.title: The Story of Anāthapiṇḍika's Son
story.content: Anāthapiṇḍika's son had no interest in the Dhamma. To encourage him, his father offered him a thousand pieces for each time he listened to the Buddha teach. Motivated by money, the son went and listened. Despite his initial materialistic motivation, the Buddha's teaching penetrated his heart, and he attained stream-entry during that very discourse. Afterward, his father offered him the promised money, but the son refused, saying, 'Father, no amount of wealth equals what I have gained today.' The Buddha then spoke this verse, explaining that stream-entry surpasses all worldly treasures and even heavenly rebirth.

chapters.summary: This chapter praises the qualities and teachings of the Buddha, describing the path to awakening and the characteristics of those who follow the Buddha's way.

verses.pali:
Yassa jitaṃ nāvajīyati, jitamassa noyāti koci loke;
Taṃ buddhamanantagocaraṃ, apadaṃ kena padena nessatha.
verses.translation: Whose victory is not turned into defeat, whose victory no one in this world can follow—by what track can you lead him, the Buddha of infinite range, the trackless?
verses.commentary: The Buddha's victory over defilements is 'nāvajīyati' (not subject to reversal). 'Anantagocaraṃ' means his mind has the entire universe as its range. He is 'apadaṃ' (trackless) because he has no 'pada' (footprints) of lust, hatred, or delusion that Mara can use to lead or track him.

story.title: The Temptation by the Daughters of Mara
story.content: After the Buddha attained enlightenment, Mara, the Tempter, was filled with despair at his failure to prevent it. However, his three daughters—Taṇhā (Craving), Arati (Aversion), and Ragā (Lust)—convinced their father that they could succeed where he failed. They approached the Buddha and used their supernatural powers to manifest themselves as thousands of beautiful women of all ages, attempting to arouse desire in him through various displays of charm and physical beauty. The Buddha remained as still as a mountain, his mind completely 'unshakable' (nāvajīyati). He told them that their efforts were in vain because he had already 'conquered' the very roots of desire. He explained that he was 'apadaṃ' (trackless); he had no mental 'footprints' for them to follow or exploit. A person is only vulnerable to temptation if they have a 'pada' of greed or pride remaining in their heart. Since the Buddha had extinguished all 'appetites' for existence, he was of 'infinite range' (anantagocaraṃ). The daughters of Mara eventually realized that they were trying to paint the sky or set fire to the ocean. They withdrew in shame, admitting that the Buddha's victory was absolute and 'could not be turned into defeat' by any worldly or celestial power. This story illustrates that the Buddha's state is one of complete 'internal immunity.' Because he no longer possesses the 'hooks' of ego and lust, the world has no way to 'lead' or influence him, proving that the highest freedom is to be 'trackless' in the midst of a world of traps.

verses.pali:
Yassa jālinī visattikā, taṇhā natthi kuhiñci netave;
Taṃ buddhamanantagocaraṃ, apadaṃ kena padena nessatha.
verses.translation: In whom there is no entangling, embroiled craving to lead him anywhere—by what track can you lead him, the Buddha of infinite range, the trackless?
verses.commentary: Craving is described as 'jālinī' (a net/entangler) and 'visattikā' (embroiled/clinging). In the Buddha, this force is 'natthi' (non-existent). Without the 'net' of craving, there is no mechanism to 'netave' (lead) him toward further birth.

story.title: Continuation of the Temptation of Mara's Daughters
story.content: As the daughters of Mara continued their attempts, they tried to use the 'net of craving' (jālinī) to entangle the Buddha's mind. They offered him not just physical beauty, but power, prestige, and the promise of celestial delights. They believed that everyone has a 'price' or a secret longing that can be used to 'lead' (netave) them back into the cycle of Samsara. The Buddha, however, revealed to them that he had completely 'shattered the net.' He explained that craving is like a sticky glue (visattikā) that binds the soul to objects; once that glue is removed, the soul is free to move in any direction—it becomes 'trackless' (apadaṃ). He pointed out that while the daughters themselves were trapped in the very net they tried to cast, he had transcended all 'wheres' and 'anywheres.' His mind was 'anantagocaraṃ'—boundless and infinite—making it impossible for their limited, finite charms to find a 'foothold.' The story emphasizes that the Buddha is not merely 'resisting' temptation; he is fundamentally 'un-temptable' because the part of the mind that 'wants' has been replaced by the part that 'knows.' Mara's daughters finally ceased their dance, realizing that the Buddha was no longer a 'person' who could be led, but an 'Awakened State' that existed beyond the reach of their entanglements. This verse serves as the final seal on his victory over the forces of desire, showing that the end of craving is the beginning of a freedom that the world cannot even comprehend, let alone track.

verses.pali:
Ye jhānapasutā dhīrā, nekkhammūpasame ratā;
Devāpi tesaṃ pihayanti, sambuddhasānaṃ satīmataṃ.
verses.translation: The wise who are devoted to meditation and who delight in the peace of renunciation—even the gods hold them dear, these mindful ones who are fully enlightened.
verses.commentary: 'Jhānapasutā' refers to those intensely devoted to meditative absorption. 'Nekkhammūpasame' is the peace that comes from 'stepping out' (renouncing) the worldly life. Such 'satīmataṃ' (mindful) beings are so rare and pure that even 'devāpi' (the gods) feel a sense of 'pihayanti' (longing/affection) for them.

story.title: The Buddha's Return from Tāvatiṃsa Heaven
story.content: After performing the Twin Miracle at Sāvatthi to silence the critics, the Buddha ascended to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven to teach the Abhidhamma to the deva who had been his mother in his previous life. He spent three months there, 'devoted to meditation' (jhānapasutā) and the 'peace of renunciation' (nekkhammūpasame). When it was time for him to return to earth, the gods of the thirty-three realms, including Sakka and Brahma, gathered to escort him. They built three magnificent ladders—one of gold, one of silver, and one of jewels—stretching from the heavens to the city of Saṅkassa. As the Buddha descended, surrounded by a radiant aura, thousands of people watched in awe. The Buddha explained to the monks that even the most powerful 'devās' (gods) 'hold dear' (pihayanti) those who have mastered their own minds. He taught that the gods do not worship wealth or power, but the 'mindfulness' (satīmataṃ) and 'wisdom' of the 'Fully Enlightened' (sambuddhasānaṃ). While humans often look to the gods for help, the gods look to the enlightened as their teachers and guides. This story illustrates the supreme status of the meditative life. By choosing the 'peace of renunciation' over the 'noise of the world,' the practitioner reaches a state so sublime that it attracts the respect of the entire universe. The Buddha’s descent from the heavens was a visible manifestation of the truth that spiritual achievement is the highest 'glory' recognized across all realms of existence.

verses.pali:
Kiccho manussapaṭilābho, kicchaṃ maccāna jīvitaṃ;
Kicchaṃ saddhammassavanaṃ, kiccho buddhānamuppādo.
verses.translation: Hard is it to be born as a human; hard is the life of mortals; hard is it to hear the True Dhamma; and hard is the arising of the Buddhas.
verses.commentary: The Buddha lists the four 'Kiccha' (difficulties/rarities). Human birth ('manussapaṭilābho') is rare; maintaining life ('jīvitaṃ') is precarious; finding the opportunity to 'hear the Dhamma' ('saddhammassavanaṃ') is statistically unlikely; and the birth of a Buddha ('buddhānamuppādo') occurs only once in eons.

story.title: The Story of Erakapatta the Naga King
story.content: Erakapatta was a powerful Naga (serpent) king who had been a monk in the time of the previous Buddha, Kassapa. Because of a minor infraction involving a blade of grass, he was reborn as a Naga, trapped in a long life of animal existence. He longed to be a human again so he could practice the Dhamma. For centuries, he waited for the 'arising of a Buddha' (buddhānamuppādo). He instructed his daughter to sing a specific song that could only be answered by someone with true wisdom. When he finally heard the Buddha Gotama had appeared, he rushed to see him, his massive serpent body creating waves in the river. The Buddha spoke this verse to him, explaining that Erakapatta should cherish the moment. He taught that 'hard is it to be born as a human' (kiccho manussapaṭilābho) because only in the human realm does one have the perfect balance of suffering and intelligence to seek liberation. He noted that even for those born as humans, life is 'hard' (kicchaṃ) and easily lost. Furthermore, even if one is alive, it is incredibly 'hard to hear the True Dhamma' (kicchaṃ saddhammassavanaṃ) because most people are distracted by worldly noise. Finally, the 'arising of a Buddha' is the rarest event in the cosmos. Erakapatta, realizing the immense value of the current opportunity, attained the first stage of enlightenment despite his serpent form. This story serves as a powerful call to urgency (samvega). It reminds us that we are currently experiencing four of the rarest conditions in the universe simultaneously, and to waste such an opportunity is the greatest possible loss.
