When the Buddha explained Anitthigandha's story to the monks, he taught this verse, explaining that the youth's previous existence in the Brahma realm, where he had lived free from sensual desires, had left a deep impression on him. The Buddha emphasized that sensual craving is a source of both grief and fear. Only when one is completely liberated from such desires can one experience true freedom from suffering. Anitthigandha's story demonstrated that freedom from sensual desire brings peace and happiness far superior to any pleasure the senses can provide.

verses.pali:
Taṇhāya jāyatī soko, taṇhāya jāyatī bhayaṃ;
Taṇhāya vippamuttassa, natthi soko kuto bhayaṃ.
verses.translation: From craving springs grief, from craving springs fear. For one who is wholly free from craving, there is no grief—whence then fear?
verses.commentary: This verse addresses 'taṇhā' (craving/thirst), the most fundamental form of attachment in Buddhist teaching. Taṇhā is identified as the second Noble Truth—the cause of all suffering. It includes craving for sensual pleasures (kāma-taṇhā), craving for existence (bhava-taṇhā), and craving for non-existence (vibhava-taṇhā). This deep-seated thirst drives the cycle of rebirth and perpetuates suffering. The complete eradication of craving is equivalent to attaining Nibbāna (Nirvana), the ultimate goal of Buddhist practice. When craving is extinguished, both grief and fear cease entirely, as there is nothing left to be desired, grasped, or feared losing.

story.title: The Story of a Brāhmin
story.content: While residing at the Jetavana Monastery, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to a Brāhmin who was a farmer. This Brāhmin held wrong views and was very attached to his farmland and crops. One day, he went to the bank of the river to work in his field. He was extremely proud of his extensive land holdings and had great expectations for a bountiful harvest. The Brāhmin had invested all his wealth and energy into his farming, and his entire sense of security and future happiness depended on the success of his crops. However, just when his crops were ready for harvest, a severe storm came with heavy rain and strong winds, completely destroying all his hard work. His fields were flooded, and all his crops were ruined. Overcome with grief at the loss of his anticipated harvest and wealth, and filled with fear about his future, the Brāhmin was in deep distress. Someone advised him to go see the Buddha, suggesting that the Buddha's teaching might bring him solace. Though initially reluctant due to his attachment to wrong views, the Brāhmin eventually went to the Jetavana Monastery. The Buddha, seeing his mental state, knew that he could be receptive to the Dhamma. The Buddha taught him this verse, explaining that his grief over the loss and his fear about the future both arose from his craving—his intense desire for wealth, success, and security through his farming. The Buddha explained that craving is the root cause of all suffering, and that as long as one is bound by craving, one cannot escape grief and fear. Only by freeing oneself from craving can one attain true peace and happiness, which are not dependent on external conditions. Understanding this teaching, the Brāhmin began to see the futility of his attachments and started to develop right view. He realized that his suffering was self-created through his craving and attachment, and this understanding set him on the path toward liberation.

verses.pali:
Sīladassanasampannaṃ, dhammaṭṭhaṃ saccavedinaṃ;
Attano kammakubbānaṃ, taṃ jano kurute piyaṃ.
verses.translation: One who is perfect in virtue and insight, established in the Dhamma, has realized the Truths, and fulfilled their duties—such a person is held dear by people.
verses.commentary: This verse presents the positive counterpart to the previous warnings about attachment. It describes the qualities of an ideal person—one who is morally pure (sīla), possesses wisdom and insight (dassana), is firmly established in the Dhamma, has realized the Four Noble Truths, and diligently performs their duties. Such a person naturally earns the respect, love, and esteem of others, not through manipulation or self-promotion, but through the inherent nobility of their character. This teaching shows that true worthiness of love comes not from seeking it, but from developing one's spiritual qualities. People naturally feel drawn to and hold dear those who embody these virtues.

story.title: The Story of Five Hundred Boys
story.content: While residing at the Veluvana Monastery in Rājagaha, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to five hundred boys. On a festival day, the Buddha entered the city of Rājagaha for alms, accompanied by a number of bhikkhus. On their way, they encountered five hundred boys who were on their way to a pleasure garden, carrying baskets of pancakes for their picnic. When the boys saw the Buddha and his monks, they paid their respects but did not offer anything to them. The Buddha said to his disciples, 'Bhikkhus, you shall eat those pancakes today. The owner is coming close behind us. We shall proceed only after taking some of these pancakes.' The monks were puzzled by this statement, as the boys had already passed by without offering anything. As they continued walking, they came upon the Venerable Mahā Kassapa, who was walking some distance behind them. The moment the boys saw Mahā Kassapa, they were immediately filled with devotion and joy. They quickly approached him with great respect, and without any prompting, offered him all their pancakes, keeping nothing for themselves. Elder Kassapa, knowing the Buddha's prediction, advised the boys to go back and offer the pancakes to the Buddha and the Sangha who were sitting nearby waiting. The boys gladly did so, and the Buddha and his disciples accepted and ate the pancakes. Some monks were puzzled and even slightly annoyed that the boys had shown such favoritism toward Elder Kassapa and not toward the Buddha or the other monks. They mentioned this to the Buddha, questioning why the boys had not been initially inspired to make offerings but only when they saw Kassapa. The Buddha explained that this was due to the special qualities of Elder Kassapa. He told them that Mahā Kassapa was perfect in virtue and insight, firmly established in the Dhamma, had realized all the Truths, and was diligent in fulfilling all his duties. The Buddha said that even the devas (celestial beings) held Kassapa dear because of these qualities. The Buddha then spoke this verse, explaining that a person who possesses such virtues naturally inspires love and devotion in others—not because they seek it, but because the purity and nobility of their character naturally draws people to them. This teaching helped the monks understand that true spiritual attainment manifests in ways that naturally inspire others, and that worthiness of respect comes from inner development, not from external status or position.

verses.pali:
Chandajāto anakkhāte, manasā ca phuṭo siyā;
Kāmesu ca appaṭibaddhacitto, uddhaṃsoto ti vuccati.
verses.translation: One who has developed a desire for the ineffable (Nibbāna), whose mind is inspired by it, and whose consciousness is not bound to sensual pleasures—such a person is called 'one bound upstream.'
verses.commentary: This verse describes someone who has developed a strong aspiration for Nibbāna, the ultimate reality that cannot be adequately described in words (anakkhāta). Their mind is deeply touched by and oriented toward this transcendent goal. Most importantly, their consciousness is no longer entangled in sensual desires. Such a practitioner is called 'uddhaṃsota' (bound upstream) because they are swimming against the current of worldly existence, heading toward liberation rather than being carried downstream by craving and ignorance. This refers specifically to Anāgāmis (Non-returners), those who have reached the third stage of enlightenment and will not return to the sensual realm but will achieve final liberation in the higher heavens.

story.title: The Story of an Anāgāmi Venerable
story.content: While residing at the Jetavana Monastery, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to a bhikkhu who had attained the fruit of Anāgāmi (Non-returner), the third stage of enlightenment. This venerable monk had been practicing diligently for many years. Through his sustained effort in meditation and mindfulness, he had gradually overcome the five lower fetters that bind beings to the sensual realm: identity view, doubt, attachment to rites and rituals, sensual desire, and ill-will. Having completely eradicated these fetters, he had attained the state of Anāgāmi. Other monks noticed a remarkable change in this bhikkhu. He seemed to radiate a special kind of peace and contentment. His eyes reflected a deep inner joy, and his demeanor showed complete equanimity in all situations. He was no longer affected by sensual attractions or aversions—his mind remained perfectly balanced whether he encountered pleasant or unpleasant experiences. The monks were curious about this transformation and asked the Buddha about it. The Buddha explained that this bhikkhu had developed an intense desire for Nibbāna, the ineffable state beyond all conditioned existence. His mind had been deeply touched by the reality of this supreme peace, and as a result, his consciousness was no longer bound to sensual pleasures. The Buddha explained that such a person is called 'uddhaṃsota' (bound upstream) because, unlike ordinary beings who are carried downstream by the currents of craving and become, this practitioner was swimming against the current, heading toward complete liberation. The Buddha further clarified that this bhikkhu, having become an Anāgāmi, would not be reborn again in the sensual realm. Even if he did not attain full Arahatship in this life, he would be reborn in the Pure Abodes (Suddhāvāsa), celestial realms accessible only to Anāgāmis, where he would definitely attain final Nibbāna without ever returning to the human world. This teaching inspired the other monks to intensify their own practice, understanding that such liberation was indeed possible through diligent effort and proper practice of the Dhamma.

verses.pali:
Cirappavāsiṃ purisaṃ, dūrato sotthim āgataṃ;
Ñātimittā suhajjā ca, abhinandanti āgataṃ.
verses.translation: When a person has been long absent and returns safely from afar, their relatives, friends, and well-wishers welcome them joyfully upon arrival.
verses.commentary: This verse uses a beautiful simile to illustrate the karmic results of good deeds. Just as family and friends rejoice when a beloved person returns home safely after a long absence abroad, so too will the fruits of one's meritorious actions welcome the doer of good deeds when they pass from this life to the next. This teaching emphasizes that our actions create consequences that follow us beyond death, and that good karma acts as a friend and protector in future existences. The verse creates a warm, relatable image that helps listeners understand the abstract concept of karmic results in concrete, emotional terms.

story.title: The Story of Nandiya (Part 1)
story.content: While residing at the Isipatana wood near Benares, the Buddha spoke verses 219 and 220 with reference to Nandiya, a wealthy man from Benares. Nandiya was an extremely devout and generous supporter of the Buddha and the Sangha. He was known throughout Benares for his charitable nature and his deep faith in the Triple Gem (Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha). One day, after listening to the Buddha's discourse on the great benefits and merit of building monasteries for the Sangha, Nandiya was deeply inspired. He decided that he would undertake such a project as his greatest offering. Consulting with the Buddha and the senior monks about what would be most beneficial, Nandiya began planning and overseeing the construction of a large and beautiful monastery. He spared no expense in this endeavor, using the finest materials and employing the best craftsmen. The monastery, which came to be known as the Mahāvihāra (Great Monastery), was built on a spacious plot of land at Isipatana. It included living quarters for many monks, a hall for Dhamma talks, meditation spaces, and all necessary facilities for the monastic community. Throughout the construction, Nandiya personally supervised the work, ensuring that everything was done with the utmost care and devotion. He viewed this not merely as a construction project, but as a sacred offering to the Buddha and a gift to future generations of spiritual seekers. After several months of dedicated effort, the monastery was finally completed. It stood magnificent and serene, a testament to Nandiya's faith and generosity. The day arrived for the formal dedication ceremony.

verses.pali:
Tath'eva katapuññam pi, asmā lokā paraṃ gataṃ;
Puññāni paṭigaṇhanti, piyaṃ ñātiṃ 'va āgataṃ.
verses.translation: Likewise, when one who has performed meritorious deeds goes from this world to the next, one's good deeds receive them there, just as relatives welcome a dear one on their return.
verses.commentary: This verse completes the simile begun in verse 219, drawing the explicit parallel between the joyful homecoming and the karmic reception in the afterlife. Just as loving relatives eagerly await and warmly welcome a returning family member, our accumulated merit (puñña) awaits us in the next existence, ready to provide favorable conditions and happiness. This teaching provides comfort and motivation: our good deeds are not lost or wasted but accompany us beyond death, creating the foundation for future happiness and progress on the spiritual path. The verse emphasizes the continuity of karma across lifetimes and the importance of performing good deeds as preparation for future existences.

story.title: The Story of Nandiya (Part 2)
story.content: On the day of the dedication ceremony for the Mahāvihāra monastery, Nandiya invited the Buddha and a large gathering of monks to receive the offering. After the Buddha and the Sangha had taken their meal, Nandiya performed the traditional water-pouring ceremony (dakkhiṇodaka) to formally dedicate the monastery to the Sangha for perpetual use. At the very moment when Nandiya poured the libation water as an act of dedication, something extraordinary happened in the celestial realms. In Tāvatiṃsa, the heaven of the Thirty-Three Gods, a magnificent palace suddenly arose, surrounded by beautiful celestial nymphs and filled with all manner of divine pleasures. The palace appeared spontaneously, as if by magic, gleaming with jewels and adorned with every conceivable luxury. The Venerable Moggallāna, who possessed supernormal powers including the ability to visit celestial realms, happened to be visiting Tāvatiṃsa at that time. Seeing this newly appeared palace, he was curious about its origin. Using his divine eye, he investigated to discover for whom this celestial mansion had arisen. The deities of Tāvatiṃsa told him, 'Venerable Sir, this palace has arisen for Nandiya, the generous donor from Benares who has just dedicated the Mahāvihāra monastery to the Sangha. This palace will be his dwelling place when he passes away from the human world and is reborn here among us. His meritorious deed of building and offering the monastery has created this magnificent result.' When Venerable Moggallāna returned to the human realm, he reported this wonderful occurrence to the Buddha and the assembled monks. The Buddha confirmed that this was indeed true, and then spoke these two verses (219-220) to illustrate the principle of karmic results. The Buddha explained that just as relatives, friends, and well-wishers joyfully welcome a loved one who returns safely home after a long journey abroad, so too do one's good deeds welcome the doer of merit when they pass from this life to the next existence. The meritorious deeds performed in this life create favorable conditions and happiness in future lives, just as Nandiya's generous act of building the monastery had created a celestial palace awaiting him in Tāvatiṃsa. The Buddha emphasized that our good deeds accompany us like faithful friends, providing protection and creating favorable circumstances in future existences. This teaching greatly inspired both lay supporters and monks, showing them the concrete results of generosity and virtue, and encouraging them to continue accumulating merit through good deeds.

chapters.summary: This chapter addresses the destructive nature of anger and teaches the cultivation of patience, loving-kindness, and the abandonment of resentment.

verses.pali:
Kodhaṃ jahe vippajaheyya mānaṃ,
Saṃyojanaṃ sabbam atikkameyya;
Taṃ nāmarūpasmiṃ asajjamānaṃ,
Akiñcanaṃ nānupatanti dukkhā.
verses.translation: One should give up anger, abandon conceit, and overcome all fetters. Suffering does not befall one who clings not to mind and body, who is free from attachment and possesses nothing.
verses.commentary: This verse presents three major obstacles to spiritual progress that must be overcome: anger (kodha), conceit or pride (māna), and all fetters or bonds (saṃyojana). The ten fetters that bind beings to the cycle of existence are: belief in a permanent self, doubt, attachment to rites and rituals, sensual desire, ill-will, craving for fine-material existence, craving for immaterial existence, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance. When one is free from clinging to name-and-form (nāmarūpa, representing the five aggregates), and possesses nothing in the sense of not being attached to anything, suffering cannot touch such a person. The verse emphasizes that true freedom comes from non-attachment rather than mere renunciation of possessions.

story.title: The Story of Princess Rohini
story.content: While residing at the Nigrodharama Monastery in Kapilavatthu, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to Princess Rohini, the sister of Venerable Anuruddha. On one occasion, Venerable Anuruddha visited Kapilavatthu and stayed at the monastery there. All his relatives came to see him except his sister Rohini. When he inquired about her absence, he learned that Rohini was suffering from leprosy and did not come out of shame for her condition. Hearing this, Venerable Anuruddha sent for her. Rohini came with her head covered, ashamed of her disfiguring disease. Venerable Anuruddha advised her to perform meritorious deeds to overcome her karmic affliction. He suggested that she should sell some of her clothing and jewelry and use the money to build a refectory (dining hall) for the monks. Rohini agreed and also asked other relatives to help with the construction. When the refectory was completed, the Buddha and his disciples were invited to receive the offering. After the Buddha and the Sangha had taken their meal, Rohini performed the traditional water-pouring ceremony to formally dedicate the merit of the refectory to the Sangha. At that very moment, her leprosy vanished completely and her skin became smooth and golden. The Buddha then explained that Rohini's leprosy had been caused by anger and hatred she had harbored in a previous existence. In a past life, she had been the chief queen of a king. When the king showed favor to another woman, Rohini became intensely jealous and angry. In her rage, she secretly applied a paste containing poisonous substances to the body of her rival, causing her great suffering and disfigurement. As a result of that evil deed born of anger, Rohini had to suffer from leprosy in this life. The Buddha spoke this verse to teach that anger, conceit, and all fetters must be abandoned, and that suffering befalls those who cling to the five aggregates of existence. For one who is free from such clinging and attachment, suffering does not arise.

verses.pali:
Yo ve uppatitaṃ kodhaṃ,
Rathaṃ bhantaṃva vāraye;
Tam ahaṃ sārathiṃ brūmi,
Rasmiggāho itaro jano.
verses.translation: One who restrains arising anger like a charioteer restrains a swerving chariot, that one I call a true charioteer. Others merely hold the reins.
verses.commentary: This verse uses a powerful simile comparing anger control to chariot driving. Just as a skilled charioteer must quickly control a chariot that begins to veer off course, so must a practitioner immediately check anger when it arises. The verse distinguishes between someone who merely goes through the motions (holding the reins) and a true master who has genuine control. In the same way, merely claiming to be on the spiritual path is not enough—one must actually develop the ability to control negative emotions when they arise. This requires mindfulness, quick recognition of anger when it emerges, and the wisdom to let it go before it takes hold. The image emphasizes both the urgency and the skill required in managing one's emotions.

story.title: The Story of a Monk and the Tree Deity
story.content: While residing at the Aggālava Stupa in the city of Ālavi, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to a monk who was building a dwelling. Once, a monk from Ālavi decided to build a small dwelling (kuti) for himself. He selected a suitable spot and began cutting down a tree to use the timber for his construction. Unknown to him, a tree deity (rukkha devatā) and her infant son lived in that very tree. When the deity saw the monk preparing to cut down her home, she approached him and pleaded, 'Venerable Sir, please do not cut down this tree. My young son and I live here, and if you destroy this tree, we will have no place to go.' However, the monk, intent on his purpose and perhaps not fully considering the consequences, ignored her plea and continued with his work. The desperate deity, seeing that words would not stop him, decided on a different approach. She quickly placed her infant son on one of the branches, hoping that when the monk saw the child, he would stop his work out of compassion. By this time, however, the monk had already raised his axe and was bringing it down with full force. He could not stop the swing in time, and tragically, the axe struck the branch where the child sat, severing the infant's arm. The tree deity was overwhelmed with grief and anger at the loss of her child's arm. In her rage, she wanted to kill the monk immediately for what he had done. She had the power to do so, and her anger was intense. However, at that critical moment, she restrained herself. She reflected on the consequences of her potential action: 'If I kill this monk in anger, I will have to suffer in hell for a very long time. Moreover, if I, a deity, set the example of killing a monk, other deities might follow my example and also harm or kill monks in the future, which would be disastrous for the Sangha and the Dhamma.' Having controlled her anger through this wise reflection, the deity instead went to the Buddha and reported what had happened. She explained the entire incident and how she had restrained her anger despite her intense grief and provocation. The Buddha greatly praised the tree deity for her remarkable self-control. He explained that controlling anger when it arises is extremely difficult, especially when one has been wronged, but it is one of the most important practices on the path to liberation. He then spoke this verse, explaining that one who can restrain arising anger like a skilled charioteer controls a swerving chariot is a true master of the mind. Others who cannot control their anger merely go through the motions of spiritual practice without true mastery. On hearing this discourse, the tree deity attained the first stage of enlightenment (Stream-entry). The Buddha, in his compassion, pointed out an empty tree near his Perfumed Chamber at Jetavana Monastery, and the deity and her injured son took up residence there, where they would be safe and cared for.

verses.pali:
Akkodhena jine kodhaṃ,
Asādhuṃ sādhunā jine;
Jine kadariyaṃ dānena,
Saccenālikavādinaṃ.
verses.translation: Conquer anger with non-anger (loving-kindness); conquer wickedness with goodness; conquer miserliness with generosity; conquer the liar with truth.
verses.commentary: This verse presents four fundamental principles for overcoming negative qualities with their opposites—a key teaching in Buddhist practice. First, anger should be conquered not with more anger (which only perpetuates conflict) but with loving-kindness (mettā) and patience. Second, wickedness or evil is overcome through goodness and virtue. Third, miserliness or stinginess is conquered through generosity and giving. Fourth, falsehood is conquered through truthfulness. These four principles represent the practice of opposing forces—cultivating positive qualities to overcome negative ones. This is more effective than mere suppression, as it actually transforms the mind. The verse teaches that we should not fight fire with fire, but rather water the fire with its opposite quality.

story.title: The Story of Uttarā the Lay Disciple
story.content: While residing at the Veluvana Monastery in Rājagaha, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to Uttarā, a female lay disciple and the daughter of a poor laborer. Uttarā was the daughter of a man named Puṇṇa and his wife, who worked as hired laborers for a wealthy man named Sumana in Rājagaha. The family was extremely poor and lived a difficult life. One day, an extraordinary event occurred that would change their fortunes. Venerable Sāriputta had just emerged from a deep meditative absorption called nirodha samāpatti (cessation attainment), which he had maintained for seven consecutive days. Upon arising from this profound meditation, he wished to bestow a blessing on someone deserving. Through his psychic powers, he perceived that Puṇṇa and his family had the potential to benefit greatly from an act of generosity toward him. Early in the morning, Venerable Sāriputta went to the field where Puṇṇa was working. He stood near a bush, waiting silently. Puṇṇa, seeing the Elder, immediately felt great reverence. Though he had very little, he wanted to offer something. He cut some branches from the bush to offer as tooth-sticks (dental cleaners) to the Elder. He then took the Elder's water filter and offered him clean, filtered water to drink. Venerable Sāriputta waited a little while longer until Puṇṇa's wife set out from home, carrying her husband's meager lunch. When she saw Venerable Sāriputta on the path, she immediately understood that this was a rare opportunity to make merit. Despite knowing that her husband would go hungry, she offered all the rice she had brought to the Elder. Puṇṇa fully supported his wife's decision, understanding the great value of offering alms to such a holy person, even though it meant he would have no food for the day. Venerable Sāriputta accepted the offering and departed. That very day, miraculous events began to unfold. While Puṇṇa was plowing the field, his plow struck something hard beneath the soil. Upon investigation, he discovered it was a huge pot filled with gold and precious treasures. Overjoyed, he reported this find to his employer, Sumana, and to the king. The king, impressed by Puṇṇa's honesty and recognizing the karmic significance of the discovery, declared that the treasure belonged to Puṇṇa. Overnight, the family went from poverty to great wealth. In their newfound prosperity, the family did not forget the Dhamma. They became devoted supporters of the Buddha and the Sangha. On one occasion, Puṇṇa's family offered alms to the Buddha and a large gathering of monks for seven consecutive days. Their daughter Uttarā grew up in this environment of devotion and generosity. She became known for her gentle nature, patience, and kindness. Later, Uttarā was employed as a maid by a wealthy but cruel mistress. This mistress had a terrible temper and would often physically abuse her servants. One day, the mistress became angry with Uttarā over some trivial matter. In her rage, she took a pot of boiling rice gruel and poured it over Uttarā's head, causing severe burns. Despite the excruciating pain and the grave injustice done to her, Uttarā did not become angry. She did not shout at her mistress, curse her, or even harbor ill will toward her. Instead, she maintained her equanimity and compassion, reflecting on the law of karma and understanding that anger would only create more suffering for both herself and her mistress. Uttarā's extraordinary response—or rather, her lack of an angry response—became widely known. When the Buddha heard of this incident, he praised Uttarā highly for her ability to conquer anger with non-anger, evil with good. He explained that this is the path of the wise—to respond to negativity not with more negativity, but with its opposite positive quality. The Buddha then spoke this verse, teaching that anger should be conquered with loving-kindness, wickedness with goodness, stinginess with generosity, and lies with truth. Uttarā's example demonstrated the supreme power of patience and loving-kindness in the face of the most severe provocation.

verses.pali:
Saccaṃ bhaṇe na kujjheyya,
Dajjā appampi yācito;
Etehi tīhi ṭhānehi,
Gacche devāna santike.
verses.translation: Speak the truth; do not yield to anger; when asked, give even if you have only a little. By these three means, one may reach the presence of the gods.
verses.commentary: This verse identifies three practices that lead to a fortunate rebirth in the heavenly realms: speaking truth, abandoning anger, and practicing generosity even with limited resources. These three qualities—truthfulness, patience, and generosity—are fundamental virtues in Buddhism. Speaking truth builds trust and maintains social harmony while purifying one's own mind. Not yielding to anger preserves peace and prevents the accumulation of negative karma. Giving even when one has little demonstrates genuine generosity of spirit, as it's easy to give when one has abundance, but true generosity is shown when giving involves personal sacrifice. Together, these three practices create the karmic conditions for rebirth in happy states and progress on the spiritual path. The verse emphasizes that spiritual progress requires consistent practice of virtue in daily life.

story.title: The Story of the Question Raised by Venerable Mahā Moggallāna
story.content: While residing at the Jetavana Monastery, the Buddha spoke this verse in response to a question raised by Venerable Mahā Moggallāna, who possessed great supernormal powers. Venerable Mahā Moggallāna was renowned for his psychic abilities, particularly his power to visit various celestial and hell realms and to perceive the karmic causes of beings' rebirths. On one occasion, he visited Tāvatiṃsa, the heaven of the Thirty-Three Gods, to observe the conditions there and understand what karmic actions led to rebirth in such fortunate circumstances. While in Tāvatiṃsa, Venerable Moggallāna encountered many celestial beings (devas) living in magnificent palaces, surrounded by incredible luxury and beauty. Each mansion was adorned with precious jewels, filled with divine music, and attended by celestial nymphs. The devas themselves were radiant, happy, and free from the suffering common in the human realm. Curious about what meritorious actions had led to such fortunate rebirths, Venerable Moggallāna approached several devas and asked them about their past good deeds. To his surprise, he found that the answers varied greatly, and some were quite simple and modest. One particular deva told Venerable Moggallāna that he had been reborn in Tāvatiṃsa not because he had given away vast amounts of wealth in charity, not because he had listened to many Dhamma discourses, and not because he had performed elaborate religious ceremonies. Instead, he had been reborn as a deva simply because, throughout his human life, he had always spoken the truth. In every situation, no matter how difficult or tempting it might have been to lie, he had maintained his commitment to truthfulness. This single virtue—speaking truth—had been powerful enough to earn him rebirth in the celestial realm. Another deva whom Venerable Moggallāna met was a female celestial being of extraordinary beauty. When asked about her past good deeds, she explained that in her previous life as a human, she had been a servant girl who was frequently mistreated by her master. He would often beat her, scold her harshly, and heap abuse upon her for even minor mistakes. Despite this cruel treatment, she had never allowed anger to arise in her heart toward her master. She never harbored ill will or hatred toward him, never wished him harm, and never retaliated with angry words or deeds. She simply endured with patience and maintained her equanimity. This practice of conquering anger and maintaining loving-kindness, even under severe provocation, had been sufficient to cause her rebirth in the deva world. Yet another deva shared that while he had not been wealthy in his human life, whenever anyone asked him for help, he would give whatever little he had. Even if he possessed only a small amount of food, a modest piece of cloth, or a little money, he would share it willingly when requested. He never turned away those who asked for help, even though his gifts were small. This generous spirit, this willingness to give even from his poverty, had resulted in his celestial rebirth. When Venerable Moggallāna returned to the human realm, he shared these remarkable stories with the Buddha and the assembly of monks. The Buddha confirmed that these accounts were true and used this opportunity to teach this verse. The Buddha explained that these three practices—speaking truth, abandoning anger, and giving even when one has little—are powerful means of accumulating merit and creating the karmic conditions for rebirth among the devas. He emphasized that one does not need to perform grand or elaborate good deeds to attain fortunate rebirths. Rather, these simple but profound virtues, practiced consistently in daily life, are sufficient to lead one to the presence of the gods. The teaching particularly emphasizes the third quality—giving even when one has little—because it demonstrates genuine generosity. Anyone can give when they have abundance, but to give when one has barely enough for oneself shows true compassion and detachment. This teaching inspired many in the assembly to cultivate these three virtues more earnestly in their own lives.

verses.pali:
Ahiṃsakā ye munayo,
Niccaṃ kāyena saṃvutā;
Te yanti accutaṃ ṭhānaṃ,
Yattha gantvā na socare.
verses.translation: Those sages who are harmless and are always restrained in body reach the deathless state (Nibbāna), where, having gone, they do not grieve.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the characteristics and destiny of true sages (munayo). The key qualities mentioned are non-harmfulness (ahiṃsaka) and constant restraint of body (kāyena saṃvutā). Non-harmfulness means not causing injury or suffering to any living being through one's actions. Restraint of body means controlling one's physical actions to avoid misconduct such as killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct. These sages reach the 'deathless state' (accutaṃ ṭhānaṃ), which refers to Nibbāna—the ultimate goal of Buddhist practice. Nibbāna is called 'deathless' because it is beyond birth and death, beyond the cycle of rebirth. Once one reaches this state, there is no more grief or sorrow because all causes of suffering have been eliminated. The verse emphasizes that physical restraint and non-violence are essential practices for those seeking liberation.

story.title: The Story of the Brāhmin Who Had Been the Buddha's Father
story.content: While residing at the Jetavana Monastery, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to a Brāhmin who, in a past existence, had been the Buddha's father. This Brāhmin was very old, and throughout his long life, he had lived virtuously according to Brāhmin customs and traditions. He had always practiced non-violence, had been generous to those in need, and had maintained strict control over his actions, speech, and thoughts. He had never killed any living being, had never spoken harshly or falsely, and had kept his body pure through disciplined conduct. Despite his virtuous life, the Brāhmin held wrong views about the ultimate nature of reality and the path to liberation. He believed in the efficacy of Brāhmin rituals and sacrifices for attaining spiritual purity and a fortunate rebirth. He had not yet encountered the Buddha's teaching and did not understand the Four Noble Truths or the Noble Eightfold Path. As he approached the end of his life, the Brāhmin became anxious about his future existence. He had heard about the Buddha, who was renowned throughout the land as a fully enlightened teacher, and decided to visit him. Despite his advanced age and physical weakness, he made his way to the Jetavana Monastery, hoping to receive some spiritual guidance before his death. When the Brāhmin arrived at the monastery, the Buddha received him kindly. Using his supernormal knowledge, the Buddha perceived the karmic connection between them—that in a previous existence, this Brāhmin had been his father. The Buddha also saw that the Brāhmin had accumulated tremendous merit through his virtuous conduct throughout his life, particularly through his unwavering practice of non-violence and physical restraint. The Buddha knew that with proper guidance, this old Brāhmin could attain liberation in this very life. The Buddha began teaching the Brāhmin about the Dhamma. He explained the nature of suffering, its cause, its cessation, and the path leading to its cessation. He taught about the impermanent nature of all conditioned things, the unsatisfactory nature of existence, and the non-self nature of all phenomena. As the Brāhmin listened with complete attention and an open mind, the Dhamma penetrated his heart. His wrong views fell away like scales from his eyes, and he began to see reality as it truly is. The Buddha then explained that the Brāhmin's lifelong practice of harmlessness (ahiṃsā) and bodily restraint had created excellent conditions for spiritual realization. These virtues had purified his mind and made it receptive to the profound truths of the Dhamma. The Buddha emphasized that such practices were not ends in themselves but were essential foundations for the development of wisdom and the attainment of Nibbāna. As the Buddha continued his teaching, the old Brāhmin's understanding deepened. His mind became increasingly clear and focused. Finally, comprehending the Four Noble Truths fully and directly, he attained Arahatship—the complete liberation from all defilements and the cycle of rebirth. The Brāhmin, now an Arahant, was filled with profound peace and gratitude. He had reached the 'deathless state,' the ultimate goal of spiritual practice. At that very place where he had been sitting, listening to the Buddha's teaching, he passed away peacefully, entering final Nibbāna (Parinibbāna). There was no grief, no fear, no anxiety—only complete peace. When the Buddha announced to the assembly of monks that the old Brāhmin had attained Arahatship and passed into final Nibbāna, some monks expressed wonder at how someone could attain such lofty realization so quickly, in what seemed to be his first encounter with the Dhamma. The Buddha explained that this was due to the Brāhmin's perfection in harmlessness and bodily restraint, cultivated over his entire life. These virtues had purified his mind and prepared it for the direct realization of truth. The Buddha then spoke this verse, teaching that those sages who are harmless and constantly restrained in body reach the deathless state of Nibbāna, where, having gone, they grieve no more. This teaching emphasized the critical importance of virtue and physical restraint as the foundation for spiritual progress and ultimate liberation.

verses.pali:
Sadā jāgaramānānaṃ,
Ahorattānusikkhinaṃ;
Nibbānaṃ adhimuttānaṃ,
Atthaṃ gacchanti āsavā.
verses.translation: For those who are always vigilant, who train themselves day and night, and who are intent on attaining Nibbāna, the mental defilements come to an end.
verses.commentary: This verse highlights three essential qualities for spiritual progress: constant vigilance (sadā jāgara), continuous practice day and night (ahoratta anusikkhinaṃ), and firm determination to attain Nibbāna (nibbāna adhimuttānaṃ). Vigilance means maintaining mindfulness and awareness of one's body, feelings, mind, and mental objects at all times. Training day and night indicates continuous effort in meditation, moral discipline, and the development of wisdom. Being intent on Nibbāna means having unwavering commitment to liberation as the highest goal. When these three conditions are met, the āsavās (mental defilements or intoxicants) gradually diminish and eventually cease. The āsavās are sensual desire (kāmāsava), desire for existence (bhavāsava), wrong view (diṭṭhāsava), and ignorance (avijjāsava). Their complete eradication marks the attainment of Arahatship.

story.title: The Story of Puṇṇā the Slave Girl
story.content: While residing at the Jetavana Monastery, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to Puṇṇā, a female slave who exhibited extraordinary diligence in both her work and spiritual practice. Puṇṇā was a slave girl who worked for a wealthy household in Sāvatthi. Her life was one of hard labor and long hours, with little rest. Despite her difficult circumstances and low social status, Puṇṇā had a naturally pure heart and a deep inclination toward spiritual matters. When she learned about the Buddha's teachings, she was immediately drawn to them. However, as a slave, Puṇṇā had almost no free time to visit the monastery, listen to Dhamma teachings, or practice meditation. Her mistress kept her constantly busy with household chores from early morning until late at night. Yet Puṇṇā was determined not to let her circumstances prevent her from walking the spiritual path. She made a firm resolution to practice the Dhamma with whatever time and opportunity she had, no matter how limited. Puṇṇā adopted an extraordinary approach to her practice. She decided that she would remain mindful and vigilant every single moment, turning her daily work itself into meditation practice. While fetching water, she contemplated impermanence. While sweeping, she practiced mindfulness of body movements. While cooking, she observed the arising and passing away of phenomena. In her mind, she continuously recollected the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha, taking refuge in the Triple Gem. At night, when her mistress finally allowed her to sleep, Puṇṇā would rest for only a few hours. She would wake up in the middle of the night and practice meditation while others were sleeping. Even during her brief rest periods, she would remain mindful, using every moment for spiritual development. She practiced walking meditation while going about her duties, sitting meditation whenever she had a spare moment, and maintained continuous mindfulness throughout the day and night. Puṇṇā's determination was absolute. She reflected constantly on the suffering inherent in the cycle of birth and death, and she set her mind firmly on attaining Nibbāna as the only true refuge. She understood that her current status as a slave was the result of past karma, but she also knew that through diligent practice, she could create the causes for liberation. Her aspiration for Nibbāna became so strong that it pervaded every moment of her existence. Through this continuous, unwavering practice—training day and night, maintaining constant vigilance, and keeping Nibbāna as her ultimate goal—Puṇṇā gradually purified her mind. The defilements of greed, hatred, and delusion began to weaken. Her mindfulness became sharper, her concentration deeper, and her wisdom clearer. One day, after months or perhaps years of this intensive practice integrated into her daily slave labor, Puṇṇā attained the first stage of enlightenment (Stream-entry or Sotāpanna). This meant that she had eradicated the first three fetters: belief in a permanent self, doubt about the Buddha's teaching, and attachment to rites and rituals. She was now assured of liberation within seven lifetimes at most, with no possibility of rebirth in lower realms. However, Puṇṇā did not stop there. She continued her practice with even greater vigor and determination. Eventually, through sustained effort, she attained the second and third stages of enlightenment, and finally, while still living as a slave, she attained full Arahatship. All defilements were completely eradicated from her mind. She had reached the deathless state of Nibbāna, the end of all suffering. Despite having attained the highest spiritual realization, Puṇṇā continued to work as a slave, serving her mistress without complaint. But now, she worked without any sense of self, without any aversion to her tasks, and without any attachment to results. She had become a living embodiment of the Dhamma, demonstrating that liberation is possible regardless of one's external circumstances. When the Buddha learned of Puṇṇā's attainment, he praised her highly before the assembly of monks. He held her up as an example of what can be achieved through continuous vigilance, day-and-night practice, and unwavering determination to attain Nibbāna. The Buddha explained that such dedication and effort, maintained without interruption, would certainly lead to the destruction of all mental defilements and the attainment of Arahatship. The Buddha then spoke this verse, teaching that for those who remain always vigilant, who train themselves day and night, and who are intent on Nibbāna, the mental defilements come to an end. Puṇṇā's story became an inspiration to many, showing that the path to liberation is open to all, regardless of social status, and that what matters is not one's external conditions but one's internal determination and effort. Her example particularly encouraged those who felt that their circumstances—whether poverty, low social status, or demanding responsibilities—prevented them from serious spiritual practice. Puṇṇā proved that with strong determination and skillful integration of practice into daily life, anyone can walk the path to liberation.

verses.translation: This is an ancient truth, O Atula, not something said only today: they blame one who sits silent, they blame one who speaks much, and they blame one who speaks in moderation. There is no one in the world who is not blamed.
verses.commentary: This verse addresses the universal human tendency to criticize others regardless of their behavior. Whether one remains silent, speaks extensively, or speaks moderately, there will always be people who find fault. The Buddha explains that this is not a modern phenomenon but has been true throughout history. Those who remain silent are criticized for being aloof, proud, or ignorant. Those who speak much are blamed for being talkative, boastful, or lacking in discretion. Even those who speak in moderation are criticized for being calculating or insincere. This teaching helps practitioners develop equanimity toward praise and blame, understanding that external criticism is often more about the critic than about one's actual behavior. The wise person should therefore not be overly concerned with pleasing everyone or avoiding all criticism, but should instead focus on practicing the Dhamma correctly, knowing that some criticism is inevitable.

story.title: The Story of Atula the Lay Disciple
story.content: While residing at the Jetavana Monastery, the Buddha spoke this verse with reference to Atula, a lay disciple, and his companions. Atula was a prominent lay disciple who lived in Sāvatthi and had a following of five hundred other lay disciples. One day, Atula decided to take his entire group to the monastery to hear a Dhamma discourse. They set out with great enthusiasm, hoping to gain spiritual insight and merit from listening to the teachings. Upon arriving at the monastery, Atula and his followers approached Venerable Revata, a highly respected elder monk known for his deep meditation practice and attainment. Venerable Revata was a 'forest dweller' who loved solitude and spent most of his time in deep meditation. He was like a lion who delights in solitude, rarely engaging in conversation. Atula respectfully saluted Venerable Revata and sat down with his followers, expecting to hear a discourse. However, true to his nature as a silent contemplative, Venerable Revata said nothing. He simply sat in silence. After waiting for some time and receiving not even a single syllable of teaching, Atula became disappointed and somewhat irritated. 'This Elder has nothing to say to us,' he thought, feeling that the monk was being unhelpful or perhaps even proud. Provoked by this perceived slight, Atula and his group left Venerable Revata and went to find Venerable Sāriputta, the chief disciple renowned for his wisdom. When they approached Venerable Sāriputta and explained their wish to hear the Dhamma, Sāriputta, in his characteristic thorough manner, began to expound the Abhidhamma—the higher philosophical and psychological teachings of Buddhism. He spoke at great length, analyzing consciousness, mental factors, matter, and various complex doctrinal points with extraordinary detail and precision. However, Atula and his followers found the discourse far too technical and abstruse. They could not understand the intricate analysis and felt overwhelmed by the complexity. 'This teaching is too profound and subtle for us,' they thought. 'What use is such difficult doctrine to ordinary people like us?' Provoked once again, they left Venerable Sāriputta and went to seek out Venerable Ānanda, the Buddha's personal attendant who was known for his excellent memory and clear teaching style. Atula explained their situation to Venerable Ānanda, telling him about their disappointing experiences with Venerable Revata and Venerable Sāriputta. Venerable Ānanda, understanding that they needed something simple and practical, gave them a very brief, condensed discourse, presenting the essential points of the Dhamma in an easy-to-understand manner. However, Atula and his followers were now dissatisfied with this approach too! They felt that the teaching was too brief and superficial. 'He has given us only a summary,' they complained. 'There is no depth or detail. This is not satisfactory either.' Now thoroughly frustrated, having found fault with three different teachers—one for saying nothing, one for saying too much, and one for saying too little—Atula and his group finally went to the Buddha himself and related their entire experience. The Buddha listened patiently to their complaints and then smiled knowingly. 'Atula,' the Buddha said, 'what you have experienced is not new or unique to this day. From ancient times until now, it has always been the custom of people to find fault with others. They blame those who remain silent, saying they are proud, ignorant, or unhelpful. They blame those who speak at length, calling them talkative, boastful, or tedious. And they even blame those who speak in moderation, suspecting them of being superficial or withholding knowledge. There is no one in this world who escapes blame entirely.' The Buddha continued, 'Even great kings are blamed by some and praised by others. Even the mighty earth itself, which supports all beings, is blamed by those who find it too hard or too soft, too hot or too cold. Even the sun and moon, which provide light to all, are criticized by some as too bright or not bright enough. Even I, a fully Enlightened Buddha, sitting before the fourfold assembly of monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen, am praised by some and blamed by others.' The Buddha explained that the praise or blame of ignorant people is meaningless and should not be taken seriously. What matters is the judgment of the wise—those who have understanding and discernment. A person who is consistently praised by the wise is truly praiseworthy, and one whom the wise blame is truly blameworthy. This teaching helped Atula and his followers understand that their fault-finding attitude revealed more about their own state of mind than about the teachers they had visited. They realized that they had been approaching the Dhamma with unrealistic expectations and a critical mindset, rather than with humility and openness to learn. The Buddha's teaching helped them develop greater equanimity toward praise and blame, and to focus on cultivating wholesome qualities rather than being overly concerned with others' opinions or trying to please everyone.

verses.pali: Na cāhu na ca bhavissati, na cetarahi vijjati; Ekantaṁ nindito poso, ekantaṁ vā pasaṁsito.
verses.translation: There never was, there never will be, nor is there now, anyone who is always blamed or always praised.
verses.commentary: The Buddha teaches that no person exists who receives only blame or only praise. This is a universal truth about human nature and social dynamics. Even the most virtuous can be criticized, and even wrongdoers find some who praise them.

story.title: The Story of Atula the Lay-Disciple
story.content: Atula, a wealthy lay disciple with five hundred followers, visited three monks seeking Dhamma teachings. Elder Revata remained silent in meditation. Elder Sāriputta taught complex Abhidhamma at length. Elder Ānanda spoke moderately. Dissatisfied with all three approaches, Atula complained to the Buddha, criticizing one for silence, another for lengthy discourse, and the third for brevity. The Buddha gently explained this ancient truth: people blame the silent, the talkative, and even those who speak moderately. No one escapes criticism entirely. The wise person recognizes that praise and blame from fools matters little; only evaluation by the truly wise holds significance.

verses.pali: Yañce viññū pasaṁsanti, anuvicca suve suve; Acchiddavuttiṁ medhāviṁ, paññāsīlasamāhitaṁ.
verses.translation: If the wise praise someone day after day, after observing him carefully, knowing him to be faultless in conduct, wise, and endowed with wisdom and virtue,
verses.commentary: This verse describes the qualities of one truly worthy of praise: flawless character, intelligence, wisdom, and virtue. The emphasis is on consistent evaluation by the discerning, not casual judgment. Such a person demonstrates sustained excellence in thought and deed.

story.title: The Story of Atula the Lay-Disciple
story.content: Following his complaint about the three elders' teaching methods, the Buddha continued instructing Atula about true worth. The Teacher explained that genuine praise comes only from the wise who observe consistently and carefully. A truly praiseworthy person possesses flawless conduct, deep understanding, and integrated wisdom and virtue—like refined gold from the Jambu River. Such qualities cannot be judged superficially or by those lacking discernment. The Buddha emphasized that Atula should not be swayed by ordinary opinions but should develop these noble qualities himself, becoming worthy of praise from those genuinely capable of recognizing excellence in character and spiritual development.

verses.pali: Nikkhaṁ jambonadasseva, ko taṁ ninditumarahati; Devāpi naṁ pasaṁsanti, brahmunāpi pasaṁsito.
verses.translation: Who would dare blame one who is like a coin of pure gold from the Jambu River? Even the devas praise him; he is praised even by Brahma.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the metaphor of the purest gold to describe one of flawless virtue. Such a person, recognized by the wise, becomes worthy of universal praise—even from celestial beings. The Jambu River gold was considered the finest, symbolizing ultimate purity and value.

story.title: The Story of Atula the Lay-Disciple
story.content: Concluding his teaching to Atula, the Buddha painted a vivid picture of the truly accomplished person. Like gold from the sacred Jambu River—known throughout ancient India as the purest possible—such an individual shines with undeniable virtue. Their excellence transcends human judgment, earning recognition from devas and even Brahma himself. The Buddha's message was clear: rather than criticizing teachers for their different styles, Atula should focus on developing these supreme qualities within himself. At the discourse's end, Atula and his companions gained deeper understanding of the path, recognizing that true spiritual worth lies not in external forms but in authentic virtue, wisdom, and inner purity.

verses.pali: Kāyappakopaṁ rakkheyya, kāyena saṁvuto siyā; Kāyaduccaritaṁ hitvā, kāyena sucaritaṁ care.
verses.translation: Guard against evil deeds, control your body. Giving up bodily misconduct, cultivate good conduct in body.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes physical discipline and ethical conduct. One must guard against the physical expression of negative emotions and impulses, abandoning harmful bodily actions like killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct, while actively practicing wholesome physical behavior.

story.title: The Story of the Group of Six Bhikkhus
story.content: While residing at Veluvana Monastery, the Buddha encountered six bhikkhus behaving inappropriately. They wore wooden sandals and carried staffs, walking back and forth on a stone slab making tremendous noise. Their loud, disruptive conduct disturbed other monks engaged in meditation and study. When other bhikkhus reported this disorderly behavior, the Buddha summoned the group of six. He taught them about restraint, explaining that monks must guard their physical actions carefully. Every movement should reflect mindfulness and respect for others. Physical discipline, the Buddha emphasized, forms the foundation of spiritual practice. Without controlling bodily conduct, progress toward liberation remains impossible. True monastics embody peace through their very movements.

verses.pali: Vacīpakopaṁ rakkheyya, vācāya saṁvuto siyā; Vacīduccaritaṁ hitvā, vācāya sucaritaṁ care.
verses.translation: Guard against evil speech, control your speech. Giving up verbal misconduct, cultivate good speech.
verses.commentary: This verse addresses verbal discipline. One must guard against harsh, false, divisive, and frivolous speech, controlling the tongue and cultivating truthful, gentle, harmonious, and meaningful communication. Right speech is essential for spiritual development.

story.title: The Story of the Group of Six Bhikkhus
story.content: Continuing his teaching to the disruptive six bhikkhus, the Buddha addressed their speech patterns. Beyond their noisy footsteps, they engaged in idle chatter, gossip, and sometimes harsh words toward fellow monks. The Buddha explained that verbal conduct requires equal vigilance as physical actions. Speech can wound deeply, create divisions, spread falsehood, or waste precious time. Alternatively, words can heal, unite, illuminate truth, and inspire practice. Monks must abandon lying, harsh speech, tale-bearing, and useless talk, instead cultivating truthful, gentle, harmonious, and purposeful communication. The Buddha taught that right speech reflects inner purity and protects both speaker and listener from harm. Verbal restraint demonstrates true spiritual maturity and respect for the Dhamma.

verses.pali: Manopakopaṁ rakkheyya, manasā saṁvuto siyā; Manoduccaritaṁ hitvā, manasā sucaritaṁ care.
verses.translation: Guard against evil thoughts, control your mind. Giving up mental misconduct, cultivate good thoughts.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes mental discipline, the most subtle and important of the three. One must guard against unwholesome mental states—covetousness, ill-will, and wrong views—developing instead wholesome thoughts of non-greed, loving-kindness, and right understanding. Mind is the forerunner of all actions.

story.title: The Story of the Group of Six Bhikkhus
story.content: Completing his threefold teaching to the six bhikkhus, the Buddha addressed the root of all misconduct: the mind. Physical and verbal actions originate in thought. The Buddha explained that these monks' disruptive behavior stemmed from unguarded minds filled with restlessness, pride, and disregard for monastic discipline. Mental misconduct includes covetous thoughts, ill-will, and wrong views. True spiritual practitioners must vigilantly observe their minds, recognizing unwholesome thoughts as they arise and replacing them with wholesome intentions. The Buddha emphasized that controlling the mind surpasses all other forms of restraint, for thoughts precede and determine all actions. With disciplined minds cultivating wisdom, compassion, and understanding, practitioners naturally manifest ethical conduct in body and speech, progressing steadily toward enlightenment.

verses.pali: Kāyena saṁvutā dhīrā, atho vācāya saṁvutā; Manasā saṁvutā dhīrā, te ve suparisaṁvutā.
verses.translation: The wise are controlled in body, controlled in speech, controlled in mind. Indeed, they are perfectly self-controlled.
verses.commentary: This concluding verse praises those who have achieved complete self-mastery in all three domains—body, speech, and mind. Such individuals, called 'dhīrā' (wise ones), have perfected restraint and represent the ideal of Buddhist practice. Their comprehensive discipline marks them as truly accomplished practitioners.

story.title: The Story of the Group of Six Bhikkhus
story.content: Having taught the six bhikkhus about restraint in body, speech, and mind separately, the Buddha concluded with this integrative verse. He explained that true wisdom manifests as complete self-control across all three domains simultaneously. The wise practitioner doesn't merely suppress external behaviors while harboring internal turbulence, nor cultivate mental peace while acting carelessly. Instead, body, speech, and mind work harmoniously, all governed by mindfulness and wisdom. The Buddha pointed to accomplished arahats as examples of perfect restraint—their every movement purposeful, words meaningful, thoughts pure. The six bhikkhus, humbled by this teaching, recognized their lack of integration. They committed to developing comprehensive discipline, understanding that enlightenment requires complete transformation, not partial reform.

chapters.summary: Using the metaphor of rust and stains, this chapter discusses various mental impurities that hinder spiritual progress and emphasizes purification through wisdom and effort.

verses.pali:
Paṇḍupalāsova dānisi, yamapurisāpi ca te upaṭṭhitā;
Uyyogamukhe ca tiṭṭhasi, pātheyyampi ca te na vijjati.
verses.translation: Like a withered leaf are you now; the messengers of death await you. You stand at the threshold of departure, yet you have no provisions for the journey.
verses.commentary: This verse serves as a stark reminder of mortality and the urgency of spiritual practice. 'Paṇḍupalāsa' (withered leaf) represents the aging, deteriorating body. 'Yamapurisā' are the messengers of Yama, the lord of death. 'Uyyogamukha' is the threshold or doorway of departure from life. 'Pātheyyaṁ' refers to provisions - specifically, the wholesome karma (kusala kamma) needed for a good rebirth. The verse warns that one approaches death unprepared, without the merit needed for the journey beyond this life.

story.title: The Story of the Old Brahmin
story.content: An elderly brahmin who had lived a life focused entirely on worldly pursuits - accumulating wealth, enjoying sensual pleasures, and performing empty rituals - came to the Buddha when he was already very old and frail. His body was bent with age, his skin wrinkled and spotted, his hair completely white, and he walked with great difficulty using a staff. He had heard about the Buddha and finally decided to seek spiritual guidance, but only after spending his entire life in worldly concerns. When he arrived at the monastery, the Buddha looked at him with compassion and spoke this verse. The Buddha explained that the old brahmin was now like a withered leaf - his body worn out, his vitality gone, his time nearly finished. The messengers of death were already waiting for him; his remaining time was very short. He stood at the very threshold of death, about to depart this life. Yet he had made no spiritual provisions for his journey - he had accumulated no merit through generosity, developed no wisdom through study and meditation, cultivated no virtue through moral conduct. He was like a traveler setting out on a long and dangerous journey with no food, no water, no map, and no supplies. The old brahmin, deeply moved by this teaching and realizing the truth of his situation, asked the Buddha what he could still do at this late stage. The Buddha taught him to practice whatever good he could in his remaining time - to give generously, speak truthfully, develop loving-kindness, and contemplate the Dhamma. Though his time was short, even a little merit created with sincere motivation would help him. The brahmin devoted his final days to practice and died peacefully.

verses.pali:
So karohi dīpamattano, khippaṁ vāyama paṇḍito bhava;
Niddhantamalo anaṅgaṇo, dibbaṁ ariyabhūmimehisi.
verses.translation: Make an island for yourself! Strive quickly; become wise! Purged of stain and blemish, you shall enter the heavenly abode of the Noble Ones.
verses.commentary: This verse provides the positive instruction following the warning in verse 235. 'Dīpa' (island) means to make oneself a refuge through Dhamma practice - one must rely on oneself and the teachings, not on external saviors. 'Khippaṁ vāyama' urges immediate effort without delay. 'Niddhantamalo' means purged of mental stains (defilements), and 'anaṅgaṇo' means without blemish. 'Dibbaṁ ariyabhūmiṁ' refers to the Pure Abodes (Suddhāvāsa), the heavenly realms where Anāgāmins (Non-returners) are reborn, called 'noble' because only Ariyas attain them.

story.title: Continuation of the Old Brahmin's Story
story.content: After the Buddha spoke verse 235, warning the old brahmin about his unprepared state, he immediately followed with this verse of encouragement and instruction. The Buddha told him not to despair but to act quickly. The word 'island' (dīpa) has deep significance - just as an island provides safety from floods, one must make oneself an island of refuge through Dhamma practice, relying on one's own effort and the Buddha's teachings rather than seeking external salvation. The Buddha urged the brahmin to strive immediately without wasting another moment, to become wise through understanding the Four Noble Truths and the nature of existence. Though his time was short, if he purified himself of mental stains (greed, hatred, and delusion) and removed all blemishes from his conduct, he could still attain a fortunate rebirth. The Buddha specifically mentioned the Pure Abodes - special heavenly realms accessible only to Anāgāmins (Non-returners, the third stage of enlightenment). While the old brahmin might not reach such exalted attainment in his remaining time, the Buddha's teaching showed him the highest possibility and encouraged whatever spiritual development he could achieve. The brahmin took this advice to heart. Despite his advanced age and physical weakness, he practiced with remarkable intensity and sincerity during his final days. He made himself an island through refuge in the Triple Gem, strived urgently in contemplation and meditation, and worked to purify his mind. When he died, he was reborn in a heavenly realm, having made the best use of his remaining time by heeding the Buddha's urgent instruction.

verses.pali:
Upanītavayo ca dānisi, sampayātosi yamassa santike;
Vāso te natthi antarā, pātheyyampi ca te na vijjati.
verses.translation: Your life has nearly ended now; you are setting out for Yama's presence. There is no resting place for you on the way, yet you have made no provisions for the journey.
verses.commentary: This verse continues the urgent message, with slightly different emphasis. 'Upanītavayo' means one's lifespan has been brought close to its end. 'Yamassa santike' - into the presence of Yama, the lord of death, referring to the judgment or accounting that occurs after death. 'Vāso natthi antarā' means there is no inn or resting place on the journey - one cannot pause or delay once death arrives. The verse reinforces that death waits for no one and that the journey into the next life is immediate and unavoidable.

story.title: The Story of the Dying Monk
story.content: A monk who had lived for many years in relative comfort, performing his duties adequately but without great diligence or urgency in meditation practice, suddenly fell gravely ill. The illness came unexpectedly and progressed rapidly. Within days, it became clear he was dying. As he lay on his deathbed, weak and in pain, he was filled with regret and anxiety. He realized he had wasted years in comfortable complacency, always thinking he would practice more seriously 'later' or 'tomorrow.' He had not devoted himself wholeheartedly to purifying his mind or developing deep concentration and wisdom. Now, facing death, he felt unprepared and frightened. His fellow monks gathered around him, and someone quickly summoned the Buddha. When the Buddha arrived, he looked at the dying monk with compassion and spoke this verse. He explained that the monk's life had reached its end - his time was finished. He was now setting out to meet the consequences of his karma, entering the realm of death. There would be no stopping place on this journey, no pause to gather supplies or make preparation. Once death came, the process would be immediate and unstoppable. Yet the monk had made inadequate provisions - his practice had been superficial, his virtue adequate but not strong, his meditation insufficient to provide real refuge. The Buddha's words, though sobering, had a galvanizing effect. In his final hours, the dying monk aroused tremendous energy. Understanding there was no more time for delay, he gathered all his remaining mental strength and practiced with absolute intensity. He focused his mind, reflected deeply on the Buddha's teachings, and let go of all attachment to life. Through this desperate but sincere final effort, he managed to attain significant insight before death, ensuring a favorable rebirth despite his previous complacency.

verses.pali:
So karohi dīpamattano, khippaṁ vāyama paṇḍito bhava;
Niddhantamalo anaṅgaṇo, na punaṁ jātijaraṁ upehisi.
verses.translation: Make an island for yourself! Strive quickly; become wise! Purged of stain and blemish, you will not undergo birth and aging again.
verses.commentary: This verse is nearly identical to verse 236 but with a crucial difference in the final line. Instead of promising rebirth in the Pure Abodes, it promises freedom from the cycle of birth and aging entirely - this refers to attaining Arahantship, complete liberation. The earlier verse offered intermediate goals appropriate for most practitioners, while this verse presents the ultimate goal. The message remains: make yourself a refuge, practice urgently, purify yourself - but the result here is full liberation from saṁsāra.

story.title: The Story of Various Practitioners
story.content: The Buddha taught these sequential verses (235-238) to different audiences with varying levels of spiritual capacity and readiness. To those just beginning spiritual life or those whose practice had been lukewarm, he taught verses 235 and 236, warning them of death's approach and encouraging them to strive for at least a favorable rebirth in the Pure Abodes or other fortunate destinies. These teachings motivated countless people to begin serious practice and to accumulate merit while time remained. However, to practitioners with greater capacity, stronger determination, and more advanced understanding, the Buddha taught this verse with its promise of complete liberation. He urged them not to settle for mere rebirth, however fortunate, but to aim for the ultimate goal - the complete ending of the cycle of birth and death. Several monks who had been practicing with moderate effort but holding back from total commitment heard this verse and were inspired to practice with absolute dedication. They realized that complete liberation was actually possible, not just a distant theoretical goal. By making themselves true islands of refuge through the Dhamma, striving with maximum urgency, becoming truly wise through penetrating insight, and purifying themselves completely of all mental stains and blemishes, they could actually end the endless cycle of suffering. Several of these monks, energized by this teaching, intensified their practice dramatically. Through sustained effort in meditation and contemplation, they purged themselves of all defilements and attained Arahantship, fulfilling the promise of this verse - they would never again undergo birth, aging, sickness, and death.

verses.pali:
Anupubbena medhāvī, thokaṁ thokaṁ khaṇe khaṇe;
Kammāro rajatasseva, niddhame malamattano.
verses.translation: Little by little, moment by moment, one by one, the wise person should remove his own impurities, as a smith removes dross from silver.
verses.commentary: This verse teaches the gradual nature of purification. 'Anupubbena' means progressively or in sequence, 'thokaṁ thokaṁ' means little by little, 'khaṇe khaṇe' means moment by moment. The simile of a silversmith is instructive: when refining silver, a smith heats the ore and removes impurities gradually - not all at once, but through repeated cycles of heating and skimming. Similarly, spiritual purification is a gradual process requiring patience, persistence, and repeated effort. One cannot eliminate all defilements instantly but must work steadily, removing mental impurities bit by bit.

story.title: The Story of the Hall Builder
story.content: A devout brahmin who lived near Jetavana monastery would wake early each morning and, in the pre-dawn darkness, observe the monks preparing for their alms-round. He noticed they dressed in a grassy area where the hem of their robes would become wet with morning dew. Moved by compassion, he brought a scythe the next day and carefully trimmed all the grass short. The following morning, he observed that with the grass cut, the monks' robes now became muddy from the exposed earth. So he brought sand and spread it over the entire area, creating a clean surface. Then he noticed that even with the sand, on very hot days the monks would perspire heavily while dressing. So he built a simple pavilion to provide shade. Then he saw that during the rainy season, the pavilion was insufficient - the monks still got wet. So gradually, over months, he constructed a proper hall with walls and a good roof where monks could dress comfortably in all weather conditions. When the hall was finally completed, the brahmin organized a great ceremony, inviting the Buddha and the entire Sangha for a feast. During the celebration, he explained to the Buddha his gradual process of improvement - first cutting grass, then spreading sand, then building a pavilion, finally constructing a complete hall. Each step had addressed a problem he observed, leading progressively to the final result. The Buddha was delighted with this account because it perfectly illustrated the principle he wished to teach. He spoke this verse, praising the brahmin's patient, progressive approach. The Buddha explained that just as the brahmin had gradually improved the monks' dressing area step by step, observing problems and addressing them one at a time, so must a wise person gradually remove mental impurities. Just as a silversmith doesn't try to purify silver all at once but removes impurities bit by bit through repeated heating and skimming, so must practitioners patiently work on their defilements, removing them little by little, moment by moment, until complete purification is achieved.

verses.pali:
Ayasāva malaṁ samuṭṭhitaṁ, taduṭṭhāya tameva khādati;
Evaṁ atidhonacārinaṁ, sāni kammāni nayanti duggatiṁ.
verses.translation: Just as rust arising from iron eats away the base from which it arises, even so the transgressor's own deeds lead him to a woeful state.
verses.commentary: This verse uses the powerful simile of rust to illustrate self-destruction through one's own actions. Rust (mala) originates from iron itself and then corrodes the iron that produced it. Similarly, a person's own evil deeds, arising from their own mind and actions, destroy that very person. 'Atidhonacārī' refers to one who indulges excessively, particularly in regard to the four requisites (robes, food, shelter, medicine). The verse teaches that we create our own suffering through our own misconduct - the destroyer is not external but internal.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Tissa and the Fine Cloth
story.content: Venerable Tissa possessed eight cubits of coarse, rough cloth suitable for making a monk's robe. Being generous, he gave this cloth to his sister who was also a devoted Buddhist laywoman. When she received the cloth, she examined it and thought, 'This rough cloth is not good enough for my venerable brother. He deserves better quality material.' Out of affection and respect, she carefully unpicked the coarse cloth, thread by thread. Then she spun fine, soft yarn and had it woven into beautiful, smooth cloth of much higher quality. When the cloth was ready, Tissa sent a message asking for his cloth back, as he needed to make his robe. His sister happily sent him the fine cloth she had prepared. However, when Tissa saw the fine, beautiful cloth, he was troubled. As a monk committed to simplicity and non-attachment to luxuries, he felt it was inappropriate to wear such fine material. He initially refused the cloth, asking for the original coarse cloth he had given her. His sister explained what she had done and why, but Tissa remained hesitant about accepting such luxurious material. Other monks heard about this situation and questioned whether Tissa was being too rigid or whether accepting the fine cloth would constitute an attachment to luxury. They brought the matter to the Buddha. The Buddha considered the situation carefully. He knew that Tissa's hesitation came from pure motives - a desire to maintain simplicity and avoid luxury. However, he also saw deeper lessons to teach. The Buddha spoke this verse, using it to teach about how excessive attachment to even the requisites of monastic life, or excessive fussiness about their quality, could become a form of self-destruction. Just as rust arises from iron and then eats away that very iron, excessive preoccupation with the material quality of one's requisites - whether insisting on the finest or refusing anything but the coarsest - could become a subtle form of attachment that would corrode one's practice. The Buddha explained that what matters is the mind's attitude, not the material's quality. If Tissa accepted the cloth with gratitude, without attachment, and used it simply as a practical necessity, there would be no problem. But if he became obsessed with having only coarse cloth, that too could become an inverted form of luxury.

verses.pali:
Asajjhāyamalā mantā, anuṭṭhānamalā gharā;
Malaṁ vaṇṇassa kosajjaṁ, pamādo rakkhato malaṁ.
verses.translation: Non-repetition is the stain of scriptures; non-maintenance is the stain of houses; indolence is the stain of beauty; heedlessness is the stain of a guard.
verses.commentary: This verse identifies specific 'stains' that ruin different things. 'Asajjhāya' (not repeating/reviewing) ruins scriptural learning - knowledge not regularly reviewed is forgotten.
