'Anuṭṭhāna' (not maintaining) ruins houses - buildings not maintained deteriorate. 'Kosajja' (indolence) ruins beauty - laziness in grooming makes one unattractive. 'Pamāda' (heedlessness) ruins a guard - an inattentive watchman fails at his duty. Each stain represents a form of neglect that destroys what should be preserved.

story.title: The Story of Various Examples
story.content: The Buddha taught this verse through multiple examples observed in daily life. First, he pointed to monks who had learned scriptures but failed to review them regularly. These monks would memorize suttas during their training, but if they didn't recite and review them consistently, they gradually forgot the texts. After some years, monks who had once known many teachings could barely remember them. The lack of repetition (asajjhāya) had stained and ruined their scriptural knowledge. The Buddha then pointed to houses and buildings in the city that had once been magnificent but now lay in disrepair. Roofs leaked, walls crumbled, paint peeled, and gardens grew wild. These structures had deteriorated not because they were poorly built originally, but because their owners had failed to maintain them (anuṭṭhāna). Regular maintenance would have kept them beautiful, but neglect had stained and ruined them. Next, the Buddha observed people whose natural beauty had been diminished by laziness. Some individuals had attractive features but became unappealing because they neglected basic grooming - they didn't bathe regularly, wore dirty clothes, didn't comb their hair, and showed general slovenliness. Their indolence (kosajja) had stained their appearance. Finally, the Buddha pointed to guards and watchmen who had failed at their duties through heedlessness. There were cases where thieves had successfully robbed homes or villages because the watchmen, instead of staying alert, had fallen asleep, become distracted, or simply neglected their responsibility. Their heedlessness (pamāda) had stained their role as protectors. Through these concrete examples, the Buddha taught that different things require different forms of maintenance and attention. Neglect in any area creates a 'stain' that ruins what should be preserved. The lesson applies especially to spiritual practice - our virtue, wisdom, and meditation require constant attention and maintenance, or they too will be stained by neglect.

verses.pali:
Malitthiyā duccaritaṁ, maccheraṁ dadato malaṁ;
Malā ve pāpakā dhammā, asmiṁ loke paramhi ca.
verses.translation: Misconduct is the stain of a woman; stinginess is the stain of a giver. Evil states are indeed stains in this world and the next.
verses.commentary: This verse identifies specific stains in particular contexts. For a woman (or any person), misconduct (duccarita) - particularly unchastity - is a stain on reputation and character. For a giver (dātar), stinginess (macchariya) contradicts and ruins the act of giving. The verse concludes with a general principle: all evil states (pāpakā dhammā) are stains that cause suffering in both this life and future lives. Note that while the verse uses 'woman' specifically due to cultural context, the principle applies universally - misconduct stains anyone's character.

story.title: The Story of the Stingy Donor
story.content: A wealthy man in Sāvatthī decided he wanted to gain merit by practicing generosity. He invited monks to his house and prepared a feast for them. However, despite his intention to be generous, he was afflicted with a deep-rooted stinginess that he couldn't entirely overcome. As he served the food, he gave very small portions, barely enough to satisfy hunger. When offering cloth for robes, he selected the cheapest, coarsest material available. Throughout the process of giving, he felt inner resistance and regret. His face showed displeasure, and he handled the gifts grudgingly rather than with joy. After the monks had left, he actually felt resentful about what he had given away, wishing he had kept more for himself. Though he had performed an act of generosity, his stinginess had completely stained and ruined the gift. The monks reported this to the Buddha, noting how the man's miserliness had tainted what should have been a joyful act of giving. The Buddha spoke this verse, explaining that just as misconduct stains a woman's (or anyone's) character, stinginess stains the act of giving. When one gives grudgingly, with regret and inner resistance, the merit generated is minimal. True giving should be done with a joyful, open heart, free from stinginess. The man's deep-seated miserliness had stained his attempted generosity. The Buddha concluded by emphasizing that all evil mental states - whether misconduct, stinginess, hatred, or any other unwholesome quality - are stains that cause suffering in this life through inner torment and negative social consequences, and in future lives through unfavorable rebirths. These stains must be removed through cultivation of opposite qualities: virtue instead of misconduct, generosity instead of stinginess, loving-kindness instead of hatred, and wisdom instead of delusion.

verses.pali:
Tato malā malataraṁ, avijjā paramaṁ malaṁ;
Etaṁ malaṁ pahatvāna, nimmalā hotha bhikkhavo.
verses.translation: But more staining than those stains is ignorance, the worst stain. Abandon this stain, and be stainless, O monks!
verses.commentary: This verse identifies ignorance (avijjā) as the supreme stain, worse than all other defilements. While misconduct, stinginess, and other evils are certainly stains, ignorance is 'malataraṁ' - more staining, worse than the worst. Why? Because ignorance is the root cause of all other defilements. Without ignorance of the Four Noble Truths, of impermanence, suffering, and non-self, no other defilement could arise. Ignorance is darkness of mind that prevents seeing reality as it is. The Buddha urges monks to abandon this fundamental stain and become 'nimmalā' - completely stainless, pure.

story.title: The Teaching on Fundamental Ignorance
story.content: After teaching about various types of stains - the stain of not reviewing scriptures, of not maintaining buildings, of indolence affecting appearance, of heedlessness in guards, of misconduct in character, and of stinginess in giving - the Buddha wanted to direct his disciples to the most fundamental stain that underlies all others. He gathered the monks and asked them, 'Of all the stains I have mentioned, which do you think is the worst?' Various monks offered different answers. Some said misconduct was worst because it violates moral principles. Others argued stinginess was worst because it prevents spiritual generosity. Some suggested heedlessness was worst because it leads to all kinds of failures. The Buddha listened to all these answers and then spoke this verse, revealing that ignorance (avijjā) is actually the supreme stain, worse than all the others they had discussed. He explained why ignorance is the fundamental stain: 'All the other stains arise from ignorance. Why does someone engage in misconduct? Because of ignorance about karma and its consequences. Why is someone stingy? Because of ignorance about the impermanence of wealth and the benefits of generosity. Why is someone heedless? Because of ignorance about the urgency of spiritual practice and the inevitability of death. Why do people cling to things that bring suffering? Because of ignorance about the true nature of existence - that all conditioned things are impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self. Ignorance is the darkness in which all other defilements breed and thrive. It is the fundamental misunderstanding of reality that makes all suffering possible.' The Buddha emphasized that while it's important to address specific defilements like misconduct, stinginess, and heedlessness, true purification requires eliminating ignorance itself - the root stain from which all others grow. He urged the monks to develop wisdom through study, reflection, and meditation, to see the Four Noble Truths clearly, to understand impermanence, suffering, and not-self. By abandoning ignorance through the development of wisdom and direct insight, they would simultaneously eliminate all other stains and become completely pure - 'nimmalā,' without any stain whatsoever.

verses.pali:
Sujīvaṁ ahirikena, kākasūrena dhaṁsinā;
Pakkhandinā pagabbhena, saṅkiliṭṭhena jīvitaṁ.
verses.translation: Easy is life for the shameless one who has the boldness of a crow, is a backbiter, presumptuous, reckless, and corrupt.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the 'easy' life of someone without shame (ahirika) who lives unethically. 'Kākasūra' means having the boldness/impudence of a crow - crows are shameless scavengers. 'Dhaṁsī' means a backbiter or slanderer. 'Pakkhandin' means presumptuous or forward. 'Pagabbha' means reckless or impudent. 'Saṅkiliṭṭha' means corrupt or defiled. Such a person finds life 'easy' because they have no moral constraints, no shame, and no concern for consequences. But this ease is ultimately destructive.

story.title: The Story of the Shameless Monk
story.content: In the Sangha, there was a monk who had ordained not out of genuine spiritual aspiration but to escape worldly difficulties and find an easy life. He had no sense of shame (hiri) or moral conscience (ottappa), the two qualities the Buddha called the guardians of the world. This monk lived without any moral constraints. He was bold and impudent like a crow, unafraid to commit any misconduct because he felt no shame. When he wanted something that belonged to another monk, he would simply take it without asking. If someone questioned his behavior, he would lie shamelessly, making up elaborate stories without any hesitation. He was a backbiter and slanderer, speaking ill of other monks behind their backs, creating divisions and spreading rumors to advance his own interests. He had no respect for senior monks or teachers, addressing them presumptuously without proper deference. He would push forward aggressively to get the best food, the most comfortable lodging, and the nicest robes, showing no consideration for others. He was reckless in his conduct, breaking minor and major rules alike with equal indifference. His whole life was corrupt and defiled, yet in a certain superficial sense, he found life 'easy.' He had no moral struggles because he had no moral principles. He felt no guilt or remorse for his misdeeds. He experienced no inner conflict because he simply did whatever pleased him in the moment without concern for right or wrong. While other monks worked hard to maintain their precepts, practice meditation, and develop wisdom - often struggling with temptations and facing difficulties in their practice - this shameless monk seemed to glide through life without effort. He ate well, slept well, and did as he pleased. However, the other monks found his presence disturbing and corrupting. They reported his behavior to the Buddha, who immediately recognized the problem. The Buddha spoke this verse to describe this monk's shameless way of life and then explained: 'Yes, for such a person life seems easy, but this ease is deceptive and destructive. Living without shame, without moral restraint, doing whatever one pleases without regard for consequences - this may seem easy in the short term, but it leads to terrible results. Such a person creates immense negative karma and is heading toward states of suffering. The truly wise person chooses the harder but more beneficial path of moral conduct and self-restraint.'

verses.pali:
Hirīmatā ca dujjīvaṁ, niccaṁ sucigavesinā;
Alīnenāppagabbhena, suddhājīvena passatā.
verses.translation: Hard is life for one who has a sense of shame, who constantly seeks purity, who is detached and not reckless, whose livelihood is pure, and whose vision is clear.
verses.commentary: This verse presents the contrast to verse 244. While life seems easy for the shameless, it is hard (dujjīva) for one with moral shame (hirī). 'Sucigavesī' means constantly seeking purity in thought, speech, and action. 'Alīna' means detached or unattached. 'Appagabbha' means not reckless or presumptuous. 'Suddhājīva' means one whose livelihood is pure. 'Passatā' means seeing clearly with wisdom. Such a person faces constant challenges maintaining high ethical standards, but this difficult life leads to genuine happiness and liberation.

story.title: The Story of Conscientious Monks
story.content: In contrast to the shameless monk described in the previous verse, there were many monks in the Sangha who practiced with strong moral conscience and a genuine sense of shame about wrongdoing. These monks found monastic life challenging in many ways. They constantly examined their thoughts, speech, and actions, seeking to maintain perfect purity in all areas. When even small unwholesome thoughts arose in their minds, they felt ashamed and worked immediately to dispel them. They were scrupulous about observing all the Vinaya rules, even minor training precepts that others might consider unimportant. Before accepting any requisite - food, robes, shelter, or medicine - they carefully considered whether it was properly offered and appropriate to accept. They maintained detachment from material things, taking no pleasure in fine food or comfortable lodgings, viewing them purely as supports for practice. They were never reckless or presumptuous in their conduct, always showing proper respect and careful consideration. Their livelihood was completely pure, relying entirely on properly offered alms without engaging in any wrong means of support. They cultivated clear vision through study and meditation, working to see things as they truly are. These monks faced genuine difficulties. They experienced inner struggles when temptations arose. They sometimes had to forgo comfortable situations to maintain their principles. They worked hard in meditation practice, facing boredom, pain, and difficult mental states. When other monks criticized or questioned them, they examined themselves deeply to ensure their conduct was truly pure. Their path was not easy, but through this difficulty they developed genuine strength, purity, and wisdom. When the Buddha observed both types of monks - the shameless one who found life superficially easy, and the conscientious ones who found life genuinely difficult - he taught these two verses to illustrate a profound principle. The shameless person's 'easy' life was actually a path to suffering and ruin, while the conscientious person's difficult life was the true path to purification and liberation.

verses.pali:
Yo pāṇamatipāteti, musāvādañca bhāsati;
Loke adinnaṁ ādiyati, paradārañca gacchati.
verses.translation: Whoever destroys life, tells lies, takes what is not given in the world, and goes to another's spouse.
verses.commentary: This verse begins a series (246-247) describing destructive behaviors. It lists four fundamental moral violations: killing living beings (pāṇātipāta), speaking falsehood (musāvāda), taking what is not given or stealing (adinnādāna), and sexual misconduct particularly with others' spouses (paradāra-gamana). These correspond to the first four of the Five Precepts that form the foundation of Buddhist ethical conduct. The verse sets up the consequences described in the following verse.

story.title: The Story of Five Lay Followers
story.content: In Sāvatthī, there lived five men who had once been devoted followers of the Buddha. They had taken the Five Precepts and practiced them faithfully for several years, enjoying the peace and happiness that come from moral conduct. However, gradually, influenced by bad companions and weakening mindfulness, each of them broke one of the fundamental precepts. One man, who had once been gentle and compassionate, began hunting animals for sport, killing deer and birds without any necessity. Another man, who had been known for his honesty, began lying in his business dealings to cheat customers and competitors. A third, who had been scrupulous about honesty, started stealing - at first small things, but gradually more valuable items, from market stalls and eventually from homes. The fourth man, who had been faithful to his wife, began visiting other women, including married women, engaging in adultery. The fifth, though not committing these acts himself, became an accomplice to his friends, encouraging and assisting their misconduct. As they continued these behaviors, the five friends noticed changes in their lives. They began experiencing anxiety and fear, worrying about being caught or facing consequences. Their sleep was disturbed by nightmares. They developed quarrels and conflicts with others. Their reputations in the community deteriorated. Despite accumulating some short-term gains from their misconduct, they felt increasingly unhappy and troubled. Other lay followers who had remained faithful to the precepts reported the situation to the Buddha, saddened by how their former companions had fallen into misconduct. The Buddha spoke these verses to warn about such destructive paths and to illustrate that breaking the fundamental precepts leads inevitably to suffering.

verses.pali:
Surāmerayapānañca, yo naro anuyuñjati;
Idh'evameso lokasmiṁ, mūlaṁ khaṇati attano.
verses.translation: And whoever indulges in intoxicating drinks - such a person digs up his own roots right here in this world.
verses.commentary: This verse completes the list by adding indulgence in intoxicants (surāmeraya-pāna), the fifth precept. The phrase 'mūlaṁ khaṇati attano' (digs up his own roots) is a powerful metaphor - just as a tree that has its roots dug up will wither and die, a person who engages in these five types of misconduct destroys the foundation of their own wellbeing and happiness, both in this life and beyond.

story.title: Continuation of Five Lay Followers
story.content: The fifth precept violation - intoxication - played a crucial role in the downfall of these five men. Initially, one of them had begun drinking alcohol moderately at social gatherings. As his drinking increased, he encouraged his friends to join him. Under the influence of alcohol, their judgment became impaired and their moral restraint weakened. The hunter found it easier to kill animals without remorse when drinking. The liar's falsehoods became more elaborate and shameless when intoxicated. The thief grew bolder in his stealing after consuming alcohol. The adulterer found it easier to pursue illicit relationships when his inhibitions were lowered by drink. Their fifth friend, who assisted their misconduct, was usually drunk when helping them. The alcohol didn't just add another transgression to their list - it actually facilitated and intensified all their other moral violations. When sober, they might have felt some remaining conscience or hesitation, but intoxication dissolved these last barriers. Moreover, the drinking itself became progressively destructive. They spent money they couldn't afford on alcohol. They neglected their families and responsibilities. They made foolish decisions while intoxicated that complicated their lives further. Their health began to deteriorate. When the Buddha was informed about these five men and their various transgressions, he spoke these two verses together. He explained that each of the five moral violations mentioned - killing, lying, stealing, sexual misconduct, and intoxication - is like digging up one's own roots. A person engaging in such conduct destroys the very foundation of their happiness and wellbeing right here in this present life, even before facing karmic consequences in future lives. The metaphor of digging up one's roots was particularly apt - these men had once been like healthy trees with strong roots in the Dhamma, but through their misconduct, they had systematically destroyed their own foundation, and now they were withering spiritually, psychologically, and socially.

verses.pali:
Evaṁ bho purisa jānāhi, pāpadhammā asaññatā;
Mā taṁ lobho adhammo ca, ciraṁ dukkhāya randhayuṁ.
verses.translation: Know this, O good person: evil things are uncontrolled. Let not greed and unrighteousness oppress you to prolonged suffering.
verses.commentary: This verse serves as a warning and counsel. 'Evaṁ jānāhi' (know this) is an appeal to understand what has been taught. 'Pāpadhammā asaññatā' means evil states are uncontrolled or unrestrained - they tend to grow if not checked. 'Lobha' (greed) and 'adhamma' (unrighteousness) should not be allowed to 'randhayuṁ' (oppress, torment, or overcome) one to prolonged suffering. The Buddha urges recognition that evil tendencies, once allowed to establish themselves, become increasingly difficult to control.

story.title: The Buddha's Warning
story.content: After describing the downfall of the five lay followers who had violated the precepts, the Buddha addressed not just them but all who were listening, using the respectful term 'bho purisa' (O good person). He wanted everyone to understand the lesson from this story. The Buddha explained: 'Understand this clearly - evil qualities and unwholesome actions are by nature uncontrolled and unrestrained. They do not remain static or limited. If you allow greed to arise and persist in your mind, it will grow stronger. If you engage in unrighteous actions, they become easier to repeat and harder to stop. What begins as a small transgression can develop into a habitual pattern that eventually dominates your life.' The Buddha used the example of the five friends: 'Each of them began with small steps. The hunter didn't immediately become cruel - he started with one small creature and gradually moved to larger game. The liar began with small, seemingly harmless falsehoods before progressing to major deceptions. The thief took something minor at first, testing whether he could get away with it. The adulterer began with inappropriate glances before progressing to actual misconduct. The drinker had just one cup at first. But evil qualities are unrestrained - they grow and spread like fire or weeds unless actively checked.' The Buddha continued: 'Do not let greed overcome you. Do not let unrighteousness gain a foothold in your life. These forces will oppress you for a long time, bringing prolonged suffering not just in future lives but even in this present existence. The suffering comes from the actions themselves, from their social consequences, from inner turmoil and guilt, and ultimately from the karmic results. Once these patterns are well-established, breaking free becomes extremely difficult. Therefore, guard yourselves carefully. Maintain your precepts vigilantly. When you notice greed or unrighteous tendencies arising, address them immediately before they gain strength. Do not think just this once or this small thing doesn't matter - that is how the descent begins.'

verses.translation: People give according to their faith and as they are pleased. If one becomes envious of others' food and drink, one attains no concentration by day or night.
verses.commentary: This verse addresses jealousy regarding others' gains. When people give according to their faith and pleasure (choosing different recipients), some may receive more offerings while others receive less. If a monk becomes envious (maṅku) of the food and drink others receive, this envy disturbs the mind and prevents attaining concentration (samādhi) in meditation. The verse teaches that jealousy and envy are obstacles to mental peace and spiritual progress.

story.title: The Story of the Jealous Monk
story.content: In a monastery, there lived two monks. One was an excellent preacher with engaging personality who attracted many supporters. Lay followers regularly invited him for meals, offered him fine robes, and provided medicine when needed. The other monk, though equally sincere in practice, was less charismatic and had fewer personal supporters. He often received only basic alms and simple requisites. Initially, the second monk accepted this situation with equanimity, understanding that people give according to their faith and preferences. However, over time, he began to notice the disparity more and more. When he saw lay followers bringing special foods to the popular monk, he felt a pang of envy. When he observed the fine robes offered to his companion while he wore patched garments, resentment grew in his heart. He began dwelling on these differences, comparing his situation unfavorably with the other monk's. 'Why does he receive so much while I get so little?' he would think. 'My practice is equally good. It's not fair.' This jealousy progressively consumed his mind. During meditation, instead of focusing on his object of meditation, he found himself thinking about the other monk's gains. At mealtimes, he would notice what food the other received and compare it with his own plain fare. At night, his mind churned with envious thoughts rather than resting in peace. His meditation practice deteriorated completely. He couldn't establish concentration because his mind was constantly agitated by jealousy. His sleep became poor, disturbed by resentful thoughts. He became irritable and unhappy. The very purpose of his monastic life - to develop peace and wisdom - was being destroyed by his own envy. Finally, consumed by these troubled thoughts, he approached the Buddha for guidance. He honestly confessed his jealousy and asked how to overcome it. The Buddha, perceiving both the sincerity of his confession and the severity of his problem, spoke this verse. The Buddha explained: 'People give according to their confidence and as they are pleased. Some donors prefer monks who are good preachers, others prefer those who are scholarly, still others prefer those who practice in solitude. This is natural and not a reflection of your worth. But by becoming envious of what others receive, you create terrible suffering for yourself. Your envy prevents you from attaining concentration. By day your meditation is disturbed by jealous thoughts; by night you cannot sleep peacefully because of resentment. You are destroying your own practice through this mental poison.' The monk, hearing this clear teaching, recognized the self-destructive nature of his jealousy. He resolved to abandon such comparison and envy, focusing instead on gratitude for whatever he received and on his actual purpose: purifying his mind and developing wisdom.

verses.pali:
Yassa cetaṁ samucchinnaṁ, mūlaghaccaṁ samūhataṁ;
Sa ve divā vā rattiṁ vā, samādhiṁ adhigacchati.
verses.translation: But one who has this envy cut off, destroyed at the root and removed - such a one attains concentration by day and by night.
verses.commentary: This verse presents the positive counterpart to the previous one. When envy is completely cut off (samucchinnaṁ), destroyed at the root (mūlaghaccaṁ), and thoroughly removed (samūhataṁ), one can attain concentration (samādhi) both day and night. The threefold description emphasizes complete elimination - not just suppression but total eradication of jealousy from the mind.

story.title: The Jealous Monk's Transformation
story.content: After hearing the Buddha's teaching, the jealous monk returned to his dwelling determined to eliminate envy from his mind completely. He understood that merely suppressing his jealous thoughts temporarily wouldn't solve the problem - he needed to destroy this tendency at its root. He began by investigating the nature of jealousy in his own mind. He watched carefully when envious thoughts arose, noting their characteristics and effects. He recognized that envy arose from comparing himself with others, from wanting what they had, and from the false belief that their gain diminished his own worth or happiness. He reflected deeply on several truths: First, that each person's karma determines what they receive - his companion monk had performed generous actions in past lives that now resulted in receiving abundant offerings. Second, that others' gains didn't actually diminish his own situation - whether others received much or little made no real difference to his own practice or wellbeing. Third, that material offerings were merely supports for practice, not ends in themselves - what truly mattered was developing wisdom and purification. Fourth, that his jealousy was actually causing him far more suffering than having fewer offerings ever could. Through sustained reflection and meditation on these truths, he gradually uprooted his jealousy. When he saw the other monk receiving offerings, he trained himself to feel joy at the giver's generosity and the receiver's good fortune. He cultivated contentment with whatever he himself received, whether much or little. He redirected his attention from external comparisons to his own internal development. Slowly but surely, he destroyed jealousy at its root. As his envy dissolved, remarkable changes occurred in his meditation practice. His mind, no longer agitated by jealous thoughts, became calm and stable. He could establish concentration easily, both during formal meditation sessions and throughout daily activities. By day, his mind remained collected and peaceful. By night, he slept well, and when he practiced meditation in the evening or early morning, his concentration was deep and sustained. Free from the torment of jealousy, he experienced genuine happiness and made rapid progress in his practice. The Buddha, observing his transformation, spoke this verse to confirm and praise his achievement, using him as an example to show that when mental defilements are completely eradicated, the mind naturally attains the peace and concentration necessary for liberation.

verses.pali: Natthi rāgasamo aggi, natthi dosasamo gaho; Natthi mohasamaṁ jālaṁ, natthi taṇhāsamā nadī.
verses.translation: There is no fire like passion, there is no grip like hatred, there is no net like delusion, there is no river like craving.
verses.commentary: This verse identifies the four primary mental defilements using vivid metaphors: passion burns like fire, hatred grips like a fetter, delusion traps like a net, and craving flows endlessly like a river. These are the fundamental obstacles to liberation, the root causes of suffering in samsara.

story.title: The Story of Five Lay-Disciples
story.content: At Jetavana Monastery, five lay-disciples attended the Buddha's discourse. One slept sitting up, exhausted from worldly concerns. Another drew lines in the dirt, his mind wandering to business matters. A third attempted to shake a nearby tree, consumed by restlessness. The fourth stared vacantly at the sky, lost in daydreams. Only the fifth listened attentively with genuine interest. Venerable Ānanda observed their different behaviors and questioned the Buddha about it. The Buddha explained that their past kamma and present defilements created these varying capacities for attention. Those dominated by passion, hatred, delusion, and craving cannot focus on Dhamma. But one who restrains these defilements can receive teachings fully. By discourse's end, the attentive disciple attained stream-entry while others remained bound by their mental afflictions.

verses.pali: Sudassaṁ vajjamaññesaṁ, attano pana duddasaṁ; Paresaṁ hi so vajjāni, opuṇāti yathābhūsaṁ; Attano pana chādeti, kaliṁva kitavā saṭho.
verses.translation: It is easy to see the faults of others but difficult to see one's own. One broadcasts others' faults like winnowing chaff in the wind, but hides one's own as a crafty gambler conceals a losing throw.
verses.commentary: This verse addresses human tendency toward critical judgment of others while being blind to personal faults. The metaphor of winnowing chaff illustrates how people publicize others' failings, while the image of a deceptive gambler hiding bad dice shows how cleverly people conceal their own shortcomings.

story.title: The Story of Mendaka the Rich Man
story.content: During travels through Anga and Uttara regions, the Buddha perceived that wealthy merchant Mendaka and his family were ready for spiritual breakthrough. Though extremely prosperous—finding golden goat statues in his yard and experiencing miraculous grain multiplication—Mendaka remained humble. En route to visit the Buddha, other ascetics warned Mendaka against meeting this young monk, criticizing the Buddha's teachings and character. They found extensive faults in the Buddha while praising themselves. Undeterred, Mendaka continued to the Buddha. Upon hearing about the ascetics' criticisms, the Buddha smiled and taught this verse. He explained that people easily spot others' minor flaws while remaining oblivious to their own major failings, like the ascetics criticizing him while harboring jealousy and false pride. Mendaka, his family, and servant all attained stream-entry that day.

verses.pali: Paravajjānupassissa, niccaṁ ujjhānasaññino; Āsavā tassa vaḍḍhanti, ārā so āsavakkhayā.
verses.translation: In one who constantly observes the faults of others and is always fault-finding, mental defilements increase; he is far from the extinction of defilements.
verses.commentary: This verse warns against habitual fault-finding. Those who constantly criticize others strengthen their own defilements—particularly pride, aversion, and wrong view. Rather than progressing toward liberation, such people move further from it, as their practice of finding fault actually cultivates unwholesome mental states.

story.title: The Story of Thera Ujjhanasanni
story.content: Thera Ujjhanasanni constantly found fault with other bhikkhus, criticizing their posture, eating habits, teaching methods, and meditation practices. Nothing satisfied him; he perpetually complained and spoke disparagingly about fellow monks. Other bhikkhus, disturbed by his negativity, reported his behavior to the Buddha. The Buddha explained that constructive criticism offered with compassion to help others improve is wholesome, but Ujjhanasanni's fault-finding arose from spite and malice. Such habitual criticism prevents concentration and jhana attainment. Rather than purifying his mind through practice, Ujjhanasanni's defilements—especially aversion and pride—actually increased through constant judgment of others. The Buddha taught that practitioners must focus on their own purification, not endlessly cataloging others' imperfections. True progress comes from self-examination, not fault-finding in others.

verses.pali: Ākāse padaṁ natthi, samaṇo natthi bāhire; Papañcābhiratā pajā, nippapañcā Tathāgatā.
verses.translation: In the sky there is no track; outside the Buddha's Teaching there is no true monk. All beings delight in conceptual proliferation; the Buddhas are free from proliferation.
verses.commentary: This verse asserts three truths: there are no footprints in sky (nothing permanent in phenomena), no true spiritual attainment outside Buddha's Teaching, and while ordinary beings cling to proliferating concepts and attachments, Buddhas abide in non-proliferation—free from craving, conceit, and views.

story.title: The Story of Subhadda the Wandering Ascetic
story.content: Subhadda, a wandering ascetic in Kusinara, heard the Buddha would pass into parinibbana that night. For years, he'd questioned six famous teachers about three matters: Are there tracks in the sky? Are true monks found outside various teachings? Are formations permanent? None satisfied him. Racing to the Sal Grove, Venerable Ānanda thrice refused him entry, protecting the weakened Buddha. But the Buddha overheard and invited Subhadda in, knowing he was the Buddha's last personal convert. The Buddha answered all three questions negatively, explaining the Noble Eightfold Path as the only way to liberation. Teachings lacking this path cannot produce true arahats. Deeply moved, Subhadda requested ordination. The Buddha granted immediate admission without the usual probation. Subhadda attained anagami fruition during the teaching, ordained, and achieved full arahatship before the Buddha's parinibbana.

verses.pali: Ākāse padaṁ natthi, samaṇo natthi bāhire; Saṅkhārā sassatā natthi, natthi Buddhānamiñjitaṁ.
verses.translation: In the sky there is no track; outside the Buddha's Teaching there is no true monk. There is no conditioned thing that is permanent; the Buddhas are unshakeable.
verses.commentary: This verse reinforces the previous teaching, adding that all conditioned phenomena are impermanent (contradicting eternalist views), while Buddhas remain unshaken—not because they're eternal, but because they're freed from craving, conceit, and views that cause agitation. This represents the Middle Way between eternalism and annihilationism.

story.title: The Story of Subhadda the Wandering Ascetic
story.content: Continuing his final teaching to Subhadda, the Buddha addressed the third question about permanence with particular emphasis. Throughout his spiritual search, Subhadda encountered teachers claiming various formations—soul, self, aggregates, or consciousness—were eternal. The Buddha decisively rejected eternalism, explaining that all conditioned phenomena arise and pass away; nothing composite is permanent. Yet the Buddha didn't advocate nihilism either. While formations are impermanent, Buddhas achieve unshakeable peace not through eternal existence but through complete liberation from the very craving, conceit, and views that seek permanence. This profound teaching illuminated Subhadda's understanding completely. In his final hours, the Buddha demonstrated perfect compassion, ensuring even this latecomer received saving wisdom. Subhadda became the Buddha's last direct disciple, a fitting conclusion to forty-five years of teaching countless beings the path to freedom.

chapters.summary: This chapter explores the nature of true justice and righteousness, teaching that wisdom comes not from speaking much but from living peacefully and fearlessly in accordance with truth.

verses.pali:
Na tena hoti dhammaṭṭho, yenatthaṁ sāhasā naye;
Yo ca atthaṁ anatthañca, ubho niccheyya paṇḍito.
verses.translation: One is not just if one hastily arbitrates cases. The wise person investigates both what is right and what is wrong.
verses.commentary: True justice requires careful deliberation, not hasty judgments. A just person thoroughly examines all aspects of a matter - both the merits and demerits, the true and the false. Making quick decisions without proper investigation, even if one appears authoritative, does not constitute real justice. The verse emphasizes that wisdom lies in thorough, impartial examination.

story.title: The Story of Corrupt Judges
story.content: One day, bhikkhus returning from their alms round took shelter from rain in a law court. They observed judges accepting bribes and deciding cases arbitrarily, favoring those who paid them while ignoring evidence and justice. The monks were disturbed by this corruption and reported it to the Buddha. The Buddha explained that such judges, though they held positions of authority and made quick decisions, were not truly just. A righteous judge must examine evidence carefully and impartially, considering both sides thoroughly before reaching a decision. He emphasized that real justice requires wisdom, patience, and integrity - qualities these corrupt judges lacked. The verse was spoken to distinguish between those who merely hold judicial positions and those who truly embody justice through careful, unbiased deliberation.

verses.pali:
Asāhasena dhammena, samena nayatī pare;
Dhammassa gutto medhāvī, 'dhammaṭṭho'ti pavuccati.
verses.translation: The intelligent person who leads others not falsely but lawfully and impartially, who is a guardian of the law - that person is called 'one established in Dhamma'.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the true judge or leader. They guide others according to truth (not falsely), according to Dhamma (lawfully), and with equanimity (impartially). Being a 'guardian of the law' means protecting and upholding justice, not merely enforcing rules. Such a person deserves the title 'dhammaṭṭha' - one established in or abiding by Dhamma.

story.title: The Qualities of a True Judge
story.content: Continuing his teaching about justice, the Buddha described what makes a true judge. It's not the title, position, or even legal knowledge alone, but the character and conduct of the person. A genuine judge leads others according to what is right, not according to personal bias, bribery, or favoritism. They apply the law fairly to rich and poor, friend and stranger alike. Such a person acts as a guardian - protecting justice itself, not just their own interests or authority. The Buddha explained that in spiritual matters too, teachers must embody these same qualities - guiding students according to truth, teaching the Dhamma faithfully, and treating all with equity. Only such wise and impartial individuals can be called 'established in Dhamma.' The monks understood that whether in courts or monasteries, true leadership requires integrity, wisdom, and justice.

verses.pali:
Na tena paṇḍito hoti, yāvatā bahu bhāsati;
Khemī averī abhayo, 'paṇḍito'ti pavuccati.
verses.translation: One is not wise because one speaks much. One who is peaceful, free from hatred and fear - that person is called wise.
verses.commentary: Wisdom is not measured by eloquence or verbosity. A truly wise person is characterized by three qualities: peace (khemī), absence of hatred (averī), and fearlessness (abhayo). These internal qualities - calmness, loving-kindness, and courage - define wisdom, not the ability to speak impressively or at length. The verse redirects attention from external display to internal cultivation.

story.title: The Group of Six Boastful Monks
story.content: A notorious group of six bhikkhus caused trouble wherever they went. They were loud, boastful, and disruptive. One day, while young novices were peacefully eating their meal, these six monks burst in proclaiming, "We are the truly wise ones! We know so much!" They talked incessantly, boasting of their knowledge and learning. Then they began throwing food and utensils about, creating chaos and leaving the dining area in complete disorder before strutting away. When other monks reported this behavior to the Buddha, he spoke this verse. He explained that speaking much, even about Dhamma, doesn't make one wise - especially when accompanied by arrogance and harmful behavior. True wisdom manifests as peacefulness, freedom from anger and hatred, and absence of fear. These six monks, despite their learning and eloquence, lacked these essential qualities and thus were not truly wise but merely learned fools.

verses.translation: One is not a Dhamma-bearer just because one speaks much. One who, having heard even a little, sees the Dhamma through the body and is not heedless of the Dhamma - that person is truly a Dhamma-bearer.
verses.commentary: Being learned in Dhamma texts doesn't make one a true practitioner. 'Seeing the Dhamma through the body' (kāyena passati) means direct experiential realization through practice, not mere intellectual understanding. Even knowing little but practicing diligently and mindfully makes one a genuine bearer of the Dhamma. The emphasis is on lived experience and heedfulness rather than scholarly knowledge.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Ekudāna
story.content: A monk named Ekudāna lived in a forest grove near Sāvatthi. He knew only one stanza of the teachings by heart, but he fully understood its profound meaning and practiced it perfectly. Every Uposatha day, he would recite this single verse to visitors. When he finished, forest devas would applaud enthusiastically, rejoicing in his deep understanding. One Uposatha day, two learned monks who had memorized the entire Tipiṭaka arrived with five hundred followers. Ekudāna invited them to teach, but they asked skeptically if anyone in this remote place even wanted to hear Dhamma. Ekudāna then recited his one verse with such depth and clarity that the visiting monks were moved, and the devas' applause resounded through the forest. The Buddha, hearing of this, spoke this verse to explain that Ekudāna, though knowing little scripture, was a true Dhamma-bearer because he practiced what he knew with perfect mindfulness and realized its meaning directly in his experience.

verses.pali:
Na tena thero so hoti, yenassa palitaṁ siro;
Paripakko vayo tassa, 'moghajiṇṇo'ti vuccati.
verses.translation: One does not become a thera merely because one's hair is grey. One who is merely ripe in age is called 'grown old in vain'.
verses.commentary: The title 'thera' (elder) should signify spiritual maturity, not just physical age. Grey hair indicates years lived but not necessarily wisdom gained. Someone old in years but lacking in virtue and realization is 'moghajiṇṇa' - uselessly aged. True seniority in the Dhamma comes from practice and attainment, not from the passage of time.

story.title: The Story of Thera Bhaddiya
story.content: Venerable Bhaddiya was extremely short in stature and young in appearance, though he was actually quite senior in ordination. He was known as Lakundaka Bhaddiya ('Dwarf Bhaddiya') due to his small build. One day, thirty monks came to pay respects to the Buddha. The Buddha, knowing they were ready for enlightenment, asked if they had seen a thera on their way in. They replied that they had seen only a young novice, not a senior monk. The Buddha smiled and explained that the person they saw was actually a thera, despite his youthful appearance and small size. He emphasized that being a true elder doesn't depend on age, grey hair, or physical appearance. Bhaddiya, though young-looking, had deep realization of the Four Noble Truths and caused harm to no one - these qualities made him a genuine thera. The Buddha taught that many monks might be old with grey hair but if they lack wisdom and virtue, they've merely 'grown old in vain.'

verses.pali:
Yamhi saccañca dhammo ca, ahiṁsā saṁyamo damo;
Sa ve vantamalo dhīro, 'thero'ti pavuccati.
verses.translation: In whom there is truthfulness, Dhamma, harmlessness, restraint and self-control - that wise one who has shed defilements is called a thera.
verses.commentary: This verse lists the qualities of a true elder: truthfulness (sacca), righteousness (dhamma), non-violence (ahiṁsā), sense-restraint (saṁyama), and self-mastery (dama). Additionally, being 'vantamala' (having expelled defilements) and 'dhīra' (wise/steadfast) complete the profile. These internal qualities, not external markers, define spiritual seniority.

story.title: The True Qualities of a Thera
story.content: After explaining that Bhaddiya's small size and youthful appearance didn't disqualify him from being a thera, the Buddha elaborated on what truly makes an elder. He listed five essential qualities: speaking truthfully in all circumstances; living according to Dhamma; practicing absolute non-harm to all beings; maintaining restraint over the six senses; and exercising complete self-control in thought, word, and deed. Furthermore, a true thera must have purified the mind of defilements through meditation and insight, and must possess the steadfast wisdom that comes from direct realization. Bhaddiya possessed all these qualities despite his unprepossessing appearance. Many outwardly impressive monks lacked these essentials and thus were not genuine theras. The thirty visiting monks, understanding this teaching deeply, all attained arahantship during that discourse. They realized that spiritual maturity is measured by internal transformation, not external appearance or years of age. This profound lesson transformed their understanding of what it means to be an elder in the Dhamma.

verses.pali:
Na vākkaraṇamattena, vaṇṇapokkharatāya vā;
Sādhurūpo naro hoti, issukī maccharī saṭho.
verses.translation: Not by mere eloquence, nor by handsome appearance, does one become good-natured, if one is jealous, selfish and deceitful.
verses.commentary: External qualities - eloquent speech and attractive appearance - don't make someone genuinely good if internal defilements persist. Jealousy (issā), miserliness (macchariya), and deceitfulness (sāṭheyya) corrupt character regardless of outward charm. True goodness requires purity of mind and intention, not superficial attractiveness.

story.title: The Monks Who Judged by Appearance
story.content: Several monks traveling together met other monks who were eloquent speakers and physically handsome. Impressed by these external qualities, they assumed these monks were virtuous and praised them to others. However, when they observed these monks more closely over time, they discovered troubling behavior. Despite their pleasing speech and appearance, these monks were intensely jealous of others' success, extremely stingy with their possessions, and deceitful in their dealings - often lying to gain advantage or avoid responsibility. The traveling monks, disappointed and confused, reported this to the Buddha. He explained that eloquence and good looks are merely external decorations that reveal nothing about actual character. Someone might speak beautifully yet harbor jealousy, appear attractive yet be deeply selfish, or present well yet be fundamentally dishonest. True goodness requires purification of these inner defilements. The Buddha urged monks to look beyond surface appearances and evaluate people based on their genuine qualities of mind and heart.

verses.pali:
Yassa cetaṁ samucchinnaṁ, mūlaghaccaṁ samūhataṁ;
Sa vantadoso medhāvī, 'sādhurūpo'ti vuccati.
verses.translation: One in whom these are completely cut off, uprooted and destroyed - that wise one who has expelled faults is called good-natured.
verses.commentary: True goodness comes from completely eliminating jealousy, selfishness, and deceit - not just suppressing them but uprooting them entirely. 'Samucchinnaṁ' (cut off), 'mūlaghaccaṁ' (destroyed at the root), and 'samūhataṁ' (removed) emphasize thorough eradication. Only one who has expelled these faults and possesses wisdom deserves to be called genuinely good.

story.title: The Transformation of Character
story.content: After explaining that external qualities don't constitute genuine goodness, the Buddha described what does. He emphasized that these three defilements - jealousy, selfishness, and deceit - must not merely be controlled or hidden, but completely eradicated from their roots. Surface control isn't enough; the tendencies must be destroyed entirely through meditation and insight. One monk in the assembly had struggled with jealousy for years. Whenever other monks received offerings or praise, he felt painful envy, though he tried to hide it. Hearing this teaching, he understood that suppression wasn't the answer - he needed to uproot the jealousy entirely through practice. He intensified his meditation on loving-kindness and contemplation of impermanence. Gradually, as his practice deepened, the jealousy dissolved completely. When he finally achieved this, his whole demeanor transformed. People naturally felt drawn to his genuine warmth and openness. The Buddha confirmed that now, having expelled these faults, he could truly be called 'good-natured' - not because of how he looked or spoke, but because of his purified mind.

verses.pali:
Na muṇḍakena samaṇo, abbato alikaṁ bhaṇaṁ;
Icchālobhasamāpanno, samaṇo kiṁ bhavissati.
verses.translation: Not by a shaven head does one become a monk if one lacks self-control and speaks falsely. How can one filled with desire and greed be a monk?
verses.commentary: The external sign of renunciation - a shaved head - doesn't make someone a true monk (samaṇa). Without inner discipline, truthfulness, and freedom from craving, the external appearance is meaningless. A genuine monk must have restrained desires and be free from greed. This verse questions how someone dominated by craving and acquisitiveness could possibly be considered a true renunciant.

story.title: The Story of the Undisciplined Monk
story.content: A monk named Hatthaka had an impressive appearance - he wore the robes properly, walked with dignity, and looked every bit the serious practitioner. However, his conduct contradicted his appearance. He constantly sought the best food, finest robes, and most comfortable lodgings. He would lie to donors, exaggerating his needs and attainments to receive more offerings. He competed jealously with other monks for support and reputation. His desires for comfort and material things were insatiable, and his greed for gain was obvious to observant laypeople. Some questioned how such a person could be considered a true monk. When this reached the Buddha, he spoke this verse. He explained that simply shaving one's head and wearing robes doesn't make one a monk - these are just external symbols. True monasticism requires inner transformation: genuine self-control, unwavering truthfulness, and freedom from desires and greed. Hatthaka, despite his appearance, wasn't a real monk but merely someone wearing monk's clothing. This teaching helped many understand that genuine renunciation is a matter of mind, not merely appearance.

verses.pali:
Yo ca sameti pāpāni, aṇuṁ thūlāni sabbaso;
Samitattā hi pāpānaṁ, 'samaṇo'ti pavuccati.
verses.translation: One who completely calms all evil, both small and great - because of having calmed evils, that person is called a monk.
verses.commentary: A true monk (samaṇa) is defined by having calmed or pacified (sameti) all unwholesome states, from the subtlest to the grossest. The term 'samaṇa' is etymologically connected to 'sameti' (to calm/pacify). Complete elimination of evil - not just major sins but even minor unwholesome tendencies - qualifies one as a genuine monk. This is about inner purification, not external status.

story.title: The Definition of a True Monk
story.content: Following his teaching about the undisciplined Hatthaka, the Buddha explained what actually makes someone a samaṇa (monk). The word itself means 'one who has calmed' - referring to the calming and elimination of all unwholesome mental states. This includes not only obvious evils like killing, stealing, and lying, but also subtle defilements like mild irritation, small attachments, and minor selfishness. A genuine monk works systematically to pacify all these, from the coarsest to the most refined. In contrast, Hatthaka had only the external markers of monasticism while his mind remained turbulent with desires and defilements. The Buddha pointed to Venerable Bhaddiya (from the earlier story) as a true example - he had pacified all evil, large and small, through diligent practice. His mind was genuinely calm, free from the turbulence of craving and aversion. This internal peace, not the shaved head or robes, made him a real monk. The assembly understood that authentic monasticism is measured by the degree of internal purification achieved, not by external appearance or years of ordination.

verses.pali:
Na tena bhikkhu so hoti, yāvatā bhikkhate pare;
Visamaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya, bhikkhu hoti na tāvatā.
verses.translation: One is not a bhikkhu merely because one begs from others. By adopting a faith that is not genuine, one does not become a bhikkhu.
verses.commentary: The term 'bhikkhu' literally means 'one who begs', but merely begging for alms doesn't make someone a genuine bhikkhu. Similarly, merely adopting the appearance or rhetoric of Buddhism without genuine faith and practice (visamaṁ dhammaṁ - an inconsistent or false dhamma) doesn't qualify one. True bhikkhu-hood requires authentic commitment and practice, not just external activities.

story.title: The Story of a Wandering Ascetic
story.content: A brahmin ascetic observed that Buddhist monks received generous offerings while going on alms round. Thinking this was an easy way to obtain food and respect, he shaved his head, put on robes resembling those of monks, and began begging for alms in the same manner. He learned some Buddhist terminology and would recite phrases he'd heard, though he neither believed nor practiced them. Outwardly, he appeared to be a bhikkhu, going door to door with a bowl. However, his motivation was purely materialistic - he wanted the benefits of monasticism without its commitments or discipline. He had no genuine faith in the Buddha's teachings and made no effort to practice meditation, morality, or wisdom. When questions arose about such individuals, the Buddha spoke this verse. He explained that the word 'bhikkhu' comes from begging alms, but begging alone doesn't make one a true bhikkhu. Merely adopting Buddhism superficially, without genuine understanding or commitment, is insufficient. A real bhikkhu must have authentic faith, sincere practice, and genuine transformation - not just the external appearance and activities of monasticism.

verses.pali:
Yodha puññañca pāpañca, bāhetvā brahmacariyavā;
Saṅkhāya loke carati, sa ve 'bhikkhū'ti vuccati.
verses.translation: One who has transcended both merit and demerit in this world, who lives the holy life, who lives in the world with understanding - that person is truly called a bhikkhu.
verses.commentary: A genuine bhikkhu has gone beyond attachment to both good and bad karma (puñña and pāpa), lives the celibate holy life (brahmacariyavā), and moves through the world with wisdom and discernment (saṅkhāya). This describes an advanced practitioner who has transcended conventional morality through direct realization, yet continues living wisely and purely. True bhikkhu-hood is this state of wisdom and liberation.

story.title: The Complete Understanding of Bhikkhu
story.content: After explaining what doesn't make a bhikkhu, the Buddha described what does. He taught that a true bhikkhu has transcended even attachment to merit-making - not by abandoning virtue, but by realizing the ultimate truth beyond conventional good and evil. Such a monk lives the holy life completely, maintaining perfect celibacy and purity. Most importantly, he moves through the world with deep understanding, seeing all phenomena with wisdom born of direct insight into impermanence, suffering, and not-self. Several senior monks in the assembly exemplified this. They had long ago abandoned not only evil but also clinging to good deeds as 'mine'. They lived impeccably pure lives, yet without pride or attachment to their virtue. They engaged with the world skillfully, helping others while remaining internally free. These were genuine bhikkhus - not because they begged alms or wore robes, but because they had realized the profound truths of existence and lived accordingly. The distinction became clear: external forms versus internal realization, appearance versus authentic transformation.

verses.pali:
Na monena munī hoti, mūḷharūpo aviddasu;
Yo ca tulaṁva paggayha, varamādāya paṇḍito.
verses.translation: One does not become a sage through silence if one is foolish and ignorant. But one who, as if holding scales, takes what is best and avoids evil - that wise person is a sage.
verses.commentary: Silence (mona) alone doesn't make one a muni (sage) if ignorance remains. The true sage discriminates wisely, like someone carefully weighing items on scales, choosing what is beneficial and rejecting what is harmful. This requires wisdom (paññā), not mere silence. The verse emphasizes discernment and wise choice as marks of a genuine sage.

story.title: The Silent Ascetics
story.content: Several ascetics from non-Buddhist traditions practiced strict vows of silence, believing this made them holy sages. They would not speak for months or even years, thinking silence itself purified them and brought spiritual attainment. They looked down on Buddhist monks who taught and conversed, considering them spiritually inferior. Some people were confused, wondering if these silent ascetics were more advanced than the Buddha's articulate disciples. When this matter was brought to the Buddha, he spoke this verse. He explained that silence, by itself, means nothing if the mind remains filled with ignorance, confusion, and defilements. One could be silent for years while internally harboring anger, lust, and delusion - this is merely mute foolishness, not wisdom. A true sage, in contrast, actively engages in discernment - like a merchant carefully weighing goods on scales, the wise person evaluates options and consistently chooses what is wholesome while avoiding what is harmful. This requires wisdom and understanding, not just refraining from speech. Therefore, the eloquent, teaching Buddhist monks who possessed wisdom were true munis, while the silent but ignorant ascetics were not.

verses.pali:
Pāpāni parivajjeti, sa munī tena so muni;
Yo munāti ubho loke, 'muni' tena pavuccati.
verses.translation: One is a sage because one avoids evil. One who understands both worlds internally and externally - for that reason one is called a sage.
verses.commentary: The verse plays on the etymology of 'muni' from the root 'munāti' (to understand/know). A sage avoids evil through understanding. Moreover, they comprehend both the internal world (mind, mental states) and external world (matter, phenomena). This complete understanding - ethical, experiential, and philosophical - qualifies one as a true muni.

story.title: The Understanding That Makes a Sage
story.content: Continuing his teaching about who is truly a sage, the Buddha explained the deeper meaning of the term 'muni'. The word comes from understanding - specifically, the profound understanding of reality both internal and external. A genuine sage understands the internal world: how the mind works, how feelings arise, how thoughts condition actions, how defilements operate, and how liberation is achieved. Simultaneously, they understand the external world: the nature of matter, the arising and passing of phenomena, the interplay of causes and conditions. Most importantly, this understanding isn't mere intellectual knowledge but direct experiential realization. Armed with this complete understanding, the sage naturally avoids all evil - not through effort or external rules, but because wisdom itself prevents unwholesome action. It becomes impossible for one who truly understands to act harmfully. In contrast, the silent ascetics understood neither themselves nor the world. Their silence was based on the naive belief that not speaking was itself purifying. The Buddha's enlightened disciples, however, possessed profound understanding and therefore were authentic sages, regardless of whether they spoke or remained silent.

verses.pali:
Na tena ariyo hoti, yena pāṇāni hiṁsati;
Ahiṁsā sabbapāṇānaṁ, 'ariyo'ti pavuccati.
verses.translation: One is not noble if one harms living beings. Through non-violence toward all living beings, one is called noble.
verses.commentary: The term 'ariya' (noble) is not determined by birth, status, or even knowledge, but by conduct - specifically, by practicing ahiṁsā (non-harming) toward all living beings. Violence disqualifies one from true nobility. Conversely, thoroughgoing non-violence toward all creatures qualifies one as genuinely noble. This redefines nobility in ethical rather than social terms.

story.title: The Fisherman Named Ariya
story.content: A man named Ariya worked as a fisherman, killing fish daily to earn his livelihood. Despite his name meaning 'noble', his occupation involved constant violence toward living creatures. Some people found this ironic and asked the Buddha about it - could someone who kills for a living truly be noble, even if named so? The Buddha emphatically answered no, then spoke this verse. He explained that true nobility has nothing to do with one's name, birth, caste, or family lineage. In ancient India, 'ariya' often referred to those of noble birth, but the Buddha completely redefined the term. A person is noble only if they practice complete non-violence toward all living beings - not killing, not causing harm, not exploiting or oppressing any creature. This includes obvious violence like killing, but also subtle harm through harsh words, cruel intentions, or exploitative actions. Conversely, regardless of one's birth or name, if one harms others, one cannot be considered noble. True nobility is demonstrated through compassionate, harmless conduct toward all life. The fisherman Ariya, despite his auspicious name, was not truly noble due to his violent occupation.

verses.pali:
Na sīlabbatamattena, bāhusaccena vā puna;
Atha vā samādhilābhena, vivittasayanena vā.
verses.translation: Not merely by virtue and observances, nor again by much learning, nor by attaining concentration, nor by dwelling in seclusion...
verses.commentary: This verse begins a two-verse teaching, listing what is insufficient for final liberation: virtue and observances (sīlabbata), extensive learning (bāhusacca), meditative concentration (samādhi), or secluded dwelling (vivittasayana). While all these are valuable practices, none individually or collectively guarantee liberation if practiced without wisdom or if practiced with complacency.

story.title: The Monks Who Stopped Too Soon
story.content: Several accomplished monks had achieved impressive spiritual milestones. Some were renowned for their perfect observance of precepts and monastic rules - their conduct was beyond reproach. Others had memorized vast portions of the scriptures and could recite them flawlessly. Some had developed deep meditative concentration, able to enter jhānas at will. Still others lived in complete seclusion in remote forests, undisturbed by worldly concerns. Despite these genuine achievements, all of them shared a dangerous tendency: they became complacent, thinking their accomplishments were sufficient. They believed their perfect morality, or their learning, or their meditative abilities, or their secluded lifestyle had brought them to the final goal. They stopped striving for Arahantship, content with their partial attainments. The Buddha, seeing this complacency with his divine eye, was concerned. These monks were close to final liberation but had stopped at the threshold. He spoke these verses to them, warning that none of these practices alone - however perfected - constitutes final liberation.

verses.pali:
Phusāmi nekkhammasukhaṁ, aputhujjanasevitaṁ;
Bhikkhu vissāsamāpādi, appatto āsavakkhayaṁ.
verses.translation: ...nor by thinking 'I experience the bliss of renunciation not resorted to by ordinary people' should a bhikkhu rest content without attaining the destruction of all taints.
verses.commentary: This verse completes the previous thought. Even experiencing the refined bliss of renunciation (nekkhammasukha) - a happiness beyond what ordinary people know - is insufficient reason for complacency. A bhikkhu should not rest satisfied (vissāsamāpādi) until achieving complete destruction of all āsavas (mental taints). Partial attainment, however pleasant or impressive, is not the final goal.

story.title: The Warning Against Complacency
story.content: The Buddha completed his teaching to the complacent monks by addressing another form of self-satisfaction: the bliss experienced by advanced practitioners. He explained that those who have made significant progress on the path often experience a profound joy and peace that ordinary worldlings never know - the happiness that comes from renunciation, the bliss of meditation, the contentment of virtue. This experience can be deeply satisfying, and therein lies a danger. Some practitioners, tasting this bliss, think they have reached the destination. They become content, believing they have achieved what they sought. But the Buddha warned firmly: even this refined bliss, though far superior to sensual pleasures, is not the ultimate goal. A bhikkhu must not rest satisfied until all āsavas - the deep mental taints of sensual desire, desire for becoming, wrong views, and ignorance - are completely destroyed. Only Arahantship represents final liberation. The monks hearing this teaching were shaken from their complacency. They renewed their practice with urgency and diligence. Many of them subsequently attained Arahantship, fulfilling the Buddha's hopes and justifying his firm warning.

chapters.summary: This chapter provides guidance on the Noble Eightfold Path, emphasizing its role as the way to purification, the cessation of suffering, and the attainment of Nibbāna.

verses.pali:
Maggānaṭṭhaṅgiko seṭṭho, saccānaṁ caturo padā;
Virāgo seṭṭho dhammānaṁ, dipadānañca cakkhumā.
verses.translation: Of all paths, the Noble Eightfold Path is the best. Of all truths, the Four Noble Truths are the best. Of all states, detachment is the best. Of all two-footed beings, the one with vision is the best.
verses.commentary: This verse declares four supremacies: the Eightfold Path is supreme among all spiritual paths, the Four Noble Truths are supreme among all teachings, detachment (virāga/Nibbāna) is supreme among all mental states, and the Buddha (the 'one with vision') is supreme among humans. These represent the path, the teaching, the goal, and the teacher - the complete framework for liberation.

story.title: The Story of Five Hundred Monks
story.content: Five hundred monks received a meditation subject from the Buddha and went to practice in the forest. After some time, they returned seeking further guidance. The Buddha surveyed their capacities and found them ripe for enlightenment. He taught them about the supremacy of the Eightfold Path, explaining that among all possible spiritual practices and philosophies, this path alone leads directly to liberation. He emphasized the Four Noble Truths as the framework for understanding reality, detachment as the supreme state to be achieved, and reminded them that he, having realized these truths, possessed the vision to guide them. The monks listened with full attention, understanding the preciousness of what they had received. Contemplating the teaching deeply, all five hundred attained Arahantship, realizing for themselves the supreme path the Buddha had described. Their direct experience confirmed the truth of his words.

verses.pali:
Esova maggo natthañño, dassanassa visuddhiyā;
Etaṁ hi tumhe paṭipajjatha, mārass'etaṁ pamohanaṁ.
verses.translation: This is the only path; there is no other for the purification of vision. Follow this path, and you will confound Māra.
verses.commentary: The Buddha declares the uniqueness and exclusivity of the Noble Eightfold Path for achieving 'purification of vision' (insight/vipassanā). No other path, practice, or teaching leads to the same liberation. By following this path, one bewilders and defeats Māra (representing all defilements and obstacles), as the path leads beyond his domain.

story.title: The Only Path to Purity
story.content: Continuing his discourse to the five hundred monks, the Buddha emphasized the exclusivity of his teaching. Many spiritual teachers in India claimed to offer paths to liberation, but the Buddha declared unequivocally that the Eightfold Path is the only way to achieve true purification of vision - the direct seeing of things as they really are. This path doesn't merely provide temporary peace or philosophical understanding; it systematically purifies perception, revealing the three characteristics of existence: impermanence, suffering, and not-self. The Buddha explained that by following this path diligently, practitioners would confuse and overcome Māra, who cannot follow or intercept those walking this way. Māra's power comes from ignorance, craving, and delusion, but this path destroys all three. The monks understood that they had found not just a good path among many, but the singular path to complete freedom from suffering.

verses.pali:
Etaṁ hi tumhe paṭipannā, dukkhassantaṁ karissatha;
Akkhāto vo mayā maggo, aññāya sallasanthanaṁ.
verses.translation: Following this path, you will make an end to suffering. I have taught you this path, having myself learned how to remove the thorn.
verses.commentary: The Buddha assures practitioners that by following the Eightfold Path, they will definitely end suffering. He speaks from personal experience - he discovered through his own enlightenment how to remove the 'thorn' (salla) of craving, which causes pain. The path he teaches is not theoretical but based on his direct realization of how to extract suffering at its root.

story.title: The Thorn of Craving Removed
story.content: The Buddha shared with the monks his personal discovery of this path. The 'thorn' represents craving (taṇhā), which pierces beings and causes constant pain. Before his enlightenment, Prince Siddhattha had tried various paths - extreme asceticism, philosophical inquiry, and different meditation systems - but none removed this thorn completely. Only through developing the Eightfold Path to perfection did he discover how to extract craving entirely, root and all. Now, from his own experience, he could confidently teach others this same method. The removal isn't temporary relief but permanent extraction. When craving is completely uprooted through wisdom, suffering ends definitively. The monks appreciated that their teacher spoke not from speculation but from his own triumphant experience. This gave them confidence that by following his guidance faithfully, they too would remove the thorn and end all suffering.

verses.pali:
Tumhehi kiccaṁ ātappaṁ, akkhātāro tathāgatā;
Paṭipannā pamokkhanti, jhāyino mārabandhanā.
verses.translation: You yourselves must make the effort; the Tathāgatas only point the way. Those who meditate and follow the path are freed from Māra's bonds.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes personal responsibility in spiritual practice. The Buddha can teach and guide, but the actual work of liberation must be done by each practitioner. 'Tathāgatas' (Buddhas) are teachers who show the way, but walking the path is each person's own task. Those who practice meditation (jhāyino) and follow the path diligently will be released from Māra's bonds.

story.title: Individual Effort Required
story.content: After teaching the path, the Buddha emphasized a crucial point: he could only show the way; each person must walk it themselves. No external being, not even a Buddha, can liberate another. This teaching was revolutionary - it contradicted the common belief that gods, priests, or rituals could grant salvation. The Buddha explained that liberation requires personal transformation through one's own effort, just as no one can eat on behalf of another to satisfy their hunger. He illustrated with meditation (jhāyino): while he could teach techniques, each practitioner must sit, concentrate, and develop insight personally. External guidance is like a map showing the route to a destination; the map doesn't transport you there - you must travel yourself. However, the Buddha assured that those who do make the effort, who meditate regularly and follow the path's eight factors, will definitely be freed from Māra's bonds - the fetters of greed, hatred, and delusion that keep beings imprisoned in suffering.

verses.pali:
Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccāti, yadā paññāya passati;
Atha nibbindati dukkhe, esa maggo visuddhiyā.
verses.translation: When one sees with wisdom that all conditioned things are impermanent, one becomes weary of suffering. This is the path to purification.
verses.commentary: This verse introduces the first of the three characteristics of existence. When through wisdom (not mere intellectual knowledge) one truly sees that all conditioned phenomena (saṅkhāra) are impermanent, constantly changing and unreliable, dispassion arises. This seeing leads to weariness (nibbindā) with suffering and the conditions that produce it, which is itself the path to purification.

story.title: Seeing Impermanence with Wisdom
story.content: The five hundred monks, having received the general teaching about the path, now received specific meditation instructions. The Buddha guided them to contemplate the three characteristics of existence, beginning with impermanence. He explained that intellectual understanding of impermanence differs vastly from seeing it with wisdom through direct meditative observation. One must watch phenomena - thoughts, feelings, sensations, perceptions - arising and passing away moment by moment. Through sustained observation, the meditator directly experiences the ceaseless flux of all conditioned things. Nothing remains stable even for an instant. This direct seeing produces a profound shift: one becomes naturally disenchanted with phenomena that once seemed solid and desirable. Attachment spontaneously loosens when one viscerally experiences that everything is dissolving constantly. This growing dispassion itself constitutes the path to purification, as attachment is the root of impurity. The monks practiced this contemplation intensively, and as they directly perceived impermanence throughout their experience, their minds purified and many attained liberation.

verses.pali:
Sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhāti, yadā paññāya passati;
Atha nibbindati dukkhe, esa maggo visuddhiyā.
verses.translation: When one sees with wisdom that all conditioned things are unsatisfactory, one becomes weary of suffering. This is the path to purification.
verses.commentary: This verse presents the second characteristic of existence: dukkha (unsatisfactoriness/suffering). When one perceives with wisdom that all conditioned phenomena are inherently unsatisfactory - unable to provide lasting happiness - dispassion arises. Even pleasant experiences are tinged with suffering because they're impermanent and don't ultimately satisfy. This insight leads to purification.

story.title: Understanding Suffering in All Conditions
story.content: The Buddha continued teaching the contemplation of the three characteristics. He guided the monks to observe that all conditioned phenomena are fundamentally unsatisfactory (dukkha). This doesn't mean everything is painful in an obvious way, but that all experiences fail to provide lasting satisfaction. Pleasant experiences are unsatisfactory because they end; unpleasant ones are obviously unsatisfactory; even neutral experiences are unsatisfactory because they're subject to change. The monks practiced observing this characteristic in their meditation and daily life. They noticed how even moments of peace or pleasure contained a subtle tension, an incompleteness, because these states couldn't last. Food satisfied hunger temporarily but hunger returned. Rest relieved fatigue but fatigue recurred. Even deep meditative bliss eventually ended. Through this profound seeing, they became genuinely dispassionate toward all conditioned phenomena. They stopped seeking ultimate satisfaction in anything impermanent. This shift in perspective itself purified the mind, loosening the grip of craving.

verses.pali:
Sabbe dhammā anattāti, yadā paññāya passati;
Atha nibbindati dukkhe, esa maggo visuddhiyā.
verses.translation: When one sees with wisdom that all phenomena are not-self, one becomes weary of suffering. This is the path to purification.
verses.commentary: This verse presents the third and most profound characteristic: anattā (not-self). All phenomena (dhamma), including mental states, are without an enduring self or essence. When this is seen with wisdom, not just understood intellectually, dispassion arises and purification occurs. This insight strikes at the root of identification and clinging.

story.title: The Deepest Insight: Not-Self
story.content: The Buddha taught the most profound contemplation: seeing that all phenomena lack inherent self or essence. This goes beyond impermanence and suffering to question the very nature of existence. The monks practiced observing: where is the 'I' in this experience? The body constantly changes - is that 'me'?
