One day, while Ugrasena was performing high in the air for a large crowd, the Buddha arrived. The Buddha called out to him, not to watch his physical balance, but to teach him about spiritual balance. He spoke this verse, telling Ugrasena to 'let go' of what is in front, what is behind, and what is in the middle. In the context of the acrobat, this meant letting go of the fear of falling (future), the pride of his past performances, and the attachment to the girl in the present. More deeply, the Buddha was teaching him to 'transcend' the timeline of the ego. He explained that if Ugrasena could 'let go' of his mental grip on all three periods of time, his mind would reach the 'farther shore' (paragu) of existence. On that shore, there is no more 'Jati-jara' (birth and decay) because there is no 'self' left to be born or to age. Ugrasena, while still balanced on the very top of the pole, took the Buddha’s words so deeply to heart that he achieved full enlightenment (Arhatship) right then and there. He climbed down, not as a performer seeking applause, but as a liberated being who had finally let go of the 'pole' of existence itself.

verses.pali: Vitakkapamathitassa jantuno, tibbarāgassa subhānupassino; bhiyyo taṇhā pavaḍḍhati, esa kho daḷhaṃ karoti bandhanaṃ.
verses.translation: For a person who is disturbed by restless thoughts, who is full of strong passions, and who sees only the beautiful, craving grows more and more. He indeed makes his bond strong.
verses.commentary: The danger of 'Subhanupassino' (contemplating only the beautiful/pleasant) is that it ignores the reality of decay. This one-sided view feeds 'Vitakka' (distracting thoughts) and strengthens the chains of the mind.

story.title: The Young Monk and the Beautiful Woman
story.content: A young monk was once walking through the village to collect alms when he caught sight of a woman who was exceptionally beautiful. Instead of looking away or practicing 'yoniso manasikara' (wise reflection), he allowed his mind to dwell on her features. For the rest of the day, he was 'disturbed by restless thoughts' (vitakkapamathitassa), replaying the image of the woman over and over in his mind. The Buddha, perceiving the monk’s distress, called him aside. He explained that the monk’s problem was that he was 'subhanupassino'—someone who looks only at the 'beautiful' or attractive side of things while ignoring the underlying reality of impermanence and impurity. The Buddha taught that when we focus solely on the superficial beauty of an object, our 'Tibba-raga' (strong passion) is ignited, and our craving (tanha) 'grows more and more.' Each lustful thought acts like a new link in a chain, making the 'bond strong' (dalham bandhanam) and harder to break. He told the monk that if he had instead looked at the woman with an awareness that her beauty was temporary and that her body was composed of elements prone to decay, his passion would have cooled instantly. The Buddha emphasized that the 'restless thoughts' were not caused by the woman, but by the monk's own biased perception. Upon receiving this teaching, the monk began to practice 'asubha' meditation (contemplating the unattractive nature of the body), which helped him balance his perception and eventually free himself from the 'strong bond' of lust.

verses.pali: Yo ca vitakkūpasame rato sadā, asubhaṃ bhāvayati sadā sato; esa kho vyantikāhiti, esa chethiti mārabandhanaṃ.
verses.translation: He who delights in subduing restless thoughts, who always meditates on the 'un-beautiful' (asubha), and who is ever mindful—it is he who will make an end of craving and cut the bond of Mara.
verses.commentary: The solution to lust is 'Asubha' meditation—recognizing that the body is a bag of skin containing bones, blood, and waste. This is not to create hatred, but to neutralize obsessive attraction.

story.title: The Practice of the Mindful Monk
story.content: In contrast to the monk who was distracted by beauty, there was another monk who had mastered the art of 'Vitakkupasame'—the subduing of restless thoughts. Whenever a sensual image entered his mind, he did not fight it with anger; instead, he greeted it with 'Sato' (mindfulness). He would immediately begin to 'bhavayati' (develop) the meditation on 'Asubha,' mentally dissecting the attractive object into its constituent parts: hair, skin, flesh, bones, and organs. By doing this, the 'beautiful' image would lose its power over him, and his craving would naturally wither away. The Buddha praised this monk in front of the others, saying that such a person is the one who truly 'makes an end of craving' (vyantikahiti). The Buddha explained that 'Mara’s bond' is woven from the illusions we create about the world. When we see things as they really are—temporary, changing, and essentially empty of a permanent self—the 'bond of Mara' is 'cut' (chethiti). He taught that being 'ever mindful' is like having a guard at the door of a house; no thief (unwholesome thought) can enter without being noticed. This monk’s success was not due to some magical power but due to his consistent 'delight' in subduing his own distracted mind. His example showed the other monks that liberation is a systematic process of replacing 'wrong perception' with 'right awareness.' By mastering his thoughts, the monk lived in a state of constant peace, no longer a slave to the visual world, and eventually attained the final goal of Nirvana.

verses.pali: Niṭṭhaṅgato asantāsī, vītataṇho anaṅgaṇo; acchindi bhavasallāni, antimoyaṃ samussayo.
verses.translation: He who has reached the goal, who is fearless, who is without craving and without blemish, has cut the thorns of existence. This is his last body.
verses.commentary: The 'goal' (nitthangato) is Arhatship. 'Bhavasallani' (thorns of existence) refers to the painful recurring cycles of life. The 'last body' means no more rebirth.

story.title: The Fearless Arhat
story.content: A senior monk named Tissa had lived a life of rigorous discipline and profound meditation for many years. One day, while he was meditating in a lonely forest, a fierce bandit approached him with a raised sword, demanding his belongings. Tissa remained completely 'asantasi' (fearless) and 'anangano' (without blemish/undisturbed). He did not beg for his life nor did he feel any anger toward the bandit. Instead, he looked at the man with pure compassion. The bandit, shocked by the monk's lack of fear, lowered his weapon and asked how he could be so calm in the face of death. Tissa explained that he had already 'reached the goal' (nitthangato) and had 'cut the thorns of existence' (bhavasallani). He told the bandit that fear only exists for those who still 'crave' life and possessive 'blemishes' in their hearts. Since Tissa had already realized that the 'self' is an illusion, there was no one left for the bandit to kill. He calmly declared, 'This is my last body' (antimoyam samussayo), meaning that even if the bandit killed him, he would not be reborn into another life of suffering. The Buddha later confirmed Tissa's state, explaining to the other monks that when a person becomes 'vitatanho' (without craving), they transcend the reach of both physical and spiritual pain. They have finished the 'work' of many lifetimes. The bandit was so moved by Tissa’s fearlessness that he threw away his sword, asked for forgiveness, and eventually became a lay follower of the Dhamma, proving that true spiritual power is the ultimate form of protection.

verses.pali: Vītataṇho anādāno, niruttipadakovido; akkharānaṃ sannipātaṃ, jaññā pubbāparāni ca; sa ve 'antimasārīro, mahāpañño mahāpuriso'ti vuccatī.
verses.translation: He who is without craving and attachment, who is skilled in the knowledge of words and their meanings, and who knows the grouping of letters and their sequence—he is called a 'bearer of the final body,' one of 'great wisdom,' a 'great man.'
verses.commentary: This verse praises the intellectual and spiritual perfection of an Arhat. They not only have the 'Direct Experience' but also the 'Nirutti' (linguistic/analytical skill) to teach the Dhamma clearly to others.

story.title: The Story of the Great Scholar Monk
story.content: There was a monk who was not only a master of meditation but also an expert in 'Nirutti'—the analytical knowledge of language and the meanings of the Buddha's words. Other monks sometimes wondered if his deep focus on 'letters and their sequence' (akkharanam sannipatam) was a distraction from the actual practice of letting go. The Buddha, however, spoke this verse to clarify the matter. He explained that when a person is 'without craving and attachment' (vitatanho anadano), their intellectual skills become a powerful tool for the Dhamma. He called such a person a 'Mahapanno' (one of great wisdom) and a 'Mahapuriso' (a great man). The Buddha taught that being 'skilled in the knowledge of words' does not mean being a dry academic; rather, it means having the clarity to explain the path to others without confusion. Because this monk had 'cut the sequence' of rebirth, he was a 'bearer of the final body.' His ability to understand the 'before and after' (pubbaparani) of the teachings allowed him to preserve the Dhamma in its purest form. The Buddha explained that a truly enlightened being uses every faculty—intellectual and spiritual—to serve the liberation of all beings. The monk's scholarship was not fueled by pride but by a 'cravlng-less' desire to be a light for others. This story encouraged the monks to value both deep meditation and the careful study of the Dhamma, showing that 'Great Wisdom' encompasses both the heart’s silence and the tongue’s clarity.

verses.pali: Sabbābhibhū sabbavidūhamasmi, sabbesu dhammesu anūpalitto; sabbañjaho taṇhākkhaye vimutto, sayaṃ abhiññāya kamuddiseyyaṃ.
verses.translation: I have conquered all, I know all, in all conditions of life I am free from taint. I have renounced all and am emancipated through the destruction of craving. Having myself comprehended all, whom shall I call my teacher?
verses.commentary: This is a historic verse spoken by the Buddha to the ascetic Upaka shortly after Enlightenment. It is a 'Lion's Roar' (Sihanada), declaring his total independence and supreme realization.

story.title: The Meeting with Upaka the Ascetic
story.content: Shortly after his enlightenment under the Bodhi Tree, the Buddha was walking toward Varanasi to find his former companions. Along the way, he met a wandering ascetic named Upaka. Upaka was struck by the Buddha’s radiant appearance and serene demeanor. He asked, 'Friend, your senses are so calm, and your complexion is so clear. Who is your teacher? Whose Dhamma do you follow?' The Buddha replied with this powerful verse, declaring that he was 'Sabbabhibhu'—one who had conquered everything—and 'Sabbavidu'—one who knew all. He explained that he was 'free from taint' (anupalitto) in all conditions because he had achieved the 'destruction of craving' (tanhakkhaye). He told Upaka that because he had 'comprehended all' by his own efforts and direct experience, he had no teacher in the world who could be called his superior. He was the Sammasambuddha (the Fully Self-Enlightened One). Upaka, however, was not yet ready to grasp the magnitude of this statement. He simply nodded, said, 'It may be so, friend,' and walked away. This encounter serves as a reminder that even the greatest truth requires a ready heart to be received. The Buddha’s 'Lion’s Roar' was not a statement of ego, but a statement of absolute spiritual fact: that the end of craving is the end of all dependency. Eventually, after many years, Upaka remembered this meeting, sought out the Buddha, and attained liberation, finally understanding the 'conqueror of all' whom he had met on the road.

verses.pali: Sabbadānaṃ dhammadānaṃ jināti, sabbaṃ rasaṃ dhammaraso jināti; sabbaṃ ratiṃ dhammarati jināti, taṇhākkhayo sabbadukkhaṃ jināti.
verses.translation: The gift of Dhamma excels all gifts; the flavor of Dhamma excels all flavors; the delight in Dhamma excels all delights; the destruction of craving overcomes all suffering.
verses.commentary: This verse contains the four 'Excels' (Jināti). It highlights that internal spiritual victories and the sharing of truth are the highest possible human activities.

story.title: The Questions of Sakka, King of Gods
story.content: Sakka, the king of the devas (gods), once approached the Buddha with four difficult questions that had been debated in the celestial realms. He asked: 'What is the greatest gift? What is the sweetest flavor? What is the highest delight? And what is the ultimate victory over suffering?' The Buddha answered with this verse, which has since become one of the most famous in the Buddhist world. He explained that 'Sabbadanam dhammadanam jinati'—the gift of the Truth (Dhamma) is superior to any material gift because material gifts only sustain the body, while the Dhamma saves the soul. He said that the 'flavor' of the Dhamma is the only one that truly satisfies the heart, unlike sensory flavors which always leave one wanting more. The 'delight' in understanding reality (dhammarati) is more stable and profound than any worldly joy (rati). Finally, he declared that the 'destruction of craving' (tanhakkhayo) is the only 'victory' that actually ends all 'Dukkha' (suffering). Sakka was so impressed and delighted by these answers that he and his celestial host honored the Buddha with heavenly music and flowers. This teaching reminds us that while we often seek happiness in objects, experiences, and worldly wins, the highest human potential is realized through the internal process of letting go. Sharing this path with others is the most generous act one can perform, as it provides the tools for eternal freedom.

verses.pali: Hanti bhogā dummedhaṃ, no ca pāragavesino; bhogataṇhāya dummedho, hanti aññeva attanaṃ.
verses.translation: Riches ruin the foolish, but not those in search of the farther shore (Nirvana). Through craving for riches, the ignorant man ruins himself as (he would) others.
verses.commentary: Wealth is neutral; it is the 'craving for wealth' (bhogatanha) that is dangerous. To the 'Dummedha' (foolish), wealth is a trap; to the 'Paragavesino' (seeker of Nirvana), it is a tool for merit.

story.title: The Story of the Miserly Treasurer
story.content: There was a tremendously wealthy treasurer in the city of Rajagaha who was so attached to his gold that he would not even spend it on proper food for himself or his family. He lived like a beggar despite his millions. One day, the Buddha visited him and spoke about the nature of 'Bhoga' (riches). He explained that wealth itself is not the problem, but 'the craving for riches' is what 'ruins the foolish' (dummedham). The Buddha said that for someone who is not 'in search of the farther shore' (paragavesino), wealth acts like a heavy weight that sinks them deeper into the ocean of Samsara. Such a person 'ruins himself' because his greed leads him to perform unwholesome acts, such as lying or exploitation, which result in suffering in future lives. The Buddha compared the ignorant man to someone who accidentally poisons himself while trying to poison others. In contrast, a wise person uses wealth to perform acts of charity (Dana), turning 'worldly gold' into 'spiritual merit' that helps them reach Nirvana. The treasurer realized that his gold had become his master rather than his servant. He understood that by hoarding it, he was starving his own spirit just as he was starving his body. Inspired by the Buddha, he began to use his fortune to build hospitals and support the monastic community, transforming his 'ruinous riches' into a bridge to the 'farther shore.' This story teaches that the value of our possessions is determined entirely by the state of our hearts.

verses.pali: Tiṇadosāni khettāni, rāgadosā ayaṃ pajā; tasmā hi vītarāgesu, dinnaṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.translation: Weeds are the bane of fields; lust is the bane of mankind. Therefore, offerings made to those free from lust yield great fruit.
verses.commentary: This and the following three verses (357-359) use the agriculture metaphor. The giver is the farmer, the gift is the seed, and the recipient is the 'field.' A field without weeds (defilements) produces the best harvest.

story.title: The Parable of the Four Fields
story.content: A wealthy landowner once asked the Buddha why some acts of charity seemed to produce much more happiness and peace than others. The Buddha, knowing the man was a farmer, used a metaphor he would easily understand. He said, 'Householder, if you were to plant seeds, would you choose a field choked with weeds or a field that has been cleared and tilled?' The farmer replied that he would obviously choose the clean field. The Buddha then explained that 'lust' (raga) is exactly like weeds (tinadosani). It chokes the human 'field,' preventing any good 'seed' from growing to its full potential. He said that mankind is often 'bane-stricken' by lust, which makes their hearts hard and unreceptive to the Dhamma. Therefore, when a person gives an offering to 'those free from lust' (vitaragesu)—such as the Buddha or his Arhat disciples—it is like planting a seed in the most fertile, weed-free soil imaginable. Such a gift 'yields great fruit' (mahapphalam) because the recipient’s purity amplifies the merit of the giver’s intention. The Buddha wasn't saying that we shouldn't give to others, but he was emphasizing the unique 'spiritual fertility' of a pure heart. He encouraged the farmer to strive to clear the 'weeds' from his own mind so that his life could become a 'fertile field' for others. This teaching helped the landowner realize that the most important part of giving is the quality of the 'soil'—both the giver’s intention and the recipient’s virtue.

verses.pali: Tiṇadosāni khettāni, dosadosā ayaṃ pajā; tasmā hi vītadosesu, dinnaṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.translation: Weeds are the bane of fields; hatred is the bane of mankind. Therefore, offerings made to those free from hatred yield great fruit.
verses.commentary: Following the previous verse, this one focuses on 'Dosa' (hatred/ill-will). Hatred 'burns' the field of the mind, making it impossible for the 'seeds' of peace to sprout.

story.title: The Story of the Angry Man and the Offering
story.content: There was a man named Akkosaka Bharadvaja who was famous for his explosive temper. When he heard that his wife had become a follower of the Buddha, he rushed to the monastery to insult the Buddha. The Buddha, however, remained completely calm and asked the man: 'If you bring a gift to a friend and he does not accept it, to whom does the gift belong?' The man replied, 'It belongs to me, of course.' The Buddha smiled and said, 'In the same way, I do not accept your anger; it remains yours.' This encounter illustrated the principle that 'hatred is the bane of mankind' (dosadosa). The Buddha later explained to his disciples that an angry person is like a field full of poisonous weeds; nothing beneficial can grow there. He taught that offerings made to 'those free from hatred' (vitadosesu) are powerful because such individuals have replaced the fire of anger with the cool water of 'Metta' (loving-kindness). A mind free from hatred is a 'fertile field' where the seeds of an offering can multiply into immense spiritual merit. Akkosaka, seeing his own reflection in the Buddha’s calm 'field,' realized how much his own hatred had been ruining his life. He decided to let go of his 'weeds' and eventually joined the Order, finding that the 'fruit' of a peaceful mind was far sweeter than the bitter taste of anger. This story emphasizes that clearing the mind of ill-will is essential for spiritual growth.

verses.pali: Tiṇadosāni khettāni, mohadosā ayaṃ pajā; tasmā hi vītamohesu, dinnaṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.translation: Weeds are the bane of fields; delusion is the bane of mankind. Therefore, offerings made to those free from delusion yield great fruit.
verses.commentary: Delusion (Moha) is the most subtle 'weed.' It is like a fog that covers the field, making the farmer plant the wrong seeds or miss the harvest entirely.

story.title: The Story of the Blind Farmer
story.content: A certain villager was very generous but also very confused about spiritual truths. He followed many different teachers who taught conflicting ideas, and he felt like he was 'wandering in a fog.' He approached the Buddha and asked for a clear path. The Buddha told him that 'delusion' (moha) is the ultimate bane of mankind. He compared it to weeds that are hard to see because they look like the crop. Delusion makes us believe that the temporary is permanent and that the painful is pleasurable. He explained that a person 'free from delusion' (vitamohesu) is like a farmer with perfect eyesight who can distinguish between a weed and a wheat stalk instantly. Offering a gift to such a person yields 'great fruit' because the recipient’s wisdom guides the giver toward the right path. The Buddha taught that while lust and hatred are like visible weeds, delusion is the 'root-weed' from which they both grow. By supporting those who have cleared the fog of ignorance, the giver also begins to see more clearly. The villager realized that his own confusion was a 'weed' he needed to pull out through the study of the Dhamma and the practice of mindfulness. He stopped following 'blind' teachers and focused on the Buddha's 'eye of wisdom.' This story illustrates that clarity of mind is the foundation for all other spiritual virtues and that supporting wisdom is the fastest way to overcome our own delusion.

verses.pali: Tiṇadosāni khettāni, icchādosā ayaṃ pajā; tasmā hi vigaticchesu, dinnaṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.translation: Weeds are the bane of fields; desire is the bane of mankind. Therefore, offerings made to those free from desire yield great fruit.
verses.commentary: The final 'weed' is 'Iccha' (selfish desire or longing). This is the 'pull' of the heart toward the world. Only those who have reached 'Vigaticchesu' (the state beyond desire) are truly free.

story.title: The Final Lesson on the Field of Merit
story.content: In his final discourse on the agricultural metaphor, the Buddha spoke to a group of wealthy donors about 'Iccha'—the 'itching' desire for more. He explained that even when lust, hatred, and delusion are suppressed, a subtle 'desire' for recognition or future rewards can still act like weeds in the field of the mind. He said that 'desire is the bane of mankind' because it keeps the mind leaning toward the future, never allowing it to rest in the peace of the present. Offerings made to those 'free from desire' (vigaticchesu)—those who give and live without any 'wanting'—yield the greatest fruit of all. Such recipients are like fields that are not only free of weeds but are also perfectly leveled and enriched. The Buddha taught that the ultimate 'Field of Merit' is the community of those who have totally abandoned selfish longing. When a giver aligns themselves with such purity, their own 'desire' begins to fall away, and they experience the 'great fruit' of mental liberation. The donors understood that the highest form of giving is not just about the object given, but about the 'weightlessness' of the heart that gives and the heart that receives. This final verse of the chapter summarizes the entire theme: that the eradication of 'Tanha' and 'Iccha' (craving and desire) is the only way to transform the 'field' of human life into a garden of enlightenment. With this, the chapter on Craving concludes, pointing the way to the 'farther shore' where no weeds can ever grow.

chapters.summary: This chapter describes the ideal conduct and qualities of a Buddhist monk, emphasizing restraint, mindfulness, contentment, and the pursuit of liberation.

verses.pali: Cakkhunā saṃvaro sādhu, sādhu sotena saṃvaro; ghānena saṃvaro sādhu, sādhu jivhāya saṃvaro.
verses.translation: Restraint in the eye is good, restraint in the ear is good; restraint in the nose is good, restraint in the tongue is good.
verses.commentary: The monk begins his training with 'Indriya Samvara' (sense restraint). This is the practice of not allowing the mind to be swept away by sensory impressions.

story.title: The Story of the Five Monks
story.content: In the city of Savatthi, five monks lived together, each specializing in the restraint of a different sense organ. One monk was exceptionally careful never to let his eyes wander toward distracting sights; the second was vigilant about the sounds he allowed into his ears; the third focused on odors; the fourth on the flavors of food; and the fifth on physical sensations. One day, they began to argue among themselves, each claiming that the sense they were guarding was the most difficult to control and therefore the most important in the spiritual life. Unable to reach an agreement, they approached the Buddha to settle their dispute. The Buddha listened patiently and then explained that all five senses are like five different animals—a snake, a crocodile, a bird, a dog, and a monkey—tied together by a single rope. Each animal pulls in its own direction toward its natural habitat. The eye pulls toward beautiful forms, the ear toward music, the nose toward fragrances, the tongue toward tastes, and the body toward comfort. The Buddha taught that if a monk neglects even one of these 'animals,' it can pull the entire mind into the 'forest' of defilements. He stated that 'restraint in the eye is good,' but it must be accompanied by restraint in all other organs to be effective. True peace comes when the monk stands like a firm pillar, unmoved no matter how hard each sense organ pulls. Upon hearing this vivid analogy, the five monks realized that spiritual mastery requires a holistic guarding of the entire sensory 'gateway' rather than focusing on just one entrance.

verses.pali: Kāyena saṃvaro sādhu, sādhu vācāya saṃvaro; manasā saṃvaro sādhu, sādhu sabbattha saṃvaro; sabbattha saṃvuto bhikkhu, sabbadukkhā pamuccati.
verses.translation: Restraint in the body is good, restraint in speech is good; restraint in the mind is good, restraint in everything is good. The monk restrained in everything is freed from all suffering.
verses.commentary: This verse expands from the five senses to the 'three doors' of action: body, speech, and mind. Full liberation requires 'Sabbattha' (restraint in everything).

story.title: The Monk Who Guarded the Three Doors
story.content: There was a monk who was very diligent in his outward behavior, walking slowly and speaking only when necessary. However, he found that his mind was often filled with turbulent thoughts of anger and desire. He felt like a hypocrite because his 'body' and 'speech' appeared restrained, but his 'mind' was a chaotic storm. He went to the Buddha, feeling discouraged and ready to give up his robes. The Buddha comforted him and explained that the training of a monk is a progressive journey through the 'three doors.' He said that while 'restraint in the body is good' and 'restraint in speech is good,' the work is incomplete until there is 'restraint in the mind.' He compared the monk to a city with three gates. If the guards only lock the front and side gates but leave the back gate wide open, the enemy can still enter and destroy the city. The mind is the back gate through which all defilements eventually find their way. The Buddha emphasized that the monk who is 'restrained in everything'—meaning he guards the body, the speech, and the subtle movements of the mind—is the one who is truly 'freed from all suffering' (sabbadukkha pamuccati). He taught the monk how to use mindfulness as a guard that sits at the center of the three doors, watching every thought as it arises. By learning to observe the mind without reacting, the monk eventually found the inner stillness he had been searching for. This teaching illustrates that true holiness is an internal alignment where the mind is as disciplined as the outward body.

verses.pali: Hatthasaṃyato pādasaṃyato, vācāsaṃyato saṃyatuttamo; ajjhattarato samāhito, eko santusito tamāhu bhikkhuṃ.
verses.translation: He who is restrained in hand, restrained in foot, restrained in speech, and entirely controlled; he who finds delight in meditation, who is settled, solitary and content—him they call a monk.
verses.commentary: A true monk is not defined by his robe but by his 'Samyato' (restraint). 'Ajjhattarato' means one who finds joy within themselves rather than in external entertainment.

story.title: The Story of a Restless Monk
story.content: A certain young monk had a habit of being very fidgety and loud. Even during meditation sessions, he would move his hands, tap his feet, and whispered to his neighbors. He found the silence of the monastery oppressive and was always looking for something to do or someone to talk to. The elder monks tried to correct him, but he argued that as long as he wasn't breaking the major rules, his 'small movements' didn't matter. The Buddha, seeing that the young man was wasting his potential, called him over. He told him that a true monk is 'restrained in hand' and 'restrained in foot.' This physical stillness is not just for the sake of appearance; it is a reflection of an 'entirely controlled' mind. The Buddha explained that if the hands and feet are restless, it is because the mind is restless. A person who is 'restrained in speech' saves energy that can then be used for 'ajjhattarato'—finding delight in the internal world of meditation. He described a true monk as someone who is 'settled' (samahito), meaning they are not constantly looking for the next distraction. Such a person is 'content' (santusito) even when 'solitary' (eko), because they have found a source of happiness that does not depend on others. The Buddha warned that a monk who cannot sit still is like a pot with a hole in the bottom; no matter how much Dhamma is poured in, it all leaks out through his restless actions. The young monk was deeply humbled and began to practice physical and mental stillness, eventually realizing that the greatest adventures are found within the quiet mind.

verses.pali: Yo mukhasaṃyato bhikkhu, mantabhāṇī anuddhato; atthaṃ dhammañca dīpeti, madhuraṃ tassa bhāsitaṃ.
verses.translation: The monk who is controlled in tongue, who speaks with wisdom, who is not puffed up, and who explains the meaning and the text (of the Dhamma)—sweet is his speech.
verses.commentary: This verse highlights the quality of 'Mantabhāṇī' (speaking with wisdom/counsel). A monk's speech should not just be polite; it should be 'Attha' (meaningful) and 'Dhamma' (righteous).

story.title: The Story of Monk Kokalika
story.content: There was a monk named Kokalika who had a very sharp and uncontrolled tongue. He frequently spoke ill of the Buddha’s chief disciples, Sariputta and Moggallana, accusing them of having evil desires despite their obvious holiness. Even after being warned by the Buddha himself, Kokalika continued his verbal attacks, driven by his own arrogance and 'puffed up' pride. Eventually, his negative speech led to his own spiritual and physical downfall. Following this incident, the Buddha spoke to the other monks about the importance of being 'controlled in tongue' (mukhasamyato). He explained that a monk's speech should be 'mantabhani'—carefully weighed and full of wisdom—rather than impulsive or malicious. He described the ideal monk as one who is 'anuddhato' (not arrogant or agitated), someone who uses their voice only to 'explain the meaning and the text' of the Dhamma. The Buddha said that when a monk speaks from a place of purity and wisdom, his words become 'madhuram' (sweet) to the ears of the listeners, and they have the power to heal and guide. In contrast, the speech of an arrogant person is like a bitter medicine that no one wants to take. He taught that words are like seeds; once they are spoken, they take root in the world, and a monk must ensure he only plants seeds of peace. The monks who listened to this teaching became very mindful of their speech, understanding that the tongue can be either a bridge to Nirvana or a gateway to the lower realms.

verses.pali: Dhammārāmo dhammarato, dhammaṃ anuvicintayaṃ; dhammaṃ anussaraṃ bhikkhu, saddhammā na parihāyati.
verses.translation: The monk who dwells in the Dhamma, who delights in the Dhamma, who meditates on the Dhamma, and who well remembers the Dhamma, does not fall away from the sublime Dhamma.
verses.commentary: The four stages of mental immersion: 'Dhammārāmo' (dwelling/living in it), 'Dhammarato' (loving it), 'Anuvicintayaṃ' (thinking it through), and 'Anussaraṃ' (remembering/practicing it).

story.title: The Story of the Two Friends
story.content: Two friends ordained as monks at the same time. One of them decided to focus on 'Ganthadhura'—the study of the texts—and became a famous scholar with many disciples. The other friend chose 'Vipassanadhura'—the practice of meditation—and retired to a quiet forest. After some years, the scholar monk began to feel superior, thinking he knew everything about the Dhamma, while his friend 'only' sat in the woods. When they eventually met, the scholar intended to test his friend’s knowledge with complex technical questions. However, the Buddha, knowing the scholar’s pride, intervened. He praised the forest monk, explaining that while the scholar 'knew' the words, the forest monk 'dwelt' in the Dhamma (dhammaramo). He explained that a true monk is one who 'delights' in the Truth (dhammarato) and 'meditates' on its application every single moment (dhammaṃ anuvicintayaṃ). The scholar’s knowledge was like a beautiful map of a city he had never visited, whereas the forest monk was actually living in the city. The Buddha taught that the monk who 'remembers' the Dhamma not just as a text but as a living experience 'does not fall away' (na parihayati) from the sublime truth. Knowledge without practice is like a cool breeze that passes through a house without lowering the temperature inside. The scholar monk realized that he had been so busy studying the 'menu' that he had forgotten to eat the 'food.' He apologized to his friend and began to practice meditation, understanding that the Dhamma is a path to be walked, not just a subject to be discussed.

verses.pali: Salābhaṃ nātimaññeyya, nāññesaṃ pihayaṃ care; aññesaṃ pihayaṃ bhikkhu, samādhiṃ nādhigacchati.
verses.translation: One should not despise what one has received, nor should one live envying others. A monk who envies others does not attain concentration (Samadhi).
verses.commentary: Envy (Issa) is a direct obstacle to 'Samadhi' (concentration). A mind that is looking at what others have cannot look at its own internal state.

story.title: The Monk and the Alms-Bowl
story.content: A certain monk was often unhappy because he felt that other monks received better quality alms-food and finer robes than he did. Whenever he saw a fellow monk returning with a bowl full of delicious food or wearing a new robe donated by a wealthy merchant, his heart would burn with envy. He would 'despise what he had received' (salābhaṃ nātimaññeyya), looking at his own simple meal with disgust. Because his mind was constantly 'envying others' (nāññesaṃ pihayaṃ), he found it impossible to concentrate during meditation. Every time he closed his eyes, he saw the faces of the donors and the items he wished he had. The Buddha called him and explained that 'envy' is like a thick smoke that clouds the mirror of the mind. He said that 'a monk who envies others does not attain concentration' (samādhiṃ nādhigacchati) because concentration requires a mind that is at peace and content with the present moment. He taught that what a monk receives is the result of his own past merit and the generosity of the community; to despise it is to show ingratitude to the world. The Buddha told him that a true monk eats his food like a medicine—only to sustain the body for the practice—without comparing his 'medicine' to someone else's. He encouraged the monk to focus on the 'wealth' of his own character rather than the contents of his bowl. Realizing that his envy was the only thing standing between him and the joy of Samadhi, the monk practiced contentment (santutthi) and soon found that even the simplest meal tasted sweet when eaten with a peaceful heart.

verses.pali: Appalābhopi ce bhikkhu, salābhaṃ nātimaññati; taṃ ve devā pasaṃsanti, suddhājīviṃ atanditaṃ.
verses.translation: Even if a monk has received little, if he does not despise what he has received, even the gods praise him, for his life is pure and he is not slothful.
verses.commentary: Gods (Devas) admire human virtue, especially 'Suddhājīvi' (purity of livelihood) and 'Atandita' (energy/lack of sloth). Contentment is seen as a divine quality.

story.title: The Story of the Contented Monk
story.content: In a small, impoverished village, there lived a monk who often received very little for his daily alms. Sometimes, his bowl contained nothing but a few scraps of dry rice or a single piece of coarse bread. Despite this 'little' (appalābhopi), the monk was always seen with a radiant and cheerful expression. He never complained to the villagers and never felt sorry for himself. He spent his days in diligent meditation and his nights in walking practice, remaining 'not slothful' (atanditaṃ) despite his meager diet. The local people were amazed by his endurance and his 'pure life' (uddhājīviṃ). The Buddha, hearing of the monk's exemplary behavior, told his disciples that 'even the gods praise' such a person. He explained that most people's happiness is tied to the quantity and quality of what they get from the world, but this monk's happiness came from within. Because he 'did not despise' his meager alms, he was a master of his own mind rather than a slave to his stomach. The Buddha taught that a monk who is content with little is like a bird that flies wherever it wants, carrying only its wings. He said that the gods look down upon the world and are bored by kings and billionaires, but they are fascinated by a human being who is truly content with nothing. This teaching inspired the other monks to stop worrying about their future provisions and to trust that a pure life and hard work are the only true 'wealth' a monk needs. The contented monk eventually attained Arhatship, proving that the size of one’s meal has no bearing on the size of one’s enlightenment.

verses.pali: Sabbaso nāmarūpasmiṃ, yassa natthi mamāyitaṃ; asatā ca na socati, sa ve 'bhikkhū'ti vuccati.
verses.translation: He who has no sense of 'mine' in regard to the Name and Form (mind and body), and who does not grieve for what he does not have—he indeed is called a monk.
verses.commentary: This verse addresses the core of 'Anatta' (non-self). 'Nāmarūpa' (mind and body) are viewed as processes rather than as a permanent 'me' or 'mine'.

story.title: The Story of the Brahmin who asked 'Who is a Monk?'
story.content: A Brahmin who was very proud of his rituals once approached the Buddha and asked, 'Who is a true monk? Is it the one who wears the robe, or the one who recites the Vedas?' The Buddha replied that being a monk is not an external status but an internal realization. He said that a true monk is someone who has 'no sense of mine' (natthi mamāyitaṃ) in regard to 'Nāmarūpa'—the mental and physical processes that make up a human being. Most people think, 'This is my body, these are my thoughts, this is my soul.' But the monk sees that these are just changing phenomena. Because he doesn't own his body or his mind, he 'does not grieve' (na socati) when they change, age, or fall ill. He doesn't feel that he has 'lost' anything because he never 'owned' it in the first place. The Buddha compared the monk to a person who is staying in a guest house; they use the bed and the chairs, but they don't cry when they have to leave because they know the furniture isn't 'mine.' He explained that the 'Bhikkhu' is the one who has reached this state of total non-attachment. The Brahmin, who had spent his life trying to 'acquire' spiritual merit and 'own' religious knowledge, was stunned by this perspective. He realized that his grief and anxiety came from his possessiveness over his own identity. Upon hearing this verse, he abandoned his pride and eventually became a follower of the Buddha, seeking the freedom that comes from owning nothing—not even one's own self.

verses.pali: Mettāvihārī yo bhikkhu, pasanno buddhasāsane; adhigacche padaṃ santaṃ, saṅkhārūpasamaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.translation: The monk who dwells in loving-kindness and has faith in the teachings of the Buddha, will attain the state of peace (Nirvana), the happy cessation of conditioned existence.
verses.commentary: 'Mettāvihārī' means 'one who makes Metta their home.' 'Saṅkhārūpasamaṃ' is the calming or cessation of all mental formations (Sankharas), which is the ultimate happiness.

story.title: The Story of the Loving-Kindness Monk
story.content: There was a monk who was not particularly famous for his scholarship or his debating skills, but he was known by everyone for his 'Mettavihari'—his practice of living in a constant state of loving-kindness. He did not have a single enemy, and even the wild animals in the forest where he lived seemed to be at peace in his presence. When other monks were struggling with complex philosophical questions, he simply kept his mind 'pasanno' (clear and confident) in the Buddha’s teachings. He believed that the simplest path to the 'state of peace' (padam santam) was to radiate love to all directions. The Buddha used this monk as an example for the community, explaining that 'Sukha' (happiness) is usually sought in conditioned things, but the highest happiness is 'Sankharupasama'—the calming of the very processes of the mind. By practicing Metta, this monk had softened his ego until his 'Sankharas' (mental formations) naturally became quiet. The Buddha taught that such a monk is like a man who has reached the 'farther shore' while others are still fighting the waves. He told the monks that a mind full of love is the most fertile soil for the realization of Nirvana. The monk’s simple, unwavering faith and his boundless love led him to the 'happy cessation of conditioned existence,' showing that intellectual complexity is often less effective than a heart that has truly learned how to love and let go. He died in total peace, leaving behind a legacy of kindness that inspired many to follow the 'Mettavihari' path.

verses.pali: Siñca bhikkhu imaṃ nāvaṃ, sittā te lahu pessati; chetvā rāgañca dosañca, tato nibbānamehisi.
verses.translation: Empty this boat, O monk! Emptied, it will sail lightly. Having cut off lust and hatred, you will reach Nirvana.
verses.commentary: The 'boat' is the physical and mental body. The 'water' that must be bailed out is the unwholesome states of lust (Raga) and hatred (Dosa) which cause the boat to sink into the ocean of Samsara.

story.title: The Parable of the Sinking Boat
story.content: A group of monks was once traveling across a wide, turbulent river in a wooden boat. Halfway through the journey, the boat began to leak, and water started filling the floorboards. The monks became panicked, realizing that the heavier the boat became with water, the faster it would sink. They began to bail out the water frantically with their hands and small bowls. Watching this from the shore, the Buddha later used the incident to deliver a profound teaching. He explained that every human being is currently in a 'boat'—the complex of mind and body—trying to cross the dangerous ocean of existence to reach the 'farther shore' of Nirvana. However, most people’s boats are heavy and sluggish because they are filled with the 'water' of lust, hatred, and delusion. He told the monks, 'Empty this boat!' (Siñca bhikkhu imaṃ nāvaṃ). He explained that 'emptying' does not mean destroying the boat, but rather bailing out the heavy, unwholesome emotional states that weigh it down. When a monk 'cuts off' lust and hatred, his mind becomes 'light' (lahu), allowing him to sail swiftly and safely across the waves of life and death. A boat filled with water is destined to sink, just as a mind filled with grievances and desires is destined to remain trapped in suffering. The monks understood that spiritual progress is not about adding more things to their lives, but about letting go of the heavy burdens they were carrying. By bailing out the 'water' of their own defilements, they found that their meditation became much more effortless and their journey toward peace much faster.

verses.pali: Pañca chinde pañca jahe, pañca cuttari bhāvaye; pañcasaṅgātigo bhikkhu, 'oghatiṇṇo'ti vuccati.
verses.translation: Cut off the five, abandon the five, and cultivate the five. The monk who has overcome the five attachments is called 'one who has crossed the flood.'
verses.commentary: The first five are the 'Lower Fetters' (Self-illusion, doubt, etc.). The second five are the 'Higher Fetters' (Lust for existence, pride, etc.). The five to cultivate are the 'Spiritual Faculties' (Faith, Energy, Mindfulness, Concentration, Wisdom).

story.title: The Story of the Monk Who Crossed the Flood
story.content: A monk who had been practicing for many years felt overwhelmed by the sheer number of mental defilements he had to overcome. He felt as though he was swimming in a vast, dark flood with no shore in sight. The Buddha, perceiving his discouragement, gave him a clear numerical framework to simplify his practice. He explained that spiritual growth is a systematic process of 'five.' First, one must 'cut off' the five lower fetters that bind one to the sensual world: personality belief, skeptical doubt, clinging to rituals, sensual desire, and ill-will. Next, one must 'abandon' the five higher fetters that bind even those in higher meditative states: desire for fine-material existence, desire for immaterial existence, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance. To achieve this, the monk must 'cultivate' the five spiritual faculties: faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom. The Buddha explained that these five faculties act as the 'bridge' over the 'five attachments' (sanga) of greed, hatred, delusion, pride, and false views. He told the monk that once these three groups of five were mastered, he would be called an 'oghatinno'—one who has successfully crossed the flood of birth and death. This structured approach gave the monk a sense of direction and clarity. He stopped looking at the 'flood' as a whole and began working on 'cutting' and 'cultivating' one group at a time. Through this methodical application of the Dhamma, he eventually reached the other side, finding the safety and stillness of Nirvana that is beyond the reach of any flood.

verses.pali: Jhāya bhikkhu mā ca pāmado, mā te kāmaguṇe bhamassu cittaṃ; mā lohagulaṃ gilī pamatto, mā kanda dukkhamidan'ti dayhamāno.
verses.translation: Meditate, O monk! Do not be heedless. Do not let your mind whirl among the threads of sensual pleasures. Do not be heedless and swallow a red-hot iron ball, so that you may not cry out 'this is painful' while being burnt.
verses.commentary: This verse uses a terrifying image from the hell realms. Swallowing a 'red-hot iron ball' (lohagula) is a metaphor for the karmic consequences of enjoying pleasures obtained through deceit or while neglecting one's vows.

story.title: The Warning to the Heedless Monk
story.content: There was a monk who had become very lazy. He would spend his time wandering the village, enjoying the fine food given by donors, and then return to the monastery to sleep instead of meditating. He felt that since he wore the robes, he was safe from the consequences of his actions. The Buddha, knowing the severe karmic danger this monk was in, spoke this verse as a sharp wake-up call. He compared the 'threads of sensual pleasures' to a beautiful bait that hides a deadly hook. He warned the monk that by enjoying the gifts of the faithful without practicing the Dhamma, he was essentially 'swallowing a red-hot iron ball.' In the short term, the ball might seem like food, but once swallowed, it burns through the throat and stomach, causing excruciating agony. The Buddha told him that if he continued his heedless ways, he would eventually find himself in a state of suffering where he would 'cry out' in pain as the results of his negligence caught up with him. He urged the monk to 'Meditate, O monk!' (Jhāya bhikkhu) and to stop his mind from 'whirling' after distractions. The image of the red-hot iron ball was so vivid and frightening that it shook the monk out of his lethargy. He realized that the monastic life is not a free ride but a serious commitment to mental purification. From that day on, he devoted himself to intensive meditation, transforming his fear of the 'iron ball' into a sincere quest for the 'coolness' of Nirvana.

verses.pali: Natthi jhānaṃ apaññassa, paññā natthi ajhāyato; yamhi jhānañca paññā ca, sa ve nibbānasantike.
verses.translation: There is no meditative concentration for one who lacks wisdom, and there is no wisdom for one who does not meditate. He who has both meditative concentration and wisdom is near to Nirvana.
verses.commentary: This verse establishes the symbiotic relationship between 'Jhana' (concentration) and 'Panna' (wisdom). They are like the two wheels of a chariot; one cannot function effectively without the other.

story.title: The Story of the Two Qualities
story.content: In the monastery, there were two groups of monks who often debated which was more important: the development of deep meditative absorption (Jhana) or the study and analytical development of wisdom (Panna). The 'Jhanists' argued that without a still mind, wisdom is just intellectual gossip. The 'Intellectuals' argued that without wisdom, meditation is just a quiet state of ignorance. The Buddha settled the debate by explaining that Jhana and Panna are not separate paths, but two sides of the same coin. He said, 'There is no Jhana for one who lacks wisdom.' This is because without wisdom, a person doesn't know how to navigate the distractions of the mind to reach concentration. Conversely, 'there is no wisdom for one who does not meditate,' because wisdom requires a calm, clear mind to see the true nature of reality. He compared them to a lamp and its light. Jhana is the lamp (the stable structure), and Panna is the light (the clarity that reveals the truth). If you have a lamp but no flame, you cannot see; if you have a flame but no lamp, the wind will blow it out. The Buddha taught that only when a monk brings 'both' together (yamhi jhānañca paññā ca) does he truly become 'near to Nirvana' (nibbānasantike). This teaching encouraged the monks to stop taking sides and to integrate both calmness and insight into their daily practice. They realized that a balanced mind is the only one capable of cutting through the thick veil of delusion that hides the truth.

verses.pali: Suññāgāraṃ paviṭṭhassa, santacittassa bhikkhuno; amānusī rati hoti, samma dhammaṃ vipassato.
verses.translation: The monk who has entered an empty place, whose mind is peaceful, and who clearly perceives the Dhamma, experiences a joy that is beyond that of mortals.
verses.commentary: 'Suññāgāra' literally means an empty house or a secluded place. 'Amānusī rati' refers to a 'super-human' or divine delight that comes from seeing the Truth (Vipassana), which is far superior to any sensory pleasure.

story.title: The Joy in the Empty Hut
story.content: A monk who had been living in the noisy city monastery felt that he was making little progress. He requested permission from the Buddha to go and live in a 'Suññāgāra'—a simple, empty hut in a remote forest. Once settled in the silence of the wilderness, his 'santacittassa' (peaceful mind) began to deepen significantly. Away from the chatter of people and the bustle of the city, he started to 'clearly perceive the Dhamma' through the practice of Vipassana. One night, while he was contemplating the rise and fall of his own breath, he was suddenly overcome by a wave of bliss so intense and refined that it surpassed anything he had ever felt. It was a 'joy beyond that of mortals' (amānusī rati). He felt as though he had stepped out of time and into a realm of pure clarity. When he later returned to visit the Buddha, he described this experience, wondering if it was a distraction. The Buddha reassured him, explaining that when the mind is perfectly quiet and sees the Dhamma as it really is, it experiences a 'divine delight' that makes all worldly pleasures seem like ash. This joy is not a trap but a sign that the mind is becoming detached from the coarse gratifications of the senses. The Buddha encouraged him to continue his life in 'empty places,' teaching that the silence of the forest is the perfect mirror for the silence of the soul. The monk eventually achieved full liberation, proving that true happiness is found not in filling one’s life with things, but in finding the 'emptiness' that is full of truth.

verses.pali: Yato yato sammasati, khandhānaṃ udayabbayaṃ; labhatī pītipāmojjaṃ, amataṃ taṃ vijānataṃ.
verses.translation: Whenever he meditates on the rise and fall of the constituent elements (khandhas), he experiences joy and happiness. To those who know, this is the path to the Deathless (Nirvana).
verses.commentary: The 'Khandhas' are the five aggregates: form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness. Seeing their 'Udayabbaya' (arising and passing away) is the core of insight meditation.

story.title: The Story of the Five Aggregates
story.content: A group of monks was struggling to understand the concept of 'Anatta' (non-self). They felt that if there was no 'self,' then life must be a cold and meaningless process. The Buddha explained to them that the 'self' is just a label we give to a collection of five changing elements or 'Khandhas.' He told them to meditate on the 'rise and fall' (udayabbaya) of these elements: how a feeling arises and then vanishes, how a thought pops up and then disappears, and how the physical body itself is a constant flow of changing sensations. He said that far from being cold or depressing, this observation leads to 'pītipāmojjaṃ'—a profound joy and happiness. This is because when you see that the things causing you pain are just passing 'elements' and not 'you,' the mind feels an incredible sense of relief. The Buddha explained that 'to those who know' (vijānataṃ), this constant flux is the gateway to the 'Deathless' (Amata). By witnessing the constant death of each moment, one finds the part of consciousness that does not die. The monks began to practice this 'moment-to-moment' observation and found that their anxiety about the future and their regrets about the past began to dissolve. They realized that the 'deathless' is not a place you go after you die, but a state of being you find when you stop clinging to the 'arising and passing' things of the world. This insight transformed their practice from a chore into a joyful discovery of freedom.

verses.pali: Tatrāyamādi bhavati, idha paññassa bhikkhuno; indriyagutti santuṭṭhī, pātimokkhe ca saṃvaro.
verses.translation: For a wise monk in this religion, this is the beginning: guarding of the senses, contentment, and restraint according to the fundamental code of monastic discipline (Patimokkha).
verses.commentary: This verse outlines the 'foundation' of the monastic life. One cannot skip these basics—restraint, contentment, and ethics—and hope to achieve high meditative states.

story.title: The Three Foundations of the Wise
story.content: A young man who had just ordained was very eager to attain supernatural powers and deep mystical states. He wanted to skip the 'boring' parts of monastic life, like following the hundreds of rules in the Patimokkha or carefully guarding his eyes during alms-round. He felt that these were for 'ordinary' monks, while he was destined for greatness. The Buddha, noticing the young monk’s arrogance and lack of foundation, gave him this teaching on the 'beginning' (ādi) of the spiritual path. He told the monk that even the wisest person must start with three things: 'guarding of the senses' (indriyagutti), 'contentment' (santutthī), and 'restraint according to the discipline' (pātimokkhe ca saṃvaro). He compared the monk to a man trying to build a seven-story palace on top of shifting sand. Without the foundation of ethics and sensory control, any 'higher state' he achieved would be unstable and dangerous. The Buddha explained that 'contentment' is the greatest wealth because it stops the mind from constantly looking for something 'better' outside. He taught that the Patimokkha rules are like a protective fence that keeps out the 'wild animals' of unwholesome behavior. The young monk realized that his desire for 'quick results' was actually a form of greed that was blocking his progress. He humbled himself and began to focus on the basics of the monastic code and the practice of being content with his simple life. Over time, he found that because his foundation was solid, his meditation naturally deepened without him having to 'force' it, leading him to the very heights he had previously sought in vain.

verses.pali: Mitte bhajassu kalyāṇe, suddhājīve atandite; paṭisanthāravuttyassa, ācārakusalo siyā; tato pāmojjabahulo, dukkhassantaṃ karissati.
verses.translation: Let him associate with friends who are noble, whose life is pure, and who are not slothful. Let him be cordial in his ways and polite in his conduct. Thereby, full of joy, he will make an end of suffering.
verses.commentary: 'Kalyāṇa-mitta' (noble friendship) is often called the 'whole of the spiritual life.' 'Paṭisanthāra' refers to the art of being welcoming and kind to others, ensuring the monk is not a social recluse in a negative sense.

story.title: The Story of the Noble Friends
story.content: Ananda, the Buddha’s loyal attendant, once remarked that he thought 'noble friendship' (Kalyāṇa-mitta) was half of the holy life. The Buddha corrected him, saying, 'Do not say so, Ananda! Noble friendship is not half, but the whole of the holy life.' He emphasized that a monk should actively 'associate with friends who are noble' (mitte bhajassu kalyāṇe)—those who are 'pure in life' and 'not slothful.' He explained that we are like sponges; we absorb the qualities of those we spend time with. If a monk hangs around lazy or greedy people, he will naturally become lazy and greedy. But if he surrounds himself with those who are energetic and virtuous, their light will inspire him to shine as well. Furthermore, the Buddha taught that a monk should not be a 'cold' ascetic; he should be 'cordial in his ways' (paṭisanthāravuttyassa) and 'polite in his conduct.' Politeness and kindness are the lubricants that make communal living possible and peaceful. The Buddha said that when a monk is surrounded by good friends and practices kind conduct, he becomes 'full of joy' (pāmojjabahulo). This joy provides the mental energy needed to 'make an end of suffering.' He taught that the path to Nirvana is not a lonely, miserable struggle, but a journey taken in the company of the wise. By choosing his friends wisely and treating everyone with respect, the monk creates a supportive environment that makes the difficult work of meditation much easier. Many monks who had been struggling alone found that their practice blossomed as soon as they found a 'Kalyāṇa-mitta' to guide and encourage them.

verses.pali: Vassikā viya pupphāni, maddavāni pavaḍḍhati; evaṃ rāgañca dosañca, vippamuñcetha bhikkhavo.
verses.translation: Just as the jasmine creeper sheds its withered flowers, even so, O monks, should you totally cast off lust and hatred.
verses.commentary: The jasmine flower (Vassikā) is beautiful and fragrant when fresh, but it sheds its petals easily when they wither. The monk should 'shed' his defilements just as naturally and completely.

story.title: The Lesson of the Jasmine Flowers
story.content: One morning, while the Buddha was walking through a grove of jasmine trees, he noticed how the ground was covered in white petals. The jasmine vines were shedding their old, withered flowers to make room for new growth. He called the monks together and pointed to the ground. He told them that they should be like the 'Vassikā' (jasmine) creeper. Just as the creeper 'totally casts off' its dead flowers without any regret or clinging, a monk should cast off 'lust and hatred' (rāgañca dosañca). The Buddha explained that lust and hatred are like withered petals; they might have seemed 'fragrant' or attractive once, but now they are just dead weight that prevents the 'tree' of the mind from flourishing. He taught that 'casting off' should not be a painful struggle, but a natural process of realizing that these emotions are no longer useful. When you realize a piece of coal in your hand is burning you, you don't 'try' to drop it—you simply let it go. In the same way, when a monk clearly sees the 'withered' and painful nature of his own anger and desire, he allows them to fall away just like jasmine petals in the breeze. The Buddha emphasized the word 'vippamuñcetha'—to release or set free. By letting go of these defilements, the monk is not losing anything valuable; he is simply making room for the 'fresh flowers' of wisdom and peace to bloom. The monks found this analogy very beautiful and used it during their meditation to visualize their unwholesome thoughts falling harmlessly to the ground, leaving their minds as clean and fresh as the jasmine grove.

verses.pali: Santakāyo santavāco, santamanā susamāhito; vantalokāmiso bhikkhu, 'santo'ti vuccati.
verses.translation: The monk who is calm in body, calm in speech, and calm in mind, who is well-settled and who has vomited the bait of the world, is called 'The Peaceful One.'
verses.commentary: The three levels of 'Santa' (calmness). 'Vantalokāmiso' is a strong term meaning 'one who has vomited the bait/lure of the world.' It implies a permanent rejection of worldly temptations.

story.title: The Story of the Peaceful One
story.content: There was a monk named Santakaya who was so exceptionally calm that he seemed to move in slow motion. Whether he was walking for alms, eating his meal, or sitting in meditation, his 'calm body' (santakāyo) and 'calm speech' (santavāco) never wavered. Even when people insulted him or praised him, his expression remained as still as a mountain. Other monks wondered if he was just naturally dull or if he was truly enlightened. The Buddha confirmed his state, saying that Santakaya was a true 'Peaceful One.' He explained that Santakaya’s outward calmness was the result of being 'calm in mind' (santamanā) and 'well-settled' (susamāhito) in meditation. But the most important quality, the Buddha said, was that he had 'vomited the bait of the world' (vantalokāmiso). The Buddha explained that 'worldliness' is like a delicious-looking bait that hides a sharp hook of suffering. Most people swallow the bait and get hooked. But an enlightened person, having realized the danger, 'vomits' it out and refuses to touch it again. Once you have vomited a poison, you don't look back at it with longing. This total rejection of worldly 'lures' is what creates the unshakable peace that Santakaya displayed. The Buddha taught that 'The Peaceful One' is not someone who is hiding from the world, but someone who has seen through the world’s tricks and is no longer fooled by them. This teaching helped the other monks understand that true peace is not just a quiet exterior, but a deep, internal 'disgust' for the things that cause suffering, leading to a state of being that is 'well-settled' and beyond the reach of temptation.

verses.pali: Attanā codayattānaṃ, paṭimāsetha attanā; so attagutto satimā, sukhaṃ bhikkhu vihāhisi.
verses.translation: Rouse yourself by yourself, examine yourself by yourself. Thus self-guarded and mindful, O monk, you will live happily.
verses.commentary: The Buddha emphasizes 'Atta-hi-attano-natho' (the self as its own protector). No one can meditate for you. 'Codayattānaṃ' (rouse/exhort the self) and 'Paṭimāsetha' (examine/assess the self) are the two pillars of self-reliance.

story.title: The Lesson of Self-Reliance
story.content: A certain monk was always asking the Buddha and the elder monks for advice, for encouragement, and for constant validation. He felt that he couldn't take a single step on the path without someone holding his hand. He was like a child who refused to walk on his own. The Buddha, seeing that this dependency was stunting the monk’s growth, gave him this powerful teaching on self-reliance. He told him, 'Rouse yourself by yourself!' (Attanā codayattānaṃ). He explained that while teachers can point the way, the actual 'walking' must be done by the individual. A monk must 'examine himself'—constantly checking his own mind for defilements and assessing his own progress. The Buddha said that a 'self-guarded' (attagutto) monk is like a man who has built a strong fortress for himself; he doesn't need to look outside for protection because he is safe within his own mindfulness (satimā). He taught that the greatest happiness comes from knowing that you are the master of your own mind. If you depend on others for your happiness, you will always be a slave to their presence or absence. But if you learn to 'rouse' and 'examine' yourself, you will 'live happily' (sukhaṃ vihāhisi) regardless of your surroundings. The monk took this to heart and stopped seeking constant external support. He began to treat his own mind as his primary teacher, using the Buddha’s words as his guide. He found that by taking responsibility for his own spiritual life, he gained a sense of strength and confidence he had never known before, eventually becoming a 'fortress' of peace for others.

verses.pali: Attā hi attano nātho, attā hi attano gati; tasmā saṃyamayattānaṃ, assaṃ bhadraṃva vāṇijo.
verses.translation: For self is the lord of self, self is the refuge of self. Therefore, control yourself as a merchant controls a noble horse.
verses.commentary: The term 'Nātho' (lord/protector) and 'Gati' (destination/refuge) reinforce the theme of self-responsibility. The 'merchant' (vāṇijo) is the conscious mind, and the 'noble horse' (assaṃ bhadraṃ) is the energetic, often unruly nature of our thoughts and desires.

story.title: The Merchant and the Noble Horse
story.content: There was a famous horse-trader in Savatthi who was known for training the most beautiful and energetic stallions. One day, a group of monks watched him as he skillfully guided a powerful horse that was trying to bolt and kick. With gentle but firm movements of the reins, the merchant kept the horse under perfect control, eventually leading it exactly where he wanted it to go. The Buddha, using this scene as a metaphor, told the monks that each of them is like that merchant. 'Self is the lord of self,' he said, meaning that you are the only one who holds the 'reins' of your own life. 'Self is the refuge of self,' meaning that when things get difficult, your own disciplined mind is the only place you can truly hide. He urged them to 'control yourself' (saṃyamayattānaṃ) just as the merchant controls his 'noble horse.' The human mind is incredibly powerful and energetic, like a high-bred stallion. If it is left untrained, it will run wild, causing destruction and eventually throwing the rider into the 'ditch' of suffering. But if it is trained with the 'reins' of mindfulness and the 'bit' of wisdom, it can carry the rider to the furthest heights of enlightenment. The Buddha emphasized that the merchant doesn't hate the horse or try to break its spirit; he simply 'directs' its energy. In the same way, the monk shouldn't hate his mind, but should skillfully direct its power away from unwholesome thoughts and toward the Dhamma. Inspired by the merchant’s skill, the monks practiced 'taming' their own mental energy, turning their wild desires into the steady, focused power of Samadhi.

verses.pali: Pāmojjabahulo bhikkhu, pasanno buddhasāsane; adhigacche padaṃ santaṃ, saṅkhārūpasamaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.translation: A monk who is full of joy and who has faith in the Buddha’s teachings, will attain the state of peace (Nirvana), the happy cessation of conditioned existence.
verses.commentary: Joy (Pāmojja) is not just a byproduct of the path; it is a necessary 'fuel' for it. A joyful mind is easily concentrated, and a concentrated mind sees things as they are. This verse is identical in sentiment to 368, reinforcing the 'happy' nature of liberation.

story.title: The Story of the Joyful Monk
story.content: A certain monk named Pāmojja was always smiling. Even when he was sick, or when he had nothing to eat, or when he was criticized by others, his inner 'joy' (pāmojja) never seemed to fade. Some monks thought he was being frivolous and that the 'holy life' should be more serious and somber. They complained to the Buddha, saying that Pāmojja didn't seem to take the Four Noble Truths seriously because he was always so happy. The Buddha defended the monk, explaining that 'a monk who is full of joy' is actually the one who is closest to the 'state of peace' (padaṃ santaṃ). He explained that sadness and somberness are often just forms of subtle aversion, while joy is a sign of a mind that has found 'faith in the Buddha’s teachings' (pasanno buddhasāsane). He said that joy is the 'moisture' that prevents the heart from becoming dry and brittle. When a monk is joyful, his 'Sankharas' (mental formations) naturally begin to calm down (saṅkhārūpasamaṃ), leading to the highest 'Sukha' (happiness). The Buddha told the monks that Nirvana is not a 'nothingness,' but a 'happy cessation' of all that is stressful and conditioned. Pāmojja’s smile was not because he was ignoring suffering, but because he had found the way out of it. He had discovered that the Dhamma is a path of light, not a path of darkness. Hearing this, the other monks realized that their own 'seriousness' was sometimes just a mask for their inner struggles, and they began to cultivate the 'joy' that comes from a clear and confident heart.

verses.pali: Yo have daharo bhikkhu, yuñjati buddhasāsane; somaṃ lokaṃ pabhāseti, abbhā muttova candimā.
verses.translation: The monk who, though young, devotes himself to the Buddha’s teachings, illuminates this world like the moon freed from clouds.
verses.commentary: 'Daharo' (young) highlights that one is never too young to start. 'Abbhā mutto' (freed from clouds) is a beautiful metaphor for a mind that has cleared away the 'clouds' of defilement to reveal its natural radiance.

story.title: The Story of the Young Samanera
story.content: In the monastery, there was a seven-year-old novice monk (Samanera) named Sumana. Despite his very young age, he was incredibly diligent in his meditation and could sit for hours in perfect stillness. The older monks sometimes looked at him as 'just a child' and wondered if he really understood the depth of the teachings. One day, the Buddha decided to show the assembly the power of the young boy’s practice. He asked Sumana to perform a difficult task that required great spiritual power, which the boy did effortlessly and with perfect humility. The Buddha then spoke this verse to the amazed crowd. He said that a monk, even if he is 'daharo' (young), who truly 'devotes himself' to the path, has the power to 'illuminate this world.' He compared the young monk to the 'moon freed from clouds' (abbhā muttova candimā). Just as the moon is always there but is often hidden by dark clouds, a person’s inner wisdom is often hidden by the 'clouds' of greed and ignorance. By practicing the Dhamma, Sumana had cleared those clouds early in life, allowing his natural radiance to shine through. The Buddha taught that spiritual maturity has nothing to do with biological age; it only has to do with the sincerity of one’s practice. He told the elders that they should not look down on the youth, and he told the youth that they should not wait until they are old to practice. The little Samanera Sumana became a great inspiration for everyone, proving that the light of the Dhamma can shine through anyone who is willing to clear the sky of their own mind.

chapters.summary: This final chapter describes the highest spiritual attainment, using the term 'Brāhmaṇa' in a spiritual sense to denote one who has achieved complete purification and liberation.

verses.pali: Chinda sotaṃ parakkamma, kāme panuda brāhmaṇa; saṅkhārānaṃ khayaṃ ñatvā, akataññūsi brāhmaṇa.
verses.translation: Exert yourself and cut off the stream of craving, O Brahmin! Discard sense desires. Knowing the destruction of all conditioned things, be one who knows the Unconditioned.
verses.commentary: The 'stream' is the flow of Samsara. 'Akata' means the Uncreated or Unconditioned (Nirvana). A true Brahmin knows the end of 'Sankharas' (conditioned things).

story.title: The Brahmin Who Sought the Stream's End
story.content: A Brahmin named Pasadaka once approached the Buddha, deeply troubled by the relentless nature of his own thoughts and desires. He felt like he was being swept away by a powerful river, unable to find any stable ground. The Buddha, acknowledging the man's struggle, gave him this vigorous instruction. He told him that spiritual life is not a passive activity; it requires one to 'exert yourself' (parakkamma). He compared craving to a 'stream' (sota) that flows from the senses to the heart. To find peace, one must 'cut off' this stream with the sword of effort and 'discard' the heavy weights of sense desires that pull one under. The Buddha explained that the world is made of 'Sankharas'—things that are put together, conditioned, and therefore destined to fall apart. A true Brahmin is someone who has looked deeply into the nature of reality and witnessed the 'destruction of all conditioned things' (saṅkhārānaṃ khayaṃ). By seeing that everything built must eventually crumble, the mind stops trying to build more and instead turns toward the 'Akata'—the Unconditioned or the Uncreated. This 'Akata' is Nirvana, the only state that is not subject to change or decay. The Buddha told the Brahmin that once he truly knows the end of the conditioned, he will no longer be a victim of the stream. He will become a 'knower of the Unconditioned' (akataññū), standing firmly on the farther shore where the water cannot reach. Inspired by this call to action, Pasadaka committed himself to intensive meditation, eventually cutting the stream of his own cravings and attaining the deathless state of Arhatship.

verses.pali: Yadā dwayesu dhammesu, pāragū hoti brāhmaṇo; athassa sabbe saṃyogā, atthaṃ gacchanti jānato.
verses.translation: When the Brahmin has reached the farther shore in the two states (concentration and insight), then all his fetters vanish through his knowledge.
verses.commentary: The 'two states' (dwayesu dhammesu) refer to Samatha (calm) and Vipassana (insight). Together, they allow the monk to reach the 'farther shore' of liberation.

story.title: The Story of the Two States
story.content: A group of learned Brahmins were debating whether the path to God was through deep trance and stillness or through philosophical inquiry and understanding. They brought their debate to the Buddha, who explained that the path is actually a harmony of both. He used the term 'dwayesu dhammesu' to describe the two essential practices: Samatha (tranquility meditation) and Vipassana (insight meditation). He explained that Samatha is like a clear, still lake that allows you to see all the way to the bottom, while Vipassana is the actual seeing and understanding of what lies there. When a practitioner becomes a 'paragu'—one who has gone to the farther shore—in both of these states, they gain a holistic knowledge that is unshakable. The Buddha taught that 'all fetters vanish' (sabbe saṃyogā atthaṃ gacchanti) only when these two powers are combined. If you have calm without insight, you are just sleeping in peace; if you have insight without calm, your knowledge is just dry theory. But when the mind is both perfectly still and perfectly clear, the 'fetters' of greed, hatred, and delusion simply evaporate. He compared this to a man crossing a river with two oars; if he only uses one, he just goes in circles, but with both, he reaches the other side. The Brahmins realized that their debate was based on a false division. Many of them decided to ordain and practice both concentration and insight, eventually finding that the 'vanishing of fetters' was not a mystical myth but a practical reality achieved through the balance of 'two states.' This teaching remains a cornerstone for those seeking a complete spiritual training.

verses.pali: Yassa pāraṃ apāraṃ vā, pārāpāraṃ na vijjati; vītaddaraṃ visaṃyuttaṃ, tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.translation: He for whom there is neither this shore nor the farther shore, nor both, who is free from fear and attachment—him I call a Brahmin.
verses.commentary: This is a highly paradoxical Zen-like verse. Once the ego is gone, the concepts of 'this world' (apāraṃ) and 'Nirvana' (pāraṃ) lose their meaning because there is no 'self' to be in either place.

story.title: The Story of the Shoreless Mind
story.content: Mara, the Tempter, once approached a monk who was deep in meditation and tried to confuse him. Mara asked, 'Where do you stand? Do you stand on this shore of the senses, or do you stand on the farther shore of Nirvana?' The monk, having realized the truth of non-self (Anatta), remained silent. The Buddha, seeing this encounter, explained the profound state of the monk to those standing nearby. He said that for a truly enlightened being, the very concepts of 'this shore' and 'the farther shore' have ceased to exist. 'This shore' represents the internal sense bases (the 'I'), and 'the farther shore' represents the external sense objects (the 'world'). For the Arhat, the boundary between the self and the world has dissolved. He is 'visaṃyuttaṃ'—completely detached from the duality of 'subject' and 'object.' The Buddha explained that as long as you think there is a 'me' that needs to get 'there,' you are still caught in attachment. But when the 'me' is gone, there is nowhere to go and nowhere to stay. Such a person is 'vītaddaraṃ'—free from the 'fever' of fear and anxiety—because there is no longer a 'self' that can be threatened by the world or limited by time. He described this state as being 'shoreless,' like the vast ocean that has no center and no edge. The Buddha told the assembly, 'Him I call a Brahmin.' This teaching was meant to push the practitioners beyond the subtle attachment to the 'idea' of Nirvana itself, encouraging them to find the freedom that exists when all labels and dualities are finally dropped in the silence of total realization.

verses.pali: Jhāyiṃ virajamāsīnaṃ, katakiccaṃ anāsavaṃ; uttamatthamanuppattaṃ, tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.translation: He who is meditative, free from passion, settled, whose work is done, free from taints, and who has attained the highest goal—him I call a Brahmin.
verses.commentary: 'Katakiccaṃ' (whose work is done) is the standard epithet for an Arhat. They have completed the spiritual task and have nothing more to achieve in the cycle of birth.

story.title: The Brahmin and the Arhat
story.content: A Brahmin priest who was very meticulous about his rituals once saw an Arhat monk sitting perfectly still under a tree. The Brahmin was impressed but also skeptical, as the monk didn't seem to be performing any sacrifices or chanting any prayers. He asked the monk, 'What work are you doing?
